webTitle: Why Cats are not the cream  of mortgages

fields.headline: Why Cats are not the cream  of mortgages
fields.standfirst: The new state standard for home loans isn't perfect, says  Neasa MacErlean, but it will help guide you round the market
fields.trailText: The new state standard for home loans isn't perfect, says Neasa MacErlean, but it will help guide you round the market.
fields.body:
If you want a cheap mortgage, don't rush out and buy one of the new Cat standard deals unveiled by the Treasury last week.

The new benchmark system ought, in theory, to guide consumers to the cheapest and simplest offers. But in practice they could lead you to a more expensive loan. Treasury Minister Melanie Johnson said: 'Cat standards will be an important part of providing simple, clear, easily comparable information. All borrowers stand to benefit, be they first-time buyers or existing mortgage holders, and regardless of their property's value or location.'

Only these loans - Cat stands for Charges, Access and Terms - comply with rules set by the Government: they must, for example, have a variable rate no higher than 2 per cent above the Bank of England base lending rate - currently 6 per cent.

But loans qualify only if they offer the same terms to all borrowers - a big problem as lenders tend to give their keenest deals only to new customers. One of the best deals available now from the Halifax is a two-year discount of 1.95 per cent off the standard variable rate, with no early redemption penalties.

But Halifax would 'struggle really hard to offer this deal to existing customers', says Patrick Bunton of London & Country Mortgages.

Borrowers taking the discount would pay 5.79 per cent; existing borrowers on the standard variable rate would pay 7.74 per cent.

So the best deals will probably be outside the Cat system. Halifax hopes to launch Cat deals in June. But most of its 25 or so offers will remain non-CAT deals. A spokeswoman says: 'The pricing structure has yet to be worked out. If everybody decided that Cat was for them, we would have 2.5 million customers transferring their mortgages.'

Yorkshire building society last week became one of the first lenders to meet the Cat terms. Its first such mortgage is a 6.74 per cent variable-rate loan. It is competitive compared with other variable rates, but does not match the best discount or fixed deals.

Spokesman David Holmes says the society has a policy of offering the same deals to new and existing customers. But he thinks lenders who try to offer both sorts of loan could change their ways if Cat standards prove popular.

'At the moment, existing borrowers are subsidising the acquisition of new business by most lenders,' says Holmes. 'But the Cat standard may have the effect of levelling the market out.'

Another possible concern is that lenders can offer very uncompetitive terms and still qualify. A variable rate needs to be within 2 per cent of base rate to meet the CAT standard. But none of the leading lenders is near 8 per cent now. Nationwide is offering 7.29 per cent, many others are offering 7.4 per cent - and the vast majority are at 7.74 per cent or less. Similarly, an uncompetitive fixed-rate deal would qualify for a Cat.

So, in short, a CAT sign is not an indication that you are getting value for money.

Many of the deals which will meet the standard are 'flexible' arrangements, through which you can 'overpay', 'underpay' and take payment breaks.

These mortgages are far more expensive than the discount offers. Virgin Direct, for example, charges a rate between 7.10 and 7.70 per cent, depending on the size of deposit that borrowers can put down.

Virgin 'emphatically' welcomed the new system last week - although, ironically, it cannot qualify since it breaches one of the less important rules. A Catmarked loan must be offered on sums of £10,000 or more; Virgin has set a £25,000 minimum.

But the Cat could still be useful - especially in help ing us all to think about the pros and cons of particular deals. To meet the standard, a mortgage must comply with these rules:

The charges

 Interest must be calculated on a daily basis (not monthly or annually as many lenders do now).

 There can be be no separate fee for mortgage indemnity (a charge levied by many firms to cover their own risk if a borrower has a deposit of less than 15 per cent.

 Fees for arranging variable-rate deals are banned. A maximum charge of £150 applies to fixed-rate loans.

 Redemption penalties cannot extend beyond the period of the discount or fix.

 Brokers cannot charge for arranging a Cat mortgage

 Rates must be adjusted within a month of a drop in the base rate.

 Variable-rate interest must be within 2 per cent of base rate.

Access

 The minimum loan is £10,000.

 Borrowers choose their repayment day each month.

 The mortgage is portable and can be transferred to a new property.

The terms

 There are to be no compulsory insurances. For instance, you cannot be required to buy buildings cover to get a particular deal.

 If you are in arrears, you pay interest only on the outstanding debt, and at the normal rate.

 You can make early repayments at any time.

 Your lender must give six months' warning if it can no longer meet the standard.

 Advertising and paperwork must be 'straightforward, fair and clear'.

fields.headline: How to ... face your redundancy
fields.trailText: 1 DECIDE how much you want to survive if your name is on the exit list. 'You're sunk if you're in two minds,' says Richard Lynch of banking union Unifi. Unless the whole department is being closed, you can sometimes save your job by fighting. 'Most times you can get it sorted out if you make it clear you want to stay, you use the appeals mechanisms, try to swap with people who want to go and almost harass the human resources department to help you.' If the company is open to consultation - as, by law, it should be - it can probably reorganise its lists.
fields.body:
1 DECIDE how much you want to survive if your name is on the exit list. 'You're sunk if you're in two minds,' says Richard Lynch of banking union Unifi. Unless the whole department is being closed, you can sometimes save your job by fighting. 'Most times you can get it sorted out if you make it clear you want to stay, you use the appeals mechanisms, try to swap with people who want to go and almost harass the human resources department to help you.' If the company is open to consultation - as, by law, it should be - it can probably reorganise its lists.

2 START negotiating as early as possible if you decide to take the loot and go. Many personnel officers are inept in handling the calculator - so you need to check their figures. Ensure holiday entitlement is included - and any other extras such as an inflation uprating. Understand that negotiations in a large, unionised business are completely different to those in small ones. Big employers often have room for manoeuvre. Small firms are more likely to forget about consultation. Don't let them do this - remind them of their duties or threaten them with an employment tribunal.

3 RECOGNISE that employers should be better at negotiating lay-offs now - and better at genuine consultation. Last year the maximum payment on unfair dismissal was raised from £12,000 to £50,000 - giving employers reason to get their procedures right.

4 APPRECIATE the rampant nature of ageism and the difficulties of getting employed if you are over 50. Management consultancy Right suggests 'interim management' assignments for middle managers - an acknowledgement that most companies are reluctant to put you permanently on the payroll but will consider temporary or casual work. People lower down the ladder will find job-seeking just as hard. 'Use your network effectively,' says Jo Bond of Right. You could find it easier to get a job this way than to send CVs to strangers who will focus on your age.

5 KEEP your CV and your morale going by doing voluntary work. If you slump into isolation and loneliness, you can find it very difficult to climb out.

webTitle: Can new owners alter our pensions?

fields.headline: Can new owners alter our pensions?
fields.trailText: My employer sold out to a new team in a management buyout two years ago. It was agreed that the new pension scheme would be at least as good as the old (final salary) scheme. Now, however, the new employer is proposing to downgrade the scheme and force us to raise our contributions. What can we do?
fields.body:
My employer sold out to a new team in a management buyout two years ago. It was agreed that the new pension scheme would be at least as good as the old (final salary) scheme. Now, however, the new employer is proposing to downgrade the scheme and force us to raise our contributions. What can we do?

You are probably in a difficult situation, with little hope of redress.

There are two ways for a business to change hands: the underlying assets are bought out; or the company shares are sold. In the former case, the members have no protection regarding the future of their pension scheme. This could change, however. At present, pensions are excluded from the European 'transfer of undertakings' provisions (TUPE), although it is possible that the UK will decide that they could be included. This would not help you since the transfer has already happened.

If the takeover was via a share deal, your pension scheme is essentially the same as existed before - even if its terms and conditions change. There is no obligation on an employer to provide a pension scheme, so it is not bound to offer the same terms.

What is protected, however, is your past service benefit. All your accumulated rights must be dealt with, when you retire, on the old terms.

 Problem at work?
Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: New mobile licence to net more billions

fields.headline: New mobile licence to net more billions
fields.trailText: The British taxpayer could benefit from a huge windfall on top of the £20 billion-plus the Government is set to earn from selling five new mobile phone licences. The new money - which could run into billions - would come from selling more radio spectrum.
fields.body:
The British taxpayer could benefit from a huge windfall on top of the £20 billion-plus the Government is set to earn from selling five new mobile phone licences. The new money - which could run into billions - would come from selling more radio spectrum.

The licences currently up for sale are for frequencies between 1,800 and 2,500 megahertz. The limited amount of spectrum available has meant that mobile phone companies looking to offer wireless Internet services over their networks are having to pay heavy prices.

However, The Observer has learnt that the Government will soon have the right to auction off frequencies between 2,500 and 3000 megahertz - enough to allow at least one other mobile phone firm to offer wireless Internet services.

The frequencies will be allocated to phone networks by world governments around the world at next month's Radiocommunications Assembly 2000 in Turkey. They will be sold in 2004 and be available in 2007 to successful bidders.

The original intention was for the extra spectrum to be allocated to the holders of the five mobile licences now being auctioned. However, sources in the telecoms world now say the Government will examine plans to sell the new tranche, known in the industry as the 'expansion band', to a fresh mobile phone company - if it believes the market could support another entrant.

The sources suggest that the huge prices currently being exacted have led the Government to reconsider this possibility.

However, if this option is ruled out, the Government will sell the extra capacity to the five licence holders, possibly in another auction. The sell-off process will be decided by the Government with its financial adviser, NM Rothschild, which is overseeing the present sale.

fields.headline: A little virtual difficulty
fields.standfirst: Branches? Pah! Banks claim clients prefer to do it online. But two readers who tried it found glitches galore, writes  Maria  Scott
fields.trailText: Branches? Pah! Banks claim clients prefer to do it online. But two readers who tried it found glitches galore.
fields.body:
Banks make much of their Internet services when defending branch closures, arguing that customers increasingly prefer the Net or the telephone to a branch.

The larger players in Internet banking claim to be signing up thousands of customers. Barclays says it took on 20,000 new accounts in the week it closed 171 branches, and now has 770,000 online customers.

We asked readers to tell us their experiences of this twenty-first century means of running a current account. This is what they told us:

Peter Gartside of Perthshire has used computers at work for more than 15 years, with 'few problems even in the learning stages', although he is a Net novice.

Last year he converted his postal-based Egg savings account into an Internet account. He was attracted by the extra interest it pays, and wanted to try online banking.

He was told he could convert while remaining with his existing Internet service provider and that his Apple Mac computer would be compatible with Egg's.

'A promotional leaflet, Egg: online, produced by Egg in spring 1999 states that "you can use either a PC or a Mac computer",' he says. One cannot get clearer than that.'

Peter says he was later told that an Egg representative would telephone to give him instructions for using his Mac with the account. But when Peter tried the system, he found that his established email connection to the ISP was no longer there.

'I telephoned the helpline, only to be advised that there would be a charge of 50p a minute as they explained how the situation could be corrected. As an alternative I would have to wait between 11 and 16 hours for them to call me free of charge.'

When Peter protested he was told: 'That is the system!'

He said: 'I also discovered that the Egg pages which I was able to access would only allow me to open a new account. I could find no option to enable the transfer of an existing postal account to Internet access.

'In a desperate search for help in restoring access to my email system, I contacted the ISP. They confirmed that the Egg instructions had overwritten the files previously used to access that ISP. Because the ISP helpline had no details about the Egg files, they suggested that the only way of proceeding was to ask Egg to advise on how to remove them again. That is at 50p per minute or free after waiting between 11 and 16 hours.

'With the assistance of a family member about 400 miles away, I was able to re-establish my links with the ISP, but I still could not transfer the Egg account to an Internet service.'

Undeterred, Peter wrote to the chief executive of Egg complaining about the two-month delay he had experienced. Eventually, by email, he received instructions on how to convert his account.

'On working through the procedure I was eventually presented with a message about data exchange which I could not understand.'

He tried to work through this, but hit a dead end when a message on his screen informed him that a script error had occurred. Eventually Egg told him that servicing the account with a Mac was 'very complicated'.

'They asked me to upgrade my browser to 4.5 from the Microsoft website. I have visited this website on several occasions but cannot find any reference to upgrading to 4.5. Egg tell me they cannot advise me on downloading the new version: I must contact the Microsoft help line - at what cost I wonder?

'It would appear that any attempt to operate the savings account through the Internet requires a degree of knowledge and understanding which is way beyond many users.'

Peter has now closed his Egg account and was discouraged to find that the Co-op Smile Internet account is not geared up for Macs, either. 'Perhaps I should find the nearest Barclays village bank for an easy life.'

Cash shared some of Peter's frustration in our dealings with Egg. We asked for a response to his criticisms. After four days and a reminder, a spokeswoman said there had been 'mis-communication' between the firm and Peter. She insisted he should be able to upgrade his browser from the Microsoft website, but volunteered an Egg engineer to help. Asked whether there had been problems for Mac users, she said: 'I am not an expert but I think there was something.'

John Dann of Sutton Coldfield, has had problems using his Mac for Internet Banking at Lloyds. 'My bank's Internet helpline assured me that my using a Mac would not bar me from joining their online banking services. And yes, both the browsers I use (Netscape 4 and Explorer 4) are OK, a fact later endorsed by a "browser check" stage in the registration process.

'Imagine then how pleased I was when, having completed the registration with each browser in turn, I received a curt little message in each case telling me my browser could not enable the required level of encryption - or words to that effect.'

John feels disillusioned. Lloyds closed the branch he once used, and he was directed to a telephone service centre. 'Now I can't even phone the centre. I am being encouraged to phone a talking machine.'

He could upgrade his computer system to get the equipment he appears to need to bank via the Internet, but wonders where this will end. 'Even if you get the right software, what happens when the bank upgrades? You may have to get another computer.'

Lloyds insists its system is so Mac-friendly it has been praised by a specialist magazine for Mac users. But it offered no consolation to John over his difficulties.

A spokesman says: 'With computers there could be any number of things that could cause this.'

fields.headline: Inwardly troubled
fields.standfirst: Management:  The UK attracts investment - because the economy is full of holes
fields.trailText: Search for 'inward investment' on the Web, and of the pages and pages of hits, apart from a couple for Tahiti, the Dominican Republic and France, almost all extol the unrivalled delights of investing in the UK: Barnsley, York, Wales, Scotland, London, Cumbria and Fermanagh on the first page alone.
fields.body:
Search for 'inward investment' on the Web, and of the pages and pages of hits, apart from a couple for Tahiti, the Dominican Republic and France, almost all extol the unrivalled delights of investing in the UK: Barnsley, York, Wales, Scotland, London, Cumbria and Fermanagh on the first page alone.

A trawl through the newspaper cuttings reinforces the impression that inward investment is almost entirely a UK story, and a glowing success story at that: 'Investors prefer UK despite euro uncertainty'; 'Investment into Britain jumps by 90 per cent to reach record high'; 'Rising tide of investment flows from overseas'. These are just a few of the recent headlines.

It is true that Britain attracts a proportionately large amount of mobile investment. With just 1 per cent of the world's population, it consumes nearly 8 per cent of all direct cross-border investment, second only to the US. In Europe, the UK is the self-proclaimed inward investment champion, gobbling up half the available total, compared with a meagre 5 per cent for France and 3 per cent for Germany.

The figures are huge. In 1998 foreign companies invested £40 billion in the UK, according to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. As many as 25,000 UK companies are estimated to be under foreign ownership, and 25 per cent of 'British' output comes from foreign-owned factories.

So that's all right, then. Well, not quite. Inward investment has gone unchallenged for so long as a plank of economic policy that people have forgotten to ask the more troubling questions. If foreign direct investment (FDI) is such a good thing, why is it only the UK that makes such a big thing of it? What does all the investment consist of? And what does it say about the functioning of the British economy as a whole?

The truth is that like so much of British management under scrutiny this 'triumph' is not nearly as wonderful as it seems. In the first place, much FDI activity represents mergers and acquisitions, which have replaced greenfield investment - building new factories - as the largest component of inward investment in developed countries.

As Bob Bischof, chairman of direct marketer McIntyre & King, points out, that makes it 'instead-of' investment, not 'additional' investment. In effect it is 'outward divestment' by UK companies rather than extra inward investment, the total of which is quite small.

Semantics? Not when you relate it to the way the economy is currently run. The implications of foreign ownership and an unsympathetic economic policy are horribly illustrated by the Rover debacle. Twenty-five per cent of UK manufacturing is in the same position as Rover. Ford is considering shutting Dagenham, Bischof notes, and his own former company, Boss Group, the UK arm of German forklift manufacturer Jungheinrich, is also in peril from the high pound.

In that situation, where would you like the decisions made, Munich or Birmingham? 'It's the "furthest away from headquarters" syndrome,' says Bischof. 'If you're in London, the Newcastle or Welsh plant goes first. Exactly the same applies internationally.'

By the same token, the vaunted 'clusters' of foreign investment in the North East or 'Silicon Glen' are fragile things. 'They are not embedded in the local economy,' says David Johnson, director of Durham Business School's Barclays Centre for Entrepreneurship. Without the anchorage of special skills or particular know-how in the area - as at homegrown Cambridge, centred on the university - there is little to tie them in when the going gets rough.

None of this is to deny the economic benefits that some inward investment provides. The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) estimates that a third of UK industrial productivity growth since the mid-1980s can be attributed to the 'ripple-through' effect of better work practices imported by the incomers, principally the Japanese. Despite the strength of sterling, Japanese implants have also done much to sustain export figures in sectors such as cars and electronics.

But there is no such thing as a free lunch. Why has Johnny Foreigner (with the exception of BMW) been able to make a go of industries which British companies are abandoning in droves - cars, electronics, televisions, utilities? Why has it taken foreign management to restore a measure of credibility to British quality and British labour?

A large part of the answer lies in vastly better management at every level. For foreign firms, the opportunity to buy cheap assets and cheap labour with which to compete in a wildly overpriced UK market is a no-brainer, particularly since ease of entry and investment are matched by ease of exit.

Meanwhile, spurning the opportunities on their doorstep, UK firms have become the world leaders in exporting capital. Last year they invested a towering $212bn overseas, more even than the US. Unlike the US, the UK is a huge net outward investor.

Bischof believes that the steady evacuation by British firms of the most competitive commercial arenas is no accident. It is driven, he argues, by fierce short-term pressures from shareholder institutions which won't tolerate the high investments, patience and determination that long-term competition requires.

Thus, in what is supposed to be the financial centre of the world, there is no British representation left in investment banking, the most globally strategic and competitive area. UK banks have retreated to the High Street - where their cartel is now under increasing pressure.

Too often, the ownership transaction isn't just a swap of accents or assets. What happens in the rust belt has a knock-on effect at the posh end of the economy.

For example, a foreign acquirer often appoints a foreign bank to replace overdraft-obsessed British ones. A foreign insurer follows. Foreign managers and continental suppliers complete the picture - initially reluctantly, says Bischof, when domestic suppliers can't make the quality standards, then systematically because of uncompetitive prices as a result of the strength of sterling.

So when the press whips up the next Mexican wave in favour of glowing inward investment figures, ponder instead what is slipping away, and why that investment was needed in the first place.

webTitle: Thousands of steel jobs at risk if Alchemy buys Rover

fields.headline: Thousands of steel jobs at risk if Alchemy buys Rover
fields.trailText: Fears are growing that thousands of jobs at steelmaker Corus, along with one or more of it manufacturing plants, will almost certainly be lost if Rover cars is sold to venture capital group Alchemy Partners.
fields.body:
Fears are growing that thousands of jobs at steelmaker Corus, along with one or more of it manufacturing plants, will almost certainly be lost if Rover cars is sold to venture capital group Alchemy Partners.

Executives and unions at the former British Steel, which merged last year with Dutch metals group Hoogovens, are worried that Alchemy's plans for drastic production cuts will add to problems caused by the high pound and could 'tip the balance' against plants and jobs in the UK.

Last month joint chief executives John Bryant and Fokko van Duyne warned that no jobs or plants could be safe while sterling was valued so highly against European currencies.

Concerns are focused on the Llanwern and Port Talbot strip steel mills in south Wales, which together account for 6,200 jobs.

Rover, which built around 450,000 cars a year before current owner BMW began scaling production back last month, accounts for more than 10 per cent of Corus's output of strip steel.

Corus supplies 100,000 tonnes directly to Rover - of which 75 per cent goes to the Longbridge plant in Birmingham. A further 200,000 tonnes is sold indirectly to the company.

The steelmaker's executives are now studying what impact Alchemy's plans for drastic cuts in production to well below 100,000 cars a year will have on its UK operations.

A company spokesman said Corus would embark on widescale restructuring - which would inevitably include plant closures and job losses, if its market share falls below 50 per cent. It currently stands at 53 per cent of production in the UK, and is being eroded by the strong pound. Rover could tip the balance to below 50 per cent.

Sources at the ISTC steelmaking union said there was serious concern about the future of Llanwern and Port Talbot.

A spokesman for the union said: 'Britain cannot live by design, insurance and music alone. The Government neglects manufacturing at its peril.'

webTitle: Bargain basement fails to lift Arcadia's fortune

fields.headline: Bargain basement fails to lift Arcadia's fortune
fields.standfirst: Ben Laurance on the woes of a retail chain struggling with high rents and a vicious climate for mid-range clothing
fields.trailText: Ben Laurance on the woes of a retail chain struggling with high rents and a vicious climate for mid-range clothing
fields.body:
The script for the horror story is easy to write. Here is a company, Arcadia, which has lost almost £9 million in the first half of the year, having made a £26m profit a year earlier. It has debts of more than £200m - some four times the company's stock market value.

It is being forced to get rid of 400 shops. And that will involve shedding no fewer than 3,500 jobs. In other words, this is a company in deep, deep trouble.

Now, bearing this in mind, consider something else: that in the nine weeks from mid-January to mid-March, Arcadia's shops - or at least those which have been under its control for more than a year - sold, on average, some 16 per cent more clothes than they did 12 months earlier. This, surely, is a picture of burgeoning retail success.

So how to square these two, diametrically opposed versions of events? Easy: they are, in fact, entirely consistent. Arcadia's shops have, indeed, increased their sales enormously. The problem is this: they sold 15 per cent more clothes, but these clothes were sold at much lower prices. Arcadia was able to shift its merchandise only by cutting prices. Hence the amount of cash taken by its shops rose by a much more modest 4.3 per cent. And, as even a novice market trader will tell you, it is easy to increase sales by cutting prices; the big challenge is increasing sales while still making a profit.

The clothing market has proved a vicious environment for mid-range retailers over the past 18 months. Estimates of the scale of price deflation vary hugely, but Arcadia's 10 per cent estimate is probably as good as any. And in the two years from 1997 to 1999, the amount of retail space devoted to clothing on British high streets is reckoned to have increased by around 5 per cent. The cost of rent and rates on each square foot of that space has risen by perhaps 5 per cent in the past year. That money has to come from somewhere. And in large part, it is coming from retailers' profits.

Arcadia and its bigger brother Marks & Spencer have been the most high-profile casualties of this squeeze. This is scarcely surprising. After all Arcadia, with a huge range of shops stretching from Evans, Top Shop, Wallis, Dorothy Perkins, Burton and Top Man to Miss Selfridge, Principles, Racing Green and Richards, has roughly 10 per cent of the national clothing market.

But in Arcadia's case, there has been a particularly nasty twist of the screw. M&S, remember, owns virtually all its own shops, so it doesn't have to pay much rent. Arcadia's rent bill, by contrast, is mammoth. That money has to be covered from the surplus on operating shops before the company even starts to make a profit. It is, in the jargon, highly operationally geared: a small change in the company's sales or margins has a big impact on its pre-tax profits. In the harsh world of retailing, it is a vulnerable beast.

Last week, as Arcadia unveiled its half-year results, the company outlined its plans to close 400 shops. Of course, there is no reason to suppose that these stores will not go to other clothing retailers. In retailing, shrinking a business does not shrink the industry as a whole; it simply shuffles a given amount of sales space into new hands.

So will Arcadia find itself facing new competition from the very shops it has shed? John Hoerner, the group's chief executive, isn't worried. In the current climate, opticians or coffee shops are more likely to pay up for extra space than a fashion retailer.

But even if Hoerner is proved right - and one suspects that, on balance, he probably will be - an upheaval on this scale costs big money. As well as closing stores, scores of outlets under one Arcadia name will be moved to a different one: a Top Man may reopen as an Evans. In total, the group is having to swallow write-offs of £60m plus further costs of £30m.

The company is still vulnerable. M&S's problems over the past 18 months have made more headlines. But M&S does still make profits of around £10m a week. In part, that is because a fair chunk of the operation is devoted to selling food. But more important is M&S's wonderful inheritance of freehold property. Arcadia doesn't have that luxury. To cover its rent bill and more, it has to run hard to stand still.

The clothing market may be uncomfortable for retailers, but consumers have never had it so good. There is more space devoted to offering choice in clothing, and the price of that clothing has fallen. We, at least, can rejoice.

webTitle: Count on hassle if you switch accounts

fields.headline: Count on hassle if you switch accounts
fields.standfirst: If you want a new home for your money, it can cost you two months of effort, as  Colin Frier discovered
fields.trailText: If you want a new home for your money, it can cost you two months of effort, as Colin Frier discovered.
fields.body:
One of the reasons given for the average current account outlasting the average marriage is the difficulties customers have in switching to other banks.

Don Cruickshank, author of the recent Review on Banking report, believes these difficulties are 'perceived' rather than real. And Melanie Green of the Consumers' Association says 'switching accounts is not as difficult as people think'.

But more than two months after I began changing banks, from NatWest to Abbey National - I can confirm it is a protracted and laborious process.

So where did I go wrong? Green points out the main pitfall: 'A survey of our members last summer found that the major problem for customers switching bank accounts was transferring direct debits and standing orders.'

As one who pays most utility bills plus other miscellaneous items by standing order or direct debit, I know this is only too true. I got into a frightful mess.

Learning from my own mistakes, I can offer the following advice: Start planning early by taking your most recent bank statements, and making a list of all your standing orders and direct debits. Arrange them in date order. If you have any which are paid quarterly or annually, add them to the list. Then find another bank.

Easier said than done, it seems. One prospective suitor told me it wouldn't be possible to transfer my overdraft, 'as you have no credit history with us'.

At another, I was told: 'You don't need to see anyone to transfer your account.' But this was followed up with: 'You can see one of the advisers on the front desk' - which I could see was empty. Something told me this wasn't the bank for me.

But persevere and eventually, as I did, you will find a bank or building society which at the very least promises to be better than your previous one. Once you've completed the application forms, it's important to ask how quickly the account can be opened. This can range from a couple of hours to two weeks. But it may take up to a further two weeks before you receive your chequebook, PIN and debit/cheque guarantee card.

Ask whether your present bank will transfer your direct debits and standing orders to your new account. This will save a lot of hassle, but not everyone will do it. HSBC and Smile, the Internet bank do. Lloyds used to, but now doesn't; while a number of others are doing so as part of a pilot project.

Next, arrange to have your salary paid in to your new bank. Do this by writing to your payroll department immediately after the final date you wish your salary to go in to the old account. This gives everyone involved the maximum time to sort out the details before your next salary goes in.

Assuming your new bank won't transfer the standing orders and direct debits for you, write to your old bank or building society asking them to cancel any standing orders. Then move on to your direct debits. Many organisations, such as Thames Water and British Gas, allow you to bypass paperwork completely, and do everything over the phone.

But where this is not an option, contact those organisations you pay by direct debit for new forms, and obtain standing order forms from your new bank. Requests can be in writing, although picking them up in person can often be quicker.

Once you have completed the forms, you must pick one of two ways to proceed. There is 'big bang' - choosing a date immediately after most of your payments have gone through, and firing off forms in all directions. Or there is the more detailed and cautious approach of waiting until immediately after each direct individual debit or standing order from your old account has been debited, before taking action.

The advantage of the former approach is that you get the administration over and done with in one go.

However, if your timing is unfortunate, you may find a payment is missed, is paid from the wrong account, or worse still, that both your accounts have been debited. In which case it may be hard to prove the error was someone else's, and not yours.

The latter approach, though slower, minimises the chances of financial chaos. And should anything go awry, you are more likely to receive full and immediate refunds from your branch.

No matter how careful you are, things can still go wrong. You are dependent on a long chain of individuals and organisations, some of whom, after all, may be the people responsible for causing you to switch your account in the first place.

Once you have decided on your overall approach, don't delay. Return the completed direct debit mandate forms to the companies concerned, and the standing orders to your new bank. It can take up to two weeks for organisations to act on these instructions.

Then write to your former bank or building society asking them to cancel the direct debits. This will usually be done within two or three days. You will normally receive a letter back confirming your instructions, and asking you to contact them if any of the details are incorrect.

Transferring your current account will nearly always take longer than you expect, typically between one and two months, says the CA's Melanie Green. So try to leave enough money in your old account to allow for any payments still to be made. And if the remaining outgoings are large or important, it may be worth transferring money into it temporarily. Keep detailed notes of what you have done, and copies of any letters or forms sent. This helps to avoid confusion, and could prove vital should there be any dispute.

Once the paperwork has been completed, allow at least a month for things to settle down. By this time you should have received confirmation from your new bank of the new direct debit and standing order instructions.

Then order statements from both old and new accounts. Make sure you go through them carefully to ensure that everything has gone through correctly. Only then can you feel confident enough to close your old account.

After all that, you will know exactly why so few people now change banks.

And if the remaining outgoings are large or important, it may be worth transferring money into it temporarily. Keep detailed notes of what you have done, and copies of any letters or forms sent. This helps to avoid confusion, and could prove vital should there be any dispute. Once the paperwork has been completed, allow at least a month for things to settle down. By this time you should have received confirmation from your new bank of the new direct debit and standing order instructions. Then order statements from both old and new accounts. Make sure you go through them carefully to ensure that everything has gone through correctly. Only then can you feel confident enough to close your old account. After all that, you will know exactly why so few people now change banks.

webTitle: Cronje and bookmaker shared hotel before one-day series

fields.headline: Cronje and bookmaker shared hotel before one-day series
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the Hansie Cronje case have discovered that the then South Africa captain spent four days in February, in the same Bombay hotel as the London-based bookmaker Sanjay Chawla, before the one-day series against India.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the Hansie Cronje case have discovered that the then South Africa captain spent four days in February, before the one-day series against India, in the same Bombay hotel as the London-based bookmaker Sanjay Chawla.

Officers were last night studying telephone records from the Taj Mahal hotel in the hope of further evidence to support the match-fixing allegations, which Cronje denies, surrounding the series last month.

Cronje stayed in room 811 of the Taj hotel, one of India's most luxurious, from February 16-28 before travelling to Bangalore Chawla occupied room 631 of the same hotel from February 20-24.

Although detectives from the Delhi police had previously obtained evidence that Chawla stayed in the same hotels as the South African squad during the series itself, they were unaware of a possible previous encounter between Chawla and Cronje in February.

This week two officers visited the hotel as well as the the cellular service provider Hutchinson Max Telecom.

In another intriguing twist, Chawla's bill at the Taj hotel was paid by the failed Bollywood actor Kishen Kumar, who police claim provided the money to pay Cronje. Kumar also booked Chawla's room. The former actor was yesterday discharged from one hospital in the Delhi suburb of Noida only to be readmitted to another, the Apollo, complaining of high blood pressure.

Police have been unable to interview Kumar since his collapse last weekend after he was implicated by an associate of Chawla's, Rajesh Kalra, now under arrest. Kalra was yes terday interviewed by the enforcement directorate, which investigates allegations of overseas money-laundering.

Police yesterday raided two small bookmakers in Dehli. Since the scandal erupted the city's six main bookmakers have made themselves scarce.

 The International Cricket Council confirmed yesterday that it will be contacting officials of the nine Test-playing nations to determine whether they agree with Thursday's call by Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, for a world summit to discuss corruption in the game.

fields.headline: Cricket's ultimate test
fields.standfirst: The domestic season starts in earnest today with the game in crisis all over the world
fields.trailText: The domestic season starts in earnest today with the game in crisis all over the world.
fields.body:
This is the summer when English cricket goes for broke, when it regains its credibility after years of underachievement, during which the sun beats down relentlessly, the crowds flock in as they have not done for years, the sponsors stick their noses in the air and sniff a good thing coming and fall over themselves for a piece of the action, as England start winning and stop being the punchline for every stand-up comic in the land when seeking a metaphor for incompetence.

Cricket has been under threat in England as never before but this first season of the new millennium always did look like as good a time as any to start afresh. You will probably find it alluded to somewhere within the jottings of Nostradamus. So under the circumstances it needed this past week as much as David Beckham needs a hairnet and a handout. For years now cricket has been craving the limelight in vain: the front-page splashes the like of which we have not seen since Botham and Willis laid waste the Australians almost two decades ago and back pages that consistently oust football from the nation's consciousness.

It is de rigueur these days for celebs, almost as a fashion item, to say they support a football team whether or not they know their Arsène from their Wenger, and cricket wants some of that, for a few months anyway, even if it just the girl who tells you she has "a problem with an overturned lorry on the M62" saying she follows Durham and thinks Steve Harmison is wonderful.

Well, cricket hit the headlines this week all right, and only time will tell whether the damage is irreparable.

What was Hansie Cronje thinking of? This is an intelligent man, for goodness sake, perfectly capable not only of assessing the potential damage his actions would do to his reputation and indeed his career but of seeing the wider issue. Ever since he took over the captaincy of South Africa he has been a dream of a role model for young cricketers and not only those from his own land. Boys looked up to him and aspired. Now that is all dust in the wind and cricket has become a game for cheats and charlatans, a catalogue of fixes and fiddles in which it is so easy to miss a straight ball, or butterfinger a dolly catch, or bowl a hittable long-hop that there is no limit to the possibilities for taking advantage of the subcontinental craze for cricket betting.

No one trusts anyone else on the field of play these days anyway and now, thanks to Cronje, the same will apply off it, even within the same team. Little surprise, then, if the next generation feels like turning its back on cricket and trying something a little less contrived: professional wrestling, say. So the game in England has its work cut out doubly.

Expectancy unfulfilled

A year ago the air had been full of expectancy. True, the Ashes had been lost again, but there were positive signs and great hopes, not only of doing well in the World Cup but of actually winning the thing. Instead complacent old England did not even qualify for the latter stages and compounded the error by severely underestimating the talent and resilience that resided in the team from New Zealand. By the end of the season England were being derided in some quarters as the worst team in the world and it was hard to argue otherwise.

Despite last winter's series defeat in South Africa, however, good things have been happening. By luck or judgment the powers that be seem to have hit on a credible and authoritative combination of Nasser Hussain as captain and Duncan Fletcher as coach, and both have been given their head. They used the time in South Africa to assess players for the longer term, eliminate some and develop a strategy for the next few years.

The result has been the 12 centrally con tracted players who met for the first time as a group a couple of weeks ago. The counties took some persuading that releasing players in this fashion, if not in their own interests directly, would bring the spin-offs of a successful national team. But they did not have much option.

It will also polarise the selection process, which is all to the good. In the latest edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly a table shows that in the decade since Graham Gooch was the captain on the tour to the West Indies early in 1990 England have played 109 Tests, one fewer than Australia, and fielded a total of 84 players, more than any other country, of whom 45 have played five times or fewer. David Graveney, who has been the chairman of selectors since the start of the 1997 Ashes series, has awarded 17 new caps in that time of which only three - Dean Headley, Andy Flintoff and Michael Vaughan - have made it to the central-contract stage.

The other 14 may never be seen at international level again. Well, the principle of central contracts certainly ought to ensure that we have seen the last of such cherry-picking. For, effectively, barring injury the team that plays the series against Zimbabwe and will form the core for the five-match series against West Indies as well, has already been selected. Test places for those outside the ranks will be rare, and outsiders have a new interim goal over which to scrap before they can hope to establish themselves in the big time.

It is also a general perception that the reluctant but inevitable decision to make the county championship a two-division competition will produce tougher, case-hardened cricketers. There is justifiable scepticism on this front, however, even if the change is preferable to nothing happening at all; there will be a bit more scrapping and less mid-table complacency, but the overall standard, as opposed to the level of competitiveness, will not be raised.

Only a competition that pits the country's best players against one another can hope to bridge the gap that exists between county and international cricket. There are those who believe - and indeed hope - that divisional cricket is merely a stepping stone to some thing altogether more solid and productive within five years. How typical of English cricket to balance the notion of more intense cricket, fewer matches and increased practice time allied to quality rest - which does not mean organising benefit matches - with the reintroduction of that old millstone, the Benson & Hedges Cup.

The first round of the preliminary matches kick-starts the season proper today and will continue all week. Without this extraneous competition the season could start next month, as it should.

So can English cricket claw its way back into the affections of the nation? It is certainly imperative that the national team start winning - and not just occasionally. They can begin with Zimbabwe and West Indies, both are very beatable. Then they must continue to be competitive throughout the winter in Pakistan and Sri Lanka, and finally they must win back the Ashes in the summer of 2001. It is not much to ask, is it, for the game to have a future

fields.headline: Blair has no right
fields.trailText: So Tony Blair now admits that he made an error of judgment over Rhodri Morgan (News, last week). But he still hasn't got the point.
fields.body:
So Tony Blair now admits that he made an error of judgment over Rhodri Morgan (News, last week). But he still hasn't got the point. Some of us card-carrying party members north of the Trent do not yet concede the principle that getting to be party leader, or Prime Minister, gives him any right at all to tell Welsh Labour whom they should choose to lead their Assembly, or London Labour whom should run for Mayor.
Peter Johnston
Bolton

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: The job of religious leader can be very lonely, says Chief Rabbi Professor Jonathan Sacks. But meeting up with     Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz, his friend of more than 30 years, lifts his spirits and lets him laugh at his problems
fields.trailText: The job of religious leader can be very lonely, says Chief Rabbi Professor Jonathan Sacks. But meeting up with Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz, his friend of more than 30 years, lifts his spirits and lets him laugh at his problems
fields.body:
Chief Rabbi Professor Jonathan Sacks: We met a long time ago when I was a student at Jews' College in London, and Rabbi Steinsaltz came to give a talk in the 70s. Everyone who begins studying the Talmud meets Rabbi Steinsaltz, because one of his great works has been to make the Talmud accessible to students. So I knew of him long before I met him because he was my gateway to the world of rabbinic learning.

Rabbi Steinsaltz always stays with me when he's in London, which is two or three times a year, and he always says something that lifts my spirits. When we meet up, we tell each other stories - we learn to laugh at our problems. And so we live from encounter to encounter, as Adin is one of those people who perhaps despite, or perhaps because, he is part of another very complicated Jewish community in Israel. He sees very far and very deeply into the problems of this community, and so always manages to say something that I needed to hear in order to have the strength to write the next chapter or fight the next battle.

The relationship is very simple. The story's told of a great Hasidic master, Rabbi Nachman of Bratslav, who one year foresaw that the harvest would be infected and whoever would eat it would go mad, and Rabbi Nachman said to his disciple, 'What shall we do? If we eat it, we'll go mad, but if we don't eat it, we will fail to share in the suffering of our community.' So they decided they would eat of the grain but each one would put a mark on the forehead of the other so that while everyone else was mad, at least the two of them would know they were mad. And that is the relationship between Rabbi Steinsaltz and myself; knowing we're both mad keeps us sane.

It was the encounter with another remarkable person, Rabbi Lubavitcher, who set me on this journey to becoming a rabbi. I met him when I was an undergraduate at Cambridge, and I travelled to New York, and immediately he started encouraging me to be a leader. I realised that here was someone who believed in me more than I believed in myself. And as the years went by, I sensed a challenge that I had to respond to.

Sometimes you discover that religious leadership can be a very lonely job, and the knowledge that there is someone else somewhere else who understands, that in itself is a source of enormous strength.

We are a people of very strong individuals, and therefore it is very difficult to be a leader because, quite rightly, every Jew sees himself or herself as a leader, and that means it can sometimes be a difficult and fraught life, but all you really need is a friend who understands and sympathises and lifts the burden, and that's what Rabbi Steinsaltz is for me. He's also a role model of how one can be very much in the heart of Jewish life and Jewish study, and yet preserve your integrity intellectually and ethically.

The word adin is the nearest Hebrew gets to a particular kind of gentleness, which is Adin's very great characteristic. Adin is both a mystical and a poetical person, and poetic spirits are relatively rare in contemporary Judaism. And to hear Rabbi Steinsaltz speak is to hear a poetic stream of consciousness. It is always a wonderfully ethereal vision, which he always brings down to earth by analogies and stories which are so unexpected that one realises one is in the presence of a very vast intelligence indeed, and a very benign one.

Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz: I met Jonathan about 30 years ago, which is a sizeable part of both of our lives. The age difference between us is only 10 years, he's 51, and as far as I remember he was a student at Jews' College when we met. I was a different, slightly older person trying to do the same thing Jonathan dreamt of doing. When I first saw him, I realised he was intellectually and otherwise, clearly above the others.

We became very friendly. We have an affinity in so many ways. I have very few friends like this, where you can be friends without needing to send cards between visits. Rabbi Sacks visits Jerusalem three or four times a year, and he has such a busy timetable that it is easier for us to spend time together in London.

The thing that was most important was that he cared. He cares about God and he cares about Jews and the religion. My real question at the time was will he have the stamina to go through with the job of being a rabbi. And it is an immense job being chief rabbi - the chief rabbi has lots of titles but very little clout. People have lots of expectations that he cannot fulfil and you just get tired of the whole thing. In one way, nobody is strong enough to ignore all the politics, whether it is government politics or internal Jewish politics. A position like this needs stamina.

When people asked my opinion about him being chief rabbi, I said I saw him as the only likely candidate - from all over the world. It was obvious to me from the beginning that he would go far. He has an unusual capacity for understanding, not only the Jewish religious world, but also the outside world.

Rabbi Sacks's role is like the role of the Queen, or of a flag on a military unit. When the flag falls, it is a great defeat, but the flag itself cannot do that much, it's just a symbol. Just as the flag is a symbol of a country, so is Rabbi Sacks.

One of the things we have in common is that we are like amphibious vessels - moving from secular philosophy to religious ideas and back again. My book Simple Words [Simon & Schuster, £17.99] says, among other things, that human beings are always amphibian in a sense, moving between the material and spiritual. The book aims to put complex philosophical ideas into simple words. Just imagine I gave you a cookie loaded with LSD, you would swallow it and then you would jump up. The book, likewise, is deceptively simple, so you might read it and think, 'There's nothing new in it. I've always thought like this', but afterwards you find your perception has changed.

Rabbi Sacks and I talk about philosophy, and we sometimes compare wounds and talk about what makes people like us tick. We have similar missions in many ways. *

fields.headline: Long déjeuner into night
fields.standfirst: Madame Bovary could give Jamie Oliver a few lessons in how to make a meal of things
fields.trailText: The Naked Chef | Madame Bovary | Ray Mears' Extreme Survival | When Louis Met Jimmy
fields.body:
The Naked Chef BBC2

Madame Bovary BBC2

Ray Mears' Extreme Survival BBC2

When Louis Met Jimmy BBC2

'Cooking's gotta be a laugh!' says Jamie Oliver (Oli-vah! Oli-vah! Gotta prosciutto or two!) as he constructs a dreamy-looking mozzarella, peach and parma ham salad: 'Baby chard, little bitta rocket, scatter... really, really casually... yeah, dead tempting to buy those bags of salad... pukka peaches - I like the skin, personally... a ripped peach looks so much better than a cut one. Buffalo mozzarella, soft and milky, better than the cheap stuff, rip it into nice little mouf-sized pieces...'

'Is it called buffalo 'cos it's so big?' asks a female voice from behind the camera. And is she, like, having a laugh or seriously confusing an Italian cheese with a brand of ugly footwear - the ones with the fat platform soles that used to be worn by Spice Girls and are now mostly favoured by 18-year-old waiflets from Eastern Europe who aspire to look like the old charity collecting-box orphan on a plinth? Either way, I don't think Jamie has any idea what she's on about.

'Nah! Cos it's buffalo milk,' exclaims Jamie. 'You're so sweet, dahlin!' and he carries on ripping and tearing his pukka ingredients and pretty soon it all looks, well, good enough to eat. Preferably now, please, God. Anyway, by the time Jamie gets to the sea bream - 'Pinch it at the breast...' He pauses. ' Breast? It's not a chicken! Pinch it at the fillet! Pucker it up!' - I am really quite weak. Just as one should never shop when hungry, so one should never watch Jamie Oliver tearing fruit and pinching fish.

There was, it seems, food everywhere, all week. In Monday's first episode of Madame Bovary , for example, while our heroine is still Mademoiselle Emma and flirting with that nice Dr Bovary and long before she becomes a small-town shopaholic adulteress addicted to the nineteenth-century equivalent of OK! and failing to make the monthly payments on her Franklin Mint L'Heritage Thimble Collection, Emma enjoyed her food. Had even joked that her invalid father favoured something 'light and digestible' for supper, such as 'roast goose with endive and a slice of strawberry tart'. God, but that sounded good!

However by episode two, on Tuesday, Emma's appetite for anything other than sex with Greg Wise and shopping for gowns of mustard silk with 50-metre skirts appeared to have wilted. 'You look ever so pinched about the gills,' observed Mme Bovary's maid shortly after her mistress had given birth to a daughter. Like Jamie's bream, Emma might have looked pinched about the breast, too, but had sensibly farmed out the baby to a wet nurse so Hugh Dancy's Leon and Greg Wise's Rodolphe might carry on thinking her good enough to eat. Indeed, we saw quite a lot of Madame's breasts and they weren't remotely pinched.

But despite the fact that, for Emma, shopping was no substitute for sex, by episode two her love life had gone as pear-shaped as the family finances. One night, seated at the dining table with her husband and her mother-in-law and wearing a face like le wet weekend, Frances O'Connor's Emma had just been been dumped by her lover, Rodolphe. Her mood was hardly surprising, all things considered, because by this time we had all seen Greg's naked bottom and it was an absolute peach. At the table then, Rodolphe-less but presumably Wiser, Emma did not rip open her apricot but nibbled at it squirrelishly, all passion apparently spent.

Chunky and pointy like a Toblerone mountain, this would be a Man's chocolate - and the kind of thing even Ray might not be too embarrassed to have tucked away in his rucksack. I love Ray Mears who, though obviously very good at surviving, appears to have no sense of humour at all - but perhaps living by your wits in the wilderness with only a film crew and a comfortable layer of, frankly, puppyish-looking fat to rely on is no laughing matter. Rather unfairly, there is something about Ray that reminds me of the blokes in the 'Let's Offroad!' Fast Show sketch but, whether alive or dead, Ray would still be the ideal companion if one had survived a plane crash in the Andes.

In the Rockies, Ray built a beautiful moss-thatched lean-to, lashed together with spruce roots - it looked like Swampy's dream home. Then he went fishing in a glacial lake using line baited with grasshoppers. 'One of my favourite ways of cooking fish is just to steam them in moss over the fire,' said Ray, whose fire had been lit with some lovely curly kindling that we must surely soon be able to purchase by the bunch in Habitat. Later he made a squirrel trap baited with mad-looking mushrooms ('Wild fungi can enhance flavours. And they can kill.') and, later still, he cooked a stew of brook trout with fungi, boiled root of cat's-tails and thickened by the pith of what sounded like 'rosebay willowherb'.

'That's pretty good actually!' said Ray, slurpily. Though 'lost' in the wilderness, Mears had still managed to eat like a Fulham foodie, so it is no wonder he is comfortably upholstered. But Ray told us that bears can smell a nice brook trout stew from 20 miles away, so it is usually best to cook downwind, eat fast and get an early night inside your Hansel and Gretel hideaway.

Meanwhile, exotic fungi - though not quite so exotic that they might actually kill you - had also added texture and flavour to Jamie Oliver's luscious sea bream affair: 'Don't use button mush rooms,' he advised. 'Forget them forever.' Jamie made a magic, mushroomy carpet of chanterelles, porcini and more, with juice infusing the sleek slivers of potato, atop which sat the bream bits, gleaming oozily. It looked much better than good.

Jimmy Savile and Jamie Oliver might nearly be anagrams of each other but that's all they have in common, as Louis Theroux revealed in When Louis Met Jimmy - an oddly troubling little film about the prickly, curmudgeonly, humourless ex-wrestler and DJ-turned-Sir. Savile doesn't even have a cooker in his Leeds penthouse: 'There's plenty of caffs. Cooker means people , means making food, means washing-up, means ladies clattering and banging. No cooker, babe - no brain damage!'

Over an hour spent in Savile's company revealed a man with, apparently, few friends and not much in the way of an interior life. Despite having raised some £40 million for charity ('To put this in perspective, it's £40m more than I've raised,' admitted Theroux drily) one wondered if his primary motivation hadn't been a need to be liked, or to have people somehow in his debt? And while I wouldn't go quite as far as to say that a man with no cooker is a man with no soul, to me, this fact alone indicated there was something very avoidable about him.

Eventually, having bankrupted her husband and made herself a laughing stock, Madame Bovary visited the local pharmacy and persuaded the besotted shop boy to hand over some arsenic, which she stuffed into her mouth, right there and then. The arsenic looked as if its body-double was a chocolate torte's-worth of icing sugar or (a long shot, this) the Al Pacino character's private cocaine stash in Scarface - but either way it amounted to a very sexy bit of footage. And while I think that publicly bingeing on poison rather than, say, resorting to a knife or some suitably sinister fungi, proved that Mme Bovary's simmering passions were not yet quite spent, Modern Mrs Bs might be forgiven for choosing to top themselves alone after a meal ripped and torn (and maybe even cooked) by Jamie Oliver. Or Ray Mears, at a pinch.

webTitle: New deal in force on home loans

fields.headline: New deal in force on home loans
fields.standfirst:
With the house-buying season about to step up a gear, Rupert Jones reports on rules aimed at making it easier to get the right mortgage
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: With the house-buying season about to step up a gear, Rupert Jones reports on rules aimed at making it easier to get the right mortgage.
fields.body:
New rules aimed at making it easier for people to find a decent mortgage deal came into effect this week, just in time for the legions of house-hunters currently pounding the streets in search of their dream home.

The new minimum standards for home loans are aimed at allowing millions of borrowers to benefit from the security of a good-value mortgage with low charges, user-friendly terms and no nasty surprises lurking in the small print.

The government originally unveiled details of the new rules, dubbed the CAT standards, back in January. This week it came out with a few more hurdles that mortgage lenders will have to jump in order to display the CAT-mark of quality.

Most of these changes are welcome. For example, it has decided to extend the new regime to discount and cashback deals. Originally, the plan was that only variable, fixed and capped rate home loans would be covered by the standards. It has also tightened up the rules to ensure people looking to borrow relatively small amounts are not prevented from obtaining these deals.

But ministers have been criticised for banning mortgage brokers from charging borrowers a fee when they recommend a CAT-marked home loan.

While this may sound laudable in theory, in practice it could mean that if brokers are denied a fee for the advice they give, some may simply not recommend these deals at all, according to some experts.

A few lenders, including Yorkshire building society and internet bank Egg were this week claiming to already offer CAT-compliant mortgages. Others are promising to bring out products within the next few weeks.

To win the CAT-mark of quality, a mortgage will have to meet a range of requirements on charges, access and terms:

There must be no separate charge for mortgage indemnity guarantee insurance (also known as "MIG" fee).

Interest must be calculated daily, not annually. This results in significantly less interest in the long run.

In the case of variable rate mortgages, the interest rate cannot be any higher than 2% above Bank of England base rate.

With fixed, discounted, capped and cashback mortgages, there must be no "lock-in" early redemption penalties after the end of the fixed/discounted/capped period. Any redemption penalties must be set out in cash terms and reduce monthly.

Early repayments are permitted at any time.

CAT mortgages are port-able and can be transferred.

There must be no requirement to buy the lender's buildings, contents or accident, sickness and unemployment insurance.

Information about the mortgage must be "fair, clear and not misleading".

The decision to extend the CAT standards to discounted variable rate and cashback deals is sensible. Excluding discount loans seemed ludicrous when some experts estimate they account for more than half of all the mortgages currently being taken out.

And it was important that cashback deals were included because these appeal to cash-strapped first-time buyers, many of whom will not be wise about the ways of the mortgage world and could be vulnerable to being sold a pup.

The government has also taken the sensible step of ruling that borrowers should not have to borrow any more than £10,000 to qualify for a CAT standard mortgage. Ministers made this change because they became aware that some lenders were looking to set quite high minimum loan requirements for their CAT mortgages - as high as £50,000 in some cases. If lenders had been allowed to get away with this, it would have penalised people who had paid off a lot of their original loan but want to remortgage. It would also have hit first-time buyers in areas outside London and the south-east looking at properties under £50,000.

However, the decision to ban mortgage brokers from charging fees directly to borrowers when they recommend CAT loans prompted a row. The government did this because it was concerned that brokers advising on products might collect a commission from the lender and then try to charge the borrower a fee as well. But one lender, First Active, said that with brokers unable to charge fees for their advice, it is unlikely they will have an incentive to promote or sell CAT mortgages.

Yorkshire building society says its basic flexible mortgage meets the CAT standards. The current interest rate is 6.74%. And Egg says its mortgages are fully CAT-compliant. It offers a basic variable rate product currently priced at 6.69%, and two fixed rate deals.

Abbey National says its CAT mortgage range will be available this summer, the Woolwich is to launch two deals shortly, while HSBC plans to have one on sale in July.

fields.headline: White ' s week
fields.standfirst: Jim White explores the wider, weirder world of sport: Tough on Bosman, tough on the causes of Bosman
fields.trailText: All those afternoons Alistair Campbell has spent in the directors' box at Old Trafford when he is keen to tell the world he would rather be 50 miles up the road at Turf Moor seem to have paid off. This week in Strasbourg lobbying European Union officials about the future governance of football, Sir Alex Ferguson, the man whom Campbell has so assiduously courted as a high-profile supporter of New Labour, revealed himself a master of the third way.
fields.body:
All those afternoons Alistair Campbell has spent in the directors' box at Old Trafford when he is keen to tell the world he would rather be 50 miles up the road at Turf Moor seem to have paid off. This week in Strasbourg lobbying European Union officials about the future governance of football, Sir Alex Ferguson, the man whom Campbell has so assiduously courted as a high-profile supporter of New Labour, revealed himself a master of the third way.

Ferguson was in the home of European junketing for a two-day meeting between EU officials and senior football figures. Generally the Manchester United manager prefers his two-day meetings to involve horses not administrators. But, while his presence in the heart of European bureaucracy was unexpected, it offered an intriguing vision of the future.

In one corner at the discussion was a delegation led by Michel Platini, representing Fifa, Lennart Johansson, speaking for Uefa, and Gordon Taylor of the Professional Footballers' Association. They all argued that the Bosman ruling of 1995 has done huge damage to football, as the free contractual passage of players has concentrated wealth and power in a handful of clubs, thus suppressing competition. In short, they want it scrapped. In the other corner were the denizens of EU headquarters who are anxious that employment laws remain homogenised throughout the community, without exceptions made for any profession, not even football. And hovering somewhere in between was Ferguson, proposing what, on the surface at least, appeared to be more common sense than anyone else there.

Although ostensibly part of the Platini/Johansson delegation, Ferguson was keen to distance himself from some of its aims. He believes, for instance, that there is significantly more wrong with his sport than can simply be attributed to Bosman. "The fundamentals of football are wrong to begin with," he said.

Meanwhile Johansson, through gritted teeth, tried to smile up some sort of united front. "I know Sir Alex disagrees with me," he said. "And that is his right."

"I can see the problem and I can see it getting worse," Ferguson replied. "I do not want to see a return to the pre-Bosman days but I do believe there are solutions to the problem which the president does not agree with."

Many who remember the manager's early days in Europe with Manchester United, trying to juggle his resources to conform to Uefa-imposed restrictions on foreign players, will sniff self-interest in this statement. Yet Ferguson's third-way analysis has considerable merit.

It runs like this: it is possible to live with Bosman, indeed to take advantage of it. Moreover it is a ruling, not an obligation: it does not force managers to bring in foreign players; the shrewd appreciate that a core of local talent binds a club with its supporters in a way that employing mercenaries never can. And that obtains as much for Catalans in Barcelona as Mancunians at Old Trafford. Besides, Ferguson reckons, there are far more vital issues for football, particularly to do with a fixture overload which is exhausting players to the point of early career burn-out. In short, the football authorities should put their own house in order.

Of more immediate interest to those who enjoy a conspiracy theory will be speculating on why Ferguson chose to go to Strasbourg in the first place. Mingling with bureaucrats has never been his favourite pastime, nor has he been renowned for making public statements about footballing issues beyond those which immediately concern his employers. No doubt some Fergie-watchers will suspect it was all part of his psychological warfare with his rivals, a subliminal message to Messrs Wenger and Vialli that he has the ear of the influential who can put a stop to their little game of loading teams with foreign expertise. My own speculation, though, is that this might be a sign of things to come.

Retirement is only 18 months away for the man recently voted by his peers to be the greatest manager ever. And, even if Martin Edwards condescends to allow him a position upstairs at Old Trafford, someone of his alarming energy levels will not be content with hanging around waiting for monthly board meetings. He will want a proper job, one with teeth and prestige. Some sort of role combining football and politics would be ideal. And given his assured manner in Strasbourg, confident enough to digress from a party line without undermining it, his skills will not have passed unnoticed.

For some time observers have been saying we need a figurehead to pull together the disparate interest groups in our national sport. What we may well have seen in Strasbourg this week was the unveiling of Britain's first US-style sports commissioner: step forward Alex Ferguson, Football Tsar.

But then again, he may just have fancied an awayday, picking up a few bottles of Alsace wine.

 After I suggested last week that prisoners come over all law-abiding the moment they step on to a pitch, a couple of readers wanted to know who I reckoned was the dirtiest group of people one can play football against.

As you might expect from their calling, in my experience lawyers and journalists have their moments. Journalistic shins still twitch at the memory of one notorious side which represented a broadsheet back the mid-80s. At least half of them seemed prepared to break opponents' legs without any of the usual financial inducements required by the limb-smashing professional. Maybe it was something to do with a recent hurried move into the east end that made them behave like villains.

The police, too, are not averse to fielding more than their quota of psychopaths, while members of the Conservative Party have been known to adopt a back-to-basics policy the moment they don a long stud.

I once played for a press team in a tense pre-party conference game at Blackpool, in which the agent of a then-government minister slugged it out in the centre circle with a political correspondent from the Sun. Come to think of it, it was soon after the game that the paper abandoned the Tories and hitched its flag to Tony Blair.

But anyone who has had the misfortune to play against students at theological college will agree that they are one group best avoided. Trainee vicars tend to over-compensate perceived prejudice about their performance by sharpening studs under their cassocks.

Intriguingly Jonathan Aitken is about to enrol at Wycliffe Hall, the theological college in Oxford. Members of rival teams will be hoping he can quickly preach to his team-mates some virtues recently learned elsewhere.
