My own speculation, though, is that this might be a sign of things to come. Retirement is only 18 months away for the man recently voted by his peers to be the greatest manager ever. And, even if Martin Edwards condescends to allow him a position upstairs at Old Trafford, someone of his alarming energy levels will not be content with hanging around waiting for monthly board meetings. He will want a proper job, one with teeth and prestige. Some sort of role combining football and politics would be ideal. And given his assured manner in Strasbourg, confident enough to digress from a party line without undermining it, his skills will not have passed unnoticed. For some time observers have been saying we need a figurehead to pull together the disparate interest groups in our national sport. What we may well have seen in Strasbourg this week was the unveiling of Britain's first US-style sports commissioner: step forward Alex Ferguson, Football Tsar. But then again, he may just have fancied an awayday, picking up a few bottles of Alsace wine.  After I suggested last week that prisoners come over all law-abiding the moment they step on to a pitch, a couple of readers wanted to know who I reckoned was the dirtiest group of people one can play football against. As you might expect from their calling, in my experience lawyers and journalists have their moments. Journalistic shins still twitch at the memory of one notorious side which represented a broadsheet back the mid-80s. At least half of them seemed prepared to break opponents' legs without any of the usual financial inducements required by the limb-smashing professional. Maybe it was something to do with a recent hurried move into the east end that made them behave like villains. The police, too, are not averse to fielding more than their quota of psychopaths, while members of the Conservative Party have been known to adopt a back-to-basics policy the moment they don a long stud. I once played for a press team in a tense pre-party conference game at Blackpool, in which the agent of a then-government minister slugged it out in the centre circle with a political correspondent from the Sun. Come to think of it, it was soon after the game that the paper abandoned the Tories and hitched its flag to Tony Blair. But anyone who has had the misfortune to play against students at theological college will agree that they are one group best avoided. Trainee vicars tend to over-compensate perceived prejudice about their performance by sharpening studs under their cassocks. Intriguingly Jonathan Aitken is about to enrol at Wycliffe Hall, the theological college in Oxford. Members of rival teams will be hoping he can quickly preach to his team-mates some virtues recently learned elsewhere.

fields.headline: Lacey
fields.standfirst: Soaring Charlton invoke spirit of Summer s
fields.trailText: The imminent reappearance of Charlton Athletic in the Premiership will warm the cockles of more than a few hearts. Charlton are a friendly club with amiable supporters and a healthy tradition of redeeming lost causes.
fields.body:
The imminent reappearance of Charlton Athletic in the Premiership will warm the cockles of more than a few hearts. Charlton are a friendly club with amiable supporters and a healthy tradition of redeeming lost causes.

Their fans not only stuck by them when, after a dispute with a former chairman, Michael Gliksten, the team left the Valley for seven years between 1985 and 1992, they also entered local politics to hasten the club's return as well as raising money to help refurbish the stadium.

Thousands travelled to the Valley for last night's game against Huddersfield Town happy in the knowledge that, even if Charlton did not achieve the victory that would complete their return to the Premiership after only one season back in the First Division, promotion was only a matter of time. And among them were those for whom this fixture will always have special meaning.

For any Charlton follower under the age of 45, say, the name of Johnny Summers has only a distant ring. Younger supporters will have difficulty recalling it at all unless their elders have first-hand recollections of a December day in 1957 when Charlton and Huddersfield met at the Valley in a routine Second Division fixture which made history.

Christmas was four days away and the crowd was a modest 12,000. The Valley was still hung over after Charlton's relegation from the old First Division the previous season, ending a stay of 21 years during which they had won the FA Cup and played before crowds of more than 70,000. Charlton had come down with a bump, conceding 120 goals. Scoring, however, was not a problem and when Summers was signed from Millwall for £3,300 halfway through the relegation season the power of his left foot was always going to bring them goals.

Summers, like Bobby Charlton and Tom Finney, was a goalscoring winger who could be equally effective in central positions. In 171 league matches for Charlton he scored 100 goals, five of them against Huddersfield on that famous December afternoon.

Even after 43 years the course of the match makes barely credible reading. After 15 minutes Derek Ufton, Charlton's centre-half and captain, was carried off with one of the 20 dislocated shoulders he suffered during his playing career. There were no substitutes then. Charlton were down to 10 men and by half-time Hud dersfield were leading 2-0. And with just under half an hour to go the contest had seemingly become a rout. Huddersfield were 5-1 up and for Charlton there was surely little left in the game but damage-limitation.

The rest, however, belonged to Summers. He had already scored once. Now, in the space of a minute, he struck again and set up a goal for John Ryan.

Summers was inspired. He scored three more times in a little over 10 minutes to put Charlton ahead at 6-5 and, even though Huddersfield drew level, he sent in Ryan for the winner as the referee was about to end the match.

Never before had any team scored six times in a league game and lost. Summers, moreover, had scored all his five goals in his team's 7-6 win with his supposedly weaker right foot. He had also changed into a new pair of boots at half-time. As footballing stories go, this one had everything.

But not a happy ending. Five years later Summers died of cancer. At the end of the 1957-58 season Charlton missed promotion by a point and they did not regain their place in the First Division until 1986.

Nevertheless the spirit of that winter afternoon in the 50s clearly continues to sustain Charlton, who could have felt sorry for themselves after a season's stay in the Premiership when more than half of their defeats were by the odd goal, but instead have responded with attacking football in the Summers tradition.

With the same manager, Alan Curbishley, and much the same team they have played with five men up both home and away, scoring 41 of their 76 goals on opponents' grounds. There is not a side in the First Division to touch them and rather fewer pundits will forecast their immediate demise next season.

O r will they? Some will argue that Charlton's free-scoring push for promotion this season, such a contrast to the difficulty they had breaking down Premiership defences, simply proves that the gulf between the two divisions is growing ever wider.

To a large extent this is right. Joe Royle has done a wonderful job bringing Manchester City from the Second Division to the threshold of the Premiership in successive seasons but if City do go up the team will have to be massively rebuilt if they are not to become just another Nationwide house of straw with ideas above their foundations.

Charlton are entitled to be more optimistic. Their previous experience of the Premiership, though brief, should help them gain a firmer footing next season. They clearly have more wrinkles than Watford and a better prospectus for survival than Bradford City.

Put another Kevin Phillips at the head of their attack and they might do as well as Sunderland. Or maybe Curbishley will spot a 6ft winger with a natural left foot and sign him for a Summers song.

fields.headline: Wenger's Arsenal sans frontières
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger puts forward his case against restricting the number of foreign players in football clubs.
fields.body:
A glance at Arsenal's squad does not suggest Arsène Wenger would support a restriction on the number of foreign players teams can field. And the Arsenal manager yesterday made clear his opposition to Uefa's proposal.

"I believe it's a completely wrong way of thinking because it goes the opposite way to the way we are going politically and economically," he said. "I'm surprised that people responsible for football can think like that."

What Uefa said this week, at a meeting attended by Sir Alex Ferguson in Wenger's hometown of Strasbourg, was that it wants to force clubs to field at least six players eligible for their national side.

Ferguson disagreed, though he said teams ought to include a core of local talent. Wenger's suggestion that clubs might instead be made to field players from their youth academy seems to go further, although a handful of his promising youngsters are not English, never mind from near Highbury. Moritz Volz (Germany), Niccolo Galli (Italy), Jérémie Aliadière (France) and Israel da Silva (Brazil) are among them.

"It's better for me to have rules like you have to have five players on the teamsheet coming out of your academy," Wenger said. "That would encourage people to invest money in the youth development.

"To say that, no matter how good a player is, you have to play him because of his nationality is not right. A rule like that will not make a bad player into a good player. It would make a good team into a bad or an average team."

Cynics will point out that Wenger's use of his academy since 1996 has been negligible. The manager says work was needed and points out that Arsenal are in the FA Youth Cup final against Coventry, where eight of the starting line-up are likely to be English.

Wenger disagrees that an emphasis on youth will work against poorer clubs unable to invest heavily. "If they have to buy to compete with the top clubs, they have no chance," he said. "If they bring youth players through they have a chance to do well."

After announcing that Davor Suker will leave this summer, Wenger said ideally he would fill the gap from within the club. He fears his young strikers Jay Bothroyd, Tommy Black and Graham Barrett are a year from being ready but said he would not consider PSV Eindhoven's Ruud van Nistelrooy at £20m.

Suker seems likely to join West Ham and Wenger said: "You have to respect that he is a world-class player and he doesn't get the number of games he deserves."

Tony Adams returns tomorrow for the fixture at Leeds which Wenger describes as "probably our most important match since the beginning of the season". Leeds's five straight defeats will give him hope as the scramble for Champions League places reaches its climax.

webTitle: The truth will out at birthday booze-up

fields.headline: The truth will out at birthday booze-up
fields.trailText: • In hindsight Stephen Weldon shouldn't have gone ahead with the birthday party. That was the giveaway, really.
fields.body:
 In hindsight Stephen Weldon shouldn't have gone ahead with the birthday party. That was the giveaway, really.

The beer was going down nicely as Weldon, a midfielder with the Masons Arms pub team in Middlestone Moor, Co Durham, celebrated his 40th year at the local working men's club.

His team-mates were happy, too. After four successive promotions the team had won one cup, had made the final of another and were well established in the Premier Division of the Ashley Air Products Over-40s League.

But then someone put two and two together and got 40 - and reported Weldon to the league committee for playing while under age.

It transpired that Weldon had made his debut as a mere youngster of 39 years and nine months. As a result the Masons Arms have been docked 24 points - three for each game in which Weldon played - relegating them to the First Division.

They have also been stripped of the Villa Real Trophy, even though Weldon did not play in the final, and barred from taking part in a forthcoming cup final.

Weldon and his team manager Maurice Flint have also been banned from the league for life and fined £100and £200 respectively.

The whole episode has aged Weldon considerably.

 The recurrence of Ronaldo's knee injury has hit a lot of people hard, according to Pele: "Things like this make you doubt the existence of God."

A tad over the top? Perhaps not. In a poll conducted by an Italian TV station, 66% of Italian mothers admitted they cried when the Internazionale forward was injured.

 As the football season nears its end, the silly season begins. Eleven Brentford fans will have their heads shaved à la David Beckham at today's game against Millwall.

Colchester United fans are being urged to turn up in shorts for their last home match of the season. It is in honour of the United manager Steve Whitton, who has turned around the team's fortunes since his arrival at the club and who always wears shorts in the dug-out, regardless of the weather.

 Chelsea have certainly reached the heights in the Champions League. Before every home tie, one of the Stamford Bridge ground staff must climb on to the roofs of the north and south stands and remove the adverts for Philips which sit on top of the two giant video screens. Under Champions League rules ads are banned if they conflict with any of the competition's sponsors, in this case Sony.

 This week the Bayern Munich goalkeeper Oliver Kahn was pictured bleeding from the head after being hit by a golf ball thrown by an opposition Freiburg fan. Now it emerges that before the game Freiburg were presented with a Uefa award for the good behaviour of their supporters. In response, Freiburg have decided to donate the 12,500 marks (around £4,000) prize money to a charity - of Kahn's choice.

 Prince William is an Aston Villa fan, honest. And to prove it he predicts they will win the FA Cup final by at least two tries to none.

webTitle: Sky Blue hat suits laughing Peruvian

fields.headline: Sky Blue hat suits laughing Peruvian
fields.standfirst: Zuniga, a striker bought on video evidence, settles into the Coventry picture
fields.trailText: Ysrael Zuniga is Latin America's golden boot. And Coventry manager Gordon Strachan forked out £500,000 for a player who as he says "doesn't understand a word I'm saying but then nor does anybody else, and he's working hard on his English." The striker's English, barely better than Strach's, suggest his translator does most of the talking here.
fields.body:
When Ysrael Zuniga decided to join Coventry City he turned to his good friend and fellow Peruvian Nol Solano for advice. The Newcastle midfielder happily obliged. "The first thing he said," Zuniga recalls, "was get a thick overcoat."

Zuniga has stopped short of turning up for training like Paddington Bear, but only just. On a morning so bright one half expects to find Gordon Strachan directing operations in a bathing costume, the 23-year-old is the only player sporting tracksuit bottoms. "In Peru we have air conditioning, here you have central heating," he says. Not for the first time he laughs.

The holder of South Amer ica's golden boot is a cheery character. His English does not stretch much beyond shouts of "Keano" and "Shawsie" - his teacher translated for this interview - but, despite not knowing his handies from his Andes, he has settled unexpectedly fast.

When he arrived from Melgar in February, Zuniga was told he was one for next season. Instead he has played and scored. The language, he admits, is "a big problem"; by nature he is a talker. But the Spanish-speaking Moroccans Mustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo have helped and he is becoming one of the lads. When he misses a sitter in training, he gets the usual treatment. Zuniga, naturally, smiles.

"His attitude's smashing," says Strachan, who signed the 5ft 8in striker on video evidence, deeming it a worthwhile gamble at around £500,000. "Sometimes when I'm giving tactics talks you can see him just grinning away. He doesn't understand a word I'm saying but then nor does anybody else, and he's working hard on his English.

"If he stays between the width of the 18-yard box he's excellent. If he goes outside that he's very ordinary. He's got a good football brain, he's a brave wee fella and he can score when he gets a chance. He doesn't panic."

Zuniga's rise has been rapid. Last season with Melgar was his first in Peru's top flight. An impressive 32 goals in 26 games catapulted him first into the national team and then into the Premiership - not bad for someone who stumbled into football with Sporting Cristal by accident. "I was studying as a dental technician in Lima," he explains, "and my older brother, Cristian, was on the books of Sporting Cristal. I was visiting him one day and the manager just invited me to join in a training session. I had to borrow some boots. It started from there.

"There was a question of whether I would continue my studies or commit myself totally to football but the manager convinced me it was worth a go. My mother nearly killed me for it. She still says I shouldn't have given up the studies completely. I was always interested in football. But it wasn't until I went to Sporting Cristal that I really had the ambition to make it as a professional."

It was there that Zuniga met Solano. The pair speak every week and Solano has emphasised the importance of learning English. Presumably, "do you stock thermal underwear?" will be the sentence he advises Zuniga to learn first.

Word in the Coventry canteen is that Zuniga has struggled with his driving as well as his speaking. The delivery of his new 4x4 prompts mental notes to avoid local roundabouts. But, when Europe called, Zuniga had no hesitation in choosing Coventry ahead of Hertha Berlin, also ignoring Porto's late overtures.

"It was a big influence that the Premiership is such a competitive league, with every team having national players like Kanu and Desailly and Deschamps," he says. "I know Coventry are always fighting to get as high up the table as possible and that's what attracted me to them."

The pace, quality and physical demands will require adjustment but Zuniga is no arrogant superstar. He appreciates how fortunate he is. After leaving Lima aged three, he grew up in the small town of Camana, close to the Pacific beaches of southern Peru. His parents lived off the land.

"It wasn't really hard," he says, "but people in Lima generally have a higher standard of living than in the countryside in Peru. My family was working class and where we lived the main product was rice, so most people made a living from growing rice or processing it, although there were also beans."

Zuniga, happily ensconced in Leamington with his wife and PlayStation, should be joined in the summer by his compatriot Walter Zevallos, though passport problems are threatening the wing-back's move. Strachan admits it will be "nearly impossible" for Zuniga to become a regular before November because Peru face 17 World Cup qualifiers. Chile await later this month. But do not bet against the odd suspension.

In the Copa America last July Zuniga came on against Bolivia in the 85th minute, scored the winner in the 87th and was sent off in the 90th. To prove that was no fluke, he was dismissed in February against the United States 13 minutes after leaving the bench.

Those, he stresses, are the only sendings-off of his career. "They weren't bad fouls," he says. "Against Bolivia it was an innocuous challenge by the halfway line but the player dived." He mimics the theatrical fall. Then, as ever, comes the smile.

The pace, quality and physical demands will require adjustment but Zuniga is no arrogant superstar. He appreciates how fortunate he is. After leaving Lima aged three, he grew up in the small town of Camana, close to the Pacific beaches of southern Peru. His parents lived off the land. "It wasn't really hard," he says, "but people in Lima generally have a higher standard of living than in the countryside in Peru. My family was working class and where we lived the main product was rice, so most people made a living from growing rice or processing it, although there were also beans." Zuniga, happily ensconced in Leamington with his wife and PlayStation, should be joined in the summer by his compatriot Walter Zevallos, though passport problems are threatening the wing-back's move. Strachan admits it will be "nearly impossible" for Zuniga to become a regular before November because Peru face 17 World Cup qualifiers. Chile await later this month. But do not bet against the odd suspension. In the Copa America last July Zuniga came on against Bolivia in the 85th minute, scored the winner in the 87th and was sent off in the 90th. To prove that was no fluke, he was dismissed in February against the United States 13 minutes after leaving the bench. Those, he stresses, are the only sendings-off of his career. "They weren't bad fouls," he says. "Against Bolivia it was an innocuous challenge by the halfway line but the player dived." He mimics the theatrical fall. Then, as ever, comes the smile.

webTitle: Lions roar for the old guard

fields.headline: Lions roar for the old guard
fields.standfirst: Millwall find two heads are better than one as they push for promotion
fields.trailText: The New Den miracle defies the "too many cooks spoil the broth" adage with a management duo about to spearhead Millwall to the First Division. Dominic Fifield talks to Lions' guffer and guffer Alan McLeary and Keith "Rhino" Stevens.
fields.body:
Convention dictates that football clubs need a figurehead; someone to issue a half-time rallying cry and put his neck on the block should things go wrong. It is different at Second Division Millwall.

Too many cooks may spoil the broth but apparently they let only one loose in the kitchen at the New Den. "I make the tea while he sits at his desk all day looking important," quips Alan McLeary, one half of the management duo on the verge of leading the Lions to promotion. The other, Keith "Rhino" Stevens, looks nonplussed.

The pair, who assumed the reins in 1998, are as south London as they come. Millwall courses through their veins. As an uncompromising defensive partnership Stevens and McLeary racked up 805 league games for Millwall between them. Their desks are no further apart now than the pair of them were at the heart of the Lions' rearguard.

"We've tried to bring in players who are loyal," says Stevens. "There's no point putting people out there who don't want to work for Millwall. You have to start with youngsters who want to play for the club."

It is a simple approach that is clearly working. This afternoon they travel to Brentford aware that a first win at Griffin Park since 1965 would keep up the pressure on Wigan and Bristol Rovers for an automatic promotion place and a return to the First Division in which they last competed in 1995.

Hero-worshipped by the fans, Stevens and McLeary are alumni of the Lions' teams promoted under George Graham in 1985 and John Docherty in 1988, into the old First Division. "We learnt a lot from George and the Doc," says McLeary. "You take bits from everyone you work with - Ray Harford has been with us for a month as a coach and we're learning from him all the time.

"There are similarities with this side and the one that went up with the Doc, but we haven't achieved anything."

The pair took over a club which had been through seven managers in eight years, had escaped financial ruin by a cub's whisker and had just finished 18th in the Second Division, its lowest league position since 1965. "The first thing we did when we took the job was paint the canteen," says Stevens. "Not that we wanted to. We needed to save some money to buy a player."

Salvaging the wreckage has taken time and effort but now Millwall's share price is on the up - boosted last month by fictitious stories suggesting Chris Evans might buy into the club. From the dizzy heights of fourth in the division, the Lions are purring in quiet satisfaction. "The canteen probably needs redecorating again," adds Stevens. "But we can afford wallpaper nowadays."

As a springboard to success, Millwall's approach is unconventional. Experiments with joint managers are invariably stopgaps and, while Charlton were steered through their most traumatic years by Alan Curbishley and Steve Gritt, tangible success came to the Valley only once the former took sole charge of team affairs in 1995. Gritt now coaches Millwall's reserve team.

"It's no different to having one manager," says the striker Paul Moody. "There's basically an extra pair of eyes to watch over us. Mind you, they're both known to have a right go at half-time if we need it."

"We've gone back to basics," says McLeary. "It's a young club. The chairman [Theo Paphitis] is young, we're quite young, the players are young. About two-thirds of our squad are homegrown. Charlton had to build through the youth set-up and look where it's got them."

A number of players - Neil Harris, Tim Cahill, Paul Ifill and Joe Dolan, for instance - will surely grace the Premiership. "They've still got a lot to learn but their futures are bright," says Stevens.

Pride is returning to the Lions' supporters as well with average gates up by 25%. Last weekend 10,742 were at the New Den for the visit of Bury to witness a 3-0 win brimming with attacking intent.

"The image of the old Third Division was of rough and rugged football played on rubbish pitches in terrible stadia," says Stevens. "Nowadays the stadia are nice, the pitches are nice and our lads want to play exciting football. If we can get it down and play, we will."

"We wanted things to move on and, since we took over, the club has progressed every year," adds McLeary. "We've got some way to go yet. Promotion is first; then we'll see."

fields.headline: Joachim ineligible for St Vincent
fields.trailText: The Aston Villa striker Julian Joachim was at the heart of a World Cup shambles last night when he was declared ineligible to play for St Vincent.
fields.body:
The Aston Villa striker Julian Joachim was at the heart of a World Cup shambles last night when he was declared ineligible to play for St Vincent.

The player was in mid-flight to the Caribbean to make his debut for St Vincent in the World Cup qualifier against St Kitts when Villa were told his journey was futile.

The FA informed the club that Joachim was ineligible to play for the island where his father was born because he had represented England at Under-21 level while at Leicester City.

The player was informed on his arrival in the West Indies and will have to catch a flight back after the briefest of visits.

Villa's manager, John Gregory, had to leave the player out of today's match against Spurs. Gregory said: "The FA told us this morning and we tried to get in touch with Julian Joachim to stop him travelling so that we could put him back in the squad to face Tottenham.

"He was already in the departure lounge and his mobile was switched off so there was no way we could prevent his journey."

 The FA, in an attempt to professionalise its disciplinary system, is to appoint a lawyer as a full-time prosecutor of disciplinary cases. The FA is also hiring an administrator with experience of how courts work to organise the case against those charged.

webTitle: Houllier joins the £1m a year club

fields.headline: Houllier joins the £1m a year club
fields.trailText: Gérard Houllier's reward for leading Liverpool to second in the Premiership will be an extended and vastly improved new contract which will make him one of the highest paid managers in British football.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier's reward for leading Liverpool to second in the Premiership will be an extended and vastly improved new contract which will make him one of the highest paid managers in British football.

The Merseyside club will shortly offer Houllier a deal which is likely to treble his current salary to around £1m.

Negotiations between the Frenchman and his Anfield employers opened in earnest a fortnight ago and the likelihood is he will agree to sign a new, six-year deal to replace his current contract which has just over three years to run.

Since succeeding his managerial partner Roy Evans 16 months ago, Houllier has transformed Liverpool's fortunes so dramatically that they are now on course for a place in the Champions League.

Although Houllier is acknowledged to be one of the most astute and learned coaches of his generation he is, strangely, one of the Premiership's worst-paid managers.

Now, in the hope of convincing Houllier he should extend his stay, Liverpool have decided to give him financial parity with Manchester United's Sir Alex Ferguson, Arsenal's Arsène Wenger, Tottenham's George Graham and Leeds United's David O'Leary. All are believed to earn around £20,000 a week.

However, Liverpool's desire to ensure Houllier is both successful and content is not simply out of gratitude for the manner in which he has helped revive a fallen giant.

Despite a love affair with Liverpool Football Club which began more than 25 years ago when he was a teacher in the city, Houllier is believed to have been seriously considering his own future since the announcement last month that his friend and confidant Peter Robinson was to leave Anfield this summer.

Robinson, the club's vice-chairman and senior administrator, is standing down after 35 years' service but his public admission that he wished to remain in football rather than retire prompted understandable speculation that he may have been the victim of a political spat.

Certainly Houllier has been unsettled by the news of Robinson's departure. This sense of unease prompted Liverpool's board to bring forward the offer of a new deal.

Although Houllier has every intention of signing - possibly next week - it is inconceivable he would stay were he to find himself at odds with a new regime.

Houllier will make any demands for transfer funds from a position of strength for, since his arrival at Liverpool less than two years ago, he has been the subject of several inquiries from leading clubs, notably in Italy and France.

fields.headline: Graham set for swift return
fields.standfirst: Tottenham manager expecting to be back from illness in seven days
fields.trailText: George Graham will be in hospital today while Tottenham take on Aston Villa, but the word at White Hart Lane yesterday was that the manager will be back by next weekend.
fields.body:
George Graham will be in hospital today while Tottenham take on Aston Villa, but the word at White Hart Lane yesterday was that the manager will be back by next weekend.

His assistant Stewart Houston said suggestions that the 55-year-old will miss the rest of the season were wide of the mark. On Thursday Graham checked into a London hospital, complaining of acute pains in his joints and a high fever.

"I've spoken to George and he's convinced the medical people have got to the bottom of the problem," said Houston, who takes charge this afternoon. "He's going to stay in hospital a few more days but the signs are he should be out shortly after the weekend and ready to work again."

Graham is not expected to be in the dug-out at Leicester on Wednesday but could return for the visit of Wimbledon a week today. The chronic inflammation of his joints is thought to be rheumatoid arthritis, which he concealed from his players.

"The Wimbledon game looks a realistic target for George from what he tells me," Houston said. "As usual there has been a lot of hype but it is a lot lower-key than some people have been suggesting. I'm just going to hold the fort for a while and I don't think it will be for very long."

 Ronny Johnsen, a long-term injury victim, has been named in Manchester United's squad for the first time this season after recovering from surgery on both knees. The Norwegian will not start at home to Sunderland as United seek to move closer to the championship.

Wins today and at Southampton next weekend could help seal the title. "You expect it to be tighter than it has turned out," said United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson.

Between Sunderland and the Dell comes the Champions League tie against Real Madrid, who may be without Roberto Carlos because of a knee injury. The 27-year-old Brazilian has been told to rest for a month by club doctors after damaging tendons but wants to play, even though that might worsen the injury.

"I am still feeling pain and I am not comfortable in training," he told the Spanish newspaper AS. "I don't have the firmness in my knee to make certain movements such as jumping and I am scared to shoot. The doctor has told me that to be fully rehabilitated I will need a month off but I don't want to wait that long."

 Chelsea, also in Champions League action next week, may be pleased to hear that Patrick Kluivert may be left out of Barcelona's side. Louis van Gaal has dropped the striker from his 17-man squad to play Real Oviedo today.

The coach made the decision after being publicly criticised by Kluivert for the second time in a week. "The truth is that Van Gaal's relationship with the players could be better," Kluivert is quoted as saying. "Above all at the present time."

Van Gaal said: "A player of his age [23] should know when to speak. We talked a couple of days ago and now the best thing is for him not to play. He shouldn't speak out."

 The French surgeon Gérard Saillant has said Ronaldo should play again early next year after rupturing a tendon in his right knee against Lazio on Wednesday.

"All being well he'll play again at the beginning of 2001. We can't expect miracles," Saillant said after operating for the second time in less than five months on the Brazil and Internazionale striker's knee.

webTitle: Uefa bans Turkish fans from cup tie in Leeds after police safety warning

fields.headline: Uefa bans Turkish fans from cup tie in Leeds after police safety warning
fields.trailText: Turkish fans have been banned from next week's Uefa Cup semi-final second leg with Leeds United after West Yorkshire police said they could not guarantee the safety of visiting supporters.
fields.body:
Turkish fans have been banned from next week's Uefa Cup semi-final second leg with Leeds United after West Yorkshire police said they could not guarantee the safety of visiting supporters.

Uefa, European football's governing body, made the decision yesterday as four men were formally charged in Turkey with the murder of the Leeds fans Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight, who were stabbed to death in Istanbul 10 days ago.

Up to 1,500 Turks had been expected to make the trip to Elland Road, and yesterday's ban drew widespread condemnation from the Turkish capital.

"They are trying to turn the murders into their advantage to win the match," said Fikret Unlu, the Turkish sports minister. "This is a biased decision. It is against human rights."

After a week of deliberations Uefa ordered Galatasaray to return their allocation of 1,750 tickets. Galatasaray will be granted only 80 tickets for an official party that will include the former Turkish prime minister Tansu Ciller. Police are preparing for one of the biggest security operations at any sporting event in England.

The game is being treated as a category C++ security risk and the police are planning a round-the-clock guard on the Galatasaray team hotel. Inflammatory messages have been posted on the internet and there are concerns that rightwing activists will target the match.

"Our advice to the travelling party will be to remain in their hotel. They will be subject to police protection throughout their stay," said Paul Garvin, assistant chief constable of operations. "Because of the high tension and the intelligence we have received there should not be any members of the party on the streets of Leeds before the game."

Uefa said: "The West Yorkshire police informed Uefa they would be unable to guarantee the safety of visiting supporters travelling independently to the match. This report was submitted to the Turkish club who proposed that the match be played behind closed doors or at a neutral venue. In reaching its conclusion, Uefa was aware the decision would not meet unanimous approval."

Having been heavily criticised for its failure to do so before the first leg, the European game's governing body has requested that both teams wear black armbands and that there is a minute's silence.

The ban was described as "disgusting" by Galatasaray's vice-president, Mehmet Cansun. But the Leeds chairman, Peter Ridsdale, said: "My reaction is one of relief. We have been pressing for this for the last week but it seems like a lot more than seven days. Given what happened in Istanbul it would have been foolish to give guarantees of security because I'm sure everyone will understand that feelings are running very high in Leeds."

In Turkey a trial date is expected to be set within six weeks and the murder suspects have been warned to expect maximum 30-year prison sentences if convicted. The prosecutor, Osman Ikizoglu, is seeking terms of two to five years for four others allegedly involved in the attacks. Another suspect faces up to four years for concealing a weapon and nine others face a maximum six months for affray.

According to the indictment, the Turkish youths were provoked by a group of Leeds fans that had smashed car and shop windows. It is said that one rubbed his genitals with the Turkish flag.

"When we saw that, we went to buy knives," the indictment quotes the suspect Ali Umit Demir. "I saw my uncle was injured in the leg. Then I stabbed the Briton next to him."

webTitle: Golden Boy who made the ball do everything but talk

fields.headline: Golden Boy who made the ball do everything but talk
fields.trailText: Nat Lofthouse: "When I watched Pele playing I thought of Wilf. Great though Pele is, I am proud to think I played with as great a player - perhaps even greater." Wilf Mannion died yesterday aged 81.
fields.body:
On the day that Middlesbrough's old Ayresome Park ground passed into history, its faithful treated the greatest performer ever to grace its turf to the thunderous thank you, as warm as it was loud, he had long deserved.

The entire ground cheered his name as it was the last to be read out in the pre-match roll-call of former Boro players. The thousands massed behind the goal burst into song as he walked unsteadily around the perimeter track. "One Wilf Mannion," they chanted. "There's only one Wilf Mannion."

With the Golden Boy's death yesterday, aged 81, after a long illness, many minds will go back to that emotional day almost five years ago. The reason is simple: almost all of those devotedly chanting his name were too young to have any other memories of the player Pele rated so highly that he invited him to coach young players in Brazil, yet his legend lived on because the tales of his genius on the pitch were passed down from grandfather to father to son. The boy who took the pre-war Boro side to the verge of the league title. The England player who was the match of Matthews and Finney. Most of all, the league match in which he made clowns of Matthews' side, Blackpool.

He dribbled and swayed past opponents like a winger in that 4-0 rout. He fired in shots like a centre-forward. In the coup de grace he played keepy-uppy with his head as he ran past stunned defenders and then allowed the ball to roll down his back before trapping it with his heel.

The Blackpool manager Joe Smith told his Boro counterpart David Jack, whose goals won the first FA Cup played at Wembley: "Your boys were brilliant. And Mannion: what a player. He made that ball do everything but talk." And all because he wanted to impress his watching fiancee.

What went largely unremembered amid all the happy recollections of a truly world-class player, however - but reinforced the affection in which he was held by those who did recall it - was the appalling treatment he had received off the pitch.

Few of those who stopped him in the streets around Ayresome asking him to sign the final day's programme even knew of the way his career was neutered - and by his own club.

When his contract ran out in 1948 he demanded a transfer and, as was the club's right in those days, he was refused. For nine months he went on strike in a fight that paralleled those later won by Jimmy Hill and, more recently, by the Belgian Jean-Marc Bosman. But Mannion was forced to capitulate when his wife became ill. Some argued that with his ambition thwarted he was never really the same player again.

He played for Boro for another five years, taking his goal tally in a career interrupted by the war to 110 in 368 games over 17 years. Yet it was another 29 years before he was granted a testimonial - which, even then, he had to share with his Boro and England team-mate George Hardwick.

Together they had shared some of England's greatest moments, Hardwick the captain, Mannion the inspiration, as Walter Winterbottom's side beat Portugal and the World Cup holders Italy away in consecutive end-of-season tours. The former's famed goalkeeper Azevedo was led away in tears during the 10-0 defeat (after being illegally substituted) in Lisbon in 1947; Italy were humiliated 4-0 in Turin in 1948 in what Sir Tom Finney calls England's greatest away win.

But it was another England hero, Nat Lofthouse, who uttered, almost 30 years ago, what might now serve as Wilf Mannion's epitaph: "When I watched Pele playing I thought of Wilf. Great though Pele is, I am proud to think I played with as great a player - perhaps even greater."

webTitle: Final eliminator for England's No1 contenders

fields.headline: Final eliminator for England's No1 contenders
fields.trailText: Nigel Martyn should be England's No 1 but David Seaman has possession which is more than nine tenths of the law. Roy Collins talks to the Leeds goalie ahead of his team's clash with Seaman's Arsenal tomorrow.
fields.body:
Nigel Martyn's seven-year-old son Thomas is not into football. So he cannot understand why his dad cannot behave like normal dads by taking him and his 21-month-old sister off to a sunny beach this summer, instead of going off to play in some silly tournament in Belgium and Holland.

Being a devoted family man, the Leeds goalkeeper Martyn admits it is difficult for him to justify spending his entire close season on England duty at Euro 2000 when he accepts that the only glimpse his family are like to get of him is when the television cameras zoom in for a close-up of the bench.

Martyn, in his 34th year, is in the best form of his life. But he understands that, when it comes to the England goalkeeping jersey, possession is more than nine tenths of the law. Arsenal's David Seaman, who will be at the opposite end to Martyn at Elland Road tomorrow, has been confirmed as the No1 by the coach Kevin Keegan, so unless he is injured, makes a couple of dreadful rickets or takes a phone call from Hansie Cronje's bookmaker, he is certain to play throughout Euro 2000.

Fortunately patience to rival that of Job is a prerequisite for goalkeepers, who often serve by merely standing and staring at the action. Martyn says: "You just have to wait your turn, like a lot of other England keepers have had to do. Chris Woods had to wait behind Peter Shilton but eventually won 43 caps.

"Of course it is frustrating because, no matter how well I play for Leeds, David is the man in possession of the England jersey. And it's not as if I can say 'give me a run on the right wing' as an outfield player might." Out of the question as that might be, if the culling of English left-sided players continues, Martyn should not rule out a request to play on the left wing.

It might ease his frustration if he could bring himself to stick pins in an effigy of Seaman, who might suspect his rival of having done so, given his dreadful bad luck with injuries this season. But there is such a freemasonry among goalkeepers that they are good mates, who will share a joke whatever the result of tomorrow's crucial game.

The televised encounter will allow the nation to join what has become a lively debate as to which of the keepers should be No1 in the Low Countries in June, with many believing that Martyn has overtaken Seaman. The latter will be distraught at learning that Gordon Banks, England's 1966 World Cup winning goalkeeper, has joined the bandwagon of doubters about his form.

Banks says: "David has been a great goalkeeper but at 36 you begin to lose some flexibility. On experience you would probably play him in Euro 2000 but after that Keegan will probably think about bringing Martyn in."

Bob Wilson, a former Scottish international and Arsenal's goalkeeping coach, has witnessed first hand the pain of Seaman as the whispering campaign against him has grown, in some quarters, to a full-throated roar. Wilson says: "He would never admit it publicly but the press campaign has got to him and he has been deeply hurt by some of the criticism. I have been unable to do anything to reverse that, which is why it was brilliant of Kevin Keegan to pull him aside after the Argentina game and tell him that he is his man. That is the biggest boost David has had all season."

Spectacular saves

Although Seaman is also Wilson's man, Wilson is objective enough to admit that international experience - Seaman has 56 caps to Martyn's 12 - is probably all that is tipping the scales at the moment. He says: "Nigel has had an excellent season and he has cut out what I would call his Bruce Grobbelaar moments. He is a very mobile, gymnastic type of keeper, who makes the sort of spectacular saves that Peter Schmeichel used to make for Manchester United.

"David is less spectacular but he has a massive presence and is probably closest in style to Pat Jennings. I think his international experience just makes the difference and Nigel finds himself in the same position as Ted Ditchburn and Bert Williams when Frank Swift was England No 1. We always seem to be blessed with more than one top goalkeeper."

Or cursed, as Martyn might see it. Both keepers, as one would expect, play for club sides renowned for their defensive organisation, which puts even more of a premium on concentration. Martyn says: "As the Leeds team has got better and better, I have had less and less saves to make in a game. But as the number of saves goes down, the level of importance goes up. Sometimes I only have to make two big saves in a game. Yet, if I make them and keep a clean sheet, people will say how well I'm playing."

Martyn could not be blamed for the two goals scored by Galatasaray in their Uefa Cup semi-final as his defence lacked their usual cohesion, doubtless affected by the death of two Leeds fans the night before the game. He says: "It would be a massive understatement to say that it was not the right preparation for the match.

"It was all we talked about beforehand. Someone saw the incident on the news and we were all going round knocking on each other's doors. It's terrible to think that two fans went out to support us and didn't come home."

Martyn is confident that Leeds can overturn the deficit on Thursday. But the players, he says, must not allow what is sure to be an emotionally charged night to suck them into an unnaturally high tempo. They will need to show patience, which is something he already knows plenty about and which young Thomas Martyn is just beginning to learn.

fields.headline: Celtic approach Hiddink as coach
fields.trailText: If Rangers today clinch a 49th Scottish championship their cheers of triumph will be drowned out by the groans of dissatisfaction coming from Celtic's fans: for Rangers to take the title the Parkhead club must lose at home to Dundee this afternoon.
fields.body:
If Rangers today clinch a 49th Scottish championship their cheers of triumph will be drowned out by the groans of dissatisfaction coming from Celtic's fans: for Rangers to take the title the Parkhead club must lose at home to Dundee this afternoon.

The leaders look sure of victory at Tannadice against a Dundee United side who have still to win a league game this year and are in such a state of free-fall that they could end the season relegated.

But if Celtic were to complete an unlikely combination of results by losing, they would be in serious trouble with supporters whose patience has already been tested beyond reasonable limit.

Yesterday was another confusing day for them. The club's chief executive Allan MacDonald was in Seville trying to persuade the Real Betis coach Guus Hiddink to take charge. There was no immediate indication that his remuneration, which might add up to £1m a year including bonuses, was going to effect his quick removal to Scotland.

"My contract is expiring this summer, and there has been contact. I won't deny there has been an approach, and that's it," said Hiddink.

Asked if an offer had been made, the former coach of Holland said: "No, it was just a polite discussion. They wanted to see me, and that's all I can say."

The club's director of football Kenny Dalglish, who has a place on the board, assumed his usual Friday position in the supporters' club talking over the heads of reporters to a bemused looking crowd of early afternoon drinkers propped up against the bar.

"I didn't leak the story to the papers," Dalglish said. But the fact that he was in Glasgow rather than Spain tends to lead to the conclusion that he has already been marginalised.

The prospect of Hiddink going head to head with his fellow Dutchman Dick Advocaat barely brought a response from the Ibrox manager.

"There has been no contact between us," Advocaat said, pondering whether the Scottish weather would be a factor in Hiddink's decision.

Advocaat's side are 16 points ahead and he was able to announce the same squad as that which took part in the midweek win over Hearts. "We do what we have to, we don't concern ourselves with others," he declared.

Aberdeen, who are bottom, play Hearts in the odd situation of knowing they are virtually certain of a European place - by virtue of reaching the Scottish Cup final where Rangers will be their opponents - but could still finish by being relegated to the First Division.

Henrik Larsson has given up any hope of representing Sweden in this summer's European Championship finals in the Netherlands and Belgium.

The Celtic striker has made a remarkable recovery from the broken leg that he sustained against Lyon during a Uefa Cup tie last October and at one stage looked ready to make a dramatic return to league action this season.

However Larsson, 28, who picked up a fresh injury during a reserve match last month, said: "I'll not play in the European Championship and although I'm disappointed at missing the tournament, I was always prepared for this."

It is a bitter blow for the Swedish FA, which had asked Celtic to allow Larsson to return home so that his progress could be monitored prior to the tournament.

But the Parkhead side are keen that Scotland's player of the year in 1999 continues his rehabilitation in Glasgow and denied the Swedish FA's request last week - a decision which was backed by Larsson.

He said: "Celtic didn't want me to go over there and I understand that because I'm under contract to them and they pay my wages. I don't have a problem with that and I have accepted their decision."

webTitle: Cat scents chance of Wembley cream

fields.headline: Cat scents chance of Wembley cream
fields.trailText: The Auto Windscreens Shield is regarded by some as a Mickey Mouse competition, and Bristol City's application to the Football League for their mascot, the City Cat, to collect the trophy should they win could be seen as taking the joke too far.
fields.body:
The Auto Windscreens Shield is regarded by some as a Mickey Mouse competition, and Bristol City's application to the Football League for their mascot, the City Cat, to collect the trophy should they win could be seen as taking the joke too far.

Yet in tomorrow's final, in front of not only the England coach Kevin Keegan but virtually a full house at Wembley, City face Stoke in a match which will be no laughing matter for either supporters or players.

Unlike last year, when only 8,000 Wigan fans walked down Wembley Way to see their team defeat Millwall 1-0, both clubs have sold about 35,000 of their 36,524 ticket allocations.

"Not many of our players have played at Wembley and Stoke have not been in a cup final since 1992, and this is why the whole town has taken an interest in the match," Stoke's football executive John Rudge said. "Our obvious priority for the season is reaching the play-offs but winning on Sunday would put the icing on the cake."

Stoke, who won the Autoglass Trophy on their last trip to the twin towers, are sixth in the Second Division and have turned around their season remarkably since being taken over by an Icelandic consortium.

In memory of Sir Stanley Matthews, who died in February, the hymn Abide With Me - normally associated with the FA Cup final - will be sung before the game.

"The death of Sir Stan was a great blow for the club and the city and winning the trophy on Sunday will be a fitting tribute to him," Rudge said.

Whereas Stoke are chasing success on two fronts, the Shield has saved City's season from petering out, according to their caretaker manager Tony Fawthrop. "The Auto Windscreens Shield is very important to the club and this has been shown by the amount of fans who are going to the game."

Yet should his team win, the City Cat will not be climbing the 39 steps to collect the trophy from Keegan. "We did check out with the league whether City Cat could lift the shield if we won but they refused," Fawthrop said. "However, we did get a verbal agreement that he will be allowed on the pitch at the end, which would be a first for a mascot."

fields.headline: Due north
fields.standfirst: Graham Duffill loads his family into a clanking motor home, leaves the cities behind and heads for the wilds in search of the great Canadian dream
fields.trailText: Graham Duffill loads his family into a clanking motor home, leaves the cities behind and heads for the wilds in search of the great Canadian dream.
fields.body:
In my mind's eye there is a scene: campfire crackling in the gloaming, tents set in the glade of trees, children playing by the stream and nobody for miles around, just bears, which we sense but never see. For two weeks, we drove hundreds of miles across Quebec in search of this scene, setting camp then striking it when the illusion broke.

Quebec is boom time for British tourists: the Canadian dollar is weak against the pound, and it is clean and civilised, an enchanting mixture of France and North America. But what attracted me was the best outdoors in the world - thousands of miles of it.

As a challenge to Canada's ability to absorb people, we flew into Montreal at the start of the busiest fortnight of the year - the mid-July construction workers' holiday. Motor homes need booking months in advance, but a chance cancellation delivered us a gleaming-white van.

Motor homes blow a huge hole in your credit card: C$550 basic for the week, plus road tax, duty, gasoline, insurance, collision-damage waiver, extra mileage, plus state tax - that'll be a total of C$1,400, please. And the driving experience is like Saturday night in a Greek restaurant: cupboards rattle, crockery smashes, curtains swish backwards and forwards around every corner.

Shouting above the clam our of the invisible poltergeist that was ripping our mobile home to pieces behind us, we headed down the 253km of motorway between Montreal and Quebec City. It was a relief to reach Quebec City and attempt to park at the Chateau Frontenac, the smartest hotel in the city, only to discover the van would not fit in its underground car park. The doorman made a superb job of hiding his utter disgust at having a camper van parked alongside the limousines outside.

Before heading into the wild, we visited an Indian settlement to brush up on hunting and survival techniques. The once-mighty Huron warriors now number only 300 and their reservation is a 2km-square plot in a Quebec suburb.

After learning how to make a sauna in a tent with hot rocks, we went hunting in the local Huron supermarket armed with credit cards and struck north, the van rattling much better after loading the fridge with bottles of beer.

We shook and bumped up Highway 175 in our first foray into wild Canadian forest, a few hundred square miles of the Reserve Faunique des Laurentides, which is wild, apart from the huge highway running through it.

After an hour and a half, we emerged on to the flat farming land surrounding Lac St Jean. Holland came to mind, or small-town Amer ica: straight roads, farm houses and fields as far as the eye could see.

We camped by an abandoned mining town, Val Jalbert, on a camp site that was far from abandoned. Although I never heard my neighbours, I did not fly 3,000 miles to sit in bay 26.

Val Jalbert is a monument to the power of the great companies that built Canada. A paper pulping company put a factory at the foot of a waterfall higher than Niagara, and for a time it was the most modern settlement in North America. Then a cheaper way to pulp logs was found and Val Jalbert closed down, its houses left to collapse. Today, Alcan controls Lac St Jean, owns the dams that power the production of aluminium, and it decides how high the level of the lake will be.

Industry, I began to realise, had a serious impact on my dream. To a Canadian lumber company, the beautiful green forests are just a factory. And you don't want tourists crawling around in your factory, especially when you have 50-ton logging trucks roaring down single-track mud tracks.

We journeyed down the River Saguenay, which sinks into a deep fjord before emptying into the St Lawrence. The campsites in the Saguenay National Park were full, so we settled for a site nearby, where many of the residents were clearly permanent, their camper vans mounted on bricks, with little fences and touches of domesticity. It reminded me of weekends at Withernsee, Hull's equivalent of the Riviera.

Frustrated by the difficulties of accessing the forest, we set off across the wind-chopped surface of the Saguenay in sea kayaks and sat like insects lost in its enormity, staring up at cliffs plunging straight down from hundreds of feet. The tanker bearing down on us coincided with a storm appearing from nowhere splashing waves over the bow. As the children shivered in the prow, we paddled with weakening arms through the 3ft waves until the tanker glided by like a runaway skyscraper and we were pushed aside by its wash.

Next day, after our clanking gypsy van surpassed itself with a 70mph race to La Baie Ste Catherine, we were lucky to get the last few places on a whale-watching boat. Between July and November, whales come to feed in the St Lawrence, where the saltwater of the sea meets the freshwater river. A deep underwater shelf forces the plankton to the surface and minke, finback and blue whales gather for a feast.

For 45 minutes, we chugged out like day-trippers to Calais on a small cross-channel ferry until the cries of the oceanographer went up over the PA system announcing the first harbour porpoises of the season. A surreal scene met us through the mist as some 20 boats lined up in a silent semi-circle. Somewhere out there were whales. Then, suddenly, the water broke, plumes of water shot up and huge sleeked backs arced out of the sea.

What followed was like Christmas sales fever at sea. As the oceanographer shouted, "Minke at 1 o'clock", 1,400 people ran to the front of the right side of the boat. "Finbacks at 9 o'clock", and they ran to the left, elbowing each other feverishly out of the way.

Whale-watching boats are not allowed to chase after whales - and it is a question for how much longer these beasts will put up with this public feeding frenzy - but a smart captain can always guess roughly where they will surface.

The most scenic part of our journey followed as we drove down from Baie St Catherine to Baie St Paul. Scots settlers built country homes and golf courses along the river. Whether it was the familiarity of the architecture or just the beauty of the scenery, we all decided that this little corner of Quebec, Charlevoix, is the area to which we would most like to return. Just south of Pointe au Pic is also where we found the best camp ground at Domaine du Gros Ruisseau.

But camp grounds are not nature, and for that we had to re-trace our steps, east of Montreal, to the Laurentides. Here the parks are smaller but better prepared for tourism. Mont Tremblant, a ski resort in winter, has biking, roller-blading, swimming and two fabulous golf courses.

We finally stumbled upon what we had been searching for in the unlikely setting of a hotel between Montreal and Hull. Chateau Montebello is a former private hunting lodge and comes with 200 sq km of land dotted with lakes stocked with pike, bass and trout. The hotel has 13 lodges for hire in this wilderness, called Kenauk, each on their own private lake.

With our fishing permits, battery for outboard motor, rods, bait and picnic, we set out with a map of a large expanse of wilderness down sparsely signposted dirt roads in search of Moose Lake. We found it at the end of a little track half an hour later: a picnic table in the shade of the trees, a pontoon with a 12ft boat on each side and a half-mile-long lake just for us. We swam, fished, sunbathed and walked until dusk enjoying the total silence. As the sun set, I realised I had come as close to my goal as I was going to get on this trip.

Out there, in the hundreds of square kilometres of land that surrounds the tiny bit of Quebec upon which roads have been built, there are tens of thousands of Moose Lakes. Until now, they have been the preserve of the out-rigger, the professional hunters who lease hundreds of kilometres for the shooting rights for moose and caribou. They are accessed only by light aircraft, or several days' drive in 4x4 vehicles with chainsaws to cut a path through trees that have fallen across the dirt tracks.

I have no interest in hunting, but next time I will eschew the rattling motor home for plane and canoe and set off there to find my dream.

The practicals

A 24-25ft motor home, which takes six and sleeps a family of four comfortably, costs £798 a week in July/August, £1335 for 14 days, through Canadian specialists Frontier Travel (020 8776 8709, http://www.frontier-travel.co.uk). This includes 800km of free mileage. For July and August it is advisable to book motor homes well in advance. For typical vehicle specifications, see http://www.canadadream.com or http://www.motorhome.com. For Chateau Montebello and Kenauk, call 020 7389 1126, http://www.fairmont.com or call directly on 001 819 423 5573. Air Canada (0990 247226) has scheduled flights to Montreal in summer for £615 return, children under twelve £412.

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Global Dome | Highland wheels | Music chamber
fields.body:
Global Dome
It's Earth Day next Saturday and an estimated 500 million people around the world are set to celebrate. You could try out the Millennium Dome's event - you'll be welcomed by a gigantic inflatable sperm whale, squid, dolphin and shark. Then there will be environmental performers, some disguised as stilt-walking seagulls, and a kite festival showing children how to make and fly kites made from rubbish. Can't wait? Try the Dome Ticket Line on 0870 606 2000 or the web site on www.dome2000.co.uk and travel agents, rail and coach stations. A family ticket for two adults and up to three children or one adult and four children costs £57.

Highland wheels
The 501-mile Aberdeen to John O'Groats, Orkney and Shetland cycle route opens on Monday. This is the longest section of the National Cycle Network to open so far but by June the network will include 5,000 miles of safe routes for cyclists. Copies of the route map, price £5.99 plus £2 p&p from 0117 929 0888 or visit the online shop at www.sustrans.org.uk

Music chamber
You can virtually conduct the Vienna Philharmonic in the House of Music which opens on June 15. Vienna's new musical centre will let you hear, see, feel and experience music, play interactive games and learn the history of Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert and Strauss, to name but a few. A whole floor of the museum is dedicated to the philharmonic, and other attractions include the prenatal experience" showing how an embryo perceives sound in the womb. Opening at 1, Seilerstatte 30, corner of Annagasse, Vienna. 10 am - 10 pm daily. Visit www. house-of-music-vienna.at

High and wild
There's a rare chance to see Pyrenean birds of prey on an eight-day birdwatching and botanical tour leaving London on either May 20 or 27. The Spanish Pyrenees should be be carpeted with gentians and buttercups and you an expect to see golden orioles, European bee-eaters and lammergeier, griffon and Egyptian vultures. Price, including scheduled flights, full board and expert guiding is £895. Details from Naturetrek on 01962 733951.

Counting the coast
Students from 500 schools and colleges are keeping an eye on how environmental pressures are affecting the coastline of England and Wales. Between June and October, students will survey land-use along the entire coastline, evaluate accessibility and build up a photographic record for Coastline 2000, organised by the Geographical Association, the National Trust and Ordnance Survey. Interim results will be available in October. Further information on www.coastline2000.org

webTitle: All quiet on the eastern front

fields.headline: All quiet on the eastern front
fields.standfirst: The Tatra mountains have wild scenery, ancient villages,and  belle époque  hotels, but few foreign tourists.  Isobel Montgomery loses touch with the 21st century
fields.trailText: The Tatra mountains have wild scenery, ancient villages,and belle époque hotels, but few foreign tourists. Isobel Montgomery loses touch with the 21st century.
fields.body:
It's quiet in the Tatra mountains, not so that you could hear a pine needle drop but quiet enough for a Londoner like me to feel, at first, slightly uneasy, then to grow to like it.

No planes break the stillness of mountains which rise 2,655m from northern Slovakia into Poland, only the occasional car zigzagging its way along the road that links the three High Tatra villages, Lomnica, Stary Smokovec and Strbske Pleso. Even the red-and-cream electric trams climbing slowly through the pines up to these settlements of chalets, sanatoria and ski lifts seem subdued versions of their cousins that rattle through the streets of Bratislava and Prague.

I've taken a purring, swaying cable car up over the forest to the blinding white snow that lies half way up Gerlach, the biggest peak in the High Tatra range. A score or so skiers, mostly Slovaks, speed happily down the smooth, sugar-white slopes. But if you take a few steps away from the café by the cable car, there's nothing - no noise, no buildings to distract from the view of the mountains on either side and the hazy valley below.

Before the 20th century attracted skiers to the High Tatras, 19th-century illnesses like tuberculosis and over-indulgence brought doctors, patients and the Austro- Hungarian aristocracy up here to clear their lungs and take gentle exercise.

By the turn of the last century, dozens of plots had been cleared among the pines for high-eaved chalets and stuccoed neo-classical sanatoria. A daily train puffed its way to the mountains from Bratislava and Budapest. Each of the villages boasted a Grand Hotel, all stained-glass covered verandas and polished wood interiors styled to suit visitors of the belle époque .

Two are still in business, places where après-skiers are served Slovak beer (every bit as good as Czech pilsner) by soft-footed waiters in cavernous rooms; and maids, in expectation of the weekend trickle of visitors, dust old-fashioned stiffly-posed photographs and potted plants.

After the first world war, Franz Kafka came here from Prague in an attempt to cure his TB, and aristocrats were replaced by middle-class politicians and businessmen, but they left little trace of their presence in the architecture. It was not until the 1960s and 1970s that new spaces were carved out of the forest, when the government built concrete rest homes for workers and "Green Schools" to give city children a taste of country life. In Strbske Pleso, the huge A-shaped hotel Panorama rises out of the pines to peer down across the frozen lake.

On a sunny day, the Tatras look gentle and inviting. But they are home to bears and lynx, sudden violent thunderstorms and avalanches that claim a score of lives each year.

Down in the valley, far away from bears and skiers, Propad is a smoky, dusty sprawl of squat tower blocks, railway tracks and decaying medieval suburbs. The guidebooks do not recommend spending much time here, but the battered socialist architecture and empty urban spaces evoke gentle decline not brutal destruction. At nine o'clock in the evening, our footsteps and a lone police car are the only sounds to disturb the darkness.

If Slovakia ever gets on the tourist map, most visitors would bypass Propad and head for Levoca's perfectly-preserved Renaissance square, where they can wander under the pollarded chestnut trees and sun themselves on benches round the bandstand. Now, there are only a few schoolgirls eying up teenage boys who hang around near the Gothic church of St Jacob and old women in black scarves picking their way through the wares in a meagre market. The wealth that built the town walls and made St Jacob's the marvel of Central Europe ran out before the town could be rebuilt to suit new fashions.

Kezmarok, Levoca's historic commercial rival has its own castle, churches and prettily-painted, though less well-kept, main street. At the height of its success, ethnic and religious differences were not allowed to interfere with the business of making money. Germans and Gypsies were welcome. But with commercial decline came intolerance, and when Trinity Church was built in 1717, the Catholic Hungarians had turned against their Protestant German neighbours. No Protestant churches could be built within city walls, no stone could be used in their construction and no foundations laid.

Trinity rises above its limitations with a baroque altar to rival the best 18th-century Catholic opulence. Its wooden pews can seat 1,500, but nowadays it opens only once a week when some of Kezmarok's remaining 800 Germans come to pray.

Vlkolinec (population 23), is a Unesco world heritage site. The cream-washed log cottages could be a haven for visitors seeking to escape the 21st century, but there is no tourist accommodation and none is planned. The choice is simple: you can either become a permanent resident - giving up piped water, indoor toilets and supermarkets - or take a day trip, toiling up the only street to peep at the villagers like animals in a historical zoo.

An old lady smiles toothlessly by the village pump, and two toddlers splash through the stream running down the centre of the street. Up by the church, the talk is not of wolves - from which the village gets its name - but of bears, which come down from the hills each autumn to help themselves to windfalls from the plum trees.

Vlkolinec's oldest resident opens the door to the house in which she was born and has never left. She offers us the traditional welcome of bread and home-made slivovic and shows us around her cottage. Here, the wooden furniture doesn't differ from the relics kept in the village house museum. Her one concession to modern life is the bag of empty beer bottles by her cottage door. In the long winters when Vlkolinec is all but cut off from the rest of the world, perhaps beer and slivovic are the only consolations.

After a moment's lapse into the romantic rural ideal, I decide that permanently step ping out of the 21st century is not for me and head off to Besenova for a Slovak-style soak. I'm lying back in the mud-coloured spa waters that bubble up from limestone rock at 40C and gazing at the snow-covered mountains when the rain begins. At first, it seems little more than a mountain mist then turns into hard, fast drops that fall like cold needles into the steam. Only the noise of rain on water and the soft talk of other bathers breaks the silence.

The practicals

Exodus (020 8675 5550) organises 8 day trips from July to September, visiting Prague, Krakow and the Tatras, from £528pp. The Heart of Central Europe 10 day trip from July to September visits the Tatras, the Aggtelek region of Hungary and the cities of Krakow, Eger and Budapest, from £765pp. Both include flights, transfers, guides and accomodation.

webTitle: Are killer bees as dangerous as the media claims?

fields.headline: No shelter from the swarm
fields.standfirst: America went into shock last month when a woman in Las Vegas was attacked by killer bees. Are they as dangerous as the media claims?  Dea Birkett finds out the hard way
fields.trailText: America went into shock last month when a woman in Las Vegas was attacked by killer bees. Are they as dangerous as the media claims? Dea Birkett finds out the hard way
fields.body:
I heard them before I saw them - an incessant hum, loud enough to make it seem as if our tiny aluminium boat was vibrating. But within a second, they were on us. And not just on us - but in us. In our hair, up our nostrils, trying to crawl inside my ear. We were being attacked by a swarm of killer bees.

Only moments before, we had been peacefully gliding up a tributary of the Rio Nosara in Costa Rica, the near-silent throb of the battery-powered boat drowned out by the calls of birds rising from the mangrove swamp. Eckhard, our guide, had been pointing out a crab-eating buzzard resting on a branch only feet above us. We felt like real explorers - my boyfriend, my six-year-old daughter, and I - yet utterly safe. Only the spot where the alligators sunned, leaving long outlines of their bodies like giants' footprints on the sand, suggested a pleasant soupçon of danger.

We were quite close to the shore, and hardly moving, looking for toads at the water's edge, when I heard the hum. Then the bees descended on us, hundreds of them, smothering our skin until it was all bumpy and black. My boyfriend was the first to be stung. He lashed out instinctively, brushing the bees from his forearm. It was a mistake. "Don't move! Don't move!" screamed Eckhard. A killer bee regards any movement as an act of aggression. The bees retaliated, and my boyfriend was stung again.

Eckhard attempted to steer us away from the swarm. This was truly heroic; he knew that even the gentle sway of his hand on the tiller meant he would be stung. The killers went for his uncovered face as he steered a path through the twisted roots of the mangrove trees. Their stings first broke like little splinters, quickly becoming craters of red. We watched. We were not heroes. If we tried to help him, we would be stung again, too.

Eckhard's hand began to wobble on the tiller. He could barely steer. The stings were beginning to make him feel woozy. We couldn't shake off our attackers; killer bees can pursue intruders up to half a mile. Eckhard's panama hat was a black furry umbrella of bees.

"They're still on me, aren't they," he groaned. "Yes," was all I said, my mouth as tight as a ventriloquist.

Eventually, our feeble boat began to outrun the bees. A few stragglers hung on, determined to punish us for invading their territory. As soon as we were free from the swarm, my boyfriend, bitten but less so than Eckhard, tried to remove the stings around Eckhard's face and neck. My daughter, who had been totally silent even when she was stung, suddenly cried. Her wail echoed along the creek, as animal as any sound from the wild beasts.

Despite their ferocious reputation, killer bees do not often attack. In eight years as a guide in Costa Rica, Eckhard had been attacked only once before. Most victims survive. Estimates of the number of fatalities in South and Central America vary from 20 to more than 1,000. But when the swarms started migrating northwards, they began to make headlines in the world's press.

The bees claimed their first Californian victim on May 20, 1998, a pit bull terrier called Killer. The news led to near panic across the country. Last month a 77-year-old woman in Las Vegas suffered a massive attack.

These bees are monsters of our own making. In 1956, African honeybees - Apis mellifera scutellata - were imported from Tanzania to Brazil, in an attempt to improve the honey production of the imported European bees. African bees were used to hot weather, and produced five times as much honey as the Europeans. A year later, 26 colonies of African bees escaped from a research apiary in Brazil and mated with the Europeans to produce Apis mellifera adansonii. Their progeny began to spread throughout South and Central America.

This new strain was different from its parentage, but not as hoped. The hybrid, soon known as the killer bee, is smaller, more vigorous, swarms more often, and is up to 10 times more likely to sting than the European bee. In technical language, killer bees have an "excessive level of colony defence". It was probably the vibration of our tiny engine that attracted them; they are often provoked by power equipment. In California, there have been two attacks on tree trimmers.

Back on the balcony at Nosara Lodge, my stoic daughter scribbled a sign and stuck it to our bedroom door - "Be Ware of Bees". My boyfriend's arms had ballooned up. Eckhard's eyes were so swollen they were nearly shut, and his ears twice their normal size. He was muttering to himself as if on a powerful drug. I strained to make out he was saying. "It's always the small animals, not the big ones, that get you," he burbled. "Better five sharks than 20 killer bees."
