webTitle: Should the Church of England be disestablished?

fields.headline: Should the Church of England be disestablished?
fields.standfirst: A report commissioned by the Home Office this week discussed the possibility of severing the link between church and state. Can the current arrangement really guarantee any degree of religious pluralism - and is it a desirable state of affairs even for anglicanism? In this week's Saturday Review debate, Professor Tariq Modood and Colin Buchanan, the bishop of Woolwich, debate the issue.
fields.trailText:
Dear Tariq,
Should the Church of England be disestablished, as a report commissioned by the government recommended this week? Clearly, yes. The English became CofE by Henry VIII's decree, to be governed by monarch-in-parliament in their civic and religious lives alike.
fields.body:
Dear Tariq,
Should the Church of England be disestablished, as a report commissioned by the government recommended this week? Clearly, yes. The English became CofE by Henry VIII's decree, to be governed by monarch-in-parliament in their civic and religious lives alike.

Henry put his managers in place of the Pope's; to this day, diocesan bishops are nominated by Her Majesty, and the vacant see is required to "elect" the person whose name has been released weeks before by the prime minister - the person who is already arranging his removal van.

Today, of course, though some folk religion of a vaguely CofE sort survives in many places, citizens are free to follow whatever faith they wish, or none. All other such religious bodies are voluntary associations, and make their own rules. The CofE alone is state-owned and state-controlled. Large numbers of Anglicans - and a sprinkling of our masters in parliament - seem to like it that way.

But this form of captivity of a dependent institution to a sovereign and secular parliament is not partnership but control. It is exercised from a distance, sometimes benevolently, so many Anglicans think they are free, or at least well-off. But that's simply part of the fantasy by which CofE leaders love to live. Away with the fantasy - let's truly be answerable to God, not Mrs T or Mr B.

Yours sincerely,
Colin Buchanan
Bishop of Woolwich

Dear Colin,
I respect your demand for Anglican integrity, but I do find your views insular and backward-looking. Henry VIII was a despot, but does that throw much light on establishment today? The CofE is not entirely autonomous, but it is hardly oppressed. In return, it has the opportunity to speak on and influence public affairs well beyond the pulpit; and a sense of responsibility for the people of this country and not just for its flock in any narrow sense. It can and does speak for the inner city and not just for those who attend its services. It can and does draw attention to discrimination against other faiths such as Muslims and Hindus.

Admittedly, it could speak more loudly on these issues. But establishment, by guaranteeing Anglicans a minimal institutional platform and access to the state, fosters civic responsibility in religion. It allows influence without the church having to be controversial and sensationalist - the only way outsiders are able to catch public attention in a soundbite culture. The issue is how we can "pluralise" Anglican privileges.

You want to liberate Anglicans, I want to institutionalise a multi-faith Britain. It's because you seem indifferent to the latter that I think you are insular and backward-looking. Before I am persuaded of disestablishment, I want to see that the alternative does not weaken the spirit of, and opportunity for, public service among religious communities. Disestablishment in a multi-faith society should be a form of levelling-up, not a levelling-down.

Best wishes,
Professor Tariq Modood
Director, Centre for the Study of Ethnicity and Citizenship
University of Bristol

Dear Tariq,
I confess my eyebrows shot up when I learned that I came across as "insular and backward-looking" - exactly my complaint about the establishmentarians I meet. They are insular in thinking that England's peculiar church-state relations are what God really wants. And they are backward-looking as they seem to think all the English are really CofE. This has gone beyond sentiment and into fantasy.

I accept the many advantages you point out about the CofE today. But I have to say that as a bishop functioning in intensive inner-city conditions, sustaining our mission within needy areas arises not from establishment but from the determination of church leaders to keep a presence going in difficult places, and from the willingness of those in more comfortable spots to contribute financially. It is an exercise in interdependence - not a manifestation of establishment.

Anglicans may be important players in social and charitable exercises, but that, again, springs from their comparatively great resources and their presence across the country. I want the same ends as you - along with a credible but biblical gospel of Jesus Christ - but I'm astonished you should think the establishment we now have will help them.

Yours sincerely,
Colin

Dear Colin,
The church's active taking of responsibility for the national population is born of a confidence and leadership that is an aspect of establishment. It comes from the "fantasy" that you describe.

The CofE, through being part of the overarching state structure, symbolically and substantively, has played its part in nurturing a sense of national community. Perhaps the community it imagined was always too narrow and exclusive; it certainly is today. Some who perceive this conclude that disestablishment is overdue. Yet it is because I see value in an institutional place for religious voices in the public that I hesitate about dismantling the structures that have traditionally given the CofE the confidence to speak and act with a sense of national responsibility.

Coming from an Asian community in which religious identity is inextricably tied up with community identities, and in which the search for collective dignity often takes the form of a public projection of a religious identity, I am concerned about how the minority faiths that are newly becoming part of the fabric of British life can be institutionalised - to have, in some degree, Anglican privileges. Hence my conviction that what is wrong with establishment is not the denial of an autonomous CofE but the exclusion of religious communities that have become shapers of life in Britain.

A knee-jerk disestablishmentarianism that fails to consider how to empower these new communities is in a crucial respect worse than the status quo. It diminishes the presence of religious identities and religious voices in public affairs, thereby making it more difficult for the new religious communities to seek public respect. For non-Christians seeking to legitimise their religions as public identities are not necessarily seeking the delegitimisation of an hitherto national religious identity - rather the widening of "the national" to include themselves. Is disestablishment really offering us this?

Best wishes,
Tariq

Dear Tariq,
An Asian apologia for the historic establishment of the CofE is a rare bird. But I think I must return to my first principles. I seek disestablishment because establishment is wrong in itself. The House of Commons is sovereign, not bound by any religious constraints, yet the prime minister has patronage to appoint episcopal leaders for the CofE, while the Commons decides whether, for instance, the church can ordain women or not.

I take your point that there has been a relationship between state religion and national identity. But any future sense of "civic responsibility" will have to spring from the very nature of our gospel, from the burning sense that our God is a God of justice, from an embattled stance on behalf of the disadvantaged. It will not spring from some constitutionally conveyed governmental charter to criticise and correct the government of the day.

But I can sympathise with your concern for empowering new communities.The Wakeham report sees a case for seating representatives of other faith communities in the Lords, alongside an overprivileged CofE squad. I see national and borough institutions keen to give each faith community a valid and honoured place in society. The CofE is not entitled to some surreptious rigging of the ring to enable it to have a greater impact. If there appears to be shelter for other religions in the established church, let them ask themselves whether that is really a trustworthy or honourable refuge to which to fly.

Yours sincerely,
Colin

Dear Colin,
Your own principled position is a minority one amongst disestablishmentarians. Most resent the power of the church, not, as you do, the power of the state. I think the overlordship of the PM and Commons over the CofE has virtually withered away, and I am not in disagreement with you in wanting to see this evolution reach its logical conclusion.

My argument is with the majority of disestablishmentarians who think that organised religion should have no collective voice in public affairs. Yet I have more in common with them than you do. Like them, I want to judge the issue by what is best for contemporary society, while your concern is the good of the Church. That is what I earlier meant by "insular".

The main point I have been trying to make is that disestablishment is not just a question of the good of the Church. While I appreciate that your position is a thoroughly principled one, I continue to think that it is based on too narrow a set of principles.

Yours,
Tariq

Related story and useful links
Fresh doubts about the future of the established church
Religion in the UK: special report
Church of England

webTitle: Are you working to live or living to work?

fields.headline: Are you working to live or living to work?
fields.standfirst: Come out of denial and take our workaholic test
fields.trailText: Come out of denial and take our workaholic test
fields.body:
Britain is a nation of workaholics. Last year, an Institute of Personnel and Development study found that over one million people are addicted to their jobs - averaging a 60-hour week and voluntarily working extra hours. Couldn't happen to you? Only one way to find out: take time to complete this quiz. And be honest.

1. Do you...
a) Arrive at work so early that you have your own key? That's if you left at all the previous night ...
b) Get in ten minutes early, so you have time to get a coffee and tidy your desk?
c) Arrive five minutes late, sweaty and out of breath, whatever time you set off?
d) Reach your desk just as the clock strikes 9.30am?

2. If your boss asks you to complete an extra task, do you ...
a) Assess your workload and priorities and take it on if you can manage it?
b) Always say yes, no matter how busy you are? It doesn't pay to say no and you might be in for a promotion.
c) Say "yes" but feel resentful and stressed for the rest of the day?
d) Say "no"? Why should you do more work? It's not as if you'll get overtime.

3. Weekends are for ...
a) Seeing your friends, chilling out or trips away with your current squeeze.
b) Hard partying. You rarely go to bed between Friday am and Sunday pm.
c) Catching up on the work you didn't finish during the week. You can check your office emails on your home PC.
d) Sleeping. After a week at work, you're too tired to do anything else.

4. On an average working day, how often do you look at the clock?
a) Every five minutes...it must be the lunch hour/time to leave soon.
b) Every five minutes....if you don't keep track of the time, you'll never get everything done by the end of the day.
c) Every couple of hours ... you don't want to be late for that meeting or miss that deadline.
d) Rarely. A watched pot never boils.

5. You keep your mobile phone ...
a) Switched on at all times, day or night. You never know when someone important might ring.
b) Switched on at all times ... you're expecting notice of a delivery from Ikea/ your dealer and how else will your friends keep in touch?
c) Switched off, except when you're travelling, out of the office or during your lunch hour.
d) Switched off, but you check your voice-mail constantly.

6. On your way into work, you usually read ...
a) The Beano.
b) The latest novel by that talented thirty-something everyone raves about.
c) The report you're working on. You've got to present it to a client tomorrow and you can't afford any mistakes.
d) The financial pages of a broadsheet newspaper. How else will you know how your company's performing?

7. How often are you ill?
a) You always used to be healthy, but lately you've been getting headaches, stomach problems and strange rashes.
b) Never, unless you count that regular Monday morning hangover.
c) Never. You haven't got time to be ill.
d) You get the occasional flu bug, but on the whole you're in pretty good shape.

8. When you go on holiday, you pack..
a) Sun cream, mosquito repellent, condoms and the latest Jackie Collins.
b) Your entire life - can't be too careful -plus a couple of workbooks you've been meaning to read for ages.
c) A jar of Marmite. How can anyone survive on foreign food for two weeks?
d) Er ... you are planning a holiday, but far too busy to book one at the moment.

9. Who has your home phone number?
a) Your family, many friends, boss and a few selected clients.
b) Who knows? Your mates thought it was amusing to stick it up in phone boxes around the city.
c) All your clients, the office receptionist and security guard so that they can contact you in an emergency.
d) Nobody. You value your privacy.

10. If you died, who would genuinely miss you (score one point for each ticked box)?
a) Your parents.
b) Your boyfriend/girlfriend.
c) Your workmates.
d) Your huge circle of school and college friends.
e) Your boss.
f) Loonies at bus stops.

Your mates thought it was amusing to stick it up in phone boxes around the city. c) All your clients, the office receptionist and security guard so that they can contact you in an emergency. d) Nobody. You value your privacy. 10. If you died, who would genuinely miss you (score one point for each ticked box)? a) Your parents. b) Your boyfriend/girlfriend. c) Your workmates. d) Your huge circle of school and college friends. e) Your boss. f) Loonies at bus stops.

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Perspectives on working in Wildlife Trusts, from both ends of the career ladder
fields.body:
Simon Lyster
Aged 47
Director general The Wildlife Trusts

The National Lottery has transformed the work of The Wildlife Trusts, according to Simon Lyster. "We have received £45m over four years and moved from a group of under-resourced volunteers to being able to contemplate bigger projects," he says. "As a result, our profile has risen, membership has increased and our political clout grown."

Stats and facts: The TWT is a partnership of 46 local wildlife trusts around the UK. It manages 2,300 nature reserves, employs over 1,000 people, has 330,000 members and has a £35m turnover.

CV to date includes: Law degree (Cambridge), PhD in international wlidlife law, ran the Falkland Islands Foundation, led a World Widlife Fund team securing a ban on ivory trading.

"My job is to ensure that the full potential of the organisation is realised by getting the 46 trusts to work towards a common vision."

The buzz? "I have the best job in the world. I am in charge of an organisation that has the power to assist wildlife - about which I care passionately."

Must-have qualities: "Today, the environment is a fast-growing business - it looks for all sorts of skills: ecologists as well as fund raisers, those with a knowledge of animals and those who understand people."

Alice Fox
Aged 24
Project officer Yorks Wildlife Trust

Otters have been one of Alice Fox's passions since childhood. "It began with summer family holidays in the west of Scotland and continued through to university days when I knew I wanted to go into conservation work," she says.

After graduating in geography from Newcastle University, Alice spent a year or so volunteering with the Worcestershire Wildlife Trust and a scheme in Lincolnshire. She was appointed otters and rivers projects officer with Yorkshire Wildlife Trust in April 1999.

Current role: Alice is one of two officers covering the county and is responsible for south, east and west Yorkshire.

"The work is a mix of surveying and monitoring the gradual otter recovery - this involves giving avice on habitat management to farmers, landowners and companies. The other half of the job is awareness raising through talks to various interest groups."

Alice is on a three-year contract which involves training courses and reviews conducted by her line manager.

Ambitions? "Possibly, specialist advisory work or large-scale wetland and river restoration projects."

webTitle: Making your career dreams come true

fields.headline: Making your career dreams come true
fields.standfirst: But don't expect agencies to wave a magic wand
fields.trailText: But don't expect agencies to wave a magic wand
fields.body:
Recruitment agencies are an increasingingly popular way of landing that first job. So, if you're set to graduate this summer it's worth doing your homework on four or five relevant agencies before signing up.

But let's get one thing clear from the start: don't rely exclusively on agencies as they're unlikely to magically offer you the job of your dreams. What they're most likely to offer is a job that will equip you with the skills and experience necessary to achieve your medium to long-term career goals (assuming that you have some).

Careers advisers suggest that you use recruitment consultants as part of your overall job seeking strategy at the same time as you are sending out speculative letters, networking, searching the web and looking at job ads in relevant publications.

Agencies should provide their service for free, so don't sign up with an agency that asks for money warns Carl Gilleard, chief executive of the Association of Graduate Recruiters.

And watch out too for those agencies that may try to charge you indirectly through the skills training and CV service they provide. Most agencies make their money by charging employers a one-off fee of around 15 to 20% of a new recruit's annual salary. But if the employee leaves within a few months the agency could forfeit this fee.

In the agency business, firms can go out of business quite quickly if they consistently fail to match a candidate to the right job. So when looking for an agency make sure it is established with a good track record.

While most agencies adhere to scrupulous and ethical practices, you could easily fall prey to a few sharks. Follow this guide and your hunt for a good recruitment consultancy should go relatively smoothly.

1. A good start in your search to find an agency in your field and at your level is to contact the Jobseekers line of the Recruitment Employment Confederation (REC) - the representative body of the industry. It can supply you with a list of agencies which specialise in your chosen sector.

2. Select the agencies with the most jobs in your field. You can find this out by asking searching questions. How many vacancies have you handled in this sector? And how many people did you find jobs for this month? Another question worth asking is how many recruits left their post after a few months. This could indicate how good the agency is at matching graduates to the right jobs.

3. Consider how the agency treats you. If you're doing all the ringing and, after months, you haven't even had one job interview, the chances are you're wasting time - time which could be better spent concentrating on other agencies and focusing on alternative job seeking methods.

4. "You want an agency that is on the ball," says Carl Gilleard, chief executive of the Association of Graduate Recruiters. "If they inform you of a vacancy and you ring up and the employer says it was filled a week ago, you'll know not to go back."

5. Nothing works better than recommendation, he adds. "If someone has had a good deal from an agency, then use them too."

6. A good consultant should provide you with relevant information about the job and firm before sending you for an interview . "If they don't, it's time to try a different agency," says Gary Woodward, a careers adviser at the University of London.

7. Just as you want the best agency, consultants want to put the best candidate forward for their clients. So treat your first and subsequent meetings with the agency as though you were going for an interview with an employer. Dress smartly, rehearse questions they may ask and come armed with your own queries.

And finally, don't be too proud to temp. Temping in a field you like could open doors and if you show enthusiasm and aptitude you could well land the job of your dreams.

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: No 31. Kodak
fields.trailText: No 31. Kodak
fields.body:
If you rewind the history of Kodak you'll find a young George Eastman arriving in London in 1879. Then, London was the centre of the photographic world and Eastman came looking for a patent on his plate-coating machine. After three years of photographic experiments, he had discovered a formula that worked.

And so in 1883 Eastman startled the trade with his announcement of film in rolls. Not only that, but his roll holder was adaptable to nearly every plate camera on the market. By 1888, Kodak's own camera had been introduced, making photography accessible to the masses.

The camera was launched with the slogan, "You push the button - we do the rest" and it came pre-loaded with enough film for 100 exposures that could be easily carried and handheld during operation. After exposure, the whole camera was returned to the manufacturer where the film was developed, prints were made and new film was inserted .

Today, it is still the world leader in imaging, and Kodak film has been used to shoot and print blockbuster movies such as Titanic , Armageddon and Saving Private Ryan. Kodak says it has built its sucess on a belief that a diverse group of highly skilled people - in an organisational culture that enables them to apply their collective talents to shared objectives - delivers the greatest value to customers and shareholders alike.

The company says it is always looking for talented young professionals, especially those in the fields of software engineering, information technology, electrical engineering, computer engineering and other technical fields.

The Kodak Manufacturing Training Scheme, known to its friends as the Seedcorn Programme, is targeted at graduates with a chemistry, physics or engineering degree. The scheme provides a comprehensive understanding of the company's manufacturing operation through a series of assignments over a two-year period.

Each assignment may be spent in any of the many departments at Kodak's four UK sites. Emphasis is placed on manufacturing areas, although one assignment in a commercial role or business unit is encouraged.

For the length of the programme, each seedcorn graduate is assigned a mentor - usually a member of senior management who has volunteered to be the main point of contact throughout the period.

Every employee receives a minimum of 40 hours training per year which, says the company, gives them the opportunity to develop their full potential.

Details of Kodak's 2001 Seedcorn Programme and current vacancies are available from the Personnel Dept, Ref S687/DPS, Kodak Limited, Headstone Drive, Harrow, Middlesex HA1 4TY.

webTitle: How to build the brand 'Me plc'

fields.headline: How to build the brand 'Me plc'
fields.standfirst: Start treating your boss as your client
fields.trailText: Start treating your boss as your client
fields.body:
Pete Duggal is 26-years old and after university he took a position as a multi-media programmer. Then he struck out on his own. He enrolled on a Masters course in music information technology and is now setting up Native Logic, his own company offering a catalogue of music over the internet.

"I got sick of the 9-5 routine and lack of flexibility," he says. "At the end of the day I couldn't dance to anybody else's tune so I set out to promote myself."

Pete's story is not unique. The new flexible world of work, the death of the job for life and the rise of portfolio careers means that people increasingly need to treat their career as their own individual cottage industry.

And that means creating Me plc.

Me plc isn't just rhetoric for superheroes who save the world on their days off. It's about being proactive and being able to seize opportunities as they arise. In other words identifying what your potential client (employer) needs, and how you can best provide that.

Author Neasa MacErlean says: "The onus is now on the individual to make him or herself employable."

Being employable rather than merely employed may seem obvious but it's suprising how many people fall into a job, progress in that industry but find themselves stuck on the wrong career path by the time they hit 30.

Peter Hawkins of Liverpool University's Graduate into Employment Unit says: "You spend most of your life at work yet most people devote more time to planning their annual holiday than to a whole lifetime of work."

Any successful business has to start with a focused plan. The first port of call is thinking about where you are now and how you want your business to grow. Or in laymen's terms, what you want out of your career both short and long term.

Think about the experience and skills that you already have and how you got them. This helps you to assess how marketable you are.

It's your awareness of your full portfolio of skills, experience, knowledge and attributes that will help you stand out. After all, if you aren't self-aware, then you're not going to be able to put your strengths across and persuade anyone to buy your services.

Next, consider where you would like to go in life both long term and short term. This part is all about what motivates you and you need to take a holistic view. It's no good wanting to be an investment banker if you dread early starts and long hours.

Pete, for example, had clear reasons for wanting to work for himself. "When you are working for someone else then effectively you use your skills for the gain of the company," he says. "I wanted to use my skills for my own long-term benefit and satisfaction."

Now think about what your ideal job would be, how the experience and skills you already have could be transferred and what skills or experience you need to land the job. There is a plethora of information from books, careers advisors and websites to help you if you're not too sure what would constitute your own dream job.

Accept that you will probably need to take a stepping stone approach by enrolling on an evening course, volunteering either at work or in your own time and most commonly, taking a 'next' job that will allow you to grow.

It's important to set yourself short terms goals so that you do expand your portfolio of skills on a regular basis. Achieving objectives that you have set for yourself will also do wonders for confidence: an attractive quality for any employer.

Effective communication is probably the single most important thing that you should think about. From job interview to a meeting with a mentor or advisor, people are constantly forming an opinion of you, so you need to make the right impression.

Remember at all times that your employer is the client - would you buy into you?

Communication skills will also help you to make full use of existing contacts as well as to make new ones. Making and sustaining a network is likely to be very profitable once you do start putting feelers out.

It is said that you are only five people away from anyone you want to meet and the old "it's not what you know it's who you know" is truer now then ever.

Pete agrees you need to make yourself stand out: "I met a lot of my contacts while out clubbing, so they all know that I am on the level, that I'm passionate about music and not just trying to flog them something."

If you don't remember anything else...

Ultimately, Me plc is little more than common sense, clear thinking and application. No one is expecting you to be superhuman and grab that chance opportunity for a strategic chat with the big cheese when you've had one too many the night before. It's more about learning to recognise opportunities when you see them, knowing your own strengths and working on your weaknesses.

Skills employers want

Self-reliance - self-awareness, confidence, self-promotion, initiative, networking, willingness to learn, action planning.

People skills - teamworking, leadership, interpersonal, customer orientation, oral communication, foreign language.

General skills - problem solving, IT/ computer literacy, flexibility, numeracy, business accumen, commitment.

Specialist skills - company or sector specific, technical.

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: Testing time | Commuting makes you fat | Wounded pride
fields.body:
 Testing time: Roll up, roll up... get yer free psychometric tests here. Test publisher SHL is offering free online psychs to graduates at www.shldirect.com where they can familiarise themselves with the types of questionnaires currently being used by employers. Personality tests, verbal reasoning and numeracy tests are just some of the delights in store.

 Tip of the Week: Jung owed much of his success to his mentor Freud. But as Jung discovered, it's equally important to know how to split gracefully once the relationship has run its course. Psychologist Linda Phillips-Jones recommends agreeing a time limit at the outset. "One year is a good time frame because neither party gets burned out," she advises.

 Commuting makes you fat: No proof yet, but New York tube trains are having to expand to meet the needs of bulging bottoms. Officials have bowed to demand and ordered new trains without the bucket-style seats which, at 17.5in across, are not broad enough for Big Apple behinds.

 Wounded pride: If your university careers advisers looked a little sorry for themselves this week, this might be the reason why. A survey of employers by the Association of Graduate Recruiters has criticised university careers offices as old-fashioned, bureaucratic and staffed by often ill-informed and sometimes arrogant advisers. Still want their advice?

 Career change of the week: Hats or helmets off to Roman Karpoukhine who has jacked in his job as a MiG-23 fighter pilot to fight bulls instead. When he strides into the Barcelona bullring tomorrow, he'll be the first Russian to become a matador. Pity he chose such a bloodthirsty occupation, but then where else was he going to use his transferable skills in killing?

 You dopes: Time Out magazine has released some staggering survey results which suggest that one in three people has taken drugs during work time. You might find it disturbing that a third of your colleagues are shooting up or enjoying a spliff in the loos if you didn't know that the magazine's exhaustive research involved a poll of... er.. 500 Time Out readers.

webTitle: Help: I don't like being on my own!

fields.headline: Help: I don't like being on my own!
fields.trailText: The holy grail of working from home can occasionally become a poisoned chalice
fields.body:
I persuaded my employer to let me work from home. Now, nine months later, I realise it was a big mistake. I'm isolated and missing out on interesting work and promotion.
Shelly K, press officer, Brighton

When you're not physically there it's easy to become forgotten because others are too busy to see beyond the immediate. Seeing someone acts as a reminder to pass on an idea or ask an opinion. Emails are no substitute for eye contact. Being invisible makes you easy to overlook; feeling marginalised, you may stop contributing ideas and become a passive recipient of work, eventually excluding yourself from the loop of those who make things happen. Don't take it personally, but work on ways of keeping yourself in vision. Disembodied communication needs to be supplemented with phone conversations and meetings. Spend the odd day in the office, participate in training events or go out with people from work. Make sure you're contributing to developments rather than acting as a work processing unit. Some of the difficulties you foresee about reversing or adjusting your present situation may be magnified by isolation. Go talk it over with your boss. Start by listening to his thoughts on this arrangement. He may have misgivings, in which case coming back to regular working habits could be passed off as a concession on your part. If he's happy with the situation he'll be keen to work with you at making it succeed. Remind yourself why you chose this option. Relive your most annoying day at work. Is what you've got now worse than that?

Email Irene Krechowiecka

Spend the odd day in the office, participate in training events or go out with people from work. Make sure you're contributing to developments rather than acting as a work processing unit. Some of the difficulties you foresee about reversing or adjusting your present situation may be magnified by isolation. Go talk it over with your boss. Start by listening to his thoughts on this arrangement. He may have misgivings, in which case coming back to regular working habits could be passed off as a concession on your part. If he's happy with the situation he'll be keen to work with you at making it succeed. Remind yourself why you chose this option. Relive your most annoying day at work. Is what you've got now worse than that? Email Irene Krechowiecka

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to managing your reputation at work

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to managing your reputation at work
fields.trailText: Your reputation can be your most marketable asset, so make sure you look after it
fields.body:
A. What do you expect?
Everybody has a reputation, although we're often blissfully unaware of how others' perceptions are at odds with our self-image. Characteristics which are good to be associated with include being calm, efficient, approachable, inspired, innovative, supportive, and knowledgeable. Ones to avoid are laid back, perfectionist, workaholic, bully, defeated, overworked and aggressive.

B. Actions speak...
Many behaviours could be described by a word from either list depending on how you're perceived. Once established, a reputation takes on a life of its own with actions interpreted according to what's believed about you. If you're universally recognised as hard working, reliable and kind, others will be reluctant to abandon that perception and generous about the odd out-of-character slippage. Those regarded as untrustworthy rarely get the chance to prove otherwise. Even their worthwhile endeavours can be misinterpreted or pass unnoticed.

C. ...louder than words
Nurture your reputation so it grows strong and enhances your employability. In times of uncertainty and change it will be your most marketable asset. Ensuring positive attributes are widely recognised without being boring or brash is not easy. Develop strategies that bring your laudable deeds to the attention of many. The trick is to get others talking about how good you are rather than having to say it yourself.

fields.headline: Medicine woman
fields.trailText: Frances Lutterodt, staff pharmacist working at Ealing Hospital
fields.body:
Name: Frances Lutterodt

Status: Staff pharmacist working at Ealing Hospital

Past: Graduated from Portsmouth University with degree in pharmacy; studied for a masters in clinical pharmacy at the University of Manchester; worked as junior pharmacist at a Manchester hospital before landing her current position.

Present: Deals mainly with HIV and Aids outpatients, advising them on drug therapy and dispensing their medicines. Provides pharmaceutical info to nurses and doctors.

Future: "I would like to make an impact in the area of HIV and Aids. Specifically, I would like to be involved in improving access to drugs and healthcare for HIV and Aids sufferers in less developed countries."

Strengths: "Once I have a vision, I pursue it with a passion."

Weaknesses: "I often underestimate my capabilities and there is always a danger of this affecting my performance."

Wisdom: "Develop a strong work ethic, build a good contact base with people in your chosen field and always have a clear vision of what you want to achieve."

References: flutterodt@ealhosppharmacy.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Go fly a kite
fields.standfirst: It's relaxing, healthy and you don't have to do an awful lot except spend a day on the beach and watch your craft play in the wind.  Matthew Brace joins the flying squad in Washington State
fields.trailText: It's relaxing, healthy and you don't have to do an awful lot except spend a day on the beach and watch your craft play in the wind. Matthew Brace joins the flying squad in Washington State.
fields.body:
The coastline of Washington State, in the far Northwest of America, can be a melancholy place. The beaches stretch for miles and the sea mists roll in from the Pacific, shrouding everything in a milky light. When the ocean wind blows on-shore, inch-high sand storms whip across bare ankles. But such conditions are perfect for one hardy breed of beach bum.

In a fresh wind on Long Beach, north of the mouth of the Columbia River, you will find an array of brightly-coloured kites fluttering in the sky. Box kites, delta wings, tandem kites... take your pick. Chances are that at the other end of the strings will be an elderly man or woman, watching their devices loop-the-loop and nose-dive to within inches of the beach before soaring high again. It has become a popular pastime for pensioners who retire here to buy a kite and spend long days watching the wind play with it, 100 or so feet above the ground.

Small, quiet towns, such as Long Beach and neighbouring Seaview, are ideal to while away the "silver years" as the politically-correct American marketeers like to describe old age. The pace of life is slow, the air invigorating, the food healthy, and the crime rate virtually non-existent.

Jim Buesing is a 65-year-old retired benefits administrator. He also ran a kite shop for 13 years and helped set up the Kite Museum in Long Beach. In it hang some fantastic creations - many of them exotic and colourful constructions from Indonesia and China. They are far too precious to risk in a Pacific wind, so the most flying they do is from wall to wall whenever the exhibit is rearranged.

The morning I met him on the beach, Jim was struggling to get a small kite launched from the back of his pick-up truck. "This is a miniature parafoil - a bit like a parachute - and I've never flown this one before," he said, deftly uncoiling his body from the string.

He walked 10 paces away from the truck towards the boardwalk and, watched by attentive seagulls, launched the kite. The first row of the audience scattered with a squawk, thinking it was a huge eagle come to steal their young. The kite rose noisily, the wind battering the squares of material, until it settled in a current of more gentle air about 90ft off the ground.

"Now you just wait and watch," he said. "That's the beauty of kite-flying: you don't do a whole lot. It's very relaxing, non-polluting and healthy.

"It's a real cleansing of the mind," he continued. "At least it is at this time of year. You should see this place in mid-August."

The annual international kite festival runs from August 20-26, when competitors from the UK, Germany, Japan and Australia turn up to take each other on in aerial dog-fights. Flyers score points by bashing into rival kites and downing them by wrapping their string around their victim's. "It can get rowdy, too. There are barbecues on the beach and quite a lot of celebrating," said Jim.

This year there will be the usual parade of fun kites - 80ft-high frogs and octopi have appeared in the past. Competitors will try to beat the Western hemisphere record for the most kites in the sky at one time and the end of the festival is marked by an illuminated aerial display.

If, like me, you graduated from the Charlie Brown school of kite-flying and your tethered charge is drawn to trees, telegraph poles and chimneypots, then it pays to keep out of the way of the professionals during the festival. But with a beach said to be the longest in the world at 28 miles, there is plenty of room to practise on your own.

Kite-flying may not involve much physical exertion, but a mixture of fresh air and concentration is enough to build an appetite. Food is the other thing this coastline is famous for. North of the Long Beach peninsula lies Willapa Bay, which produces wonderful oysters. But don't stop at the starters. At the 19th-century Shelburne Inn, on the Pacific Highway in Seaview, the salmon is full of flavour.

Views from most of the hotels along the coast are good, but among the best are those from the Boreas Guesthouse in Long Beach. Eagle perches have been erected at the back of the house in the dunes, so guests can watch the giant birds.

You get a great sense of space up here in America's Pacific Northwest, and such freedom makes the Washington State coastline ideal for holiday-makers seeking peace and relaxation. There is little to do other than to admire the ravishing scenery and wildlife, dine on the most wonderful seafood and, er, fly kites.

fields.headline: £60,000 contract on farmer who killed
fields.trailText: A £60,000 contract has been offered to kill Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer on trial for the shooting of two burglars, a jury was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A £60,000 contract has been offered to kill Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer on trial for the shooting of two burglars, a jury was told yesterday.

The source of the threat was unknown but it was being taken seriously by police, Norwich crown court heard.

Martin, 55, of Bleak House, near Emneth, Norfolk, wept in court as he began his evidence yesterday, the fifth day of his trial. He said he had felt "blind, terrified, vulnerable" when he heard people entering his home.

He admits having fired a gun but denies murdering Fred Barras, 16, and denies attempting to murder Brendan Fearon, 30, both of Newark in Nottinghamshire. He denies wounding Fearon with intent to commit grievous bodily harm, and denies possessing a Winchester 12-bore pump action shotgun with intent to endanger life. He admits possessing a shotgun without a certificate.

He told yesterday how he had been asleep in bed, fully clothed, when he heard noises downstairs in his farmhouse. "I just heard a horrendous noise. I thought I was in a horror movie. There was a banging noise. It sounded like somebody coming up the stairs.

"I tried to avoid the situation ... and then I had to get down to reality. I had been broken into. I laid there for a while. I did not really want to move. I don't actually think I could move, though I realised I had to move. So I got up.

"I decided to go to the landing. I saw a bright light coming up the stairs. I became fearful."

He went back to his bedroom where he kept a gun, the jury heard. "I loaded it and stood there with it. I was still hearing this terrific banging. There was a noise downstairs, so I went on to the landing."

A light was shone in his face. "I think it was a torch. I had the impression I was on the stairs. The light came from the doorway downstairs. It went straight in my face. I was very frightened. Lots of things go through your mind. Blind, terrified, vulnerable."

Martin told the court that he then fired the gun, but he did not know how many times. He aimed below the light and thought he was firing at the bottom of the doorway.

Anthony Scrivener QC, Martin's barrister, told the jury that the issue in the trial was self-defence. Martin knew that an unknown number of people had broken into his dark, isolated house. He did not know if they were armed or under the influence of drugs.

They had not been put off by Martin's three rottweilers, said Mr Scrivener, and were not bothered about him being in the house.

"What would you do?" he asked the jury. "Say 'hold on chaps, can we discuss this rationally?'" Mr Scrivener said that in law any citizen had the right to kill in self-defence if he believed he was being attacked.

The judge, Mr Justice Owen, said the jury must weigh up whether Martin believed it was necessary to use force, and whether the force he used was reasonable.

Yesterday the judge issued an order preventing identification of the defence's witnesses.

Det Sgt Peter Newton, questioned by Mr Scrivener, said that only three or four officers on the case, and Martin's solicitor, knew the address where Martin, who is on bail, was staying. He confirmed the contract threat had been made. Asked if police had advised Martin never to go back to his farmhouse, Mr Newton said that was for him to decide - but police had made it clear to him they could not protect him for the rest of his life.

The trial was adjourned until Monday.

Meanwhile, police released pictures of inside Martin's almost-derelict house, taken shortly after the shootings. The jurors have been taken to view the house. The prosecution has alleged that the staircase was "booby-trapped" by Martin, with steps at top and bottom removed. In another picture, the window frame wrenched out by Fearon can be seen lying on the floor.

fields.headline: Book of Kells is damaged
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ireland's priceless Book of Kells has been damaged while being taken to Australia, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Ireland's priceless Book of Kells has been damaged while being taken to Australia, it emerged yesterday.

A volume of the 9th century manuscript is the centrepiece of an exhibition in the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra.

The damage - described as "very minor" by Bill Simpson, head librarian at Trinity college, Dublin, where the book is normally kept - was discovered when the volume arrived in Australia.

It is thought that the pigmentation on a part of the calfskin manuscript has been affected, and that it could have been due to vibration on the flight.

The extent of the damage and the cause are unlikely to be established until it is examined in Dublin next month.

The incident coincides with a campaign for part of the book to be put on display in Kells in County Meath.

Parliamentary representatives from Meath, including the former prime minister John Bruton, head of the Fine Gael opposition party, met Trinity college officials to discuss a possible move.

fields.headline: Rushdie returns
fields.standfirst:
Writer pays first visit to India since fatwa
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Salman Rushdie last night made his first public appearance in the Indian subcontinent since an ageing Iranian cleric imposed a death sentence on him 12 years ago and declared: "It's fantastic to be back. It's been far, far too long."
fields.body:
Salman Rushdie last night made his first public appearance in the Indian subcontinent since an ageing Iranian cleric imposed a death sentence on him 12 years ago and declared: "It's fantastic to be back. It's been far, far too long."

After days of speculation and several unconfirmed sightings of the novelist, a besuited Rushdie turned up at a hotel in Delhi for the ceremony for the annual Commonwealth writers' prize for which his latest novel, The Ground Beneath Her Feet, was shortlisted. "I'm very flattered people are still interested in me," he said.

The author slipped into India eight days ago with his 20-year-old son, Zafar. They had spent the last two days at the ancestral bungalow in Solan, near the town of Shimla, once owned by Rushdie's grandfather. The visit provoked a small demonstration yesterday outside the parliament building in Delhi.

Rushdie, whose book The Satanic Verses caused the fatwa to be imposed, said: "My message to Indian Muslims is I have never been your enemy and if they read my book they would see that."

The prize went to JM Coetzee for Disgrace. Also on the shortlist were Shauna Singh Baldwin, for What the Body Remembers, and Lily Brett for Too Many Men.

"I'm very flattered people are still interested in me," he said. The author slipped into India eight days ago with his 20-year-old son, Zafar. They had spent the last two days at the ancestral bungalow in Solan, near the town of Shimla, once owned by Rushdie's grandfather. The visit provoked a small demonstration yesterday outside the parliament building in Delhi. Rushdie, whose book The Satanic Verses caused the fatwa to be imposed, said: "My message to Indian Muslims is I have never been your enemy and if they read my book they would see that." The prize went to JM Coetzee for Disgrace. Also on the shortlist were Shauna Singh Baldwin, for What the Body Remembers, and Lily Brett for Too Many Men. Salman Rushdie

fields.headline: Libel threats blight websites
fields.standfirst: Change in law sought as legal action cows internet service providers
fields.trailText: If the internet was once seen as a window through which the bright light of free speech would shine, it has now become clear that a dark legal curtain is descending.
fields.body:
If the internet was once seen as a window through which the bright light of free speech would shine, it has now become clear that a dark legal curtain is descending.

Since a leading British website hosting service backed out of a libel action, paying the litigant's costs and damages, there has been a flurry of legal threats and website closures. A radical gay magazine's website, an anti-censorship site and a site that highlighted alleged miscarriages of justice have all fallen victim.

There are real fears that, given the effectiveness of a simple threat of court action, anyone with access to a decent lawyer can censor anything they find uncomfortable - whatever the truth of the claim. The application to the web of Britain's much-criticised libel laws has raised uncomfortable questions which the government is being called upon to answer.

Outcast, the "queer current affairs magazine" whose website was taken down after a libel suit threat from the more mainstream gay Pink Paper, is leading the call. David Price, a lawyer who acted for Scallywag magazine in its fight against legal action brought by the former prime minster John Major, is taking the Outcast case to the European court of human rights in an attempt to bring clarity to internet regulation.

Mr Price believes that the "chill factor" of Britain's libel laws must be challenged. It was not acceptable that a litigant could force the closure of a website by threatening legal action. There ought to be an onus to prove that statements complained about were false, or were maliciously posted.

"An internet service provider should only be liable if it knows that what it is publishing is defamatory and false, or is recklessly indifferent," he said.

A number of ISPs, including Netbenefit, which was host to Outcast's website, believe that the internet in Britain should be granted "common carrier immunity". The principle, adopted in the US, is that ISPs are treated like telecommunications companies. For example, if someone makes a slanderous statement on the telephone, the slander victim cannot sue the phone network.

The Internet Services Providers' Association is drawing up guidelines for its members. While it does not appear to go as far as advocating the common carrier principle, it is calling on the government for an urgent review of the law.

"ISPs are caught between a rock and a hard place," said the association's secretary general, Nicholas Lansman. If they stuck to their guns and failed to remove a defamatory allegation - even if they believed it to be true, an absolute defence in libel law - they faced a costly legal action. If they closed a website they could be sued by its owner for breach of contract or loss of business. "What we need is a clear picture of where ISPs stand."

In the same way that telephone companies did not monitor all phone calls carried on their networks, ISPs could not be expected to police the postings on websites they hosted, Mr Lansman argued. "A small ISP might have 200 websites. If each website has 20 or 30 pages, you are talking about 6,000 pages to trawl through."

As the threat of legal action is raised, websites are taking their business elsewhere. Outcast has switched to a host in the US.

The government must not allow business to drain out of Britain because of unnecessary legal constraints that could easily be altered, Mr Lansman said.

Chris Morris, editor of Outcast, denied that his magazine's European legal action could lead to a flood of scandalous allegations being made on the web with impunity. "There always needs to be a balance between rights and responsibilities," he said. "Journalists and editors must be held accountable. But as things stand ISPs as commercial organisations are censoring anything mildly controversial, just because they think they might get sued."

He accused ministers of failing to grasp the nettle. "This is such a hot potato, and nobody is taking it seriously."

webTitle: Scientists devise glue for light cars

fields.headline: Scientists devise glue for light cars
fields.trailText: Scientists are poised to revolutionise vehicle manufacturing with a technique which will enable new cars to be stuck together with glue.
fields.body:
Scientists are poised to revolutionise vehicle manufacturing with a technique which will enable new cars to be stuck together with glue.

A team at Edinburgh University believes its research will provide the key to a new generation of environmentally friendly, lightweight aluminium cars with low fuel consumption.

The team has found a cheap way of joining metal components using powerful glues instead of welding, which will allow manufacturers to use lightweight metals for the first time in vehicle construction and slash costs.

The new technique will be outlined at the Edinburgh Science Festival today.

Colin Pulham, of the university's chemistry department, said the team had developed a new promoter which would enable the strongest glues to be used in car-making.

At present, only expensive and environmentally harmful substances can be used to roughen metal surfaces before they are glued. Dr Pulham expected the technique to be available in about two years.

webTitle: Rivals flock to the courts in showdown over Elian

fields.headline: Rivals flock to the courts in showdown over Elian
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The showdown over the fate of Elian Gonzalez yesterday spawned a clutch of court cases as lawyers for the US government and the Cuban boy's Miami relatives embarked on intricate and conflicting manoeuvres to determine the future of the celebrated six-year-old.
fields.body:
The showdown over the fate of Elian Gonzalez yesterday spawned a clutch of court cases as lawyers for the US government and the Cuban boy's Miami relatives embarked on intricate and conflicting manoeuvres to determine the future of the celebrated six-year-old.

The justice department applied for a federal order to reinforce its ruling that Elian should be returned to his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who flew from Cuba more than a week ago to collect his child.

The move reflected the reluctance of the US attorney general, Janet Reno, to send federal officials into the Miami home where Elian has been staying since he was shipwrecked in November to take the boy from his great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez.

Immigration officials were yesterday reported to be rehearsing a raid on the house, using mainly female officers wearing civilian clothes instead of uniforms to minimise damaging publicity.

But Lazaro Gonzalez's house in Miami's Little Havana remained ringed by an encampment of defiant Cuban exiles braving heavy rain to maintain their routine of prayers and anti-communist chants.

Insisting that Elian's repatriation to Communist Cuba would constitute a violation of his human rights, they have vowed to present a human barrier to any government attempt to remove him, and to ensure that any attempt to enforce Ms Reno's orders would create an ugly scene.

Justice department officials said yesterday they hoped a raid would not be necessary. They warned that if Lazaro Gonzalez defied the federal court order the department was seeking, he would be in contempt and face a jail term.

Lazaro Gonzalez has said repeatedly he would not offer resistance to any government attempt to move Elian, but nor would he deliver the boy to the authorities. He has maintained that the boy's father, Juan Miguel, is being coerced by Fidel Castro's government and does not really want to return to Cuba - a claim Juan Miguel has rejected.

Lawyers for Lazaro won an injunction on Thursday preventing Elian's return to Cuba. The government countered yesterday by offering to prevent Mr Gonzalez from leaving with his son until an appeal by the Miami relatives against the repatriation could be heard next month. But that offer was conditional on Elian being returned to his father.

The Cuban American National Foundation, an exile group which has funded the Miami relatives' legal costs, embarked on yet another court case in Washington yesterday, seeking to prevent the US government from sending Elian back to Cuba unless it could guarantee his rights would not be infringed by the government in Havana.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez has begun to show signs of strain. He was said to be furious at the broadcast on Thursday of a video made by Elian's Miami relatives in which the boy repeatedly insisted he did not want to go back to Cuba.

Most psychologists agreed his performance appeared to have been heavily coached, and the Los Angeles Times compared it to "the unsettling spectacle of a POW mouthing the words of his captors".

Defending the video yesterday, a Cuban American National Foundation spokesman said: "I can understand the frustration of the Miami family, who have been saying for months that the little boy has not been heard."

fields.headline: The IMF on trial
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia will be the spectre at the meetingEthiopia: special report
fields.trailText: This week Gordon Brown staunchly defended the IMF, claiming it had undergone a radical change of heart demonstrated by its new poverty-reduction strategy. His words rang hollow when a fund official disparaged the initiative as having more to do with public relations.
fields.body:
The spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Washington rarely get coverage beyond the finance pages, but this weekend that will change with the arrival of the heterogeneous coalition of protesters which caused chaos in Seattle last November. The IMF and the World Bank officials are having to defend themselves against accusations of supervising and implementing a process of globalisation driven by the US Treasury and western multinationals. This week Gordon Brown staunchly defended the IMF, claiming it had undergone a radical change of heart demonstrated by its new poverty-reduction strategy. His words rang hollow when a fund official disparaged the initiative as having more to do with public relations.

The spectre haunting these debates will be that of the terrible plight of Ethiopia where 8m people are in danger of starvation. No one can suggest that the blame for the Horn of Africa's food insecurity can be laid entirely at the door of the IMF and the World Bank. Of course the Ethiopian government bears a heavy responsibility for a border war with Eritrea which is costing reportedly £600,000 a day, diverting much needed resources, manpower and government attention from averting the imminent famine. Much long-term aid and debt relief, as Clare Short rightly insisted this week, is being held back as a carrot to entice the countries into a settlement. But by blaming the war for the crisis, other questions are obscured, such as those arising from the role of the international institutions and donors since the last famine in 1984 in assisting Ethiopia's efforts to break out of a punishing cycle of crisis.

The problem has been that as soon as Ethiopia slips off our television screens, the aid tails off. But what the country most needs is a large concerted international effort to achieve the national food security strategy drawn up by the World Bank and the Ethiopian government in recent years - and it is not cheap, nearly $1bn for the first stage. Ethiopia has done a lot to tackle food security, setting up early warning systems, distribution granaries as well as recognising the importance of spending on health and education. But its efforts were hampered in the mid-1990s by the IMF insisting on cuts in social spending to ensure budget surpluses. Ethiopia's experience is repeated all over Africa: in 12 out of 16 countries which have implemented IMF programmes, it has led to cuts in education spending - yet education is widely acknowledged to be the single most effective development policy.

This is squandering opportunities which we will bitterly regret; disturbingly, the problems in Ethiopia look likely to grow more intractable. Five of the last six Belg rains have failed, indicating disruption of Ethiopia's chronically unpredictable rain patterns due to climate change. The population has doubled since 1985: plots are being sub-divided and a pattern of leasing land has resulted in soil degradation - yields are falling, soil is being washed away. Since the late 80s, even in a good year 5-6m people have depended on food handouts for survival. This is exacerbated by the third largest number of HIV-Aids victims (3m) in the world.

The IMF has one overriding thing to prove both to the demonstrators on the streets in Washington this weekend and to those struggling to feed their children in Gode, south Ethiopia: it is that it can set aside economic ideology to achieve the poverty reduction it now claims to be championing.

fields.headline: BNFL faces public safety 'reminder'
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: The competence of British Nuclear Fuels and its commitment to environmental protection have been questioned by the board of the environment agency which has demanded to meet the directors to remind them of their responsibilities for public safety.
fields.body:
The competence of British Nuclear Fuels and its commitment to environmental protection have been questioned by the board of the environment agency which has demanded to meet the directors to remind them of their responsibilities for public safety.

This latest broadside against BNFL by the government body responsible for radioactive discharges questions not just safety at the Sellafield site in Cumbria but all its operations, including the handling of the eight Magnox nuclear stations.

The minutes of the March board meeting begin: "Recently there have been a number of incidents at BNFL sites which have led the agency to question seriously the competence of BNFL's management of radioactive waste and its commitment to environmental protection."

The minutes disclose that breaches of safety regulations at Magnox nuclear stations had led to three enforcement notices against BNFL in recent months, the most serious for releases of radioactive Carbon 14 into the atmosphere from Hinkley Point A station in Somerset. In February abnormal radioactive releases occurred from a waste plant at Sellafield, the letter says.

The agency's concerns mirror those of the nuclear installations inspectorate which released devastating reports in February about the falsification of documents at BNFL last year and questioned the management culture of the Sellafield site.

BNFL was given two months to answer those concerns or face closure of Sellafield and on Tuesday is to publish its blueprint for improving its management there.

Archie Robertson, the environment agency's director of operations, wrote to Norman Askew, the chief executive of the state-owned company, outlining his fears on March 3. He said he was concerned about how seriously BNFL's leadership took its responsibilities for the environment.

fields.headline: Why history matters
fields.standfirst: David Irving's libel defeat is a cause for celebration. Now, argues writer DD Guttenplan, who sat through the trial, we can engage in clear-headed discussion about the Holocaust
fields.trailText: David Irving's libel defeat is a cause for celebration. Now, argues writer DD Guttenplan, who sat through the trial, we can engage in clear-headed discussion about the Holocaust
fields.body:
When I went to see Judge Charles Gray in his chambers, the day before his first hearing in the David Irving libel trial that ended this week, he confessed anxiety. "There is some risk," he explained, "of one's being asked to become a historian. Judges aren't historians."

For their own reasons, both sides agreed that (whatever else the trial was about), history, in Leopold von Ranke's phrase, "what actually happened," had no place in the courtroom. But facts have a kind of gravitational pull of their own, and by the end, everyone involved - Gray, Irving, Deborah Lipstadt, her lawyers, the experts who testified and those of us who merely listened - spent a great deal of time hearing about what happened to the Jews of Europe and about how the knowledge of what happened has been preserved.

Unlike myth, history is not tidy, and the events that became known as the Holocaust are as complex as any genuine - as opposed to literary - calamity. There is the added confusion created by the efforts of the perpetrators to cover-up their crimes. But there was also a final bar to understanding perhaps unique to the Holocaust - that we believe we already know all about it. Of all the "lessons" of the Holocaust, Pastor Martin Niemöller's account of his own complicity in the escalating brutality of life in Nazi Germany is probably the best known. His litany of indifference, "First they came for the Jews, but I was not a Jew..." is one of the things everybody knows about the Holocaust, along with the bars of soap made from the fat of murdered Jews, and the gas chambers at Dachau and Belsen. But what everybody knows about the Holocaust isn't always true.

Although the grisly tale of the soap figured in some of the earliest accounts of Nazi-occupied Europe, it is now rejected by historians as a fabrication - similar to the atrocity stories of Allied propaganda during the first world war. Dachau did have a gas chamber, but it was never used. This week the BBC referred to the "death camp" at Belsen, but there were no gas chambers at Belsen.

Nor did the Nazis come first for the Jews; as Peter Novick explains in his brilliant and provocative new book, The Holocaust in American Life, "First they came for the Communists" - a circumstance acknowledged by Niemöller, who continued, "but I was not a Communist - so I said nothing. Then they came for the Social Democrats, but I was not a Social Democrat - so I did nothing. Then came the trade unionists, but I was not a trade unionist. And then they came for the Jews, but I was not a Jew - so I did little. Then when they came for me, there was no one left who could stand up for me." The Holocaust Museum in Washington DC is just one of those who, in Novick's phrase "prudently omits" Communists from Niemöller's homily.

But prudence and political calculation have influenced our knowledge of the Holocaust from the beginning. Even the word itself - from the Greek holos, for whole, and kaustos, for burnt - is contested. In some circles, the Hebrew word Shoah, meaning destruction, is preferred. The Princeton historian Arno Mayer coined the term "Judeocide" to describe the subject of his study Why Did the Heavens Not Darken? For a long time after the war, the fate of European Jewry was hardly mentioned, partly because, as the cartoonist Art Spiegelman's father says in Maus, his survivor's tale in cartoon format, "No one wants anyway to hear such stories," and partly because in camps liberated by British and American troops including Dachau, Belsen and Buchenwald, only a minority of the prisoners were Jews. In Ed Murrow's famous 1945 broadcast from Buchenwald the words Jew and Jewish are never spoken.

In her first book, Beyond Belief, Lipstadt wrote that even when confronted by the evidence, many correspondents were reluctant to admit to themselves and their readers the reality of genocide. She attributes some reluctance to anti-Semitism. Novick, who teaches history at the University of Chicago, suggests a different reason for postwar reticence: with the realignment of the cold war, talk of the Holocaust was inimical to US interests. In 50s America few besides Communists shouted "Remember the six million!"

For most Americans, including Jews, the Holocaust was "the wrong atrocity" - mention of it was at best an embarrassment, at worst a cause for suspicion. Today the Holocaust is ubiquitous. Films such as Schindler's List, television programmes, novels, memoirs all add to what we know - or think we know - about what Raul Hilberg called "the destruction of the European Jews". His book with that title was published in 1961. The first reviews were mostly hostile: it was years before Hilberg won prizes. Merely consider the reception of Binjamin Wilkomirski's Fragments (1995) to see how much has changed: it won the National Jewish Book Award for autobiography. Even after evidence mounted that Wilkomirski was really Bruno Dössekker, a Swiss musician whose account of a childhood in the camps is fictional, Fragments attracted readers, such is the appetite for Holocaust literature.

How did this change come about? Novick mentions a gradual easing of the cold war, outbreaks of neo-Nazism in Germany and the US, the 1952 publication of Anne Frank: The Diary of A Young Girl, adapted to stage and screen. But the single greatest catalyst was the trial of war criminal Adolf Eichmann. Much of the initial response was negative. But as the trial wore on, the mass of detail overcame scepticism. The trial was televised, and for the first time the American public was confronted with the Holocaust distinct from the general carnage of war.

Now, nearly 40 years after, Eichmann's name again echoed in a court. For over nine weeks in Courtroom 73 of the Royal Courts of Justice the Holocaust has been on trial as Charles Gray presided over David Irving v. Penguin Books Ltd and Deborah Lipstadt. Towards the end of the trial, which, thanks to British libel laws, forced Lipstadt to prove the truth of the claim in her book Denying the Holocaust that Irving knowingly distorted or suppressed evidence regarding the Nazi massacre of European Jewry, it was announced that the Israeli authorities had agreed to release Eichmann's diaries. But the problem of Lipstadt and her lawyers couldn't be solved by new evidence. The problem was how to interpret what was already there.

To Irving, author of numerous books on the Third Reich, the Holocaust is "an ill-fitting legend". He didn't deny many Jews died; he denied that any of them were killed in gas chambers, that Hitler directly ordered the annihilation of Jewry, and that the killings were in any significant way different from the war's other atrocities.

In Hilberg's insight, the destruction of European Jewry was a bureaucratic process, the result of "a series of administrative measures". In their pursuit of the Endlösung - the Final Solution to the Jewish question - the Nazis left the detritus of any large organisation: memoranda, requisition forms, purchase orders and blueprints. A million Jews were murdered at Auschwitz and all had to be taken there by train in the middle of a war in which the railways were the lifelines of the German army. Yet time and again those who insist on the truth in all its complex, unsentimental, paradoxical, and ambiguous detail are shouted down. Holocaust deniers, as the latest incarnation of a paranoid tradition, are by nature impervious to fact. For them, Irving's defeat confirms his martyrdom; the scale of his undoing proves the power of the forces against them. The Holocaust has always had a political as well as historical meaning; in America, that meaning has shifted a great deal from the days when conservatives saw a Communist behind every mention of the 6m.

This may mean giving up comfortable certainties about the distinctness of Jewish suffering, the exterminationist nature of German anti-Semitism and the redemptive force of Zionism. But if the effect of the Irving decision is to strengthen the hand of those who wield the Holocaust like a totem, or a truncheon, then truth and history might as well never have had their day in court.

webTitle: Arms treaty victory strengthens Putin's hand in the west

fields.headline: Arms treaty victory strengthens Putin's hand in the west
fields.standfirst: Russia's endorsement of the Start II nuclear pact heralds a new era of weapons-reduction talks and strategiesRussia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian parliament finally approved the Start II nuclear arms reduction treaty yesterday, more than seven years after the agreement was signed and four years after it was ratified by the US senate.
fields.body:
The Russian parliament finally approved the Start II nuclear arms reduction treaty yesterday, more than seven years after the agreement was signed and four years after it was ratified by the US senate.

Russia's belated ratification should lead to thousands of American and Russian nuclear warheads being scrapped, and clear the way for more radical arms cuts. But whether that will happen remained unclear last night as further discord loomed over the next stage of the disarmament process.

The ratification vote was accompanied by a stern threat by President Vladimir Putin to pull out of arms negotiations altogether if the US proceeds with the planned development of its missile defence system, in contravention of the earlier ABM (anti-ballistic-missile) arms pact.

The former Russian president, Boris Yeltsin, tried for six years to get the Start II treaty endorsed but repeatedly came up against the communist majority in the lower house, the Duma. Yesterday's 288-131 vote was the first demonstration of Mr Putin's power in the new Duma, and gave him a crucial boost on the eve of his debut on the international diplomatic stage.

Making an unexpected visit to the Duma to urge deputies to support ratification, Mr Putin said that Russia could not afford to be dragged into a global arms race. "We had one before, and if we allow it again it will be even worse," he said.

He told them that approving the treaty was the best way of ensuring Russia's security, and reassured deputies that Russia would still have sufficient weapons to destroy any enemy "several times over".

Ratification would let the Russian armed forces concentrate their meagre resources more efficiently, he said.

"It will preserve a powerful nuclear shield, but also allows us to channel funds to the support of conventional forces, allowing us to make our army more combat ready."

Start II is intended to halve the US and Russian nuclear arsenals from 6,000 warheads to between 3,000 and 3,500 each, and to enable both countries to intensify their efforts to work out a new treaty, Start III, requiring further cuts.

The communist factions in parliament voted against ratification yesterday, arguing that it would fatally weaken Russia and give Washington a huge military advantage, but they lost their majority in the assembly in last December's elections. A large group of communist activists protested outside the Duma with banners denouncing Mr Putin and the US.

Gennady Zyuganov, the communist leader, described the vote as not "ratification of a treaty but the decisive disarmament of the country". Russia was destroying rockets which could have protected its security for another 15 years, he said.

Mr Putin had made approval of Start II a priority, and its ratification will ease his meeting with Tony Blair in Britain on Monday, and the foreign minister, Igor Ivanov's negotia tions in Washington later this month.

Nevertheless, Washington's wish to amend the 1972 ABM treaty, which it argues is essential if the US is to shield itself from rogue states such as North Korea, Iran and Iraq, is likely to lead to further conflict.

Moscow has refused to contemplate amending the treaty, on the grounds that an enhanced missile defence system in the US would weaken Russia's ability to ensure the "guaranteed destruction" of the US in the event of nuclear war: the factor which theoretically prevented the two countries attacking each other throughout the cold war.

Should the US try to alter the ABM treaty, Mr Putin warned, Russia would "withdraw not only from the Start II treaty but from the whole system of treaties on limitation and control of strategic weapons".

The Duma approved a non-binding resolution stipulating that Russia will have the right to revoke Start II if Washington breaks the ABM treaty. Another non-binding clause gives Russia the option to back out if Nato deploys nuclear weapons in countries that have joined the alliance since 1999: the former Soviet satellites Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.

Many Russian missiles are past their service life and will soon have to be scrapped anyway. The government cannot afford further heavy spending in this field, and its defence minister said yesterday that its limited military funds should instead be focused on new modern arms such as the Topol-M land-based missile, a submarine based version, and a new cruise missile for its strategic air force.
