Start II is intended to halve the US and Russian nuclear arsenals from 6,000 warheads to between 3,000 and 3,500 each, and to enable both countries to intensify their efforts to work out a new treaty, Start III, requiring further cuts. The communist factions in parliament voted against ratification yesterday, arguing that it would fatally weaken Russia and give Washington a huge military advantage, but they lost their majority in the assembly in last December's elections. A large group of communist activists protested outside the Duma with banners denouncing Mr Putin and the US. Gennady Zyuganov, the communist leader, described the vote as not "ratification of a treaty but the decisive disarmament of the country". Russia was destroying rockets which could have protected its security for another 15 years, he said. Mr Putin had made approval of Start II a priority, and its ratification will ease his meeting with Tony Blair in Britain on Monday, and the foreign minister, Igor Ivanov's negotia tions in Washington later this month. Nevertheless, Washington's wish to amend the 1972 ABM treaty, which it argues is essential if the US is to shield itself from rogue states such as North Korea, Iran and Iraq, is likely to lead to further conflict. Moscow has refused to contemplate amending the treaty, on the grounds that an enhanced missile defence system in the US would weaken Russia's ability to ensure the "guaranteed destruction" of the US in the event of nuclear war: the factor which theoretically prevented the two countries attacking each other throughout the cold war. Should the US try to alter the ABM treaty, Mr Putin warned, Russia would "withdraw not only from the Start II treaty but from the whole system of treaties on limitation and control of strategic weapons". The Duma approved a non-binding resolution stipulating that Russia will have the right to revoke Start II if Washington breaks the ABM treaty. Another non-binding clause gives Russia the option to back out if Nato deploys nuclear weapons in countries that have joined the alliance since 1999: the former Soviet satellites Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Many Russian missiles are past their service life and will soon have to be scrapped anyway. The government cannot afford further heavy spending in this field, and its defence minister said yesterday that its limited military funds should instead be focused on new modern arms such as the Topol-M land-based missile, a submarine based version, and a new cruise missile for its strategic air force.

webTitle: Hopes fade as Mugabe backs squatters

fields.headline: Hopes fade as Mugabe backs squatters
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Hopes that President Robert Mugabe's Zimbabwe government was seeking a compromise proved premature yesterday when it appealed against a court order to evict thousands of black squatters on white-owned farms.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Hopes that President Robert Mugabe's Zimbabwe government was seeking a compromise proved premature yesterday when it appealed against a court order to evict thousands of black squatters on white-owned farms.

Mr Mugabe's party, Zanu-PF, dispelled any lingering optimism by accusing the main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, of treason.

Its leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, who was in London yesterday, rejected the allegation but warned the British government to tone down its attacks on Mr Mugabe or risk turning him into a martyr.

The mood yesterday contrasted with Thursday when the Zimbabwe government indicated that it was ready to try to encourage the squatters to leave the farms and Mr Mugabe named a delegation for land talks in London.

But the attorney general, Patrick Chinamasa, has now said he will appeal to the supreme court against the high court ruling that the police should move the squatters. "The police lack the resources to enforce the order," he said.

The contradictory signals renewed the uncertainty. Although there were reports that squatters had left farms yesterday, the Commercial Farmers' Union, which represents white farmers, insisted that none had gone.

More than 1,000 farms are affected by the invasions and 615 are currently being occupied, according to the union. The situation yesterday was described as generally quiet, although one white farmer's son was attacked with bricks.

Mr Mugabe, attending a conference of developing countries in Havana yesterday, kept up his anti-British rhetoric and insisted that the "acquisition" of land would continue.

In a worrying development, his government accused the MDC of forming an alliance with the United States, Britain and two South African politicians to sabotage the country and undermine Mr Mugabe, a charge dismissed as "fantasy" by the Foreign Office.

The accusation was aired by the Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation on Thursday night and printed in full in the state-owned Herald newspaper yes terday. The minister of information, Chen Chimutengwende, said: "MDC is both waging a war and preparing for an escalation of that war against the government of Zimbabwe and Zanu-PF.

"We no longer believe that the MDC is genuinely inter ested in parliamentary elections, because they are concentrating on violence and the preparation of a full-scale military war instead of concentrating on explaining their policies in order to win the minds of the people.

"This is a war they cannot win, nor can they win the forthcoming general elections."

Parliamentary elections are due in Zimbabwe and must be held before August, but Mr Mugabe has not yet set a date.

The MDC secretary general, Welshman Ncube, blamed Mr Mugabe's covert security agency for the treason charge.

We have no doubt it was prepared by the Central Intelligence Organisation," he said.

He warned that it might be used by Mr Mugabe to claim that the security of the country was threatened, declare a state of emergency, and arrest the MDC leadership.

Mr Tsvangirai, who is visiting South Africa, Britain and the US in order to build up the credibility of his party, declared: "There is no MDC-Anglo-American agreement."

He also described the illegal take-over of land as "racism in reverse" and said that if Mr Mugabe had left government in 1995 he would have gone with his reputation intact, but "the past five years have been a disaster".

Mr Tsvangirai was reluctant to get into a slanging match, however. "We must be very careful that we don't push Mr Mugabe to the extent of being a martyr at this stage," he said, "because that's exactly what he is looking for.

"He is history anyway, so why push him to the extent where you are likely to resuscitate his image?"

He advised the British government to proceed with caution. "They should stop talking about sanctions and give him an honourable avenue out."

Mr Tsvangirai met the Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, and the Foreign Office minister Peter Hain, and urged them "to tone down condem nations". He said Mr Hain, one of the most outspoken critics of Mr Mugabe, had "admitted he had been a little bit harsh".

Mr Cook concurred with the need for a measured approach to dealing with Mr Mugabe and sought to clarify Britain's position with regard to funding a land reform programme.

The British government's offer to hold talks on the issue in London have been presented by the Foreign Office as a move towards achieving a peaceful resolution. But Mr Mugabe's government has claimed it as a diplomatic coup.

After meeting Mr Tsvangirai, Mr Cook said: "I set out our position, that Britain would support a genuine land reform programme which would benefit the rural poor and provide fair compensation to those farmers willing to sell land."

But Mr Ncube said: "We in the MDC are surprised at that particular move by the British government.

"In our judgment it is unwise to reward the Mugabe government for its actions. It would be telling the Mugabe government that if you apply terror tactics and use intimidation you get rewarded. That is what Zanu-PF has been doing on the land issue.

"The British government is sending signals that it is seeking accommodation, but that will be used by the Mugabe government as a victory for its tactics."

webTitle: Fears grow of violent global trade protests

fields.headline: Fears grow of violent global trade protests
fields.standfirst: World Trade Organisation: special report
fields.trailText: Washington was last night bracing itself for a weekend of violent demonstrations as anti-globalisation protesters vowed to halt meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott  and  Jane Martinson in Washington
fields.body:
Washington was last night bracing itself for a weekend of violent demonstrations as anti-globalisation protesters vowed to halt meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

The entire 3,500-strong District of Columbia police department was mobilised in a show of force designed to prevent a repetition of the riots that erupted in Seattle during the World Trade Organisation conference in December.

With a hard core of up to 10,000 demonstrators expected to try to storm the IMF headquarters in 19th Street, staff from the fund and the bank were yesterday told to dress down to avoid being targeted. Between 30,000 and 45,000 protesters thronged the streets of Seattle four months ago.

The IMF has been sealed off for a week amid the tightest se curity in the 56-year history of the two international organisations. But sources at the bank said they feared the protesters would try to fence off the building using "sleeping dragons", lengths of pipe and wire that are used to link people together and prevent police from removing them.

The protests have been organised by a group known as A16 - named for April 16, the day the IMF's key committee is to meet - with campaigners using the internet to coordinate their activities.

Although the US capital has been peaceful all week, seven people were arrested on Thursday and charged with conspiracy to commit a crime after police found pipes, wire, duct tape, gas masks, bolt cutters and heavy chains in the back of a truck.

Police said yesterday they expected most of the demonstrators to attend a peaceful rally tomorrow in the Ellipse, an open space between the White House and the Wash ington monument. But they were also ready for widespread civil disorder and preparing for the possibility of mass arrests.

Local police are being backed up by an array of other law enforcement agencies, including the secret service, which has been conducting undercover operations to discover the activists' plans.

Both the bank and the fund have been rattled by the vehemence of the protesters, who argue that the two institutions have railroaded through economic liberalisation policies to the detriment of the global environment and the world's poor.

But the demonstrators are divided between those seeking to reform the fund and the bank and those who believe that they should be scrapped altogether.

A spokeswoman for Jubilee 2000, the debt campaign group, said: "We have a lot of solidarity with the protesters because these are very valid is sues. There is a lot of anger out there.

"But we don't think the IMF and the World Bank should be shut down. We think these meetings should take place. This is the year for debt cancellation and we have to discuss it."

Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, yesterday said the meetings would bring progress in speeding up debt relief and reforming the institutions.

"If we are to tackle poverty successfully, we should not retreat from globalisation and we should not retreat into discredited laissez-faire policies which served the world so badly in the past," he said.

"The world financial and economic system can be, and is, being reformed. I ask the protesters to join with us to improve and strengthen the IMF and the World Bank. That is the surest way of building a virtuous circle."

webTitle: Now the bargaining can really begin

fields.headline: Now the bargaining can really begin
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin will fly to London tomorrow to tell the west that the ratification of Start II shows he can stamp his authority on the Duma, that he is a man it can do business with.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin will fly to London tomorrow to tell the west that the ratification of Start II shows he can stamp his authority on the Duma, that he is a man it can do business with.

He said after yesterday's vote that the onus was now on the US to take negotiations further. "The ball is in their court. We are now in a very good position, diplomatically and politically, to continue dialogue and strengthen international security."

The Duma strengthened Mr Putin's hand by attaching a series of conditions to its ratification. These say that Russia will consider itself freed from its Start obligations if the US breaks the ABM treaty, or if Russia's national security is threatened by the growth of "aggressive strategically armed nations".

Other get-out excuses include the US or Nato deciding to strengthen their forces in a way which threatens Russian security, the deployment of weapons which hamper the functioning of its early warning system, or an emergency which could spark an ecological threat.

With the political success of the Start II vote behind him, British defence sources said yesterday, Mr Putin will concentrate on trying to negotiate a package in which he accepts some amendment to the ABM treaty, to allow the US to build a limited missile protective shield in return for an American commitment to Start III.

Despite continuing public Russian opposition to any change in the ABM treaty, the sources were optimistic that a deal could be agreed.

Igor Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister, said yesterday that his government would propose several alternatives to changing the ABM treaty in talks in the US at the end of the month.

Moscow wants Star III to cut the number of each side's long-range nuclear warheads to 1,500 or less, to enable Russia to concentrate on a leaner, more modern force, based on the Topol-M missile.

"A few modern missiles, capable of breaking through a missile-defence system in a retaliatory strike, would be a much more effective deterrent," a centrist member of the Duma, Andrei Kokoshin, said yesterday.

But the US does not want to go below a floor of 2,000 to 2,500 warheads, leaving it enough to target 2,000 strategic Russian sites.

US and Russian officials will meet in Geneva next week to assess the prospects for launching talks on Start III, which was agreed in outline three years ago.

Future arms talks will take place against the background of Washington making it clearer than ever that it has abandoned the cold war doctrine of mutual assured destruction (MAD) and the notion of minimum deterrence.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, described the Duma vote as "a big step forward", and in Brussels the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, said: "If this is a sign of the ability and of the resolve of Mr. Putin and the Duma to work together, it is a good sign for all of us."

webTitle: RSPCA move to block hunt takeover

fields.headline: RSPCA move to block hunt takeover
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The venerable animal charity, the RSPCA, is seeking a court ruling to prevent the organisation being taken over by pro-hunt supporters in a coup being organised by Richard Meade, the former international showjumper.
fields.body:
The venerable animal charity, the RSPCA, is seeking a court ruling to prevent the organisation being taken over by pro-hunt supporters in a coup being organised by Richard Meade, the former international showjumper.

The charity has suspended applications from more than 300 people until it can get the high court to decide the validity of a mass membership drive being organised by the Countryside Animal Welfare Group (CAWG) - a pro hunting organisation set up by Meade.

The RSPCA has had strong views against hunting and shooting and huntsmen and women are being canvassed to join the RSPCA so they can overturn its stance while the government inquiry into the field sport set up by Jack Straw, the home secretary, deliberates on the issue.

One letter obtained by the Guardian from Joe Cowen, the senior joint master of the Fernie Hunt, sent to supporters reads: "A number of influential people closely connected to hunting and the Countryside Alliance, led by Richard Meade, consider that the current anti-hunting policy of the RSPCA could be reversed if only half the subscribers of each hunt joined the RSPCA and voted to ensure appropriate representation on the Council.

"If this were to take place it would be a very significant and highly effective victory for field sports. The credibility of the RSPCA is widely accepted amongst the general public and it would be enormously helpful in a number of ways if this organisation were seen to reverse its policy and become in favour of hunting."

It goes on: "To this end, Richard Meade and his supporters have formed a separate organisation called the Countryside Animal Welfare Group. Hunt supporters in particular, and indeed all friends of hunting, are asked earnestly to consider becoming members of the RSPCA NOW."

Mr Meade confirmed to the Guardian that he was organising a campaign. "I'm a former member of the RSPCA council myself and I believe they have wrong views of hunting so I am getting as many members of hunts to join them so we can change the situation. I cannot comment on the court action being taken by the RSPCA."

A RSPCA spokeswoman confirmed that the charity had taken the unusual step of going to court to get a ruling on who can join the organisation - which is governed by the 1932 RSPCA Act.

The spokeswoman said: "The RSPCA has started proceedings in the high court to seek guidance on the way in which membership applications are to be handled and to clarify the relevant position of the society's constitution.

"The RSPCA's council is concerned by the damage being done to the society as a result of CAWG's activities. Three hundred or so membership applications are being held in abeyance pending guidance from the high court. It is hoped that an early hearing date can be obtained in order to resolve this matter."

fields.headline: Winsor buildsbridges with Railtrack
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, yesterday ushered in a new deal for Railtrack which is designed to remove confrontation between the company and Ofrail.
fields.body:
The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, yesterday ushered in a new deal for Railtrack which is designed to remove confrontation between the company and Ofrail.

The regulator wants to replace the rigid regime imposed on Railtrack at the time of privatisation with a more flexible system from April next year. If Railtrack can create additional train miles it will be rewarded with more profit.

Mr Winsor said that he would not be withdrawing enforcement notices, but that in future he would define the penalties in advance so that Railtrack was fully aware of targets.

Mr Winsor outlined proposals to ensure that Railtrack's performance incentive regime is clearer. "It gives them the carrot, with the stick only being used as a last resort," he said.

From next year, Mr Winsor will make life easier for Railtrack. If it fails to meet its targets in one year, it will only be required to provide an explanation and a detailed plan to remedy the problems.

Failure to meet the target in two consecutive years would be expected to result in financial penalties set in advance.

Mr Winsor said: "No regulator should discard enforcement action if commercial incentives fail for any reason. But I will inject greater clarity and transparency in which enforcement action may be taken and the basis on which penalties will be established."

Railtrack is facing an enforcement notice which could result in a £10m fine - the highest corporate penalty ever imposed in Britain - for failing to improve its performance to levels set by the regulator. It will almost certainly contest the decision, even though Mr Winsor has congratulated it on what it has managed to achieve.

Under Mr Winsor's plans, train operating companies will be given clearer rights to compensation from Railtrack for delays. Independent monitors will be appointed to verify information supplied by Railtrack. "I want it to be more imaginative and creative, and more responsive to its customers' needs," Mr Winsor said.

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, said the plan did not go far enough in providing the right incentives and rewards for investment.

Railtrack can appeal to the competition commission.

Independent monitors will be appointed to verify information supplied by Railtrack. "I want it to be more imaginative and creative, and more responsive to its customers' needs," Mr Winsor said. Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, said the plan did not go far enough in providing the right incentives and rewards for investment. Railtrack can appeal to the competition commission.

fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst: The notion that the west is threatened with mass invasions of immigrants is a mythRefugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A recurrent theme in the west is to see immigrants as threatening, a massive, indiscriminate flow from poverty and misery to the prosperity of "our" countries. But today we know much more than we used to about these flows.
fields.body:
A recurrent theme in the west is to see immigrants as threatening, a massive, indiscriminate flow from poverty and misery to the prosperity of "our" countries. But today we know much more than we used to about these flows.

Emigration typically encompasses a small share of a country's population. Except for terror-driven refugees and mass famine, most people are quite reluctant to leave their home villages or towns.

Proportionately, hardly any people from the Indian subcontinent actually used the option they basically all had to enter Britain before immigration law was tightened in the 1960s. Yet there was great poverty then in India and Pakistan.

Nor was it the case, as some would have it, that at the end of the 1980s everyone in eastern Europe wanted to go to Germany. Most immigrants to Germany from eastern Europe were ethnic Germans - for whom it represented coming back home - and "Gypsies," or Roma people, from Romania, who were being persecuted.

There is certainly in many countries a minority who are determined and will come no matter what; they represent the pent-up demand. Then there is a grey area of potential emigrants who may or may not leave, depending on pull factors; but the vast mass of people in a poor country are not likely to consider emigration.

Another important fact that is not widely known is that only a minority of EU nationals use the option they have to migrate within the EU, even though there is still the incentive of considerable variation in earning levels among different member states. Recent figures show little cross-border mobility. Only about 5m EU nationals are working in an EU country that is not their country of citizenship out of a total population of 344m.

Likewise, immigrants always are a minority of a host country's population. Immigrants are under 5% of the EU population and 9% of the US population The eight major EU countries have a total immigrant population from the Maghreb, a group that has engendered considerable debate, of 2m. This is 14.5% out of the 5% that constitutes the total immigrant population in the EU; and it is 21.2% of the non-EU immigrant population; and a mere 0.62% of the total European population. Similar concern has been raised about Turks: yet they represent less than 2% of the German population.

There is considerable return migration except when the military-political situation in countries of origin makes this unfeasible. An estimated 60% of Italians who went to the US around the turn of the century returned to Italy. A good number of Mexicans return to Mexico after a few years of work in the US or upon retirement. The legalisation of Mexicans under 1986 legislation led to a significant return flow to Mexico as these legalised immigrants felt that they could now circulate freely between the two countries.

Current immigration policy in many countries does not help the logistics of return, partly because of the presumption that mostly people want to come rather than leave. But we now have numerous accounts of individuals and families who want to return but lack the means or fear reprisals from the government if they are unauthorised residents.

One important tendency is towards the formation of permanent settlements for a variable proportion of immigrants, (but never all of them). Britain's policy-makers recognised that settlement would take place, unlike the gastarbeiter concept prevalent in Germany. But regardless of policies, all such countries now have a settled immigrant population, many born there. Most of them are seen as "aliens" in one way or another. In France they are referred to as immigres even when they have become French.

Unauthorised immigration has emerged in all developed economies since the second world war. Although this suggests that it is possible to enter these countries no matter what policies are in place, the available evidence makes it clear that the majority of unauthorised immigrants are from the same nationality groups as the "legal" population of immigrants and they are generally fewer in number than them. Again, this signals a measure of boundedness in the process of unauthorised immigration, and the possibility that it is shaped by similar systemic conditions as the legal population, and is thereby similarly limited in its scope and scale.

Immigration includes both people seeking permanent settlement and those seeking temporary employment who want to circulate back and forth. These are the two major patterns that are emerging today. We also know that there was a significant increase in the permanent resident immigrant population when borders were closed in Europe in 1973-4, suggesting some of this growth might not have occurred if the option of circular migration had existed.

Much migration has to do with supplementing household income in countries of origin; given enormous earnings differentials, a limited stay in a high-wage country is often sufficient.

Recognising these differences might facilitate the formulation of policy today. There is a growing presence of immigrants who are not searching for a new home in a new country; they think of themselves as moving in a cross-border and even global labour market.

We know that when unauthorised immigrants are regularised, they often only work a few months at a time in the immigration country, an option that becomes available when they can circulate more freely. Some Polish women who work as cleaners in Germany only feel the financial need to do this work for three or four months a year. This is also the case with some of the African migrants in Italy.

Most migrations end. They do not go on for centuries. Indeed, 20 years is probably more common in Europe. There were large-scale migrations of Italians and Spaniards to northern Europe: these flows of hundreds of thousands of workers were in full swing in the 1960s and basically ended in the 1970s. Today, when Italians and Spaniards are free to move within Europe, there is almost no new migration. That phase of labour migration, embedded as it was in the postwar reconstruction of Europe and then in the expansion of the 60s, came to an end when these conditions no longer held.

International migrations are conditioned, patterned and bounded processes. They do not have the characteristics of mass invasions.

Saskia Sassen, professor of sociology at the University of Chicago, is the author of Guests And Aliens (New Press, New York, £17.95)

webTitle: Jay attacks union chief in asylum row

fields.headline: Jay attacks union chief in asylum row
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText:
The row between Labour and Bill Morris, leader of the
Transport and General Workers' Union, intensified last
night when Lady Jay, the leader of the Lords, accused
him of attacking the government's asylum policies in
an attempt to protect his members carrying illegal
immigrants into the country.
fields.body:
The row between Labour and Bill Morris, leader of the Transport and General Workers' Union, intensified last night when Lady Jay, the leader of the Lords, accused him of attacking the government's asylum policies in an attempt to protect his members carrying illegal immigrants into the country.

Her remarks came as three charities pulled out of plans to participate in the government's asylum scheme on the grounds that the voucher system would leave claimants living below the poverty line.

Mr Morris called for the toughest campaign the union movement could muster to stop the "degrading, divisive and stigmatising" asylum voucher system. Ministers were only one step away from such a system being introduced for the unemployed and people on benefits, he claimed.

Ministers, who were initially caught on the hop by Mr Morris's attack, had spent the day trying to sound emollient. However, that strategy fell apart when Lady Jay said that the attack had been provoked by pressure from lorry drivers in Mr Morris's union. She said that in the last few days lorry drivers had been caught carrying as many as 50 immigrants into the country in the backs of their vehicles.

Lady Jay speaking on Radio 4's Any Questions, said: "Now obviously I could see that Bill Morris would find himself under some pressure from his members on that question. The thought that this chap did not know that they were there really beggars belief. I suspect that that may be part of it."

The government hit further trouble when Mike O'Brien, the Home Office minister, revealed he had told his civil servants to stop using the word "bogus" in association with asylum seekers in 1997. He asserted that the current Home Office minister responsible for immigration, Barbara Roche, used the phrase "unfounded claimants".

Confronted by the fact that both Robin Cook and Tony Blair had recently used the word "bogus", Mr O'Brien said: "We do not language-police ministers." He said words such as "flooding" had only been used by Conservatives.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, said he was "genuinely mystified" by Mr Morris's attack on the government's asylum and race policies.

But Trevor Phillips, Labour's candidate for deputy mayor of London, added to the criticism of the government, attacking Home Office plans to place a £10,000 bond on visitors to the UK. He said: "It's a sledgehammer to crack a nut. There are simpler ways of making the system easier and more accessible and that don't discriminate against poorer members of the community."

Barnardos, Shelter and Marie Curie, meanwhile, all joined Oxfam in not accepting the vouchers in their hundreds of high street charity shops. Chris Holmes, director of Shelter, said it had been particularly angered by a Home Office rule that retailers who took part were banned from giving change to asylum seekers who used the vouchers to shop.

"This has been a difficult decision but we do not believe it would be responsible for Shelter to have agreed to profit from the change that people seeking asylum need in order to provide for their families," said Mr Holmes.

The protest against the voucher scheme, which replaced cash benefits for thousands of asylum seekers two weeks ago, has also been backed by Save the Children, which said retailers were being enticed to join the scheme by the prospect of profiting from the "no change" policy, yet the vouchers at £36.54 a week for an adult were barely enough to live on.

Oxfam, which launched the boycott campaign, said the policy not to give change discriminated against some of the most vulnerable people in Britain.

webTitle: Looking for God in the pavilion

fields.headline: Looking for God in the pavilion
fields.standfirst: A disgraced cricketer is the latest celeb to call in the ultimate umpire
fields.trailText: Mark Lawson on a disgraced cricketer who is the latest celeb to call in the ultimate umpire
fields.body:
This is the beginning of what Christians call Holy Week and it has become traditional for the churches to use high-profile believers in campaigns to promote worship. This usually consisted of billboards of Cliff Richard, Thora Hird or Terry Waite, these being our culture's main available representations of faith.

This year, the flock of possible advocates was larger - following unexpected Christian testimony from AA Gill, Fay Weldon and Jack Dee - but Easter 2000 has in fact brought an inadvertent and more challenging advertisement for Christianity.

The South African cricket captain made his 3am admission of accepting cash from a bookmaker in a call not, as cynics might have expected, to his spin-doctor, agent or tabloid press go-between, but to his pastor. Later, Hansie Cronje's dad told a reporter that the only figure fit to pass judgment on the ex-captain was, as the poem has it, the One Great Scorer.

It seems to us that we live in a secular age and yet Cronje is merely the latest public figure to refer media questions upwards. Declining to respond to an interrogation from Jeremy Paxman, Jonathan Aitken insisted that he was answerable only to God. Last year, President Clinton was unavailable at the dramatic climaxes of the Lewinsky business because he was in prayer sessions with his pastors.

There's a natural expectation that public advocates of religion should appear better than other people; it's a surprise to find them freely admitting to being worse. The obvious temptation is to assume - particularly with Aitken, whose evangelism followed his humiliation - that religion is being employed tactically to seek sympathy: sin as spin.

Certainly, there's a suspicion in these recent cases that Christianity is being used as the equivalent of diplomatic immunity: the number-plates of faith being worn for safe passage through a public scandal. Aitken specifically, Cronje and Clinton tacitly, have indicated it is somehow inappropriate for their activities to be subjected to earthly questioning.

While the Bible can notoriously be quoted selectively to promote almost any good or ill, it's true that Christ can be found warning against moralising by figures lower than God: most notably at the stoning of the adulterous woman. Yet interpreted strictly, this instruction that only the totally pure can express opinions would demolish politics, the judiciary and, decisively and first of all, journalism.

What's theologically most interesting about these cases is that the judgment of God tends to be represented by these headline figures as the softer option. The equivalents of a Clinton, Aitken or Cronje in medieval times would - if they were sincere Christian believers - have feared the flames of hell consuming them. Vengeance is mine, saith the Lord. In comparison with this eternity of torment, a few testing questions from contemporaries or an inter view with a journalist might have seemed preferable.

Today's God, though, has oddly - and quite without any Council of Trent or Vatican III - become the soft cop, the mother from whom the Victorian child wished for discipline rather than the stern father. This is not entirely a freelance initiative by high-profile sinners. It's true that Hell has been more or less removed from the teaching of the mainstream Christian churches - and that forgiveness is increasingly stressed in the sermons of those vicars who still mention God - but it's still a leap from this to the concept of a deity who will blame no one.

When Paxman starts getting nasty, pointing to the gaps in the act of contrition, Aitken is able to console himself that God will be much more understanding - more relaxed, as they like to say in New Labour circles - about the whole thing. Significantly, the presiding authority at the dreadful day of judgment is no longer the Old Testament lord of vengeance but, for Aitken, "him upstairs", like an off-stage character in a flat-share sitcom.

Cronje's dad seems similarly convinced that the Creator will be more tolerant with the disgraced captain than the International Cricket Committee, while Clinton - still smarting from special prosecutor Starr's attempt to play God - holds to the existence of a supreme being who will smile gently and say Monica Schmonica.

Ann Wroe's excellent book Pilate (being read next week on Radio 4) shows how each generation and culture has created a picture of Jesus's judge in its own image, reflecting the hopes and prejudices of believers. The same now seems to be happening with God. Once a hanging judge, He is now - for our most high-profile Christians - an omniscient liberal pragmatist, the social worker in the sky.

There's a final irony in considerations of the theology of cricket. Imran Khan - a brilliant athlete and fierce believer - once insisted to me in an interview that God controlled the outcome of matches and had directly intervened to give Pakistan the cricket World Cup: deus ex pavilion. Some years later it was revealed that certain Pakistani players (though not Imran) had been allowing Mammon to dictate certain results through collusion with betting syndicates. The case of Cronje makes the same point. Religious belief requires above all faith, but Christ's current public advocates are stretching credulity.

Full background on the match-fixing scandal at <A HREF="http://www.cricketunlimited.co.uk"

comment@theguardian.com" TARGET="_NEW">www.cricketunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The Icarus of Ickiness
fields.standfirst: Julie Burchill is available to give more practical and personal advice as an online agony aunt. Post your problems at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/burchill
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill: A friend pointed out that the less power a person has, the better my manners. Show me a menial worker, and I'm all but genuflecting
fields.body:
Every month, I am delighted to see the new Vogue on the shelf at the corner shop, and inevitably on the way home I will break into a brisk little trot - the nearest I get to exercising. Sometimes, I can't wait to get it home, and instead stop in the middle of the park and sit on a bench, breaking it open as though it was the best box of chocs in the world.

Now, I'm not one of those sad sacks who needs to be told how to clothe myself by some colour-blind French flit; neither am I one of those frigid fashionistas who gets no nearer to an orgasm than the new François Nars blusher of the same name. No, the reason for my excitement is Justine Picardie, a writer and features director at Vogue.

Even in a magazine culture as creepy and kow-towing as ours, with journalism and PR locked into some sort of infernally Dante-esque three-legged race of servility, Picardie is something to write home about (smarmily). If, like me, you believe that Sucking Up is the greatest spectator sport known to man, you're in for a treat. This one has been honing her craft for some time, building from a solid ground of mere grovelling to a peak of such superlative slurping that I don't believe there's a man to match her now - not the rock press on Ian Dury, not Paolo Hewitt on Oasis, not me on Princess Diana. No one . With her recent piece on the actress Tilda Swinton - "The camera clicks, then the lights come on and we all clap, feeling somehow blessed yet also faintly disturbed . . . her beautiful, heroic nose . . . something grandly virginal about her, a quasi-Queen Elizabeth I marooned in the 21st century . . . she looks rather like a Mitford heroine, tall, patrician, every inch the general's daughter that she is . . . everyone around us is gripped by Tilda, craning to look . . . she looks like a Botticelli angel, a happy one, who hasn't fallen into the devil's hands but has discovered heaven on earth . . . she has something of the unicorn about her; mythic, rare, unsullied by commerce" - Picardie outdid herself, shooting into the suck-up stratosphere. She is the Gagarin of gush, the Icarus of Ickiness.

I've never thought I had the Suck-Up Gene myself, but a friend recently pointed out to me that the less power a person has, the better my manners. Show me a menial worker, and I'm practically genuflecting. Some people write this off simply as inverted snobbery, but that's like calling goodness inverted evil - totally meaningless. Snobbery works only one way. I once read that Princess Lee Radziwill was meant to be a very irritating person to have dinner with, apparently, because of her habit of looking up into the waiter's or waitress's face whenever they set down or removed a plate and saying, "Thank you so very much", as though they'd just given her the most fantastic present. This had a real effect on me, and ever since I was a kid I've behaved that way.

I've got no time for those prigs who declare, "Of course, I'm happy to tip - but only if the service is up to it." With me, it's the other way around: the worse the service, the more embarrassed I feel for the server, and the more money I give them. Once, in a bistro in Bristol, an American girl kicked me hard in the shin (bruising it), knocked water over my silver Walkman (breaking it) and finished up by tipping soup into my Versace handbag (ruining it). Then she burst into tears, sat down and said her PMT was killing her. I ended up giving her a £30 tip for a £20 lunch.

But when I feel that someone is higher up the pecking order than me, I have an irresistible impulse to provoke and defy them. "Of course not!" I said, genuinely amazed and hurt by his question. We went in, shook hands, sat down and then I leaned across the table and said, "So, are you the person responsible for commissioning that awful piece of crap, Smack The Pony? God, it really stinks! But I'd rather be like that than be, like so many showbiz and media types, rude to waiters.

And what happened soon after? Each man kills the thing he loves, said Oscar Wilde, and went on to point out that one of the best ways to do this was with flattery. I can't help but think that inside every Sucker Upper twists a warped, envious nihilist, desperately jealous of others' talents. I hope so, because the alternative is just too grim.

The line about imitation being the sincerest form of flattery rings a trifle too resonantly here, I fear.

webTitle: The Cosmo girl's dirty little secret

fields.headline: The Cosmo girl's dirty little secret
fields.standfirst: "Helen Gurley Brown's success depended on a false image. Without being seen as wild and free, she'd never have got where she did"
fields.trailText: Alexander Chancellor: "Helen Gurley Brown's success depended on a false image. Without being seen as wild and free, she'd never have got where she did"
fields.body:
One of the secrets of success in life seems to be to appear different from what you really are. Take Helen Gurley Brown, whom I have just been reading about in an American magazine. When her first book, Sex And The Single Girl, came out in 1962, it caused a sensation by telling women that they didn't have to get married but that they should have sex and enjoy it with whomever they wanted. The book made her briefly a heroine of women such as Gloria Steinem, but Brown fell from favour with the feminists after she took over the struggling Cosmopolitan in 1965 and made it the US's best-selling women's magazine by seeming to promote the idea that women should live entirely for men.

A typical Cosmo cover displayed a busty model and a lascivious cover line. In her best-seller of 1982, Having It All, Brown advised women: "Never refuse to make love, even if you don't feel like it." And now, at the age of 78, she has published another book of memoirs, I'm Wild Again, in which she repeats her favourite aphorism: "Sex is one of the three best things we have, and I don't know the other two." To her office wall is pinned the slogan, "Good girls go to Heaven, bad girls go everywhere."

Naturally, most people think of Brown as a bad girl, obsessed with sex and men, even in her old age. But I'm Wild Again, despite its racy title and its cover picture of her in a slinky red dress, belies this notion. According to David Plotz, writing in Slate magazine, "This is the autobiography of a puritan. It chronicles how Brown exercises obsessively; doesn't drink, smoke or eat; has remained utterly faithful to her husband of 35 years; and lives for her job. The Cosmo girl's dirty little secret isn't sex. It's work."

But Brown's success has depended, to a large extent, on her false image. Without being thought of as wild and free, she would probably never have got where she did. And one can understand feminists' problem with her: a woman's right to enjoy sex with anybody may have been part of the feminist creed, but how was a woman to achieve this happy state of affairs without going out of her way (as recommended by Brown) to make herself attractive to men, which is not what feminists were supposed to do. (The British government, by the way, seems to be taking the Brown view in its curious campaign to fatten up the nation's women.)

The case of Helen Gurley Brown set me thinking about other successful people whose appearances are deceptive. Behind the nerdish, academic exterior of Bill Gates there lurks a ruthless businessman with monopolist urges, as an American court has found. And take Andreas Whittam Smith, founding editor of The Independent: would he have generated the necessary confidence to launch his bold capitalist enterprise without his air of episcopal gravitas? I am even tempted to speculate that my friend, Alan Rusbridger, the editor of the Guardian, may have been unwittingly assisted in his rise to the top by his reserved, rather scholarly demeanour.

It is not really possible to generalise about what you have to look like to get on, since fashions change and are different for different professions. People still want their doctors to be smart, clean and soberly dressed, but they no longer want businessmen to be stout and bald and wear suits and ties. We are in the age of businessmen such as Richard Branson, who cultivate the informal, sporting look that suggests drive and energy and risk. Rupert Murdoch looks rather old-fashioned and out-of-date now, though he is still doing pretty well.

But people who look after your money, such as bankers, should ideally be rather fat. It is noteworthy that several Chancellors of the Exchequer - Nigel Lawson, Norman Lamont and Gordon Brown, say - have been on the stout side, though there is nothing flabby about their brains. Their physical fatness, however, gives confidence. The same goes for Mohammed Fayed: he looks as he ought to, like the keeper of a grocery store, whatever else he may get up to.

In journalism, I think, an air of integrity and earnestness helps because of the low esteem in which the profession is generally held, though in reality it is difficult for a person to be a good journalist without possessing a certain amount of cheerful irresponsibility. In business, especially since the advent of the new economy, it is useful to look as if you are about to run a marathon. Politicians are also now required to cultivate relaxed informality. There would be no place in contemporary politics for stuffed shirts such as Eden, Macmillan, or even the pipe-smoking Attlee.

So, as always, appearances are important, but you have to keep up with the times and pick the right image for whatever it is you want to do.

webTitle: Committee for freedom, justice and snake-oil

fields.headline: Committee for freedom, justice and snake-oil
fields.trailText: Short But Happy Political Life of George W Bush | Wal-Mart UK
fields.body:
I'm in Boulder, Colorado, for the annual conference on world affairs, which sounds rather grand, but is actually a sort of intellectual fraternity party, at which debate and discussion on the future of the planet is interspersed with heavy drinking The CWA may, one day, be the last place in America which doesn't merely tolerate but actively encourages serious inebriation.

Two of the conference panels I've spoken on have been about Northern Ireland. For some reason, this year there was a superfluity of Irish-American republicans onstage with me. These people talk about Britain with a ferocity which almost nobody in the real Ireland has deployed for years. Any body with a title like, for example "The Committee for Freedom and Justice in Ireland" is likely to be, in translation, "The Committee for Abusing the Brits while totally ignoring Republican terrorism and intransigence."

Appearing alongside these people was fun, in an adrenalin-intensive kind of way, but also deeply depressing. As travelling propaganda snake-oil salesmen, they spread an awful lot of disinformation around America - on TV, radio, in newspapers and at public meetings. By comparison, official British spokesmen on TV tend to sound, in the local demotic, as if they had corncobs up their ass.

Did you know, for instance, that until recently Catholics were forbidden the vote, thanks to the British? Or that Reuters news agency is controlled by the British government? More generally, I was surprised to learn that the Unionist party exists to do only the bidding of the British tyrants. Sorry - I thought it was Protestant irredentism which was one of our main problems. Ask why they imagine that Britain should want to hang on to a territory which costs us billions of pounds a year, many lives, and considerable international prestige, and they mutter darkly about hitherto undiscovered oil reserves, strategic considerations - must be the threat from the Icelandic navy sailing up the River Foyle - and the way our army "treats the Six Counties as a boot camp, with live targets". I kept trying to say that, among everything, I felt the British had made great misjudgments, but that we would almost all, with the exception of Daily Telegraph leader writers, love to get the hell out. They dismissed this wishy-washy view with contempt.

 Most American newspaper columnists are dull or rightwing or both, so it's truly awful to learn that Molly Ivins, the funniest, sharpest and most humane of the lot, has breast cancer and is undergoing chemotherapy. Normally she'd be here at the conference, attracting huge audiences with her witty, persuasive and sassy talk, all delivered in a Texan accent which requires a sour cream, hot pepper and jack cheese dressing, plus sub-titles.

So we've had to make do with her latest book, Shrub - The Short But Happy Political Life of George W Bush - who, according to the polls, has exactly a 50-50 chance of becoming the next president of the US. What Molly points out is that Bush, who is running the most expensively funded campaign in the history of the world, has probably never met a rich man or a big corporation he didn't like, and has absolutely no idea of how poor people - or even most ordinary Americans - actually live. One example: while Bush, as governor of Texas, was trying to reduce the number of poor children who had health insurance, he was simultaneously pushing through a $45m tax reduction for big oil companies. As they say here, do the math. When Al Gore was serving in Vietnam, at least as an army reporter, Bush was in the Texas Air National Guard, a cosy, bullet-free home from home for the children of privileged parents.

The received wisdom among some British writers is that the the interminable American electoral system subjects a candidate to a searching scrutiny unmatched anywhere else in the world. So it does. But in November, Americans are still going to be stuck with a choice between Bush and Gore.

 Wal-Mart, the vast American chain of superstores, is about to arrive in the UK with help from those great guys at Asda. At first sight, their amazingly low prices will seem a welcome relief from rip-off Britain. Not for long, I suspect. A new book published here - How Wal-Mart Is Destroying America, by Bill Quinn, warns us that the store is a virus which can destroy almost any town it attacks. Just as the supermarkets killed off grocers, bakers, butchers and fishmongers, so Wal-Mart can finish the job by ending what is left - small stationers, clothiers, hardware stores and every chemist who hasn't already been swallowed up by Boots and Superdrug.

Wal-Mart's strategy is to open a store offering astounding bargains outside a town. As the independent competition disappears, the prices rise. And the income, which would previously have been spent on local goods and services, is despatched overnight to Wal-Mart HQ, further impoverishing the town and what's left of its core.

This might not matter so much in the cities, already blighted by chainstores, but it could be devastating to small market towns, among our few remaining glories. Any town that welcomes Wal-Mart and Asda - which are geniuses at weaselling-out planning permission - may soon find they are left with shell communities, their town centres composed of a few old buildings interspersed with gifte shoppes and theme pubs - a handful of disconsolate tourists wandering alone as the population shops miles out of town.

 On Sunday I went skiing for the first time ever. Or rather, I set off for a day's falling down. The resort, I visited, Eldora, is a small and unpretentious set-up. A mere £22 bought me ski and boot hire, plus use of the lift and two hours beginner's instruction from a man called Tom who looked as if he'd just escaped from the set of Bonanza. At the end of the two hours, my four classmates, who included a couple of middle-aged men, were sailing merrily up the chair lifts to the higher slopes while I was still falling down.

What amazed me, as it always has, is the sheer politeness of Americans. Every time I fell down someone swooshed by with a consoling word. "Heck, everybody's like that the first time" - no they're not, look at my co-beginners. "Not your fault, the snow's no good today, we need a fresh fall." Get real, please.

 Years ago, bored at a Liberal party conference full of talk about environmental disasters and the evils of multi-nationals, I invented the new horror of cocktail sticks, or, as at left, the satay stick. Victims would speak about how the roof of their mouth had been hideously savaged. Young activists would rush off to picket the heartless makers of cocktail sticks who were obsessed with shareholders' profits, and lawyers would grow fat winning compensation for people who, biting into a mini-wonton, had pierced their cheeks like landed trout. But of course America is always ahead of us. At a buffet here, the tables were decorated with large signs reading: "Warning! Sandwiches contain toothpicks!"

fields.headline: Making war on famine
fields.trailText: The secretary of state understandably does not want to fuel the border war by providing long-term funding for Ethiopia (Short denies Ethiopia famine aid cut back, April 11), however I question that "the famine was entirely unaffected by the decision to cut back long-term assistance to Ethiopia".
fields.body:
The secretary of state understandably does not want to fuel the border war by providing long-term funding for Ethiopia (Short denies Ethiopia famine aid cut back, April 11), however I question that "the famine was entirely unaffected by the decision to cut back long-term assistance to Ethiopia". NGOs in the Sudan (whose famine bears close resemblance to Ethiopia) have become increasingly frustrated that their long-term programmes have been deprioritised. They face the situation where three generations of children have received no education. Aid agencies in Ethiopia have suffered similar problems; crucial assistance for training and capacity-building to assist communities to develop sustainable practices and develop early warning systems has been reduced.

The government appears to have no coherent policy, providing some development assistance to Zimbabwe and Sierra Leone, but not to the Sudan or Ethiopia. There is no doubt that aid must not be abused by warring factions, but long-term assistance channelled through NGOs is vital if future disasters are to be avoided.
Dr Jenny Tonge MP
Lib Dem international development spokesperson

 It is no surprise Ethiopia is again in crisis. Initial findings of an Oxfam study late last year showed that half the population live on less than $1 a day and two out of three cannot read or write. Seven out of 10 people don't have enough food, leading to more disease and other chronic health problems. Half the under-fives are underweight and nearly 500,000 die each year. In spite of this, Ethiopia cannot afford to spend sufficient money on health and education because it has a $10bn debt to service.

Aid donors should agree a substantial package of increased long-term aid and debt relief for Ethiopia and Eritrea to help overcome years of poverty and conflict. In return, the two countries should make immediate peace and commit to use the money for poverty reduction. The economics of a "peace package" make as much good sense as the morality behind it. The money will be saved ten-fold if it helps break the poverty-famine cycle in the Horn of Africa.
David Bryer
Director, Oxfam

 War is not a phenomenon that can be turned on and off like a tap. The causes of the conflict between Ethiopia and Eritrea are profound and rooted in the history of the region. Conflict also breeds suspicion and hatred that take generations to dispel - think of how easily aggressive nationalism can be roused here. We cannot expect of the Ethiopian and Eritrean governments a willingness to absolve what they see as their responsibility over territorial sovereignty that would not be shown by our own. In taking a naive view of the policies of, and scope for change open to the Ethiopian government, we perpetuate an oversimplified perception of African reality that underlies many racist stereotypes.
Roy Love
Sheffield

 It is now well-documented that the famines of 1973 and 1984 were largely man-made, as the international community failed to address the main causes of the famine: the war in Eritrea and later on in Tigray. There was no famine in Ethiopia after the end of the war in 1991. In fact by 1997 Ethiopia was reported to be self-sufficient in food. What has happened in three short years to lead to such a calamity? Again it is war, but this time it is on a larger scale. At the moment over half a million armed soldiers are facing each other. It does not take a rocket scientist to figure out that the cost of maintaining these armies is several-folds more than the cost of feeding the victims of drought.
Dr Zerai Woldehiwet
University of Liverpool zerai@liverpool.ac.uk

fields.headline: Heckled in Hebrew
fields.trailText: Tony Cliff (Letters, April 14) was once speaking to a meeting on the miners' strike when a man stood up and began to heckle in Hebrew. Without hesitation Cliff shouted something back in Hebrew and the heckler sat down. He then quipped: "I was just correcting his grammar."
fields.body:
Tony Cliff (Letters, April 14) was once speaking to a meeting on the miners' strike when a man stood up and began to heckle in Hebrew. Without hesitation Cliff shouted something back in Hebrew and the heckler sat down. He then quipped: "I was just correcting his grammar."
Joe Hartney
Edinburgh

 Yet more opprobrium on SF classic Blake's 7 (Pass notes, April 14), but do get your facts right. It was boyish young convict Nova who drowned in the foam bath lotion and he never counted as one of the Seven. By the way, the original series is reshowing on BBC2 on Saturday afternoons, though the BBC seems to be trying to keep it secret.
Harriet Monkhouse John Heyes
Manchester

 I am deeply suspicious of the adaptation of Madame Bovary (TV review, April 11). Why should the BBC wish to portray the most tedious of French novels in such an entertaining way? Just part of the conspiracy to take us into the euro, if you ask me.
John Heyes Ronan Conroy
Oxford

 The media keep referring to David Irving as a historian. We lack a word for someone who tries to falsify the past as an exercise in justification. I suggest histortionist.
Ronan Conroy Graham Norman
Dublin

 Re the dodgy picture in Wisden (Leicestershire left-armer bowls Wisden a googly, April 14). Only a right arm bowler can deliver a googly, as it is a disguised leg break which turns from off to leg rather than from leg to off. The equivalent by a left-arm bowler is a "Chinaman".
Graham Norman
Limington, Somerset.

 Is the flashing cricketer really "a spinner who struggles to maintain a good length"?
Mark Deveney
London

fields.headline: Race and relations
fields.trailText: Bill Morris is quite right to attack the government for racism in immigration policies (Black union leader attacks 'hostile' Straw, April 14). But even more worrying than present practices is a scarcely noticed clause in the race relations (amendment) bill now at committee stage in the Commons.
fields.body:
Bill Morris is quite right to attack the government for racism in immigration policies (Black union leader attacks 'hostile' Straw, April 14). But even more worrying than present practices is a scarcely noticed clause in the race relations (amendment) bill now at committee stage in the Commons. The bill as a whole is meant to bring all functions of public authorities within the scope of the Race Relations Act. But one enormous exception has been made in clause 19. In immigration, asylum and nationality determinations, it will be lawful for a minister and for officials acting under ministerial authorisation to discriminate on grounds of nationality, ethnic or national origin.

Of course immigration laws, of their nature, discriminate on grounds of nationality. But discrimination on grounds of ethnic or national origin is quite another matter. This is a licence for racist controls written into statute. Liberal Democrat amendments will be considered on Tuesday: the last chance, except for third reading, to stop this clause becoming law.
Ann Dummett
Oxford

 Geoffrey Wheatcroft writes (Totally modern, April 14) that when Tony Blair became leader in 1994: "Labour was broke and needed fixing, and if the modernisers did nothing else, they made the party electable." This implies the party was unelectable under John Smith, which is a doubtful proposition. Tony Blair has said Labour would have won. So if "modernisation" was not about making an unelectable party electable, what was its purpose?
David Morrison
Belfast

 It was not my intention to start a family debate with my son through your columns (Letters, April 13), but I do realise this is not socialism - but then that simply was not on the table at the time, nor was it electable. When we vote again, remember the dark days of the 80s.
Peter Manwaring
Bognor Regis

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: • Our French neighbours are often slated for their snooty attitude to e-commerce and their barely concealed contempt for that Anglo-Saxon conspiracy, the internet. But those of us who found these features a positive incentive for immediate emigration southward may be alarmed by the emergence of an aggressive, highly profitable French e-retail operation, promising efficient two-hour delivery of products ordered online to any customer in the main European capitals. Et toi, Asterix? Does quality of life now count for rien? Not exactly. The company is called Le Rouge et le Blanc, and the product in question is - ah! - champagne. Don't ever change.
fields.body:
 Our French neighbours are often slated for their snooty attitude to e-commerce and their barely concealed contempt for that Anglo-Saxon conspiracy, the internet. But those of us who found these features a positive incentive for immediate emigration southward may be alarmed by the emergence of an aggressive, highly profitable French e-retail operation, promising efficient two-hour delivery of products ordered online to any customer in the main European capitals. Et toi, Asterix? Does quality of life now count for rien? Not exactly. The company is called Le Rouge et le Blanc, and the product in question is - ah! - champagne. Don't ever change.

 Beyond the borders of Gaul, e-styria continues apace. Byron Wien, analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, has done an interesting calculation. On one side are 25 rock-solid companies, many of them household names: Ford, Texaco, Merrill Lynch, Dupont, McDonald's, Fox Entertainment and Hilton Hotels, not to mention venerable Dow Jones itself. On March 23, they were collectively capitalised at $541bn. Quite right too. On the other side is lonely Cisco, maker of switching systems for the internet and capitalised, on the same day, at, oh, about $541bn. Worries Mr Wien: "I love Cisco and have loved it for a long time . . . but I do wonder what the fair value for . . . [its] achievement is." So do the rest of us, old son.

 Back to earth, and Tuesday is unlikely to linger happily in the memories of Barclays' boss Matt Barrett and his counterparts at Lloyds TSB and HSBC, given that this is the day our legislators bring the big banks to account for, inter an awful lot of alia, branch closures and "compensation" (that thing the rest of us get for being involved in car accidents and bankers get for turning up for work). Once the three have finished their ordeal before the Treasury select committee, their arch-tormentor Don Cruickshank will take the floor to elaborate further on his report into "competition" in the banking industry (or lack of it). It ought to be a frosty meeting in the committee corridor - Mr Cruickshank has already accused the big banks of making his report late because of their refusal to cooperate with the early stages of the investigation.

 On the compensatory theme, here is a sorry tale of the corruption of lofty ideals by the love of money. Once there was a gentle Finnish university student, Linus Torvalds, who along with a gaggle of herbivorous American software programmers working on a voluntary basis devised the Linux operating system, available free off the web. Commercialism crept in when a company started packaging Linux for use on CD-roms and elsewhere, but the company was called Red Hat, which trendy handle suggested it was not entirely enslaved to Mammon. More recently, Nasdaq-listed Red Hat has been trying to recruit a new chief financial officer. Chief executive Matthew Szulik tells us he was keen on one very good candidate until he demanded a private plane as part of his package. "He wasn't joking. We ended the talks there and then." This bean counter is apparently not alone in his super-cupidity. Mr Szulik said: "There are more than 200 vacant finance director positions in silicon valley alone. It's very difficult to find quality people at the right price." A digitalised finance director ought to work out a lot cheaper. Automate or liquidate, old boy.

 Elsewhere in the hades of multinational corporate capitalism/bastion of human dignity and freedom, fears of a re-run at the IMF meeting in Washington of last autumn's battle for Seattle have reached new peaks with the cancellation by the Potomac Boat Club of its regatta this weekend. It seems the intrepid oarsmen feared their jolly boating activities might have made them a target for the crack troops of popular resistance/violently anarchic rent-a-mob. This must mean either the Lycra-clad river folk are easily confused with the pointy-heads of global finance or that regattas generally are yet another manifestation of the international capitalist conspiracy, along with Pimms, blazers, straw hats, er, water, er...

 On a similarly plutocratic note, two cheers for Treasurer, the new brand of ultra-costly fags that, at £17 for 20, would make even Gordon Brown go pale. The smokes are produced by tobacco company Chancellor (get it?), whose chairman is Nigel Anderson, former joint managing director at Gallaher. Our expert tasting panel found them disappointing in terms of "hit", but smooth and stylish, with a steady "draw". That said, Rameses II, at £9.50 a packet, remain the better value.

 Finally, a PS on the banks. Why has Lloyds TSB caught so much less flak than Barclays over branch closures? Simple. When the white vulture is taken down for the last time, the branch has closed. When the black horse gallops off into the sunset, the branch has "moved", as in the cheery notice pasted on defunct Lloyds outlets: "Sorry, we have moved to [address of nearest functioning branch]." Fight branch movements! doesn't have quite the same ring, does it?

fields.headline: Brickbats for Britart
fields.trailText: For a paper so consistently sceptical on political issues, it is astonishing how unthinking you are about the manipulation of Britart. These artists present themselves as radical and leftwing, but they have been promoted and patronised by the likes of Charles Saatchi, and the values of the advertising world permeate the whole school.
fields.body:
For a paper so consistently sceptical on political issues, it is astonishing how unthinking you are about the manipulation of Britart. These artists present themselves as radical and leftwing, but they have been promoted and patronised by the likes of Charles Saatchi, and the values of the advertising world permeate the whole school.

Why doesn't Gordon Burn (The knives are out, April 10) explain the production of Damien Hirst's latest sculpture, Hymn? Hirst saw his son's toy, had the idea of enlarging it 20 times, paid some company to do it, and is selling the result for £1m. Now it has a full-page picture in your paper before it has been exhibited. Isn't there something missing here, something empty and cynical ?

Most absurd of all is the statement "it is no longer possible... for an important avant-garde artist to go unrecognised". Where are you looking? The new avant-garde, by definition, will be where you least expect it.
David Amery
London

 As the authors of the book about Charles Saatchi, Supercollector (The Godfather, April 14), we categorically deny that there is any anti- Semitic intent - as implied by Gordon Burn and Bernard Jacobson - in our text or the book's cover illustration. If we are anti-Semitic, then so is the artist Peter Clarke, and the Guardian - the image first appeared in your newspaper.
Rata Hatton & John Walker
London

fields.headline: Booby prize
fields.trailText: The Oscars hailed in Higher Education (Oscars are coming, April 11) are the reverse side of the coin to the suicide of the teacher, deplored in your letters the same day. Both stem from the philosophy of treating teaching as a commodity which can be measured and labelled.
fields.body:
The Oscars hailed in Higher Education (Oscars are coming, April 11) are the reverse side of the coin to the suicide of the teacher, deplored in your letters the same day. Both stem from the philosophy of treating teaching as a commodity which can be measured and labelled and teachers as competitors for Oscars or booby prizes. Dedicated professionals are either reduced to despair or join the rat race.
Prof G Ganz
University of Southampton

 The new categories of Ofsted inspections are: satisfactory, underachieving, serious weaknesses and special measures, ie three categories of failure and one of faint praise. Is it any wonder that teachers are depressed and demoralised?
Alison Hallum
Tonbridge, Kent

fields.headline: Crazy about Crackerjack
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel has revealed the phenomenal interest on the internet in all things to do with the bits in between TV programmes (Dream TV, with no programmes, April 11).
fields.body:
Matthew Engel has revealed the phenomenal interest on the internet in all things to do with the bits in between TV programmes (Dream TV, with no programmes, April 11).

There has been a huge growth in websites devoted to TV station logos, and the long-gone days of bow-tied announcers. Thousands of people mourn the loss of the musical frontcaps so familiar on commercial television a few years ago, such as the Thames skyline. As ITV slims down from 15 contractors to what will inevitably be one mammoth company, more TV logos will be banished to the wilderness of TV history.

This week Carlton's Lord Ali announced the possible rebirth of Crossroads. The motel drama was closely tied up with Lew Grade's ATV Midlands in Birmingham, where it was recorded. Viewers of The Morecambe and Wise Show repeats from the 1960s can enjoy the familiar ATV bongs that herald Eric and Ernie's arrival.

As TV logos are all but an endangered species, interested viewers can visit an array of TV web sites and watch logos to their hearts' content. There is also a non-commercial CD of start-up music, made by media enthusiasts. There is even a 24-hour-a-day media chat group.

Access to the mailgroup and other websites can be located through mhp-chat@ meldrum.co.uk. Ex-contestants of Double Your Money or Crackerjack are welcome to relay their experiences, and join in the growing volume of interest in TV nostalgia.
David Brockman
Tydd St Giles, Wisbech
david@tyddnest.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Confuciused
fields.trailText: I was startled at your article (Feng shui sow seeds of conflict, April 13). Clearly, Confucius reigns.
fields.body:
I was startled at your article (Feng shui sow seeds of conflict, April 13). Clearly, Confucius reigns. Feng shui is an artform and philosophy dating back some 6,000 years. People who subscribe to this philosophy believe the elements to be the fundamental foundations of life. In this turmoiled chaos of a global society, the answers are staring us in the face. fields.headline: Not such a class act
fields.standfirst: Caine mutinies; Horrocks gets Carter
fields.trailText: In the New Statesman David Hare takes issue with one of our columnists who was sniffy about the capacity of artists to think politically (Tracey Emin was the case in point). To deny the artist's right to criticise the political status quo was, the playwright said, totalitarian. Few would disagree with a proposition as broad-brush as that. But few would disagree with the proposition that artists, plastic and performance, sometimes talk a lot of guff.
fields.body:
In the New Statesman David Hare takes issue with one of our columnists who was sniffy about the capacity of artists to think politically (Tracey Emin was the case in point). To deny the artist's right to criticise the political status quo was, the playwright said, totalitarian. Few would disagree with a proposition as broad-brush as that. But few would disagree with the proposition that artists, plastic and performance, sometimes talk a lot of guff. The further they get from their last, the sillier they can become. Just as it would be risky to seek political enlightenment from Damien Hirst outside his studio so, admirable screen actor that he is, Michael Caine is not to be deferred to as a sociologist.

The star of Get Carter etc etc has a right to be miffed at the puny number of Bafta statuettes he has picked up over the years. He might have asked, if Sir Sean why not Sir Michael. But Michael Caine's long self-imposed exile from the UK and conspicuous success in Holly wood make his barrow-boy social criticism a bit hard to credit. For their part Jane Horrocks and Kathy Burke may dislike Helena Bonham Carter, but the success of a few aristos is not evidence of an upper-class stitch-up in St Martin's Lane. Corin Redgrave has ridden out from the red corner to second them; would Burke and Horrocks place his regal mother in the same box as Judi Dench and Maggie Smith?

Actors do not always find it easy to see where the imaginary ends and real life begins. Hard questions could indeed be asked about social divisions within our cultural life. But they would need to be answered with facts, about audiences, directors, drama schools, agents and, if there is really a dearth of parts for working-class women, writers. A system that can propel Vinnie Jones into stardom and keep Bob Hoskins there for years is not entirely class bound; what about the many actors, Ewan McGregor for example, who have no class aura at all?
