webTitle: The kit that's fit to set the pace

fields.headline: The kit that's fit to set the pace
fields.standfirst: On the eve of the London Marathon, Richard Nelsson runs through the must-have gear for the jogger and the athlete
fields.trailText: It may only take the top athletes just over two hours to complete, but for the majority of the 30,000 runners in tomorrow's London marathon, the race can feel like an eternity of pain.
fields.body:
It may only take the top athletes just over two hours to complete, but for the majority of the 30,000 runners in tomorrow's London marathon, the race can feel like an eternity of pain.

Being able to finish the 26 mile course naturally depends on fitness and months of hard training. But being properly equipped is also important. Spending an extra bit of cash on trainers that fit properly can help prevent injuries, while there are numerous gadgets available that can help you go that extra mile.

Despite the astronomical cost of fashion trainers, a good road-running shoe can be bought for between £50 and £70. Before rushing into a shop and choosing the pair with the snazziest colours, it is essential to determine whether you overpronate- whereby the foot rotates inwards and downwards as you run- or supinate, its opposite. Whatever your running style, most good sports shops will be able to suggest the correct footwear.

A popular shoe for those who overpronate is the New Balance 853 (£59.99) and a good trainer for beginners is the lightweight Hi-Tec Shadow (£30). For marathon aficionados, Adidas has brought out a limited edition of its Equipment Gazelle at £80. Only 2,000 pairs will be available this year and the design includes a marathon route map as well as the Flora London Marathon logo. The regular Gazelle sells for the same price.

It is worth bearing in mind that as trainers are constantly being redesigned, older styles can be found substantially below the original price.

But with even the best pair of trainers in the world, blisters can still occur. This is often due to poor quality socks. Many serious runners wear thin 1,000 Mile socks (£5.99) which guarantee blister-free running due to a unique two-layer system. The outer layer is supposed to grip the shoe while the inner one holds the foot.

Alternatively, there are thicker padded ones such as those made by Thorlo (£9.99). If you do get blisters while on a race or miles from home when out training, emergency relief comes in the form of Compeed (£3.99). This is a plaster that relieves the pressure on the blister as well as forming an anti-bacterial second skin.

With more than 1m people in Britain jogging regularly, the signs are that the sport is becoming as popular as it was during the 80s. In particular, more women than ever are taking up jogging and - not surprisingly - manufacturers are now tailoring running clothes specifically for females.

For wet or windy weather, runners wear lightweight jackets which keep out the elements while at the same time allowing perspiration to escape. Nike's Clima-FIT jacket (£69.99) comes in female sizes which have a narrower cut than the men's so that they don't billow out while running. Meanwhile Ronhill Women's Tracksters (£18.99) are good all purpose legwear.

Instead of wearing an old cotton T-shirt that becomes cold and clammy when you begin to sweat, it is better to choose garments made from synthetic materials which draw moisture away from the body and dry quickly. Nike's Dri-FIT base level long sleeve top (£29.99) comes in both male and female sizes. A Hind women's Capri shirt (£32) is made from cotton feel lycra, while Mountain Hard Wear's Kinetic shirt (£44.99) has a half zip and mesh panels to regulate your temperature while out on the road.

It has been suggested that women are put off taking up jogging because of the fear of developing sagging breasts. For peace of mind this can be avoided by investing in a properly designed sports-bra which can not only provide support but also help prevent long-term damage. One, such as the Supplex, is claimed to stay in place even during the most vigorous exercise and it comes in both Action Sportbra and Super Sportbra (£24.99) sizes.

If you get bored just pounding the streets on your own, it may be worth investing in an electronic device that acts like a personal training partner. The Polar M-Series consists of a lightweight chest transmitter belt and a wristwatch receiver.

The equipment monitors everything from your heart rate to calories burned as well as telling you when to increase or decrease intensity of training. Prices range from £39.95 right up to more than £300 and there is also an interface (£125) which allows you to download information on to your PC.

To ensure runners in the marathon don't suffer from dehydration, there are refreshment stations all along the route providing more than 700,000 bottles of water.

While out training, though, it is necessary to carry your own supplies. A simple Runner Feed bottle which is gripped by the hand costs only £2.99. Alternatively a bum bag such as one made by Asics (£14.99) has a pocket for the water bottle as well as room for snacks and valuables.

For longer distance runs and for those who want to drink while on the move, a hydration system such as the CamelBak (from £29.95) is recommended. Here a bag of liquid is strapped to your back like a rucksack: to drink from it you bite a plastic tube and suck. For extra sustenance, isotonic high energy drinks are recommended and if you didn't get a place in tomorrow's race, you can console yourself by drinking the London Marathon's own Liquid Power drink (£6.99).

fields.headline: Management menace
fields.standfirst: Leaseholders are calling for protection from unscrupulous agents, says Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: Government plans to overhaul the leasehold system will need rigorous safeguards to protect leaseholders from dodgy managing agents employed by unscrupulous landlords, say critics.
fields.body:
Government plans to overhaul the leasehold system will need rigorous safeguards to protect leaseholders from dodgy managing agents employed by unscrupulous landlords, say critics.

"The walls of my office are lined with letters complaining about managing agents," says Barry Gardiner MP, a veteran campaigner on leasehold reform. "The cases range from not keeping the building in good and decent repair to improper administration of monies." Mr Gardiner this week repeated his call for man aging agents to be subjected to independent scrutiny. "If past form is anything to go by we cannot rely on the industry regulating itself."

Anyone can set up as a managing agent, although many belong to the Association of Residential Managing Agents (ARMA) or the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). Agents do not have to attend courses or receive training.

But Nigel Wilkins of the Campaign for the Abolition of Residential Leasehold, says unscrupulous freeholders use the system to milk leaseholders. "If a lease states that a managing agent should be appointed to manage the block, the freeholder can set up a separate 'management company' and run the block themselves," says Wilkins.

When it comes to commissioning repairs, there are opportunities for dodgy agents to gain personally from awarding contracts to friendly suppliers.

In its consultation paper on leasehold reform published last November, the government noted: "It is difficult for people or bodies with responsibilities for managing leasehold property either to select a managing agent with confidence... or to acquire the knowledge and skills required for themselves, other than through trial and error 'on the job'."

David Hewett, executive secretary of ARMA, says most managing agents do a good job. However, even he acknowledges the sector has an image problem. "We are all in favour of greater safeguards. But our members already have to have insurance and properly audited accounts," he says.

ARMA and RICS members are also expected to abide by a good practice guide that governs everything from keeping clients' money to commissioning repairs and complaints procedures for dissatisfied leaseholders.

Mr Gardiner agrees that ARMA, whose members manage blocks of flats, is trying to improve standards. "But until they give themselves the power to fine members and publish the names of members who violate the code of practice, they have no teeth," he says.

"We have removed a number of companies from membership because they are not able to comply with our insurance or auditing requirements," Mr Hewett responds.

Mr Gardiner claims to have brought cases of poor practice to ARMA's attention. When the complaints began to be investigated the companies left the organisation.

Leaseholders unhappy with how a block is run or angry about sky-high service charges can apply to a Leasehold Valuation Tribunal (LVT) and ask them to appoint a manager. If the tribunal agrees, the landlord ceases to have management control over the building. The new manager is answerable to the tribunal alone.

In August, the government will publish a draft bill setting out plans to overhaul leasehold laws and introduce a new form of tenure called commonhold. Under the new system, leaseholders would be able to manage their block without proving the freeholder was at fault and without having to acquire the freehold to the property.

"Leaseholders may want to employ a managing agent to do the work for them," says Mr Hewett.

Mr Wilkins argues that the introduction of a "no fault" right to manage is not enough: "The landlord will have the right to object and appeal to the LVT. If the block consists of only half a dozen flats, few leaseholders would have the resources to fight him."

Mr Gardiner argues for a two-pronged attack involving both greater leaseholders' rights and regulation of managing agents.

fields.headline: Scenting a bargain
fields.trailText: Scent is one of those commodities where the packaging can be as important as the content. The most pre-eminent scent bottle-maker of the early 20th century was René Lalique.
fields.body:
Scent is one of those commodities where the packaging can be as important as the content. The most pre-eminent scent bottle-maker of the early 20th century was René Lalique.

Lalique (1860-1945) was initially acclaimed for his Art Nouveau work in jewellery and gold. His wide range of creations included car mascots, vases, tableware, plates, clocks and jewellery. He later became the foremost glassmaker of his day, producing thousands of designs after 1900 - with those for scent bottles being the most numerous.

Lalique was considered a pioneer in glassmaking, developing and patenting new techniques where prevailing moulding methods could not achieve his innovative effects. He pushed out in new directions in colouring.

Many of Lalique's items are in opalescent glass, produced by adding phosphates, fluorine and aluminium oxide to make the glass opaque, then adding a minute amount of cobalt to give an internal blue tint. Other objects are in clear and frosted glass, or other tints, such as green, red and yellow.

Most of Lalique's works were mass produced, but he was able to make individual pieces to his design not produced en masse by the workshops. Many of his scent bottles fall into this category. He could make unique casts by splitting the moulds to retrieve the glass.

Daniel Gallen, a specialist in Lalique at Christie's, South Kensington, says: "Perfume bottles were beautiful examples of Lalique's work in miniature. Other artists like Lanvin and Baccarat made scent bottles but Lalique, to my mind, was the finest and is certainly the most sought after. Scent bottles were expensive even in their day because they usually contained fragrances by top parfumiers."

Christie's is holding a specialist Lalique glass and 20th century bronzes and sculpture auction on May 12. This will include the Pickard-Cambridge Family Collection, which Christie's says is one of the most important private collections of Lalique scent bottles to come on to the market for some years. More than 70 perfume bottles will be offered.

David and June Pickard-Cambridge started their collection in 1973 when they purchased Quatre Soleils and Bouchon Mures from an antique dealer in Cape Town for just a few rand. In 1989, they exhibited their collection in the Galerie Moderne in Paris to great acclaim. They subsequently exhibited at the Tien Metropolitan Gallery in Tokyo.

At the top end of the range are a rare group of tiara-stoppered scent bottles. There is the coveted Bouchons Mures circa 1920 - a clear and enamelled scent bottle with a mulberry tiara stopper in blue frosted glass, which is estimated to sell for £10,000 to £15,000; the Bouchon Cassis, circa 1920, in blue frosted glass (£7,000 to £9,000), Bouchon Fleurs de Pommier, circa 1919, a clear and frosted pink stained scent bottle, the stopper moulded with flowering branches (£6,000 to £7,000); the elegant Bouchon Eucalyptus, circa 1919, with its stopper moulded as a crown of eucalyptus berries hung with a cascading arch of leaves (£6,000 to £7,000) and, finally, Bouchon Trois Hirondelles, circa 1920, the stopper dramatically moulded in relief with three swallows in flight (£6,000 to £9,000).

Not all the bottles are this expensive; prices start at £1,000. On the way up from this is the unusual Au Coeur des Calices which is a blue frosted scent bottle modelled as a single flowerhead with a stopper as a wasp. This is estimated at £4,000 to £7,000.

Then there is what the auction house calls the imaginative Amphytrite, circa 1920, an emerald green and frosted bottle moulded as a nautilus shell, the stopper with a crouching naked female. This should easily reach its pre-sale estimate of £3,500 to £4,500.

If some of these prices seem rarefied, they should be seen in context. Lalique enjoyed a boom and bust experience in the late 80s. The Japanese developed a passion for him. As with other areas of collecting, particularly modern art, the Japanese scramble sent prices soaring. The record for a Lalique scent bottle is £38,000 achieved in 1990.

When the Japanese economy went into the rough in the early 90s, prices collapsed somewhat. Lalique has been in semi-recession ever since. Daniel Gallen says there has been a recovery in the past few years but prices have not reached the levels of the late 80s. So there could be bargains for the dedicated collector.

 For further information; Christie's, South Kensington, tel: 020-8581-7611.

The record for a Lalique scent bottle is £38,000 achieved in 1990. When the Japanese economy went into the rough in the early 90s, prices collapsed somewhat. Lalique has been in semi-recession ever since. Daniel Gallen says there has been a recovery in the past few years but prices have not reached the levels of the late 80s. So there could be bargains for the dedicated collector.  For further information; Christie's, South Kensington, tel: 020-8581-7611.

fields.headline: Sloppy surveys get green light
fields.standfirst: The court of appeal has just made it more difficult to claim compensation if you have been let down by your surveyor, writes Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: The court of appeal has just made it more difficult to claim compensation if you have been let down by your surveyor.
fields.body:
The court of appeal's rejection of the claim by a Sussex businessman who bought a house which he was wrongly advised would not be affected by aircraft noise, will make it difficult for many who suffer at the hands of negligent surveyors to obtain compensation.

Before Graham Farley bought his home at Blackboys, near Lewes in Sussex, he was sufficiently concerned about the possibility of disturbance from Gatwick flights to ask his surveyor, Michael Skinner of MS Associates, to investigate.

Rather than make proper inquiries of the Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Skinner merely asked a few neighbours. They were perhaps less sensitive to noise than Mr Farley, and said they did not think there was a problem.

It turned out that planes were stacked above the house at peak hours, making it unpleasant for Mr Farley to sit outside early in the morning or for pre-dinner drinks. However, there was no evidence that the noise level was such as to affect the value of the house.

If there had been, Mr Farley would have been entitled to compensation. But he had been deprived only of his enjoyment of his property. The county court judge decided that Mr Farley should receive £10,000 for this.

To put the figure in context, this is as much as the courts would award someone who had lost their index finger in an accident. Mr Skinner's appeal was not on the basis that £10,000 was excessive, but that nothing should be awarded.

As a general rule, the courts will not order damages where the victim has merely suffered disappointment. This leads to results described by one judge in the court of appeal as "unfortunate, surprising, and even, in the view of the general public, unjust, but not absurd".

Mr Farley defended the county court's award on the basis that his contract with the surveyor had been specifically designed to give him the pleasure of living in a noise-free house. He claimed there were analogies to actions brought by disappointed travellers, who can, as an exception to this general rule, recover damages from tour operators, when holidays are a serious flop.

The court of appeal decided it could not apply those principles to cases involving surveyors. It was conscious of an unsuccessful claim brought in 1986 by Richard and Collette Strover of Kent. A surveyor had advised them the house they were considering buying was connected to the main drainage but it actually drained into a cesspool. They were so upset by this that they decided to sell the property. In fact they got substantially more for it than they had paid, so there was no financial loss.

The judge, after hearing expert evidence, had decided "somewhat against my own instincts" that the cesspool could not have affected the value of the property. The Strovers' claim for damages, based partly on occasional smells from the cesspool, was rejected.

The court of appeal in Mr Farley's case declined to treat the instructions to the surveyor as giving rise to a claim for disappointment. While the courts have, in recent years, become more willing to award damages in cases like these, to make such an order against a surveyor would have been extending the law too far.

Therefore the county court's order for £10,000 was overturned. Mr Farley wants to appeal to the House of Lords, though the costs of doing so will be far more than he can hope to recover.

The effect of this decision will be to leave many home buyers who receive bad advice from a surveyor without any remedy. Many features of a property have little impact on its value, but may still be of utmost importance to buyers. Examples might be the type of soil in a garden, the depth of a swimming-pool, even the dimensions of a garage.

Many such matters can be tested by buyers themselves, just as Mr Farley could have spoken to the Civil Aviation Authority. That may be safer than relying on surveyors.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Go through the first-time maze
fields.trailText: Picking a mortgage used to be simple. But now, with nearly 5,000 products on the market, first-time buyers have to tread carefully through the money maze.
fields.body:
Picking a mortgage used to be simple. But now, with nearly 5,000 products on the market, first-time buyers have to tread carefully through the money maze.

Borrowing too much in relation to the value of the property could leave you haunted by the spectre of negative equity.

First-time buyers have to do their homework to root out the best loans. Lenders have backed off from marketing cheap deals specifically for first-time buyers because of objections from existing customers who resent subsidising newcomers.

Most high-street lenders shy away from offering 100% loan to value (ltv) mortgages in their standard ranges. You will generally need a deposit of at least 5% - plus cash for legal and other costs associated with house purchase.

But some lenders give 100% loans through subsidiaries. Mortgage Express, a Bradford and Bingley subsidiary, will lend up to 102%. A £65,000 mortgage at an an assumed interest rate of 7.5%, with a 0.5% discount, free valuation and free completion fee requires monthly repayments of £480.34. It is tailored so that borrowers can move home after two to three years.

The Royal Bank of Scotland also offers 100% mortgages and will add up to £1,000 for legal or survey fees to the loan. There is a 2% discount until September 2001 which reverts to the standard variable rate of 8.24%.

Halifax has nudged its range up to the 97% ltv. "This is not about increasing risk," says Halifax's Joyce Grummitt. "In reality the housing market is robust and price increases mean that first-time buyers struggle to save a deposit."

Halifax offers a 5.74% discounted rate until September 2001 on 97% or a fixed rate of 6.99% until September 2003. There is also 1% cashback and a free valuation. A cashback deal on 97% is 3% with a rate of 7.75% and this is also available to existing customers.

Nationwide has reduced its rates on its fixed, capped and discounted mortgages. It offers a 6.15% two-year fixed rate or a two-year discounted mortgage at 5.75% to first-time buyers.

Alliance and Leicester has also launched its new fixed-rate two-year mortgage at 6.19% for 90% ltv and 6.29% for a loan of up to 95%. A quarter of their new customers take up the 321 stepped discount mortgage which gives decreasing discounts over the first three years. First-time buyers have their valuation fee refunded and a £250 cashback, plus discounts on home decorating products, van rental and even beds.

Not all mortgage deals are flagged up as specifically for first-timers but they are tailored to offer advantages. It could also be worth looking for a loan from a trade, professional association, or affinity group.

webTitle: Cheap deal? Check the small print

fields.headline: Cheap deal? Check the small print
fields.trailText: Lenders are always keen to tempt consumers in a market full of lookalike plans with incentives that make them think they have bought a mortgage on the cheap. But apparent generosity does not suspend that basic law of economics - there is no such thing as a free lunch.
fields.body:
Lenders are always keen to tempt consumers in a market full of lookalike plans with incentives that make them think they have bought a mortgage on the cheap.

But apparent generosity does not suspend that basic law of economics - there is no such thing as a free lunch.

What they give with one hand, they can take back with another. The big difference is that the giving will be writ large while the taking away will be in the small print.

Banks and building societies often provide discounted mortgages at low interest rates for fixed periods. And some schemes come with a cashback. This means that money (usually a percentage of the property's value) is actually given to the borrower just for agreeing to take the loan. It resembles a discount except that you get the money upfront instead of having to wait for the savings to add up.

But such temptations often come with a sting. One potentially crippling cost is the redemption penalty that comes with many cashback or discount loans. This means a lender can charge you a percentage of the loan if you decide to move or seek an alternative package before completing a minimum period. This can be anything up to six years. Some loans have penalties that can extend well beyond the life of the deal's cheap rate portion.

Penalties can either be based on a number of months' interest at the non-discounted rate or on a percentage of the sum borrowed.

So, if the current rate of interest is 7.74% and the loan was for £100,000 with a 12 months' penalty, and you decided to leave after a year, you would end up having to hand over £7,740. Most redemption penalties fall as time goes by so if you cancel after one year you will face higher charges than pulling out after three. Abbey National is currently offering a 5% cashback with a five-year redemption penalty. Here, the cashback alone is reclaimed as the rate is the standard 7.74%.

Prudential Banking has a taper for its redemption penalties. Take out its discount package and you get 2.5% off in the first year, 1.5% discount in year two and 0.5% off in the third year.

But you are held in for six years unless you pay a penalty. Cancelling in the first year entails a fine of 5% of the sum borrowed, falling to 2.5% by the sixth year.

A discount sounds great but you had better make sure you intend to stay put. Parting with a few thousand pounds just for changing your mind is not a line the salespeople will use to tempt you.

Some financial advisers believe that redemption penalties give the borrower more loans to choose from, but the surfeit of deals on the market can be confusing - especially for a first-time buyer. And no matter how much lenders defend these schemes in the name of consumer choice, such variety can be misleading for many borrowers.

Not surprisingly, redemption penalties are popular with lenders because either way they are covered. If you decide to move before the agreed time you hand them over a hefty fee and if you don't they are still making a profit from your compulsory loyalty.

If there is no redemption penalty in the small print beware another potential trap. Some lenders oblige customers to take out their buildings and contents cover or other insurance policies. These will almost always be more expensive than shopping around.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Looked at from the outside, every senior executive in the room was a visibly successful competitor in the corporate career race. Talked with individually, many told how the role often felt uncomfortable, how out of sync they felt with   their view of their real self, or how different they assumed themselves to be from other senior executives.
fields.body:
Looked at from the outside, every senior executive in the room was a visibly successful competitor in the corporate career race. Talked with individually, many told how the role often felt uncomfortable, how out of sync they felt with their view of their real self, or how different they assumed themselves to be from other senior executives.

Walking back from the event I called into a card shop. There screaming from the rack was a dayglo confection announcing: "Success is getting what you want, happiness is wanting what you get." The sentiment well describes what I have observed in those who have achieved board membership or partner status.

Having focused for many years on the goal as an end point marker of achievement, disillusionment often follows quickly. The disappointment comes with the recognition that the most valued reward that comes with success is not the financial package, but the more elusive perk of working with that success so personal rewards are still delivered.

The first disillusion is often looking at those others who occupy a similar role, and in particular looking at the chief executive or senior partner. A personal reputation for aggression, analytical ruthlessness, or emotional coolness feels very different when experienced in a meeting room rather than through decisions sent down the line.

If newly promoted executives speak openly about their lack of confidence in such meetings, the advice is likely to focus on how to enhance their presentational impact or increase confidence through preparation. When this doesn't take away their unease, some choose to fake it as the price of making it. In contrast, Judi Marshall of Bath University has argued that many senior women leave rather than compromise their sense of self. There is, however, a third way reported by Herminia Ibarra of Harvard Business School, which encourages individuals to flex their behaviours within the new environment without abandoning their integrity.

Every ambitious individual knows that acquiring an influential mentor can be a key determinant in both learning the rules of the game, and being well positioned to apply them. Great play is put on the power of the teacher:pupil relationship as a means of quickening progress but its limitations, Ms Ibarra argues, are often ignored. It leads individuals to believe that emulating the behaviours of key individuals is the smartest corporate compass. However, in her study of those who were able to make the transition comfortably into partner status, the more successful were those who were willing to take a collage approach to observing others.

They observed a variety of people, and identified behaviours which seemed to work for them. They then took the courageous step of trying out those behaviours and observing both how others reacted to them and how they felt themselves. From this came an increase in their behavioural range drawn not from direct emulation, but through developing an identity which was true to themselves. The pay-off was increased confidence that they could be a legitimate part of the senior management team without giving away important parts of their self.

In contrast the unease which I have observed in senior managers is often based on assumptions about how they have to be as the price of success. Posing the question "what do you assume about how you have to be in order to be successful?" brings into the open information that can be reality checked and allows for identifying assumptions that would help them move nearer to achieving their personal model of success, and the sentiment of the greetings card.

 Carole Pemberton is managing consultant at Career Matters.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill finds it hard to imagine any type of justice other than that distributed by the state (April 8). One has only to look at the range of legal misjudgments to point out that, perhaps, this it not always the case.
fields.body:
Julie Burchill finds it hard to imagine any type of justice other than that distributed by the state (April 8). One has only to look at the range of legal misjudgments to point out that, perhaps, this it not always the case.

Her view that mediation is 'another excuse for the nasty to walk all over the nice' is misguided. Mediation, unlike traditional justice, allows the 'nasty' to experience first-hand the results of their actions, and increases perception of the harm they have done.

Similarly mistaken was her description of the judgment of Solomon as the first mediation. It was not, otherwise the 'mothers' would have decided the outcome of the problem. In the same way, much so-called mediation that takes place internationally is not true to the process, breaking many of the principles of impartiality and agenda-free conflict resolution.

Unfortunately, Burchill is not wise enough to distinguish between mediation and its use as a guise to administer state justice by another name.
Tara Barker
Mediation UK, Bristol

So Julie's going online to give advice. I now know where to go when I want a Bloody Mary mix or to become a one-time lesbian. But what about those poor sods with real problems. What will they get? Probably a giant virtual hand that slaps them around the face and tells them to pull themselves together. Serves them right.
Chris Orr
Brighton

In my earnest 20s, Julie Burchill annoyed me. In my neurotic 30s, she angered me. With the imminent advent of 40, she amuses me no end. By 50, I'll be a devotee. Keep winding them up, gal.
Deborah Haines
Birmingham

So, Julie Burchill thinks moaning micro-celebrities should shut up and get on with it? Off you go then.
Deborah Persaud
London N1

Weren't you a week late with the Julie Burchill 'agony aunt' scam?
Ray Flood
Dundee

Among other attacks, How To... Ramble (April 8) said that ramblers are 'achingly dull, cagouled idiots' and ended by suggesting they 'should be hunted by horse and hound'. There have been several articles picking on minority groups recently: vegetarians and people with beards, for example. In the playground, anyone who is different may be picked on like this and suffer greatly, but why is bullying acceptable in your paper?
Jim Howard
Canterbury, Kent

All For One (April 1): a right-on, virgin-birth, trinity-myth for the new millennium? It got more fantastic as I read on - science fiction on a planet where only women existed, fed only by electronics, ultrasounds, epidurals and aviation fuel?

Not quite: a nasty male technician appears for a second, a shadowy boy in a photo and, at the very end, fleetingly, a husband 'unwanted' and 'redundant'. There's also a father in an ancient black-and-white photo playing happily with his wife and daughters, but nowhere in the text - but clearly that was taken on a very different planet. Aha, it was April 1, and it followed a piece called The Guy Can't Help It. I geddit now.
John McKean

fields.headline: Words were not enough
fields.standfirst: Wars, disasters, catastrophes . . . as a reporter, Dominique Lapierre was always there, in the thick of it all. And he made a fortune in the process. Now he has leapt over the fence: a doer and a fixer, who has invested millions, and himself, in making things better. By Hugo Young
fields.trailText: Wars, disasters, catastrophes . . . as a reporter, Dominique Lapierre was always there, in the thick of it all. And he made a fortune in the process. Now he has leapt over the fence: a doer and a fixer, who has invested millions, and himself, in making things better. By Hugo Young
fields.body:
A hazard of the writer's trade is that writing is sometimes not enough. Great writers know there is nothing else to do, and most lesser writers would probably be incapable of any other way of life, however sketchy their literary satisfactions and paltry their rewards. Whether novelists, historians or general-purpose hacks, we know our limitations, and usually find that these do not extend beyond the filling, one way or another, of the unwritten page. But there are exceptions. An engulfing aura of pointlessness is capable of sinking the author whose two-year labours produce sales of a couple of thousand copies. Might it not be better, for heaven's sake, to do something, to act, rather than spend more years in futile toil at the word-processor screen?

The writer who wants to change the world could be particularly vulnerable to this temptation. But succumbing to it seems a kind of betrayal. One writes one's piece, perhaps one's several pieces, filled with sincere outrage and all the literary power one can muster - and then passes on to the next subject. The writer has to write. The reporter has merely to report. In journalism especially, the line between writing and acting should be guarded with professional severity. Crossing over, in the short term or the long, is an offence against the canons of the trade. The battlefield reporter doesn't stop to pick up corpses.

Anyone Here Been Raped And Speak English? - the title of Edward Behr's memoir sums up the code of the disaster correspondent hurtling to meet his deadline. Dominique Lapierre spent plenty of time as such a writer. A senior reporter on Paris Match for 20 years, he covered the Algerian war and many other catastrophe zones on the front line. He has also been a staggeringly successful author. From the 60s, his mega-works of popular history, several written with his American confrère, Larry Collins, piled the shop-shelves high for months and years. The two men developed a uniquely accessible line in documentary reporting, with a strong human interest. They were early practitioners of total research. Is Paris Burning?, their first effort, reconstructed the liberation of the city from the Germans, based on interviews with no fewer than 1,200 witnesses. They wrote the life of a Spanish matador, El Cordobes, and, among other things, a celebratory history of the military operations behind the foundation of the Jewish state - O Jerusalem.

The subjects, it is apparent, were picked for their commercial possibilities, as well as thematic grandeur. The Paris book, without the apparatus of scholarship, was revelatory as well as humanly gripping, and eventually had sales of five million, which at the time was just about unprecedented for a work of non-fiction. It was a classic of reconstructive history, personal and graphic, before television developed the genre and seized it, however fitfully, for itself. What counted most, though, were the numbers. These were in a league that almost any other author would consider justification enough of his life. Lapierre is a writer with no reason to feel frustrated that his passions and concerns are not exposed to a substantial part of the reading universe. When he branched out on his own, he became an even bigger name for publishers to boast of. City Of Joy, a book built around the poor children of Calcutta, which later became a Roland Joffe film, has sold eight million copies worldwide.

Lapierre's books are the work of a reporter, but they always had an intensely emotional undertow. He plunges into his subject with a degree of sympathy that is sometimes disorienting if one approaches the books expecting dispassionate narrative. Though public events are his subject matter, the human stories come out more strongly than the political and diplomatic complexities. Perhaps he always was a candidate for going over to the other side. His style of hot-blooded engagement was halfway to expressing the need he later felt: to be quite extravagantly much more than that distanced, all-seeing but nothing-doing creature, the professional writer.

His start was orthodox enough. There was no conflict between the quest for evidence and any distracting compulsion to react to it as a human being. He was no different from any other reporter, and was very good at it. "In Algeria," he told me recently, "I did some very tough reporting on people dying. They were wounded and I did not pick them up. My first loyalty was to my paper, and my first problem if I had a camera was to do the photos and make sure they got back to my office." Did he feel nothing beyond that? "My compassion for the victims may have been total," he now reflects, "but I just had no time. I couldn't stop to pick up a child who was bleeding and bring it to hospital. I discovered on the battlefield that one cannot at the same time be Hemingway and Mother Teresa."

Forty years ago, I guess the Mother Teresa aspect of things featured hardly at all. As for the laconic Hemingway, any comparison with Lapierre's voluble excitement seems somewhat inapt. But it's clear enough what the macho newsman's priorities were. The facts, lady, just give me the facts. Those were wars in which reporters, with rare exceptions such as James Cameron, felt no more need to carry a stretcher than they did to propagandise - even between the lines, let alone as openly as happened in Bosnia in the mid-90s - about the rights and wrongs of the conflict. By the time he was 50, however, Lapierre began to think he had had enough of that life. This wasn't a case of the kind of physical fatigue that might overtake a reporter who had been 30 years in the field, so much as a certain kind of inconvenient moral enlightenment that had come from writing certain kinds of book. "I experienced, suddenly, remorses," Lapierre said, in an arresting departure from his fluent English. "I had seen so many things, and done nothing about them. It was a great moment to make retribution for all the things I had left undone."

The retribution he made - if that's the right word for someone whose books, while perhaps over-effusive, hardly deserved punishment - was more spectacular than any writer has ever, to my knowledge, performed. Dominique Lapierre's leap from writer into actor has so far involved him in the sacrifice from his own earnings of around five million dollars. The catalyst was direct and personal: a benign reversal, one might call it, of the biblical law that approves an eye for an eye. Lapierre decided to repay, hugely, the very sources of his own prosperity - the subjects who made his latest books pruriently fascinating, the victims out of whom he might have made another fortune. He couldn't escape the emotional logic that said writing did not suffice. He may not have saved a single child from dying in Algeria, but, in the 70s, the producer of best-sellers, which had by now acquired an almost routine inevitability, found the new gold-mine from which, as he thought of it, to make amends: India.

The place caught him at the time when he already suspected he had to change, and was looking for a way to shift the focus. "India lends itself particularly well to that kind of psychological process," Lapierre told me. "It is a very touching, very warm country. Maybe if the same thing had happened in Germany, I would not have been as touched by the sufferings of the Germans as I was by the hard lot of some of those Indians I met during my research." Freedom At Midnight, an account of the run-up to Indian independence, led fast to City Of Joy, his Calcutta epic that has nothing but common humanity as its theme and finally excludes all trace of the reporter's conventionally sceptical mind-set. It scrutinises deeply - in a way, almost celebrates - the human consequences of Indian poverty. The writer's life was not the only one this book changed for ever. Giving the money, however, turned out to be only the start. Lapierre's journalistic instinct, rather than being discarded, was put to service in a different way. He began as a disgorger of his gains, but soon became a ferocious polemicist. Examining what he has done with his five million dollars, one finds roughly equal portions of pity and fury.

Let the fury come later. Not long ago, I was in Calcutta and went to see some of the fruits of his pity. He has been giving half his royalties to projects around the Ganges delta for 20 years, and has collected through the publicity he can generate - virtually unheard in this country, but loud in France, Italy, Spain and the US - another $200,000 a year over the past five years. Topped up by his own giving, the projects take around half-a-million dollars a year. In the bottomless ocean of human need in West Bengal - one of the poorest, most densely populated, disease-ridden, flood-prone, weather-beaten places in the world - it seems a tiny contribution. But it certainly rates against, say, a leader in the Guardian about third world debt.

He began with lepers. India has a quarter of the world's sufferers, and their children, mostly living in slums and filthy, secluded compounds, have little chance. Contrary to most people's impression, once leprosy is diagnosed, it is quite easily treated and cured. But finding the victims and hoisting them out of the filth is another matter. Lapierre kept seeing them while researching the Calcutta life of Mahatma Gandhi, the key character, of course, in Freedom At Midnight. Mother Teresa herself told him that if he had money to spare, they should be his target. It was the beginning of an odyssey that has taken him into alliance with characters that would fit as well into a Joseph Conrad fiction as the most florid reporter's notebook.

On the edge of the city, an hour's honking, heaving perilous bus-ride from the centre, sits the Resurrection Home - Udayan - for children of the victims of leprosy. Its founder, major domo, podgy and eagle-eyed superior is a former British businessman by the name of James Stevens. Between them, these two benevolent western autocrats - one who now says he never calls England home, the other who makes sorties to India three times a year from his house in St Tropez, to watch over his social investments - have made quite an impact on leprosy.

Stevens got to Calcutta in 1968, intending to stay for a couple of years. But he couldn't get the leprous children out of his head. When he met Lapierre, who was fresh from Mother Teresa, he told him Udayan was about to shut down because he'd run out of cash. The Frenchman and his wife were electrified. They were ready for the transformation. "My wife took out of her bag the bundle of dollars we had brought with us," Lapierre recounts in his recent autobiography, A Thousand Suns. "'This initial donation will enable you to pay off your debts.' I said, and before really thinking, I added: 'We will fight to see that you never have to close the Resurrection home.'"

It is now a paradise of calm, which has seen 6,000 boys pass through it, cleansed of leprosy and fitted up with a basic education. Married to an Indian, Stevens has left Bristol far behind, though he did become an Anglican priest somewhere along the way. Collecting me from the city centre, he sits up front in the bus, the patriarch of a six- acre spread, chanting hymns to himself, gesturing almost regally to the throngs who see him approaching.

Udayan began with 11 boys, and now houses 300 at a time, along with a handful of girls. The atmosphere and buildings come straight from a modest English public school. There can't be a more orderly, obedient, pacific collection of children east or west of the playing-fields of Eton, all of them seemingly grateful for their temporary rescue from the compounds and roofless hovels of those who are literally untouchable.

Indian officialdom isn't sure it likes this kind of independent enterprise. It seems, after all, very European, even while being wholly Indian. There's been talk of infiltrating some party overseers, and Stevens spends a fair bit of the day hooked to his mobile telephone, grappling with Bengali bureaucrats. But the facts are there, that nobody else made. Some of these boys, going back a few years, have become teachers and civil engineers. At Udayan now, they live in clean, well-lit pavilions, eat regular meals, have regular lessons - and sleep on 300 beds and mattresses that suddenly turned up one day at the dockside, a gift from the Australian cricket captain, Steve Waugh. The name of Dominique Lapierre is splashed lavishly around the property, which would collapse without his money. It seems, in the circumstances, a modest replacement for the ego-trip of writing.

So are the Dominique Lapierre dispensary boats that ply the remoter tributaries of the Ganges delta. A day on one of these takes you back to the simplicities of medicine. The door marked Pathology, below decks, covers a room no more than six feet by six, in which the equipment consists of a single microscope. The room marked X-ray, on this particular boat, still awaited its apparatus. Here is a health service, carried from the little mainland port of Raidighi to places that may take three days to reach and do not even appear on the maps, yet contain thousands of people who otherwise would see no doctor and get no medicine.

After the former British businessman, enter the former Naxalite terrorist, who has become another Lapierre protégé. Wohab is the leader of SHIS, the Southern Health Improvement Samity, who shows that writers aren't the only ones in need of some form of displacement activity. At one time, Wohab ran among killers, but in 1980, under the influence of a Swiss priest, he changed sides. "He persuaded me to change from taking life to giving life," Wohab told me as we eased down a mercifully quiescent Ganges towards the village of Lakshmi Janardhanpur.

"I was from the extremist group of the Marxist-Leninist party," he said quite solemnly. His extraordinary health work he sees as a kind of socialism in action, Marxism with a human face. Wohab is still intensely political, fired up by the myriad injustices you can never get away from in West Bengal and least of all here in the Sunderbans, which have changed little from the description given by one of the early Victorian mapmakers who first came across them: "a sort of drowned land, broken up by swamps, intersected by a thousand river channels and maritime backwaters".

An embryonic system of floating dispensaries was underway before Lapierre came along. But he has made it grow hugely, on the back of Wohab's zeal. This time the enemy is not leprosy, but tuberculosis. Arriving at the village, we climb the mud-bank into a throng of scores of women and children, for whom this day has been long awaited. The doctor sounds and probes, the nurse - Sabitri, whose pioneering work with these people was the beginning of SHIS, of which she is now president - dispenses, Wohab himself supplies his own confident inexpert diagnoses to women who may have walked five hours barefoot to get here. More than 150 people were queuing up. "I lost so many friends from TB," Wohab told me. "I declared a holy war against it."

Not without some victories. These SHIS dispensaries and clinics now serve some 400 riverine villages, and 1,600 on the mainland - the largest non-governmental TB control project in India. In 1998-99, more than 40,000 people were treated for it, all the poorest of the poor. What Lapierre's money bought, as well as a couple more boats, was technology and power-supplies, especially for X-rays.

"I went myself to negotiate the purchase of radiology equipment from the Siemens representative in Calcutta," writes Lapierre. Its arrival in the remote countryside "provoked the sort of stupor a UFO falling out of the sky might have occasioned". But in 10 years, he reckons, TB disappeared from more than 1,000 villages, and 100,000 sick people were cured.

All this is good work. Far better than you or I could do, or probably would do, even with five million to spare. It's not, however, the work of an idealist who is starry-eyed, or unfailingly nice. Alongside the pity, we have the fury, which includes a certain vanity, directed at what the author-amateur sees as the excesses of professional aid organisations by comparison with his own. He, indeed, has no organisation. That is his point. As well as giving, he has the donor's interest in ensuring that the money doesn't go astray. "I find it an absolute scandal that so many welfare organisations spend so much money on running their activities," he said. "My readers, our supporters, know that when they send us a hundred dollars, it is a hundred dollars which will go to Calcutta."

I have no way of verifying that. A Canadian donor, with experience inspecting such projects all over the world, told me as we chugged back up the Ganges that this was nothing special. Indeed, the 600 workers employed - inefficiently, as he thought - by SHIS made it sound like an aid-recipient itself, perhaps a Lapierre-financed exercise in outdoor relief in a social context where one job is commonly reckoned to keep a dozen family members alive. Nothing wrong with that, said my Canadian friend, but why didn't they spend more money fitting out the boat with better equipment for, say, minor surgery?

What nobody could dispute, though, is that this kind of individual effort stays close to the people. There are no layers of offices, stretching back from Calcutta through Delhi to Geneva. Nobody flies first-class, checking into the local Oberoi. "When I read that Ted Turner gives a billion dollars to the United Nations for the poor of the world, I think it's fantastic," Lapierre said. "But I could tell you down to the last dollar what's going to happen to this billion dollars. These big organisations are not equipped to determine the real needs of the people. They don't know what a Bengal farmer really needs. How could they? Unless you have lived as a Bengal farmer, slept in his house, gone through the monsoon with him?"

Here, by contrast, the donor-in-chief is the scourge of all suppliers. "There's no other way than to be extraordinarily attentive," he said. "That begins with the banks in Paris, reducing the commission when you transfer $100,000. Then getting the banks in India to get a decent rate of exchange. Then making sure the contractor who is building your school is really doing what he says in his estimate. One brick in India can be four rupees if it's a good brick, three-and-a-half rupees if one corner is cut, three rupees if two corners are cut, and only two rupees if it is broken in two. Which brick is he going to put in your school and charge you for?"

Equally, he has few illusions about his own people. "You give an ambulance to a centre, you create a problem. Who is going to be the driver? Is he going to steal half the diesel fuel? Is he going to put air in the tyres? When you come next year, is the ambulance going to be running?" As the ambitions expand, so do the problems. "You still have to monitor these extraordinary people very closely. This Wohab is a fabulous person. But he is now asking me for a scanner. A scanner! Many French cities don't have a scanner, and we're in the middle of Bengal!"

To this kind of end, nonetheless, Lapierre is now planning to sell his house outside St Tropez, and provide still further for people who will be depending on him when the literary stream dries up. The action man is approaching 70, and A Thousand Suns sets down a life from which all cynicism has departed. The "pornography of poverty", a phrase sometimes used to classify works, usually TV films, that exploit the poor for little more than voyeuristic ends, cannot conceivably apply to a man with five million dollars in the virtual Bank of Recompense. He doesn't dismiss the ongoing value of the profession he used to follow. "Reporters must tell the world about Rwanda, Kosovo, Chechnya, Venezuela," he said. "It's their duty to make the world aware of those tragedies, to move opinions, to force political leaders to take action. For a battlefield reporter suddenly to drop his camera and become a nurse would be a beautiful individual gesture. But I think, ultimately, his photos would be more important than holding an IV bottle."

He himself just moved on. He discovered that, by becoming an actor, he could change things. To him, it is just another way of dealing with reality. "I still faced reality, like a reporter. But this time with the idea of changing that reality." Anchored defiantly in the world he left, one can't escape the trace of feeling humbled.

 Dominique Lapierre's core charitable fund is: Action Aid for Lepers' Children of Calcutta, 26 Avenue Kleber, 75116 Paris, France.

Here is a health service, carried from the little mainland port of Raidighi to places that may take three days to reach and do not even appear on the maps, yet contain thousands of people who otherwise would see no doctor and get no medicine. After the former British businessman, enter the former Naxalite terrorist, who has become another Lapierre protégé. Wohab is the leader of SHIS, the Southern Health Improvement Samity, who shows that writers aren't the only ones in need of some form of displacement activity. At one time, Wohab ran among killers, but in 1980, under the influence of a Swiss priest, he changed sides. "He persuaded me to change from taking life to giving life," Wohab told me as we eased down a mercifully quiescent Ganges towards the village of Lakshmi Janardhanpur. "I was from the extremist group of the Marxist-Leninist party," he said quite solemnly. His extraordinary health work he sees as a kind of socialism in action, Marxism with a human face. Wohab is still intensely political, fired up by the myriad injustices you can never get away from in West Bengal and least of all here in the Sunderbans, which have changed little from the description given by one of the early Victorian mapmakers who first came across them: "a sort of drowned land, broken up by swamps, intersected by a thousand river channels and maritime backwaters". An embryonic system of floating dispensaries was underway before Lapierre came along. But he has made it grow hugely, on the back of Wohab's zeal. This time the enemy is not leprosy, but tuberculosis. Arriving at the village, we climb the mud-bank into a throng of scores of women and children, for whom this day has been long awaited. The doctor sounds and probes, the nurse - Sabitri, whose pioneering work with these people was the beginning of SHIS, of which she is now president - dispenses, Wohab himself supplies his own confident inexpert diagnoses to women who may have walked five hours barefoot to get here. More than 150 people were queuing up. "I lost so many friends from TB," Wohab told me. "I declared a holy war against it." Not without some victories. These SHIS dispensaries and clinics now serve some 400 riverine villages, and 1,600 on the mainland - the largest non-governmental TB control project in India. In 1998-99, more than 40,000 people were treated for it, all the poorest of the poor. What Lapierre's money bought, as well as a couple more boats, was technology and power-supplies, especially for X-rays. "I went myself to negotiate the purchase of radiology equipment from the Siemens representative in Calcutta," writes Lapierre. Its arrival in the remote countryside "provoked the sort of stupor a UFO falling out of the sky might have occasioned". But in 10 years, he reckons, TB disappeared from more than 1,000 villages, and 100,000 sick people were cured. All this is good work. Far better than you or I could do, or probably would do, even with five million to spare. It's not, however, the work of an idealist who is starry-eyed, or unfailingly nice. Alongside the pity, we have the fury, which includes a certain vanity, directed at what the author-amateur sees as the excesses of professional aid organisations by comparison with his own. He, indeed, has no organisation. That is his point. As well as giving, he has the donor's interest in ensuring that the money doesn't go astray. "I find it an absolute scandal that so many welfare organisations spend so much money on running their activities," he said. "My readers, our supporters, know that when they send us a hundred dollars, it is a hundred dollars which will go to Calcutta." I have no way of verifying that. A Canadian donor, with experience inspecting such projects all over the world, told me as we chugged back up the Ganges that this was nothing special. Indeed, the 600 workers employed - inefficiently, as he thought - by SHIS made it sound like an aid-recipient itself, perhaps a Lapierre-financed exercise in outdoor relief in a social context where one job is commonly reckoned to keep a dozen family members alive. Nothing wrong with that, said my Canadian friend, but why didn't they spend more money fitting out the boat with better equipment for, say, minor surgery? What nobody could dispute, though, is that this kind of individual effort stays close to the people. There are no layers of offices, stretching back from Calcutta through Delhi to Geneva. Nobody flies first-class, checking into the local Oberoi. "When I read that Ted Turner gives a billion dollars to the United Nations for the poor of the world, I think it's fantastic," Lapierre said. "But I could tell you down to the last dollar what's going to happen to this billion dollars. These big organisations are not equipped to determine the real needs of the people. They don't know what a Bengal farmer really needs. How could they? Unless you have lived as a Bengal farmer, slept in his house, gone through the monsoon with him?" Here, by contrast, the donor-in-chief is the scourge of all suppliers. "There's no other way than to be extraordinarily attentive," he said. "That begins with the banks in Paris, reducing the commission when you transfer $100,000. Then getting the banks in India to get a decent rate of exchange. Then making sure the contractor who is building your school is really doing what he says in his estimate. One brick in India can be four rupees if it's a good brick, three-and-a-half rupees if one corner is cut, three rupees if two corners are cut, and only two rupees if it is broken in two. Which brick is he going to put in your school and charge you for?" Equally, he has few illusions about his own people. "You give an ambulance to a centre, you create a problem. Who is going to be the driver? Is he going to steal half the diesel fuel? Is he going to put air in the tyres? When you come next year, is the ambulance going to be running?" As the ambitions expand, so do the problems. "You still have to monitor these extraordinary people very closely. This Wohab is a fabulous person. But he is now asking me for a scanner. A scanner! Many French cities don't have a scanner, and we're in the middle of Bengal!" To this kind of end, nonetheless, Lapierre is now planning to sell his house outside St Tropez, and provide still further for people who will be depending on him when the literary stream dries up. The action man is approaching 70, and A Thousand Suns sets down a life from which all cynicism has departed. The "pornography of poverty", a phrase sometimes used to classify works, usually TV films, that exploit the poor for little more than voyeuristic ends, cannot conceivably apply to a man with five million dollars in the virtual Bank of Recompense. He doesn't dismiss the ongoing value of the profession he used to follow. "Reporters must tell the world about Rwanda, Kosovo, Chechnya, Venezuela," he said. "It's their duty to make the world aware of those tragedies, to move opinions, to force political leaders to take action. For a battlefield reporter suddenly to drop his camera and become a nurse would be a beautiful individual gesture. But I think, ultimately, his photos would be more important than holding an IV bottle." He himself just moved on. He discovered that, by becoming an actor, he could change things. To him, it is just another way of dealing with reality. "I still faced reality, like a reporter. But this time with the idea of changing that reality." Anchored defiantly in the world he left, one can't escape the trace of feeling humbled.  Dominique Lapierre's core charitable fund is: Action Aid for Lepers' Children of Calcutta, 26 Avenue Kleber, 75116 Paris, France.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: In the pink: smoked salmon
fields.trailText: In the pink: smoked salmon
fields.body:
The subject
Should be a great delicacy. Too often industrial slop.

The basics
Take one whole side of high-quality salmon, preferably wild (though this is a matter of opinion) and Scottish (this is undisputed fact). Sprinkle with salt; leave for a while; give the salt the brush-off. Put the fish in a kiln where hardwood smoke circulates freely, at a temperature between 10C and 29C. Leave for 24 hours or so - heavy flavour of smoke. Remove. Eat. You can still buy salmon like this. It can be made in the mild 'London' style, lightly salted and smoked, or the stronger Scottish style. The London style is the original, created by and for European Jewish immigrants.

The details
Aka the problems. First of all, most salmon is farmed and standards vary enormously; some is revoltingly fatty (look for thin, whitish fat layers between the sections of muscle fibre.) Next, not all 'Smoked Scottish Salmon' is Scottish - as long as it's smoked in Scotland, it can be called that, even if it originally came from Bhutan (though Norway is more likely). Third, some producers use short cuts such as brine-injection (fast, cheap, weight-boosting) and spraying with 'liquid smoke' (ditto); some add sugar to counteract the excessive saltiness that results from injecting. So: smoked salmon is cheaper than ever. So: some is not worth buying at any price. A tasting of supermarket packets chez The Knowledge created no clear consensus. Waitrose Organic Orkney (Mild Oak) did well among the mild specimens, Sainsbury's Isle of Skye Traditional (Oak and Beech) among the heavy-smoked. Personal choice: smoked salmon from Forman's, London's premier smoker, with its nice tang, firm texture, and good balance between fishy and smoky flavours.

Where to buy
Forman's: ring 020-8985 4321 for stockists, or online from www.lobster.co.uk or www.formans.co.uk.

The easier-said-than-done way out
Catch your own fish and find a good smokehouse.

fields.headline: Kids' stuff
fields.standfirst: Egg fried rice
fields.trailText: Egg fried rice
fields.body:
160g brown rice

2 tbsp vegetable oil

1 onion, chopped fine

1 red pepper, chopped fine

50g butter

Dark soya sauce, to taste

4 eggs, lightly beaten

Salt and pepper

Fill a large saucepan three-quarters full with cold water. Add a large pinch of salt, and bring to the boil. Add the rice and cook for around 20 minutes, until it is al dente. Drain.

Meanwhile, put the oil in a wide-bottomed pan over medium heat. Add the onion and pepper, and fry off for three to five minutes, without allowing them to brown. Add the butter and soya sauce, and once it has melted, stir in the eggs until they are scrambled. Toss in the drained rice, season and serve immediately with the chicken in lemon cream sauce from last week. Serves four.

 Recipes are devised and cooked at Le Cordon Bleu. Call 020-7935 3503 for details of children's classes.

fields.headline: Drink
fields.standfirst: While the giant brewers continue to standardise their output, Roger Protz gives thanks for a smaller operation that's looking after the great British ale heritage
fields.trailText: While the giant brewers continue to standardise their output, Roger Protz gives thanks for a smaller operation that's looking after the great British ale heritage
fields.body:
King & Barnes of Horsham, West Sussex, a family-owned brewery with a history dating back almost 200 years, has launched a beer-at-home service as part of its campaign to remain independent and fight off an unwelcome takeover bid from Shepherd Neame of Kent.

A phone call, fax or email to the brewery will now get you a tamper-safe box of six beers for the good-value price of £10, plus £3.95 carriage. All six bottle-fermented, which means they contain live yeast and will continue to improve with age, so you might as well order two boxes of the same beer and lay down six of them - though that's not to say the beers aren't ready to drink straight away.

The choice varies - the box I received contained Worthington White Shield, which the Horsham brewery now produces under arrangement with Bass. Other beers in the range include Old Porter, a magnificent interpretation of the 19th-century beer style; a bottled version of the brewery's famous premium draught beer, Festive; Coppercast, a spicy ale made with rye as well as barley malt; Cornucopia, a powerful beer that is a blend of corn and malt; and a delicious pale beer, called Faygate Dragon, that is bursting with citrus fruit from the hops.

The fact that White Shield is now brewed in Horsham has caused some raised eyebrows among beer connoisseurs. That's because, historically, it is a classic beer from Burton-on-Trent, a direct descendant of the India pale ales developed in the early 19th century to refresh ex-pats stationed in the colonies. But White Shield left Burton many years ago, sent by Bass first to a subsidiary brewery in Sheffield and then to Mitchells & Butlers' vast Birmingham beer factory.

Now, however, it's back in safe hands, and the singular character of Burton-brewed beers - the spring waters from the Trent Valley - can be replicated by adding such salts as gypsum and magnesium. In general, I'm not in favour of beers that have been moved away from their original homes, but Bass would have killed off White Shield as a low-volume irritant if King & Barnes hadn't offered to take it on. Crucially, K&B is using Bass's yeasts to ferment the ale: one strain for primary fermentation, a second one for bottle-conditioning.

The Horsham brewery also brews its own bottle-fermented India ale, which is available as part of the take-home service, too. (The full K&B range can be found on www.kingandbarnes.co.uk; tel 01403 270470; fax 01403 225737; email info@kingandbarnes.co.uk.) Devotees of the IPA style can taste both beers side by side, and decide which they prefer.

In the days BC (Before Caffreys), when Bass cared about its great ales, a brewer in Burton told me that Worthington White Shield came into drinkable condition about a month after bottling, was at its best after three months (the length of a sea journey from England to Calcutta in the 19th century) but then mysteriously went out of condition after nine months - this was known as the "sickness period"; then, after a year, it was drinkable again. I tasted some aged White Shield at Burton, and found it remarkably complex. The hops had softened, but there was a rich fruitiness reminiscent of citrus fruits and raisins. I have a dusty nine-year-old that I will crack open soon and compare with a fresh one.

On another note, the trickle of organic beers has yet to become a flood, but the number is slowly increasing. It's especially encouraging when one of the big hitters among regional brewers joins the small band of chemical-free producers. Fuller's of west London, famous for its London Pride and ESB bitters, has brewed a pale Honey Dew beer for several years, mainly for the spring and summer. For the past year, however, it has been experimenting with organic materials in order to turn Honey Dew into a fully-fledged organic ale. The result - brewed from English organic barley malt and Target hops grown by Peter Hall at Marden in Kent, the only regular grower of chemical-free hops - was launched last month. As the name suggests, the beer's ingredients also include fresh honey, which imparts a pleasant and not overly sweet character to the aroma and flavour. The result is a complex ale with a rich aroma, a palate of juicy malt, honey and spicy hops, and a long, lingering, bitter-sweet finish. Honey Dew is 5% alcohol in bottle. A draught, cask-conditioned version at 4.3% will be available in Fuller's pubs and the free trade during the spring (for more information, call Fuller's on 020-8996 2000)

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck prefers to take his time
fields.body:
In a crowded room, fairly full of chattering homo sapiens , with the odd malodorous individual wafting by ('Should have washed under your armpits, Nigel, and did you have a fag outside?' or, worse, though thankfully less frequently, 'Isn't that Scandale you're wearing, Hortensia? It smells so je ne sais quoi on you'), the wine scribe plies his trade among the serried ranks of bottles into which producers the world over have poured the fruits of a year's labour in a vineyard, several intense weeks activity in a winery and, perhaps, a year or more's assiduous nurturing in a cellar.

In this press of humanity, judgments are made on scores of wines that are not, like the bottle you will open for dinner tonight, sipped at leisure but instead are gathered hastily into the mouth, swilled around the palate and then ejected into a spitoon. It is possibly to effect such stoicism that the problems of the crowd are largely mitigated, but the problems of the relationship between each wine is, largely, one that few tasters successfully overcome. Can each wine really be expertly judged on its individual merits, if that individuality is effected by each wine tasted before it and every wine tasted afterwards? The wine that wins a gold at many a fatuous competition often has an impact totally at variance with its true worth.

I am not now going to suggest that all this week's wines are overly subtle, but I do consider that they are wines that would be ignored by wine competition judges. Take a red at Asda: Puglia Toggia 1998 (15 points, out of 20, £3.99), an Italian that shows interesting layers of flavour which go from dry herbiness to cherry/plumminess and back again. Its progress over the taste buds is slow. It would not fare well in a big competition to find the best red of the year, but is still terrific value for money and hugely quaffable.

Majestic has a Spaniard in much the same position: Tempranillo Vina Armantes Calatayud 1997 (15.5 points, £3.99). It is savoury, dry, full (never, though, blowsy or too ripe), deeply flavoured and finishes with some multi-layered richness of fruit.

Oddbins has Domaine Saint Jullien Cteaux du Languedoc 1998 (15.5 points, £3.99). Nigel would regard the brightness and ripeness of the fruit as too full. Hortensia's receding gums would find the tannins too assertive. For my money, however, this is a splendid specimen of drinkability and unpretentious fruitiness. Standing beside some brute from the Barossa, it would seem tardy, even a mite grouchy, but for the drinker who is prepared to take the time to let the wine have its way, the reward is a provocative experience of rusticity yet classiness.

The mencia grape is most certainly rustic, confined as it is to north-western Spain. Safeway has an entertaining example of it in El Leon Bierzo 1998 (15 points, £3.99). It has bite, freshness and an attractive cherry/plum dry-ness. In a wine competition, it would be drowned by the din of a hundred others.

But whether the same fate would engulf Safeway's Merlot 24 Selection Frederic Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (15.5 points, £4.49), I am not so sure, because there is something in the finish that might even make Hortensia's tongue sit up. It is very dry, yet also curiously rounded and ripe. It is nicely textured and plump, with a raisiny echo as it quits the throat that suggests it has reached its apogee of drinkability. Mencia is not a variety to make wines that age. The same is true of cinsault, and in Safeway's own-label South African Cinsault 1998 (16 points, £3.99) there is a wonderful immediacy, which reminds this drinker of a marriage of great Beaujolais and stunning Ctes du Rhne. It has brilliant softness and richness.

Last this week, what of Hardys Chardonnay/Sauvignon Blanc 1998 (£3.99) at Somerfield? It is a very alert blend that compresses the athletic virtues of both grapes: the long-distance muscularity of chardonnay with the freshness of the sprinting sauvignon. This unlikely union may win no golds, but it rates 16 points.
