fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Never was a name more fitting, says Matthew Fort of the Star Inn
fields.trailText: Never was a name more fitting, says Matthew Fort of the Star Inn
fields.body:
I'd never have found it if it hadn't been for the General. I followed him across Yorkshire and along a bewildering series of dual carriageways, roads, back roads and lanes, all at dizzying speeds. At least, they were dizzying to me. The General seemed to think that it had all been a bit of a breeze when I taxed him about this on our arrival at the Star.

Do you ever have that feeling, as soon as you walk into a place, when you know that you've hit the jackpot in terms of creature comforts? Well, I had that feeling as we crossed the threshold of the Star. In fact, I had it as soon as I clapped eyes on the Star, sitting prettily off a back road on the edge of the village of Harome. It just looked nice: properly nice, pleasant, sensible. It has that traditional crepuscular lighting, too, that no amount of art can achieve. It had real beams, real fires, real beer and real food. It had fine wines, judiciously priced. It had delightful, intelligent service. And it had those qualities that are rarer than rubies and more valuable than frankincense: warmth, both genuine and deep, consideration, and an innate feeling for what you, or at least I, want.

What I wanted more than anything was to draw up a chair by the fire, sit down and meditate on the menu over a pint of Black Sheep. So that is what I did, while all around people went on grazing through their lunches. You can eat in a thoroughly comfortable and well-appointed, half-timbered dining room, which is fine for high days and holidays, but which for my money could not match the winning charm of the bar and the fire. It also allowed me to scrutinise the dishes as they were brought in, so that I could better make up my mind, among the first courses, between terrine of gammon with fried quail's egg; risotto of chanterelles, red chard and Twineham Grange Parmesan; and smoked salmon with grilled scallops and cucumber relish (relishes, chutneys and dressings are something of a feature on this menu). And, for the mains, between braised lamb shank with pearl barley "risotto" (their inverted commas) and root vegetables; fricassée of chicken with oyster mushrooms and baby spinach; and braised faggots with oxtail hash, red onion marmalade and ale juices.

Although mightily tempted, I did not opt for the faggots. No, I decided on the dishes of the day: calves' liver with spring greens, preceded by a terrine of herring and potato, and caper mayonnaise. The General settled down to a few slices of home-cured beef and salad of ox tongue, pickled red onion and horseradish dressing, following up with duck sausages, creamed cabbage mash and baked beans. Not any old baked beans, as he pointed out, but, like everything else, made in-house. Okay, so this is all on the bold and hearty side, but I like bold and hearty. You know where you are with it. And there's no wondering which menu this kind of food has been cloned from. There are a few modish Mediterranean dishes and touches, but for the most part native ingredients are used with native wit and intelligence to make suitably updated native dishes in an identifiably English tradition. On top of all that, it was jolly good.

The potato in the terrine was just cooked through, enough to define a different texture from that of the sweet herring. There was dill in evidence, and a rich bite from the caper mayo. It was all very fresh-tasting, light and morally uplifting. The General's beef and tongue was a smart representation of traditional elements - the grainy-textured beef showing off the benefits of a sprightly cure, the smooth density of the tongue sitting happily with the leafy freshness of the salad.

My liver showed a similar benefit from care and thought. There were two thick slices, whose thickness means you get a sequence of textures, from the crisp outside to the melting tenderness of the middle. The red-wine sauce with which they came was almost too forceful in its attentions, but the greens had a sparkling brilliance and were squeaky with spring. The General raised an eyebrow at the scale model of the Matterhorn made of mash and sausages that appeared before him, muttered something about "Yorkshire portions", and then set to with a will, and levelled the plate. He allowed me a portion of sausage along the way. It was sweet-flavoured and equal to the finest conventional banger, marrying particularly well with the potato and cabbage mash. It wasn't a dish for the nibbler or those under doctor's orders, but it had splendid vigour.

Perhaps not surprisingly, the General decided to call it a day at this point. I could not resist, however, the promise of baked ginger parkin with hot spiced treacle and rhubarb-ripple ice cream, and I defy any other right-thinking person to do so. This was a brilliant addition to the roll of honour of British puddings - tart, tasty, spicy, racy and plum duff delicious - and, at £4.50, a snip for so splendid a dish.

In fact, I couldn't fault the Star on the pricing front, either. A fillet steak at £13.95 represents top whack. The home-cured beef, which could easily do lunch for a lesser trencherperson than the General, is £5.50. The potato-and-herring terrine was a mighty £4.95, the liver a monster £10.95 and the duck sausages an epic £7.95. True, we boosted the bill with a bottle of easy-virtued Chteauneuf-du-Pape at £27.50, and there was a bit of water, coffee, etc, but our food bill was comfortably under £40, which for quality as well as quantity is outrageous.

The Star is run by Andrew and Jacquie Pern. He cooks. She looks after you. Like the Star, they should be treasured

fields.headline: Cabin fever
fields.standfirst: Forget those images of damp, murky interiors - a barge can give you a smart city centre address at a beautiful price. Lesley Gillilan wants to moor for her money
fields.trailText: Forget those images of damp, murky interiors - a barge can give you a smart city centre address at a beautiful price. Lesley Gillilan wants to moor for her money
fields.body:
There can't be much more than 3ft of water between Rick and Sue Wall's floating home and the Bristol harbour quay that provides their moorings. Yet, for them, there is a psychological distance between the two that represents a complete escape from dry land. They might as well have left the mainland for an island.

Until a year ago, the Walls lived in a big, cluttered Victorian townhouse barely a mile from the city docks. A series of mid-life crises prompted them to subject their old lives to a process of "drastic surgery". They sold everything - absolutely everything - bought Isobel, a half-converted industrial barge, and transformed her into a modernist dream boat. "We made a huge leap in a new direction," says Rick. "It was a very scary thing to do." I found it scary enough just crossing that 3ft gap: getting on to the Isobel is a case of clattering down a gangway that, in keeping with the rest of the boat, has been reinvented as a zig-zag of aluminium steps.

There are, however, even more frightening ways of getting on to boats. Visit the Walls' stern-end neighbours, Richard Rankin and Theresa Blosse, and you have to reverse down a ladder, navigate a path across the roof of their cabin (past a smoking chimney and a television aerial), and clamber into their narrowboat quarters - backwards.

There are more conventional ways, too. The front door of Vicky Cairns's Heloise Bay (at the bow end of the Isobel) is reached by a robust set of wooden steps with a proper handrail. She's even got a door-knocker and a cat-flap; though there is nothing conventional about the hand-painted scenes of riverside wildlife that provide a backdrop to Cairns's small, on-deck garden.

In wild, windy weather, the steps are prone to swing from side to side with the slight, but perceptible, movement of the boat. And what a surprise, when you step below-deck, to find a huge - indeed vast - open-plan space stuffed with, well, stuff; the kind of stuff that you really don't expect to find on boats: standard lamps, portraits of Edwardian grandmothers and an upright piano.

This rich diversity of lifestyle - the different means to the same end - is one of the things that attracted the Walls to join Bristol's dockland community of "boat people". There are dozens of them spread out around the city's floating harbour. Clinging to wharf walls between bridges, below modern office blocks and converted Victorian warehouses, they include water-borne homes of every description, from canal boats and converted barges to ordinary motor cruisers that you wouldn't know were homes, were it not for the net curtains.

Rankin and Blosse are, perhaps, the stereotypical boat people. For them, there is almost no life beyond the water. Rankin builds boats and operates a private pleasure cruiser; Theresa runs the "Friends of the Swans", the volunteers who feed the 200 or so birds that glide around the docks. She also looks after their five-month-old son, Noah. And though the couple are far from conventional, their home, Excalibur, is what you'd expect of boat life. A traditional narrowboat, it's barely wider than a double bed - the route from one end to the other is an assault course of armchairs, baby buggies and dog baskets.

There are compensations, says Richard. Unlike her bigger neighbours, Excalibur is fully mobile. You can take her on a spin around the docks and back again. You can even travel down the Kennet and Avon Canal to Bath. "It only takes a week."

The Isobel used to move, too, but that was more than 100 years ago, when it ran between Bristol and Bath carrying cargoes of tar. Now, it's going nowhere: Rick and Sue Wall removed the engine to make more space - masses of light, open space. Again, it's not what you expect of a boat home but, more frequently, it is what you get. Broad-beamed industrial river barges, both English and Dutch, have become the floating equivalents of the New York-style loft. In the Walls' case, even the process of conversion has direct parallels.

The Isobel had been lived in before, but it was little more than a shell when they first saw her. "The ceiling was barely higher than I am," says Sue. "It was very dark inside, with windows across the top but none at water level." They employed an architect and a boat builder (neither had worked with anyone in the other's profession before), and drew up a brief that, says Sue, "threw out the rule book on boat decor".

The initial response was along the lines of "It's not very classical, is it? Where's the tongue-and-groove?" But the Walls persisted, and their happy alliance with both architect and builder produced the nearest Bristol gets to a Modern movement house boat. The exterior, for example, is clad in copper and features a long, canopied deck bordered by shrubbery arranged in lines of aluminium planters. Inside, it's all white paint, raw plaster, pale-wood floors, black leather and stainless steel.

Taking the minimalist route was not about following the diktats of fashion, insists Rick: "It was about saying that one part of our life is over, so what's next?" The couple had lived in the same house for 20 years, raised three children, worked in high-pressure jobs; they wanted the boat to encapsulate the risks they'd taken in leaving all that behind. "To us, minimalism is about having no more than one plant to water," explains Sue, adding that the flower arrangements are realistic fakes. "We wanted a simple, low-maintenance life. Friends who knew us in our old house, say things like, 'Where do you put your nick-nacks?' We don't put them anywhere. We don't have them anymore." What they do have is "a nice balance between living right in the inner city, but having something natural going on outside".

According to Rick and Sue, there's a big difference between "just looking at the water and actually feeling part of it". In their book, you don't get to be part of it just by buying a flat with a watery view. I see what they mean when I step below deck and into their loft-like living space, where the surface of the green, urban waterway sits just below a line of tall, unboaty windows and just above floor level. A constant procession of passing vessels (water taxis, "booze cruisers", canoes, etc), sends a gentle ripple of waves sloshing against the side of the boat.

The Walls have not only got to know the neighbours across the "street" (Pete the plumber; a musician who plays euphonium), but they've also got to know the birds by name. Sylvester, the "guard goose", is a frequent visitor. They have even become a feature of tourist-boat commentary: "Look everyone, there's the Isobel: the only boat where the swans can watch the television through the windows."

Neighbour Vicky Cairns agrees that the close proximity of water makes boat-life attractive. But, in other respects, it's not much different from living in a house, she says. "It costs less than a house - certainly less than a city-centre house." In fact, a quick comparison with harbour-side flats suggests we are probably looking at twice the space for roughly two-thirds of the money. Vicky needs a lot of space for her huge collection of stuff (maps, china, glassware, souvenirs of travels in India, clocks, wind-chimes, pictures of boats). Despite all the possessions, she has so much space here that her young son, Rowan, plays cricket indoors.

The downside, she adds, is the water. Not the river water, but the tanks of the stuff she has to get from a stand-pipe every 10 days or so. This is a curiosity of Bristol; many permanent moorings elsewhere have running water. But boat-owners everywhere have to take their vessels into dry dock every five years to scrape the barnacles off the hull and so qualify for insurance.

There are other problems. Mooring fees are high, though not as high as London. And there are risks in buying boats without a marine survey. Sue and Rick Wall did but, in retrospect, they can't believe how lucky they were. "We've since heard horrible stories about people innocently buying boats with major structural problems," says Rick.

Another unexpected revelation is other people's perception of boat life, ranging from snobbery and prejudice ("If you live a few feet from the land, people think you are an itinerant," says Rick) to blatant curiosity ("We have become a kind of tourist attraction") to simple misunderstandings. "We've invited friends around for dinner, and they've said things like, 'Oh, we'll wear something warm. It gets chilly on the river at night, doesn't it?'" says Sue.

But they have no regrets. "Our old lives became grey and stressed," says Sue. "The new one has been relaxing and terribly liberating." It's the perfect solution for tired city people who are looking for an escape - without really going anywhere.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: www.geistafabrik.com
fields.body:
One of my admirers emailed to tell me that there's a site (www.geistafabrik.com/widerstand ) where you can give Jorge Haider a virtual beating. The site is in German, so I couldn't get anywhere. Haider would have been a poor substitute for Migraine Alan, the true object of my wrath after the weekend fiasco, but I was intrigued by the notion of 'virtual beating', so I entered the words in the Mamma search engine.

I girded myself for the sleaziest sites on the net, the kind that advertise the video of Pamela Anderson and Tommy Lee uncut, but to my surprise what I got instead was The Church Of Sarah Michelle Gellar, Save Souls and Virtual Jerusalem.com, offering the Torah channel. You find God in the oddest places these days.

Patrick, my hairdresser, was driven to drink by his saga with his scanner (he was told by someone at technical support that the product is so cheap - £60 - it's not worth their while to offer a guarantee), so I decided to intervene. I emailed Andy Black at www.action.com, the retailers, who was magnificent, and sorted it all out. Patrick is so repentant that he has offered to do my hair for free when it grows again. In the meantime, I needed a wig, so I found www.Paulayoung.com. There are dozens of models, all 100% natural hair. I chose Flame/A Pixie With Presence (very me), modelled by Raquel Welch ($59). Lightweight Shag sounded tempting, too, but I know from experience that it seldom works.

Mum is still in Assisted Hatching in the clinic up north. She seems quite upbeat about it. 'I don't care what Tony does: Mike will have to take paternity leave,' she said adamantly. Mike works for Rover (you can still buy a Rover with confidence - www.rover.co.uk) so I don't think that will be a problem when the time comes.

fields.headline: The poor relation
fields.standfirst: The magnificent tulip doesn't get the attention it deserves. Christopher Lloyd is baffled as to why
fields.trailText: The magnificent tulip doesn't get the attention it deserves. Christopher Lloyd is baffled as to why
fields.body:
We are now into the high season for tulips - and what a joy they are, especially when responding to the warmth of sunshine and opening wide to reveal those extraordinary colours and designs so often to be seen at the bloom's centre.

There will be a tulip competition at the RHS show in Westminster at the end of the month, but it can be guaranteed to be a non-event. It is curious that whereas narcissi have always received great attention within the Society, tulips have remained the poor relations. One theory I have heard to explain this is that the Dutch have done so much work on tulips that the RHS felt themselves upstaged and therefore looked the other way.

And yet tulips have far greater scope for development and variation than narcissi. I would add that they have far more personality. Narcissi are po-faced, always looking in the same direction, always predictable, never changing in response to sunshine or cloud, to warmth or to cold. This makes them reliable exhibition material; you know where you are with them. Whereas tulips are wayward and fool - or dazzle - you with all kinds of antics. Like the characters in a Dostoevsky novel, you never know quite where you stand with them.

I am growing more than ever this year. There are always places to be found for them if you look, though you may not be ready to plant them straight away. It was after Christmas before we had planted our last, but tulips are very forgiving.

There are two ways of growing them as garden plants (we also grow them in containers, of course): either as spring bedding, in which case the bulbs will need to be lifted to make way for a summer sequence, or as permanencies among perennials or near to deciduous shrubs.

If your tulips need to be lifted while still in full growth, don't replant them, hoping they won't have noticed the disturbance. You can't fool a tulip. Knock most of the soil off their roots and lay them on racks in a cool, airy shed. There they will withdraw nutrients back from stems and leaves into the bulbs. When sere, finish the job; pull out the withered stems, rub off any remaining soil from the bulbs and store them somewhere mouse-proof for the summer. We hang them in net bags (labelled) from a horizontal pole between two cross-beams. Squirrels would not be foiled, but mice are. At some stage (in that wet weather that never seems to materialise), we sort through our bulbs, separating those that are (or look) large enough to be used again for bedding next year from those that don't. We don't throw these away, but line them out to grow on and be used again for bedding the year after.

If you retain old bulbs, you give them the chance of "breaking" and of making for you those remarkable stripy tulips that feature in all the old Dutch flower paintings and were so highly regarded at that time, but which it has become illegal to sell, because we now know that "breaking" is caused by virus infection. Like eating of the tree of knowledge, we can no longer live in happy ignorance. The viruses are still there and can never be eliminated, but we now go through the motions of shutting the stable door and pretending that the horse hasn't bolted, while knowing full well that it has.

So, if we want broken tulips (and who wouldn't?), we must let them occur on retained stock in our own gardens - which will quickly happen sooner rather than later, (the viruses are spread by aphids, which are ever with us) although always with unpredictable results. I haven't the space to go further into the subject here but you should certainly read Anna Pavord's fascinating monograph, The Tulip (published by Bloomsbury), for the full story. She writes with restrained passion and with a great deal of research behind her.

The second way of growing tulips, as border permanencies, is full of possibilities, as you discover more ways in which to use them. I grow a lot of border phloxes ( Phlox paniculata and its cultivars); my heavy soil suits them. They need replanting every three or four years, but this gives me the opportunity of running tulips between their clumps and thereby pepping up an area in spring that would otherwise be rather dull. We did this with a late-flowering orange (flushed pink) tulip called 'Dillenburg', which is now coming up for its third season. And where there was initially one bulb, there are now clumps of several. Any gardener will appreciate how satisfying, not to say flattering, this is. The tulips really like us; hurrah!

But how shall we act when we really must rejuvenate our phlox plantings? That cannot for much longer be delayed. We can do it in the autumn, but cannot contemplate pulling the border to pieces until November, as we pride ourselves on our lively October garden. By November, the tulips will already be making strong new roots and the check would be serious. The answer is that we shall lift them during the summer, while their tops are still visible but they are fully dormant; then store them until we are ready to plant in November. Stored dry, they will remain dormant.

In other parts of the border, the tulips never need disturbing, as they are among perennials that detest disturbance. For instance, we have had the Darwin Hybrid 'Red Matador' with Eryngium x oliverianum for 30 years, and the tulip clumps are enormous

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Betty Schimmel
fields.trailText: Betty Schimmel
fields.body:
Betty Schimmel, now in her 70s, was born in Budapest. Before the war, she planned to marry her childhood sweetheart, Richie. But, in 1944, the Nazis sent Betty and her family to a concentration camp in Austria, and they lost contact. She survived, went on to marry and moved to America, but never forgot Richie. Thirty years on, she visited Budapest and met him by chance. To See You Again, Betty's book about the two loves of her life, is currently being made into a movie. She has three children and lives in Arizona.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Health in the family.

What is your greatest fear?
Losing somebody in my family.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Golda Meir - for what she has accomplished for Israel.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
I am too critical.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Gossip.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Buying expensive clothing.

What objects do you always carry with you?
A heart necklace.

Where would you like to live?
By water - Nice or Monaco.

What makes you depressed?
Illness.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
Being fat.

What is your favourite smell?
Lily of the valley.

What is your favourite building?
Parliament Building in Budapest.

What is your favourite fantasy?
To trek in the Himalayas

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
No.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
Yes.

For what cause would you die?
To save my children.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My husband.

What is your greatest regret?
That I had no schooling.

How do you relax?
When I paint.

What would your motto be?
Live and let live.

Do you believe in life after death?
No.

How would you like to be remembered?
As a decent person.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Live one day at a time.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum:  Et tu, Sweetie
fields.standfirst: 'You know Gordon had other affairs while he was married to you?' Stay calm
fields.trailText: 'You know Gordon had other affairs while he was married to you?' Stay calm
fields.body:
"So, I see Gordon's got what he wanted: you're back together." Elaine has invited me out to lunch, so we may revile our ex-husband. But her opening salvo falls short. "Oh no!" I warble gaily. "We're a post-nuclear family kinship group."

Elaine glowers. She's angrier with him than I am. Although I am irritated by his habit of sprawling on the sofa staring at the TV while his aunt follows me about the house with news of her latest suppurating blisters. Uneasily aware that the platonic uplands of the post-nuclear kinship system are riddled with treacherous old mine-shafts of ancient grudge.

"The special today is organic guinea fowl with mange touts, saffron couscous, lightly sautéed plantain and a coulis of blood orange and cassis," announces a beautiful blonde woman who has arrived at our table. We are at Montezuma, a new bistro. "All our veg are organically grown, although I'm afraid the mange touts are from Israel," she acknowledges, with a graceful shrug. Experience sudden atavistic urge for fish and chips. We order, and then hostilities resume. As Elaine sees it, she is not getting enough maintenance. Although it must be said she is living in a Georgian rectory with Tom, a young plumber who adores her. I was adored once.

"So, how's the restoration going?" I attempt to divert her attention from the painful topic of our ex-husband's penury. This was a mistake. Her face clouds over with a fury. "Tom's been re-plumbing all winter," she seethes. "He took all the fucking radiators out, in November! Imagine! With a child in the house!" Recall the house of the childless Elaine, years ago, before we reached our present impasse. Her sofas were cloudy, her carpets immaculate seas of virgin beige, and her thermostats turned right up to keep her warm in her elegant little shifts of coral silk.

It is hard not to feel a slight tremor of pleasure at the sight of her now, looking plump in a scratchy old Aztec sweater that I am sure Tom gave her for Christmas. Also, she is going grey. Et tu, Sweetie.

"Still, once we've done the floors and painted the attic, Country Living is going to do a piece about it." Express admiration, though trying to avoid choking on the Israeli mange touts. Nowadays, I cannot tackle anything with strings. I could choke just listening to the Amadeus Quartet. "We took photos of the filthy mess it was when we bought it," she goes on, effortlessly swallowing mange touts with mysterious confidence. "The kitchen was covered with ghastly flowery tiles from top to bottom." Express outrage and incredulity, while preparing a stiletto of innuendo.

"It must be costing a bomb."

Oh happy moment! Elaine goes red, then pale.

"The whole thing is being paid for by Tom's inheritance!" she cries guiltily.

"His father died two years ago - otherwise, we couldn't even have considered it."

Feel I have disconcerted her, however, and moments later she brings out the big one. "I expect you know that Gordon had other affairs while he was married to you," she hazards, watching me intently. I remain calm. These are the infidelities of history. They no more concern me than Rasputin's putting it about or JFK's anti-migraine medication of a "strange piece of ass" daily. Besides, I am now engaging with the guinea fowl, whose ass is even stranger.

"There was Sally, that lecturer," Elaine drives on relentlessly . . . and that girl who Alice had an affair with - the bisexual." Recall the vivacious Elly. Not surprised, really, that she managed to screw Spouse, as she seemed determined to shaft the whole family. Even I felt her hot breath on my neck. Express my lofty disenchantment with men.

Elaine's eyes flare with excitement. She is evidently approaching some pinnacle of the unpalatable. "Of course," she says, "Tom was unfaithful to you, too - with some raving beauty called Francesca." Choke on my lofty disenchantment.

"Frankly, my dear," I splutter, "I don't give two hoots."

On the way home, though, I give enough hoots to keep Bill Oddie happy for hours. Wish I was a female spider. They eat their blokes, which saves a lot of trouble.

fields.headline: Making bacon
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: Monday, April 3, 2000, Arthur Askey Way
fields.body:
Monday, April 3, 2000, Arthur Askey Way

My love affair with Pamela moved into a sexual stage tonight, though "full union", as she calls it, has yet to take place. Pamela is a fan of the female condom, but, after examining one she took out of her briefcase, we discovered that it had been issued in 1998. We decided not to risk it. Pam was keen to consummate, saying, "I just want to get it out of the way, Adrian."

I explained that I hadn't kept condoms in the house since William took one to nursery school as his contribution to the hot-air-balloon mural. It was an eagle-eyed Ofsted inspector who spotted the "big boy arouser" rising between the cotton-wool cloud.

Pamela asked me if I'd like to go to Stockport next weekend to meet her parents. I lied and said, "Yes, Wiggly." She asked me to call her Wiggly. She calls me Snuffly. I've had a slight head cold since we met.

Tuesday, April 4

The Ludlows held a welcome home from prison party for Vince tonight. I went next door at 10pm, after William and Glenn had gone to bed. I don't want my boys to associate the word "prison" with the word "party". Vince said he had seen Jonathan Aitken in the prison chapel, and had witnessed Mr Aitken's religious fervour. Vince said, " 'e was shakin' 'is tambourine so 'ard that 'is Rolex fell off". Vince told me to back Papillon in the Grand National. I said it was highly unlikely that another son/jockey and father/ trainer combination would win.

I rang Pamela as soon as I got home. She said she was in bed with a Trollope. "Anthony or Joanna?" I asked. Pamela laughed, as though I'd made a joke.

Thursday, April 6

The Piggs' don't like children, so my mother is babysitting William for the weekend and Glenn is going to his mother's.

Pamela warned me tonight not to tell her father that I am an unpublished poet and novelist. I pointed out that I have published two cookery books: Offaly Good and Offaly Good Again. She told me that her father was a militant vegetarian and a former RAF kayak instructor. I dread meeting Mr Pigg.

Friday, April 7, The Olde Forge, Stockport

He is even worse than I feared. "Call me Porky!" he boomed. He was wearing a sort of fleecy Babygro garment and rubber socks. He had just returned from a training session on an artificial slalom course on the River Tees. He has offered to take me down the rapids in his double kayak on Sunday. Mrs Pigg was loading her van in preparation for a country fayre, at which she sells the hedgehog boot scrapers she makes out of pine cones and plastic bristles.

As Mrs Pigg was showing me to my single bed, she asked me to call her Snouty. When I enquired what her real Christian name was, she glared and said, "Why are you presuming that my parents were Christians?" I told her I'd seen the photograph on the mantelpiece of her parents' wedding, which had been taken outside a church and been attended by a vicar holding a copy of the Old Testament. She said that I "mustn't bother" Pamela in the night, as Mr Pigg did not approve of sex before long-term commitment.

Saturday, April 8

The Piggs took me to a Beefeater restaurant for dinner tonight. A cardboard cut-out of the TV chef Brian Turner welcomed us in. The conversation ground to a halt over pre-dinner drinks, when Porky discovered that I am a single father living in a council house. The tension was palpable. Pamela developed a most unflattering tic in her left eye.

But all was not lost because Porky and I chose the lightly breaded deep-fried mushrooms at £2.95 (with a choice of two dips). Porky and I now have something in common: we will talk about our Beefeater experience for many years to come.

Thank you, Mr Turner.

fields.headline: How to be sorry
fields.trailText: Apologies are the old rubber tyres that are hung over the sides of huge egos to prevent damage when they rub up against each other
fields.body:
Apologies are the old rubber tyres that are hung over the sides of huge egos to prevent damage when they rub up against each other. Apologies are all the rage these days. If you can't stomach an apology, you can say instead that you regret something. This is shorthand for, 'I regret being in a situation where an apology is called for'. In fact, modern apologies don't mean that you apologise, that you regret anything or that you are at fault. They're just the most polite way in which you can say, 'I dislike you intensely.'

An apology can be short-term pain for long-term gain. An apology, played right, can actually give you the upper hand. First of all, you've shown that you're big enough to admit that you're wrong. Second, you've obviously had to take the pain, so you are in some way the victim and they are the brutal oppressor, even though they're right on some slim technical grounds. From this position, you can either counter-attack - 'I've said I'm sorry. What do you want? Blood!?'; or you can play the self-flagellation card - 'I'm wrong, I'm always wrong, I'm a worthless human being'; or there's the philosophical approach - 'Factually, you're right, but in moral terms I'm right.'

A breezy apology can be very annoying. Quickly saying, 'I'm sorry, what an idiot I am', denies the other person the chance to say, 'Apologise, you idiot.' Never repeat the fault in the apology. 'I'm sorry I called you a grumpy old trout, and I want everyone here to know that.' If you're really sorry, you can send a huge bunch of flowers and a little note saying, 'I'm sorry I made fun of your pollen allergy.'

Apologising on behalf of other people is also a good tactic. Try arriving late at a meeting and saying, 'I'm sorry you all arrived early.' Expert apologisers apologise even when it's obvious that they're absolutely right. This gives the impression not that they're sorry, but that they're sorry for you for being such a loser.

The only time it's really easy to say sorry is when saying sorry simply isn't enough. 'I'm sorry I blew your leg off,' doesn't really do it. What's called for is a lifetime of remorse. And you can't just say, 'I've blown your leg off, I can feel a lifetime of remorse coming on.' You've got to feel it, live it and show it, even though, deep in your heart, you know it was really their leg at fault.
fields.bodyText: Apologies are the old rubber tyres that are hung over the sides of huge egos to prevent damage when they rub up against each other. Apologies are all the rage these days. If you can't stomach an apology, you can say instead that you regret something. This is shorthand for, 'I regret being in a situation where an apology is called for'. In fact, modern apologies don't mean that you apologise, that you regret anything or that you are at fault. They're just the most polite way in which you can say, 'I dislike you intensely.' An apology can be short-term pain for long-term gain. An apology, played right, can actually give you the upper hand. First of all, you've shown that you're big enough to admit that you're wrong. Second, you've obviously had to take the pain, so you are in some way the victim and they are the brutal oppressor, even though they're right on some slim technical grounds. From this position, you can either counter-attack - 'I've said I'm sorry. What do you want? Blood!?'; or you can play the self-flagellation card - 'I'm wrong, I'm always wrong, I'm a worthless human being'; or there's the philosophical approach - 'Factually, you're right, but in moral terms I'm right.' A breezy apology can be very annoying. Quickly saying, 'I'm sorry, what an idiot I am', denies the other person the chance to say, 'Apologise, you idiot.' Never repeat the fault in the apology. 'I'm sorry I called you a grumpy old trout, and I want everyone here to know that.' If you're really sorry, you can send a huge bunch of flowers and a little note saying, 'I'm sorry I made fun of your pollen allergy.' Apologising on behalf of other people is also a good tactic. Try arriving late at a meeting and saying, 'I'm sorry you all arrived early.' Expert apologisers apologise even when it's obvious that they're absolutely right. This gives the impression not that they're sorry, but that they're sorry for you for being such a loser. The only time it's really easy to say sorry is when saying sorry simply isn't enough. 'I'm sorry I blew your leg off,' doesn't really do it. What's called for is a lifetime of remorse. And you can't just say, 'I've blown your leg off, I can feel a lifetime of remorse coming on.' webTitle: Testosterone can improve men's chat-up lines

fields.headline: Testosterone can improve men's chat-up lines
fields.standfirst: How hormones affect map reading
fields.trailText: Men with high levels of testosterone may be better at chatting up women than those with low levels of the male sex hormone, research suggests.
fields.body:
Men with high levels of testosterone may be better at chatting up women than those with low levels of the male sex hormone, research suggests.

Tests on healthy young men given a weekly injection of testosterone showed a 20% improvement in their verbal fluency skills within four weeks.

The research, led by Daryl O'Connor from the University of Manchester, also found a reduced spatial ability among the men tested.

The research, for the World Health Organisation, studied 30 men aged 18 to 40, half of whom were given a weekly injection of 200mg of testosterone for eight weeks, while the other half were given placebo injection.

A 200mg dose of testosterone is the same as that contained in the male contraceptive, and suggests that the research may have wide ranging implications for male sexual functioning and anabolic steroid use, and also for other behaviour believed to be affected by hormones, such as road rage.

The men were asked to perform a range of neuro-psychological tests after one week, four weeks and at the end of the study.

As well as tests in motor co-ordination and memory recall, they were tested for verbal fluency. They were asked to name as many words as possible beginning with a particular letter in one minute, and this test was done three times.

On average, all the men were able to name a total of 40 words in the first week, but while those who were not given testosterone did not improve their word count four weeks later, those given the hormone were able to name between six and eight extra words, a 20% increase.

Although this improvement was sustained in week eight, there was no further improvement after week four.

At the same time, the men given testosterone performed worse in spatial ability tests, such as map reading, than the men in the placebo group over the eight weeks of the study.

Dr O'Connor said: "This provides a preliminary insight that testosterone may have non-sexual benefits, with a role to play in mental functioning. It also suggests there might be an optimal level of testosterone."

It is generally accepted that women outperform men in verbal tests and that men perform better in spatial awareness, and also that women's verbal fluency improves when their oestrogen levels are at their highest, but this is the first research testing the effect of the male sex hormone on men.

webTitle: Prison for perjurer cleared of murder

fields.headline: Prison for perjurer cleared of murder
fields.trailText: A man cleared of murder more than 10 years ago was yesterday jailed for perjury after eventually having admitted killing his victim.
fields.body:
A man cleared of murder more than 10 years ago was yesterday jailed for perjury after eventually having admitted killing his victim.

At his first trial in 1991, William Dunlop, 36, from Billingham in Teesside, denied killing Julie Hogg, 22, in a frenzied sex attack in November 1989. Her naked and mutilated body was found three months later behind a bath panel at her home in Billingham. The jury at Newcastle crown court failed to agree, and after a second trial in which the jury also failed to agree, a formal verdict of not guilty was returned.

This year, while serving a seven-year sentence for assaulting another woman, Dunlop told a prison officer he had killed Miss Hogg. He was charged with perjuring himself in his evidence under oath at the two trials.

At Teesside crown court yesterday, Dunlop was jailed for six years on each charge, to run concurrently after the term he is already serving. The court heard that Dunlop had this year told police he strangled the woman in a rage after she mocked injuries he suffered in a fight earlier in the evening. But, said James Spencer QC, prosecuting: "Had he not committed perjury he would have been convicted of murder, but because he had committed perjury, he has got away with murder."

Detective Superintendent Peter Wilson, who led the murder inquiry, said afterwards: "We have always been convinced of his guilt."

webTitle: Geniuses 'made with hard work, not born'

fields.headline: Geniuses 'made with hard work, not born'
fields.standfirst: British Psychological Society: Everyone has potential to do well
fields.trailText: Geniuses are made, not born, and even the biggest dunce can learn something from the world class minds of Albert Einstein, Charles Darwin and Amadeus Mozart.
fields.body:
Geniuses are made, not born, and even the biggest dunce can learn something from the world class minds of Albert Einstein, Charles Darwin and Amadeus Mozart.

Despite the widely-held belief that geniuses are all child prodigies, a race apart from ordinary mortals, a British psychologist claimed yesterday that the secret of their success lay more in hard work than in any innate intellectual gifts.

Professor Michael Howe, of Exeter university, told the British Psychological Society's annual conference in Winchester that as extraordinary as geniuses with exceptional scientific or creative talents are, they have much in common with ordinary people.

"Genuine creative achievements depend more on perseverance over the long haul than on prodigious childhood skills. We cannot all be geniuses but we can learn from them.

"What makes geniuses special is their long-term commitment. They struggle very hard and they keep on persisting. They enjoy their work.

"They excel at concentrating and persevering. Their efforts are focused, and all geniuses have a firm sense of direction."

Like everybody else, even the greatest minds that have ever existed have had to struggle and strive to achieve their goals.

Professor Howe pointed to Charles Darwin, who was wrongly believed by many to have been "an aimless young man who unaccountably turned into a great genius".

In fact, he was the most capable and best-prepared young biologist of his generation.

Albert Einstein, who many thought was a failure at school, was in fact always a high achiever and came from a family with strong scientific interests.

But it was not only geniuses with a scientific bent who had made enormous efforts to equip themselves with special qualities.

"The Bronte sisters did not suddenly begin writing great novels. They perfected their writing skills through intense preparation over a period of many years.

"And George Eliot had an excellent training. She was immensely diligent and made herself into a superb scholar and writer through her serious and sustained effort."

Neither was it the case that every genius was once a child prodigy. Many child prodigies did not go on to be particularly productive adults while some - including Charles Darwin - were unexceptional in their youth.

And while almost all of the world's greatest musicians and composers were child prodigies, including Mozart, Handel, JS Bach, Beethoven, Chopin, Liszt, Schumann and Debussy, even the most exceptionally able still took at least 10 years of hard study to become a major composer.

Professor Howe, author of the book Genius Explained, said that virtually all geniuses also had a firm sense of purpose and a strong motivation to achieve.

This was combined with a capacity to concentrate for long periods of time and to resist distractions - abilities particularly honed by scientists such as Isaac Newton, Darwin and Einstein.

A third shared attribute of geniuses was the capacity to focus efforts towards specific goals. Many geniuses also benefited from a supportive home environment.

"Absorbing the lessons of geniuses will not make everyone into a genius but numerous ordinary people can benefit from the insights that exploration of genius can reveal."

fields.headline: Death in the family
fields.standfirst: First Sofia Coppola was vilified as an actor in her father's film; now she is acclaimed for her debut as director. The linking thread is family tragedy
fields.trailText: First Sofia Coppola was vilified as an actor in her father's film; now she is acclaimed for her debut as director. The linking thread is family tragedy
fields.body:
It was Francis Ford Coppola's desire - and certainly no one else's - that his daughter, Sofia, play the part of Mary, Michael Corleone's only daughter, in his production of The Godfather Part III. This was 1989. Sofia was 18 and had no experience of acting. The role had been intended for the equally young but by no means inexperienced actress Winona Ryder, but she arrived in Rome for her first day of shooting, December 28, suffering from nervous exhaustion, and on medical advice had to pull out with no notice.

What was Coppola to do? Julia Roberts was willing but busy elsewhere - casting her would have meant suspending production for weeks - and he was already over budget and behind schedule. Madonna was ready and awaiting the call to get on the plane to Italy, but casting her would have meant rewriting the part of Mary for a woman more than 10 years older. And, as Coppola kept pointing out, "She's meant to be Diane Keaton's daughter."

Sofia was the right age. Sofia was the right look - half Italian, half WASP - exactly as Michael and Kay's daughter would look. And, more to the point, Sofia was there and, by all accounts, in bed asleep when the phone rang and her mum, Eleanor, woke her with the news that she was to be Mary, and to hurry up because she was expected at the studio. "First, I am going to have a shower," Sofia said, not bolshie but cool.

A soft-spoken woman, now 28, shy but fiercely observant and extremely intelligent - as her own directorial debut, The Virgin Suicides, reveals - she probably had a pretty strong sense of what lay behind her dad's decision. As, undoubtedly, did her mother, who did nothing to interpose herself between her daughter and her husband, even when all hell broke loose.

Coppola, of course, is well known for casting his family in his films. His sister, Talia Shire, plays Michael's sister, Connie Corleone, throughout the three parts of The Godfather. But Shire is a professional actor, she screen-tested for the part against competition, even though Coppola himself had originally forbidden her to audition so as to avoid any charges of nepotism. His father, Carmine, and his mother, Italia, both had bit parts in the first Godfather; his wife and two sons appear as extras in the baptism scene.

But the casting of Sofia in The Godfather Part III was different. Mary is a major part in the film, one of the strongest female characters Coppola has written. As the love interest of the aspirant new Don, Vincent Corleone, played by Andy Garcia, she has to have the pluck to go against her father's wishes; she also has to be a bit of a vamp capable of seducing her fiery cousin. Sofia's softness, a gaucheness - in the acting, in the girl - now up there on the celluloid for all to see, seemed to militate against his decision.

Paramount Studios pleaded with Coppola to change his mind. They wanted someone they saw as "hot", they wanted "the right heat". In addition, Coppola, they said, would be making himself and Sofia vulnerable to the cruelty of the press. "You know how cruel the press can be." His response was, "I wanted her [Sofia] all along. I was fashioning Winona in her image."

Looking back, Coppola was right, and Paramount was right. The press massacred Sofia. Critics referred to her "gosling gracelessness", her "total lack of charisma". They sneered at her voice - soft and weak. It was New Yorker critic Pauline Kael alone who seemed to understand something of her casting. "It is obvious that this teenage girl is not a trained actress," Kael wrote. "But . . . she gives the film a breath of life . . . I grew to like her."

In the film, Sofia comes across as real. There are moments when she looks completely lost, especially during the come-on scenes with Garcia. But there are also moments of wonderful spontaneity, such as the dancing-scene with Pacino, her fictional father, when her real-life niece, the little daughter of Sofia's dead brother Gio, suddenly runs into shot clutching at her aunt's skirt. All of this directed by Sofia's real father. It was the fact that Sofia couldn't act, wasn't acting, that Coppola needed. Sofia was his bridge between the fiction and reality. And it was Sofia, and only Sofia, who could provide him with his ending.

It seems odd now that it took so long to arrive at. As late as March 1990 (the film opened in America in December 1990), Coppola and Mario Puzo, the author of The Godfather book, were exchanging letters over how Michael Corleone should die. Suicide? Illness? Puzo wanted him to go out in a hail of bullets - as Coppola had written it in the original script. But by now the director had changed his mind. Violent death, he said, is "too easy" for a man who has wasted his life doing all the wrong things for what he has persuaded himself are the right reasons. At the end of his life, Corleone knows he has lost everything of value. Coppola wanted some representation of this emotional suffering. He has Corleone survive his assassination attempt on the steps of the Teatro Massimo. The bullet meant for him kills Mary. We watch as Corleone tries to take in what has happened to him. In Pacino's silent scream we know that we are hearing the worst of grief - the death of a child.

In May 1986, Coppola's own son, Gio, 22 years old, had died from head injuries after a speedboat accident. Some time after, Coppola said this: "I realised that no matter what happened, I had lost . . . I could have all my fondest dreams come true . . . my dream of dream of dreams and . . . I had lost already . . . There will always be that part of me missing."

Maybe it sounds selfish, this ravelling of grief to himself. Clearly there were others who suffered greatly. Gio's fiancée, three months pregnant with their daughter, Gia. His mother. His younger brother, Roman, just 20, Sofia, 15. Griffin O'Neal, the actor Ryan O'Neal's son, who was drunk and driving the speedboat when his friend was killed. But maybe it is a feature of profound grief that it seems to be yours alone. Elsewhere, Coppola has said that it was seven years before he could wake in the morning and his first thought would not be of his son.

So, in casting Sofia in The Godfather Part III, was he using her? Of course. He used her to help him to make some fictional representation of his own loss - because, maybe, this was the only way that he could force himself to face it. Using Sofia, he could go through the experience again, but this time with the protection and control of directorial distance. Now he could shape it, retrieve it from the senselessness of chance. He knew what he was doing. The character of Mary is abstract, a symbol of "innocence killed", he wrote later to Mario Puzo. And her killing is significant only in "the effect and suffering it brings to Michael".

His wife, Eleanor Coppola, knew what he was doing. At the time, she wrote in her diary, "Well-meaning people tell me I am permitting a form of child abuse." And his sister, Talia Shire, knew. In an interview in Vanity Fair magazine before the film was released, she said, "She [Sofia] is basically structuring her father in this act, and she's doing a damned good job." Shire is probably right here.

Sofia also knew what he was doing. She says now, "He didn't make me do it. It was my choice." And, of her savaging by the film critics: "I can't say it wasn't painful. It was hard, but not devastating." It taught her something, she says. "That I didn't want to act." And later, "When I started directing, it was helpful to know what it was like to be on the other side of the camera."

It took her another 10 years to make the crossover, from one side of the camera to the other, from innocence to experience, you could say. It was a period of retreat from the movie world, during which she studied, then later took up careers in modelling and photography. But, having finally found herself in the right place, she directed a film, her own adaptation of Jeffrey Eugenides' serio-comic novel The Virgin Suicides, set in 1975, about a suburban family of five beautiful adolescent girls - the Lisbon sisters - who, one by one, all commit suicide, seemingly without motive. First the youngest, Cecilia (played by Hanna Hall, who throws herself from an upstairs window), then the other four. The story of their lives and deaths is narrated, 25 years on, by the young neighbourhood boys, now men, who lived opposite the Lisbon girls and were bewitched by them. What she loves about Eugenides' story, Sofia says, is its mixture of melancholy and light-heartedness. "It's that sort of cosy melancholy that you feel when you are inside and outside it's raining." Its humour and tragedy. "To me, it is not about the girls' suicides. It is about the boys who love them so much that, years later, when they've gone, they are still with them, serenading them."

So there is nothing depressing about the film, she says, and despite its title, it is not about death. "The girls are not real, you don't identify with them. That's why they are written in such a dreamy way." It is the boys' story. The girls' deaths are a metaphor. "For the end of childhood, the loss of innocence."

That a young woman should make a film about five young women committing suicide and yet consider that the young men who live on are the most interesting part of the story might seem odd. But Sofia made The Virgin Suicides from the point of view of a survivor. In that sense, it relates to her brother's death as it affected her. Just as the death of Mary Corleone in Godfather III reflected Coppola père's own experience. Sofia thinks she takes after her mother, but admits that her brother insists she takes after her father.

She was the last child, born in 1971, six years after her brother Roman and eight years after Gio, and her dad was so delighted and surprised to have a girl in the family that he dropped his video camera and failed to film the birth. Her early life she measures out in her father's film locations. Birth was Godfather Part I, Italy; fifth birthday was Apocalypse Now, the Philippines. In her mother's fascinating documentary, Hearts Of Darkness, about the making of that movie, you sometimes see, in the background, these beautiful little blond things running around half-naked.

"We were all blond as kids," she says. "Then the Italianness kicked in." For her 13th birth-day, her dad took her with him to Cuba. It was fun, she says, and he was fun. "Bigger than life. Affectionate, youthful, enthusiastic."

Her first home was a 28-room mansion in Pacific Heights, San Francisco, overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge. From here, with the money made from the first two Godfather films, the family moved to a 1,700-acre estate in the Napa Valley, where her parents still live and her dad has a winery. For most of her childhood, this was her base, the place they returned to. The family would traipse around after Coppola, "like a circus family". Her mother was "the cool, down-to-earth one", who'd try to impose some normality. It was sometimes hard moving around, "always to be the new girl". But, as Sofia says, "Our lives were plentiful - I am fortunate and appreciative of that."

None of them was especially clever at school. "Ours was a different kind of education from most." And her parents, she says, were not overly ambitious for them. What mattered was family and, in particular, her dad's family. "I am the only girl in the whole generation," she says. "My dad's brother and sister both had three boys." She then corrects herself. "I mean the only girl on the Italian side. My mum's brother has a daughter, but we don't see much of them."

As siblings they were extremely close. "I guess because we didn't have that many friends. The friends we tended to have were back in Napa." And as they grew up, each of her brothers gravitated towards the movie business. Gio, at 16, left school and went to work with his dad. Roman is a director of commercials. She was going to be the renegade, she says. "Find a way out of film, the family business. All the family is in the business." And then, when she was 15, at precisely that moment as she says, "when you are supposed to be enjoying yourself, breaking out", Gio died. And everything went into a kind of suspension. Including her rebellion.

She found out in a phone call that he was dead. "O'Neal had driven their boat in between two other boats, not realising that one was being towed." The rope caught her brother, flung him back, causing massive injuries. Only minutes before, they had left Gio's pregnant girlfriend on the shore. Sofia couldn't bring herself to go and see the body. "Sometimes I wonder if maybe I should have. Maybe seeing the body makes it more real for you. But I didn't want to have that image of him in my head forever. I'm glad I don't have that."

It was such a pointless death, she says. "It is hard to imagine there was any reason for it, though it changed all our lives forever." It forced her to look at her parents differently. "You're so used to seeing them as strong. Then you realise they are not so strong, after all." Everyone goes through this. "I just went through it younger. Realised that parents are mortal." You recover, she says, but you change. "My mother is strong in a deep way, but it changed her." And, for herself, "I am very different from the person I would have been if I had never known him and the things he taught me." That's all she can say, she explains. "It is what the film [The Virgin Suicides] is about. That things happen for which there are no reasons. And if you try to find them, you won't." No pattern, then, no god? "I can't say there is no god. I believe in something, some energy." But not, she says, in a benign, bearded man.

From the moment she read The Virgin Suicides (a gift from the rock musician Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth), she knew she wanted to adapt it as a screenplay. She told her dad, who advised her against it, because somebody else had already bought the rights to the book and he didn't want her to be disappointed. There are loads of other books out there, he advised her, rather missing the point. But she went ahead anyway, wrote her own adaptation and, when he read it, Coppola was so impressed that he bought the script, and American Zoetrope, Coppola's company, produced the film.

It was shot in 29 days, using a bit of family help - her brother Roman assisted with the diary montages - and friends. Her best friend Stephanie's little sister, Leslie Hayman, plays one of the Lisbon sisters, Therese. To begin with, despite having such heavy hitters as James Woods, Kathleen Turner and Danny DeVito in the cast, the film had no distribution in the US, only in Europe. "I think they were put off by the title." But its acclaim at the Sundance Film Festival changed all that, and it opens in America and here in May. Fourteen years to the month after Gio's death.

It's impossible not to see the film as her response to her brother's death. But it's hard to pin down in quite which way. Unlike The Godfather Part III - in which it is simple to transpose Corleone for Coppola - Sofia Coppola's film doesn't give itself up easily to parallels. She says, for instance, that she identifies with the boys who tell the story. This makes perfect sense. She stands back, as do they, from death. She then tries, as do they, to assimilate death into life. But the boys are half-seduced by death in a way that she isn't. Never could be.

At another level, she is the girls. Their mean-age (13-17) is 15 - the same age she was when Gio died. And, like them, she is aware of the infectiousness of grief - one sister commits suicide, the others follow suit. In the novel, the haunting images of infection, rot, are even more abundant than in Coppola's adaptation. Like the girls in her film, Sofia had her teenage rebelliousness repressed - in the case of the girls, it is by a dominant, Bible-thumping mother, played by Kathleen Turner, who thinks she is protecting them by not letting them out of the house. In Sofia's case, it was sudden death, a different authority, that has closed the lid and weighed it down.

Celebratory is the word that Coppola herself uses to describe her film. There is a fabulous sequence when 14-year-old Lux (Kirsten Dunst), the youngest surviving child, is crowned queen of the homecoming ball with her date, Trip Fontaine (Josh Hartnett), the prettiest boy anyone ever laid eyes on. He abandons her, post-coital, on the football pitch in the middle of the night, so she awakens at dawn, alone.

 The Virgin Suicides opens on May 19.
fields.bodyText: It was Francis Ford Coppola's desire - and certainly no one else's - that his daughter, Sofia, play the part of Mary, Michael Corleone's only daughter, in his production of The Godfather Part III. This was 1989. Sofia was 18 and had no experience of acting. The role had been intended for the equally young but by no means inexperienced actress Winona Ryder, but she arrived in Rome for her first day of shooting, December 28, suffering from nervous exhaustion, and on medical advice had to pull out with no notice. What was Coppola to do? Julia Roberts was willing but busy elsewhere - casting her would have meant suspending production for weeks - and he was already over budget and behind schedule. Madonna was ready and awaiting the call to get on the plane to Italy, but casting her would have meant rewriting the part of Mary for a woman more than 10 years older. And, as Coppola kept pointing out, "She's meant to be Diane Keaton's daughter." Sofia was the right age. Sofia was the right look - half Italian, half WASP - exactly as Michael and Kay's daughter would look. And, more to the point, Sofia was there and, by all accounts, in bed asleep when the phone rang and her mum, Eleanor, woke her with the news that she was to be Mary, and to hurry up because she was expected at the studio. "First, I am going to have a shower," Sofia said, not bolshie but cool. A soft-spoken woman, now 28, shy but fiercely observant and extremely intelligent - as her own directorial debut, The Virgin Suicides, reveals - she probably had a pretty strong sense of what lay behind her dad's decision. As, undoubtedly, did her mother, who did nothing to interpose herself between her daughter and her husband, even when all hell broke loose. Coppola, of course, is well known for casting his family in his films. His sister, Talia Shire, plays Michael's sister, Connie Corleone, throughout the three parts of The Godfather. But Shire is a professional actor, she screen-tested for the part against competition, even though Coppola himself had originally forbidden her to audition so as to avoid any charges of nepotism. His father, Carmine, and his mother, Italia, both had bit parts in the first Godfather; his wife and two sons appear as extras in the baptism scene. But the casting of Sofia in The Godfather Part III was different. Mary is a major part in the film, one of the strongest female characters Coppola has written. As the love interest of the aspirant new Don, Vincent Corleone, played by Andy Garcia, she has to have the pluck to go against her father's wishes; she also has to be a bit of a vamp capable of seducing her fiery cousin. Sofia's softness, a gaucheness - in the acting, in the girl - now up there on the celluloid for all to see, seemed to militate against his decision. Paramount Studios pleaded with Coppola to change his mind. They wanted someone they saw as "hot", they wanted "the right heat". In addition, Coppola, they said, would be making himself and Sofia vulnerable to the cruelty of the press. "You know how cruel the press can be." His response was, "I wanted her [Sofia] all along. I was fashioning Winona in her image." Looking back, Coppola was right, and Paramount was right. The press massacred Sofia. Critics referred to her "gosling gracelessness", her "total lack of charisma". They sneered at her voice - soft and weak. It was New Yorker critic Pauline Kael alone who seemed to understand something of her casting. "It is obvious that this teenage girl is not a trained actress," Kael wrote. "But . . . she gives the film a breath of life . . . I grew to like her." In the film, Sofia comes across as real. There are moments when she looks completely lost, especially during the come-on scenes with Garcia. But there are also moments of wonderful spontaneity, such as the dancing-scene with Pacino, her fictional father, when her real-life niece, the little daughter of Sofia's dead brother Gio, suddenly runs into shot clutching at her aunt's skirt. All of this directed by Sofia's real father. It was the fact that Sofia couldn't act, wasn't acting, that Coppola needed. Sofia was his bridge between the fiction and reality. And it was Sofia, and only Sofia, who could provide him with his ending. It seems odd now that it took so long to arrive at. As late as March 1990 (the film opened in America in December 1990), Coppola and Mario Puzo, the author of The Godfather book, were exchanging letters over how Michael Corleone should die. Suicide? Illness? Puzo wanted him to go out in a hail of bullets - as Coppola had written it in the original script. But by now the director had changed his mind. Violent death, he said, is "too easy" for a man who has wasted his life doing all the wrong things for what he has persuaded himself are the right reasons. At the end of his life, Corleone knows he has lost everything of value. Coppola wanted some representation of this emotional suffering. He has Corleone survive his assassination attempt on the steps of the Teatro Massimo. The bullet meant for him kills Mary. We watch as Corleone tries to take in what has happened to him. In Pacino's silent scream we know that we are hearing the worst of grief - the death of a child. In May 1986, Coppola's own son, Gio, 22 years old, had died from head injuries after a speedboat accident. Some time after, Coppola said this: "I realised that no matter what happened, I had lost . . . I could have all my fondest dreams come true . . . my dream of dream of dreams and . . . I had lost already . . . There will always be that part of me missing." Maybe it sounds selfish, this ravelling of grief to himself. Clearly there were others who suffered greatly. Gio's fiancée, three months pregnant with their daughter, Gia. His mother. His younger brother, Roman, just 20, Sofia, 15. Griffin O'Neal, the actor Ryan O'Neal's son, who was drunk and driving the speedboat when his friend was killed. But maybe it is a feature of profound grief that it seems to be yours alone. Elsewhere, Coppola has said that it was seven years before he could wake in the morning and his first thought would not be of his son. So, in casting Sofia in The Godfather Part III, was he using her? Of course. He used her to help him to make some fictional representation of his own loss - because, maybe, this was the only way that he could force himself to face it. Using Sofia, he could go through the experience again, but this time with the protection and control of directorial distance. Now he could shape it, retrieve it from the senselessness of chance. He knew what he was doing. The character of Mary is abstract, a symbol of "innocence killed", he wrote later to Mario Puzo. And her killing is significant only in "the effect and suffering it brings to Michael". His wife, Eleanor Coppola, knew what he was doing. At the time, she wrote in her diary, "Well-meaning people tell me I am permitting a form of child abuse." And his sister, Talia Shire, knew. In an interview in Vanity Fair magazine before the film was released, she said, "She [Sofia] is basically structuring her father in this act, and she's doing a damned good job." Shire is probably right here. Sofia also knew what he was doing. She says now, "He didn't make me do it. It was my choice." And, of her savaging by the film critics: "I can't say it wasn't painful. It was hard, but not devastating." It taught her something, she says. "That I didn't want to act." And later, "When I started directing, it was helpful to know what it was like to be on the other side of the camera." It took her another 10 years to make the crossover, from one side of the camera to the other, from innocence to experience, you could say. It was a period of retreat from the movie world, during which she studied, then later took up careers in modelling and photography. But, having finally found herself in the right place, she directed a film, her own adaptation of Jeffrey Eugenides' serio-comic novel The Virgin Suicides, set in 1975, about a suburban family of five beautiful adolescent girls - the Lisbon sisters - who, one by one, all commit suicide, seemingly without motive. First the youngest, Cecilia (played by Hanna Hall, who throws herself from an upstairs window), then the other four. The story of their lives and deaths is narrated, 25 years on, by the young neighbourhood boys, now men, who lived opposite the Lisbon girls and were bewitched by them. What she loves about Eugenides' story, Sofia says, is its mixture of melancholy and light-heartedness. "It's that sort of cosy melancholy that you feel when you are inside and outside it's raining." Its humour and tragedy. "To me, it is not about the girls' suicides. It is about the boys who love them so much that, years later, when they've gone, they are still with them, serenading them." So there is nothing depressing about the film, she says, and despite its title, it is not about death. "The girls are not real, you don't identify with them. That's why they are written in such a dreamy way." It is the boys' story. The girls' deaths are a metaphor. "For the end of childhood, the loss of innocence." That a young woman should make a film about five young women committing suicide and yet consider that the young men who live on are the most interesting part of the story might seem odd. But Sofia made The Virgin Suicides from the point of view of a survivor. In that sense, it relates to her brother's death as it affected her. Just as the death of Mary Corleone in Godfather III reflected Coppola père's own experience. Sofia thinks she takes after her mother, but admits that her brother insists she takes after her father. She was the last child, born in 1971, six years after her brother Roman and eight years after Gio, and her dad was so delighted and surprised to have a girl in the family that he dropped his video camera and failed to film the birth. Her early life she measures out in her father's film locations. Birth was Godfather Part I, Italy; fifth birthday was Apocalypse Now, the Philippines. In her mother's fascinating documentary, Hearts Of Darkness, about the making of that movie, you sometimes see, in the background, these beautiful little blond things running around half-naked. "We were all blond as kids," she says. "Then the Italianness kicked in." For her 13th birth-day, her dad took her with him to Cuba. It was fun, she says, and he was fun. "Bigger than life. Affectionate, youthful, enthusiastic." Her first home was a 28-room mansion in Pacific Heights, San Francisco, overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge. From here, with the money made from the first two Godfather films, the family moved to a 1,700-acre estate in the Napa Valley, where her parents still live and her dad has a winery. For most of her childhood, this was her base, the place they returned to. The family would traipse around after Coppola, "like a circus family". Her mother was "the cool, down-to-earth one", who'd try to impose some normality. It was sometimes hard moving around, "always to be the new girl". But, as Sofia says, "Our lives were plentiful - I am fortunate and appreciative of that." None of them was especially clever at school. "Ours was a different kind of education from most." And her parents, she says, were not overly ambitious for them. What mattered was family and, in particular, her dad's family. "I am the only girl in the whole generation," she says. "My dad's brother and sister both had three boys." She then corrects herself. "I mean the only girl on the Italian side. My mum's brother has a daughter, but we don't see much of them." As siblings they were extremely close. "I guess because we didn't have that many friends. The friends we tended to have were back in Napa." And as they grew up, each of her brothers gravitated towards the movie business. Gio, at 16, left school and went to work with his dad. Roman is a director of commercials. She was going to be the renegade, she says. "Find a way out of film, the family business. All the family is in the business." And then, when she was 15, at precisely that moment as she says, "when you are supposed to be enjoying yourself, breaking out", Gio died. And everything went into a kind of suspension. Including her rebellion. She found out in a phone call that he was dead. "O'Neal had driven their boat in between two other boats, not realising that one was being towed." The rope caught her brother, flung him back, causing massive injuries. Only minutes before, they had left Gio's pregnant girlfriend on the shore. Sofia couldn't bring herself to go and see the body. "Sometimes I wonder if maybe I should have. Maybe seeing the body makes it more real for you. But I didn't want to have that image of him in my head forever. I'm glad I don't have that." It was such a pointless death, she says. "It is hard to imagine there was any reason for it, though it changed all our lives forever." It forced her to look at her parents differently. "You're so used to seeing them as strong. Then you realise they are not so strong, after all." Everyone goes through this. "I just went through it younger. Realised that parents are mortal." You recover, she says, but you change. "My mother is strong in a deep way, but it changed her." And, for herself, "I am very different from the person I would have been if I had never known him and the things he taught me." That's all she can say, she explains. "It is what the film [The Virgin Suicides] is about. That things happen for which there are no reasons. And if you try to find them, you won't." No pattern, then, no god? "I can't say there is no god. I believe in something, some energy." But not, she says, in a benign, bearded man. From the moment she read The Virgin Suicides (a gift from the rock musician Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth), she knew she wanted to adapt it as a screenplay. She told her dad, who advised her against it, because somebody else had already bought the rights to the book and he didn't want her to be disappointed. There are loads of other books out there, he advised her, rather missing the point. But she went ahead anyway, wrote her own adaptation and, when he read it, Coppola was so impressed that he bought the script, and American Zoetrope, Coppola's company, produced the film. It was shot in 29 days, using a bit of family help - her brother Roman assisted with the diary montages - and friends. Her best friend Stephanie's little sister, Leslie Hayman, plays one of the Lisbon sisters, Therese. To begin with, despite having such heavy hitters as James Woods, Kathleen Turner and Danny DeVito in the cast, the film had no distribution in the US, only in Europe. "I think they were put off by the title." But its acclaim at the Sundance Film Festival changed all that, and it opens in America and here in May. Fourteen years to the month after Gio's death. It's impossible not to see the film as her response to her brother's death. But it's hard to pin down in quite which way. Unlike The Godfather Part III - in which it is simple to transpose Corleone for Coppola - Sofia Coppola's film doesn't give itself up easily to parallels. She says, for instance, that she identifies with the boys who tell the story. This makes perfect sense. She stands back, as do they, from death. She then tries, as do they, to assimilate death into life. But the boys are half-seduced by death in a way that she isn't. Never could be. At another level, she is the girls. Their mean-age (13-17) is 15 - the same age she was when Gio died. And, like them, she is aware of the infectiousness of grief - one sister commits suicide, the others follow suit. In the novel, the haunting images of infection, rot, are even more abundant than in Coppola's adaptation. Like the girls in her film, Sofia had her teenage rebelliousness repressed - in the case of the girls, it is by a dominant, Bible-thumping mother, played by Kathleen Turner, who thinks she is protecting them by not letting them out of the house.
