fields.headline: Children 'should be told of hell'
fields.standfirst: Liberals twitch as evangelicals turn to fire and brimstoneReligion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Schoolchildren should be taught about the Christian views of hell and the day of judgment to keep them on the straight and narrow, according to a report published today presaging a return to fire and brimstone teaching.
fields.body:
Schoolchildren should be taught about the Christian views of hell and the day of judgment to keep them on the straight and narrow, according to a report published today presaging a return to fire and brimstone teaching.

The report by the Evangelical Alliance - the biblical wing of the Anglican and Nonconformist churches, which is the fastest-growing sector of Protestantism with around a million members in Britain - calls for a return to traditionalist beliefs in hell as a state of eternal damnation and punishment as the reward for sin and the rejection of Jesus. The more tentative official view that it is essentially a state of separation from God.

The alliance's report on what happens after death says: "The hell that awaits is the domain of the devil and his hordes - a sphere of damnation, punishment, anguish and destruction. We urge evangelicals involved in religious education in schools to ensure that modules of Christianity include presentations on death, judgment, heaven and hell."

The 150-page report has alarmed some church leaders concerned that it contradicts the image of a loving and caring God prepared to forgive sinners, and it will cause liberal churchmen to fear that fundamentalism is stirring in religious circles in Britain as well as in the US.

It states uncompromisingly that scripture is trustworthy. It is concerned about the fate of unchristened children who die in infancy or those whose mental disabilities make them unable to respond to the Bible. Nor has it much comfort for those who die declaring their lack of belief in God, warning evangelicals only to be cautious in warning grieving relatives explicitly where the deceased is likely to end up.

"What is clear is that if those who die as infants are granted eternal life, it will come through no merit or claim of their own," it says. "The same would apply to those whose mental disability renders them unable to respond overtly to the gospel. We are not at liberty to presume that any individual will be saved apart from professing faith in Jesus Christ."

The report, the product of a two-year study by the alliance's theological commission, will draw support from many Anglicans but runs counter to the Church of England's position. A church report five years ago, The Mystery of Salvation, described hell as a state of alienation and apartness from God and the utter absence of love: "Hell is not eternal torment but is the final choosing of that which is opposed to God so completely that the only end is non-being."

In an exegesis on ancient and modern theological writings on the issue, the evangelicals find no reasons to question that hell exists, despite a lack of empirical evidence, but plenty to dismiss theories that sinners who repent might ultimately be saved, or the Roman Catholic view that they will have to endure a period in purgatory first.

Nor are they convinced that those cast into hell will be burnt to a crisp rather than undergo eternal, conscious punishment: "What is clear is that all who die will be resurrected to face the judgment of God and that this judgment will be either heaven or hell."

David Hilborn, the report's main author, said: "While recognising that hell is a clear and present danger for those who reject the gospel, the report stresses that this threat is lifted for those who by grace have faith in Jesus Christ. Ultimately only God can know who he will save, but Christians have a responsibility to present Jesus as the only way revealed by God through which people can be redeemed."

He told the Church Times separately: "We are not trying to frighten five-year-olds, but it would be appropriate at secondary level."

But the Right Rev Geoffrey Rowell, Bishop of Basingstoke, accused the authors of wanting a bit of punishment and a bit of annihilation.

Stephen Conway, chaplain to the Bishop of Durham, said: "I personally would find it hard to conceive that anyone faced with the glory of God could possibly choose hell."

fields.headline: Herbal remedies 'can boost brain power'
fields.standfirst: Ginseng boosts exam results & the case for caffeine
fields.trailText: Students could boost their brain power by taking two ancient herbal remedies on the day of their examinations, new research has found.
fields.body:
Students could boost their brain power by taking two ancient herbal remedies on the day of their examinations, new research has found.

Even a single small dose of ginseng, a plant extract sold over the counter in Britain, can sharpen up memory while a small dose of ginkgo biloba can significantly improve concentration.

But a combination of the two together has even more powerful effect, the researchers found.

Psychologist Andrew Scholey, from the University of Northumbria, who led the research, said: "The holy grail of cognitive enhancement is a drug that will improve both memory and concentration.

"These two herbs added together have shown a remarkable finding.

"What seems to be happening is that this drug is improving the mental energy available for cognitive performance as people go about their day-to-day business."

Dr Scholey's team tested 20 participants on four separate days, giving them three different doses of each of the plant extracts and one placebo, but the participants were not told which they were getting on which day.

Even after just one dose of ginkgo biloba, the volunteers displayed much faster reaction times in tests requiring concentration.

Coffee drinkers could find that their caffeine "buzz" is all in the mind

Dr Scholey said people who were given decaffeinated coffee but told that it contained caffeine were able to perform mental tasks faster, just as if they had drunk caffeine. They did, however, make more mistakes.

But when they were given coffee with caffeine and told this was what they were drinking, speed and accuracy improved.

fields.headline: Horse skull 'not from Shergar'
fields.trailText: A horse's skull discovered near Tralee, Co Kerry, was too short in the tooth to be that of the Derby champion Shergar, an examination found yesterday.
fields.body:
A horse's skull discovered near Tralee, Co Kerry, was too short in the tooth to be that of the Derby champion Shergar, an examination found yesterday.

The skull with two bullet holes in the forehead had been found by Tom Foley, a Kerry county councillor, and was sent to the Irish Equine Centre in Co Kildare to establish whether it was that of the multi-million-pound horse stolen by the IRA in 1983.

Des Leadon, the centre's head of clinical pathology, said the animal had probably been professionally destroyed; and its molars proved it was much younger than Shergar when it died.

"We know that Shergar was at least five at the time he was kidnapped, but this horse died somewhere between one-and-a-half and two-and-a-half years of age."

Mr Foley, who found the skull last Saturday while helping in a community clean-up of a glen, said: "I am very disappointed. I was more or less positive it was Shergar because of the Kerry link with the abduction. I still wish Shergar to be found to lay the mystery to rest once and for all."

Shergar was stolen from the Ballymany stud near Newbridge, Co Kildare. It was thought that the IRA took the horse to secure a huge ransom. But the attempt failed, and it is widely believed that the double Derby winner died while in the hands of his kidnappers.

fields.headline: Florence Nightingale diary found
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: A long lost diary written by Florence Nightingale has been sent anonymously to the National Trust house still partly occupied by descendants of her family.
fields.body:
A long lost diary written by Florence Nightingale has been sent anonymously to the National Trust house still partly occupied by descendants of her family.

The diary covers a crucial period of her life in 1850, when she was travelling in Europe and Egypt, observing nursing and hospital procedures, having rejected a proposal of the poet Richard Monkton-Milnes, because she believed God had called her to perform some service. Three years later she led her team of trained nurses to the Crimea, and became the Lady with the Lamp.

Antony Sattin, who edited her letters from the same period, and whose Radio 4 documentary may have sparked the return of the diary, said last night: "In some ways this presents a less sanitised version of her experiences and thoughts than she was writing home to family and friends."

The small maroon leather bound book tumbled out of an envelope when custodian Ray Sandham was opening the morning post at Claydon House, Buckinghamshire, the home of the Verney family since 1620.

Edmund Verney, her great-great step-nephew, said: "I think the family are slightly surprised and bemused, but it's very nice to have it here among her other papers and letters."

Mr Sattin recognised her handwriting and it has also been authenticated by Alix Attiewell, curator of the Florence Nightingale museum in London.

fields.headline: Laud of the dance
fields.standfirst: Morris men frolic from London to Norwich
fields.trailText: "You should make a point of trying everything once," the composer Arnold Bax advised young people, "except incest and folk dancing."
fields.body:
"You should make a point of trying everything once," the composer Arnold Bax advised young people, "except incest and folk dancing."

Those avid morris dancers, Kemp's Men of Norwich, take his point sufficiently to post his warning on their website.

And even the historical lord of their dance - Shakespeare's anarchic clown Will Kemp - despaired that anyone would find "anything but blunt mirth" in what they did.

Yet today the biggest, English gathering of morris dancers for centuries will rally to mark the 400th anniversary of Will Kemp's Nine Daies Wonder - his nine-day dance along the 127 miles from London to Norwich.

Nearly 300 dancers will re-enact this in relays along the minor roads of East Anglia, with eight footsore men and two puffing musicians going the whole way.

Yesterday Paul Campbell, the organiser, said: "It's fun stamping your feet and banging sticks together. It's a very English way of making fools of ourselves. It is our own, home-bred form of eccentricity."

fields.headline: Tribunal finds for jail governor
fields.trailText: A governor whose outspoken views made her a "thorn in the side" of the prison service yesterday won her claim for victimisation under the Sex Discrimination Act.
fields.body:
A governor whose outspoken views made her a "thorn in the side" of the prison service yesterday won her claim for victimisation under the Sex Discrimination Act.

An employment tribunal in Manchester found in favour of Katie Dawson, 56, the former governor of Risley women's prison in Cheshire.

It had been told that Mrs Dawson, who had complained about conditions, only learned her prison was to be shut at a staff meeting.

She also said she had been denied the chance to apply for other jobs and had been isolated.

After the ruling, the service agreed £6,000 to compensate for injured feelings. Mrs Dawson said: "Money never was the issue.

"These proceedings were brought to alert the public to [conditions], not just at Risley but everywhere. That is why they didn't like me - because I spoke out."

However, the tribunal said it found the treatment of Mrs Dawson, who still works in a senior post, was partly due to an earlier claim of sex discrimination that had led the service to see her, a "dedicated and capable woman", as a thorn in its side.

webTitle: Asda to pay farmers to go organic

fields.headline: Asda to pay farmers to go organic
fields.trailText: Asda is to pay livestock farmers to go organic to increase supplies to the fastest growing sector of the food market.
fields.body:
Asda is to pay livestock farmers to go organic to increase supplies to the fastest growing sector of the food market.

The supermarket chain yesterday promised a total of £3m over three years to help the transition, which can take a farmer three to five years.

It is the first time private funds have been offered so directly to change farming methods.

Asda wants a larger slice of the organic market, aiming to sell £1m of produce a week by the end of the year, leaving it still well behind Sainsbury's, Tesco and Waitrose.

Asda is to launch its own label organic meat range next month, but it has sources for only five animals a week for beef when it is aiming at 140.

Angela Spindler, its meat and produce director, said it might pay farmers higher prices than usual for conventionally reared animals during conversion, rather than handing over cheques. To see a return on the investment, it might tie farmers into agreements after conversion.

The government says it is doing all it can to help conversion to organic farming. By next April , £24m will have been spent in two years in England, allowing 1,100 farmers to convert, compared with 400 in Britain in the five years before.

However, all the money was committed by the end of last year, leaving a 15 month gap until new £20m a year funding becomes available.

fields.headline: Life for 'sex fantasy' murder
fields.trailText: Darren Colling, 30 was jailed for life yesterday after a jury had found him guilty of murdering a schoolboy by battering him with a hammer before sexually abusing him, and dumping him in a canal where he died.
fields.body:
Darren Colling, 30 was jailed for life yesterday after a jury had found him guilty of murdering a schoolboy by battering him with a hammer before sexually abusing him, and dumping him in a canal where he died.

The murder was one of "extreme brutality for sexual pleasure", Mr Justice Toulson said at Exeter crown court.

The victim, George Mortimer, 16, lived in Exeter and was a pupil at St Peter's high school.

He suffered more than 30 head wounds and 12 fractures from the claw hammer Colling wielded during a canal-side meeting on January 29 last year.

The schoolboy was to have gone on to a party after meeting Colling, who used drug deals as a means of getting close to young men and boys, the jury had been told.

Colling denied the killing but was linked to it by DNA, the court had heard.

The defendant's flatmate and former lover, Damien Sinclair, gave evidence for the prosecution, and told how Colling, who came originally from Exeter, had confessed to the killing when he returned to their flat in Cheshire.

He said that Colling, whom he met in jail, had once spoken of his fantasy about kidnapping the schoolboy, doing what he wanted with him sexually, then killing him.

The judge told Colling that he believed he would be a risk to young men until he lost all interest in sex due to old age.

"I shall be alarmed if anyone were to consider your release before then," he said.

webTitle: Inquiry urged into mentally ill in jail

fields.headline: Inquiry urged into mentally ill in jail
fields.trailText: A coroner yesterday called for an urgent review of how mentally-ill people were treated in prisons, after hearing of the suicide of the son of Culture Club bass player Mikey Craig.
fields.body:
A coroner yesterday called for an urgent review of how mentally-ill people were treated in prisons, after hearing of the suicide of the son of Culture Club bass player Mikey Craig.

Keita Craig, who was diagnosed with schizophrenia, hanged himself with his shoelaces in Wandsworth prison, south London. He had been given back the shoelaces even though staff had been warned he was a suicide risk.

Paul Knapman, the Westminster coroner, issued a list of immediate recommendations for improvements at Wandsworth, and said he would be writing to Jack Straw, the home secretary, with a call for a review of prison procedure.

His comments came on the day a report in the British Medical Journal said that mentally-ill prisoners were being failed by poor services, and were spending long hours locked in their cells, and as the government announced the appointment of a "tsar" to lead the modernisation and reform of mental health care in general. Louis Appleby, professor of psychiatry at Manchester university and director of the confidential inquiry into suicides and homicides among mentally-ill people, will be seconded to the Department of Health for three years. He will have the job title of national director for mental health.

Keita Craig, who was 22 and the grandson of Erin Pizzey, pioneer of the women's refuge movement, had been arrested over a street robbery. Magistrates had remanded him to Wandsworth after being unable to find him a place in a suitable mental health unit.

His social worker, probation officer and a Securicor guard accompanying him, all warned the jail he was showing suicidal tendencies and the guard ordered his shoelaces be taken away. However, a 73-year-old doctor at Wandsworth decided Mr Craig was not at risk. His shoelaces were returned and he was found dead the day after arriving at the prison.

A jury returned a verdict that Mr Craig killed himself while the balance of his mind was disturbed.

webTitle: Parkie meets Ali G in Bafta contest

fields.headline: Parkie meets Ali G in Bafta contest
fields.trailText: The avuncular but ageing charm of Michael Parkinson is going head to head with the yoof babble of Ali G, the put-on street cred interviewer, for one of TV's top awards.
fields.body:
The avuncular but ageing charm of Michael Parkinson is going head to head with the yoof babble of Ali G, the put-on street cred interviewer, for one of TV's top awards.

The pair are nominated for best entertainment performance at the British Academy Television Awards, along with Graham Norton, the Channel 4 comedy host, and John Bird and John Fortune, who appear with impressionist Rory Bremner.

BBC1's the Royle Family dominates the comedy performance category with three nominations - Caroline Aherne, Ricky Tomlinson and Sue Johnston - while Dawn French is nominated for her Vicar of Dibley.

The Royle Family has a fourth nomination for best sitcom - against the Vicar of Dibley, Dinnerladies and Spaced.

Ali G is the comic creation of Sacha Baron Cohen, a Cambridge graduate. He became a cult figure, through interviewing establishment figures for Channel 4's the 11 O'clock Show, pretending to be the "voice of youth" by speaking the language of street culture. He also has a second nomination for his subsequent show, the Best of Ali G, in the best comedy programme section.

Nominations for the awards, decided by members of Bafta, were unveiled yesterday by ITV sports presenter Des Lynam, who will host the London ceremony on May 14.

Dame Thora Hird and her co-star in the ITV drama Lost for Words, Pete Postlethwaite, have been nominated in the best actress and actor categories.

Two other shows have double nominations in the acting categories: Lindsay Duncan and Timothy Spall for Shooting the Past, and Francesca Annis and Michael Gambon for Wives and Daughters.

Dame Maggie Smith is the final contender in the best actress section, while Aidan Gillen is short-listed for Queer as Folk.

Lost for Words is also nominated for best single drama, as is ITV's the Murder of Stephen Lawrence. BBC1's lavish Wives and Daughters is further short-listed in the drama serial category.

Unsurprisingly EastEnders, Coronation Street, Brookside and Emmerdale fight it out for the soap title.

Big Breakfast host Johnny Vaughan finds himself in unlikely company: he is up against Newsnight presenters Jeremy Paxman and Kirsty Wark and wildlife expert Sir David Attenborough for best presenter in factual, features and news programmes.

Walking with Dinosaurs features in a new best innovation category, along with the praised 1900 House series, the League of Gentlemen and Tina Goes Shopping.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Plague pit gives way to road
fields.body:
Plague pit gives way to road

Plague victims are to be exhumed from a 16th century burial ground to make way for a new road.

The remains have been located in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, on the route of the town centre link road.

A Barnsley council spokesman said the bodies would be covered with quick lime to stop infection spreading and would be reburied elsewhere.

Couple can sue hospital

Keith and Susan Shaw, of Liverpool, were yesterday given permission to sue Alder Hey hospital over the removal in 1991 of the organs of their 11-month-old son, Lee. Judge Gerard Fitzgerald said in Liverpool county court he did not agree with the hospital that decisions on civil actions should wait until after a government inquiry.

Man jailed for revenge rapes

A man who committed 13 sex attacks on women and girls as young as 11 was yesterday jailed for 18 years at Luton crown court. David Ellis, 29, of Luton, admitted the offences, vengence for his girlfriend's alleged affairs.

webTitle: Low speed world threatens to hold back a hi-tech hub world stuck in a low speed corner

fields.headline: Low speed world threatens to hold back a hi-tech hub world stuck in a low speed corner
fields.standfirst: Lack of transport and soaring house prices squeeze Britain's answer to Silicon ValleyThe brains behind the technology
fields.trailText: Paul Kelly looks like the right man in the right place at the right time. He heads a thrusting young genetics firm on a new science park in Britain's hi-tech heartland - Cambridge, aka Silicon Fen, the hothouse of entrepreneurial flair and scientific brilliance hailed by the government as its champion in a cutthroat new world economy where IT and biotechnology reign supreme.
fields.body:
Paul Kelly looks like the right man in the right place at the right time. He heads a thrusting young genetics firm on a new science park in Britain's hi-tech heartland - Cambridge, aka Silicon Fen, the hothouse of entrepreneurial flair and scientific brilliance hailed by the government as its champion in a cutthroat new world economy where IT and biotechnology reign supreme.

For companies like Mr Kelly's Gemini Genomics, the new technology works fine. It is the old technology which is not working.

Gemini's computers can exchange information with their offices in Uppsala, Sweden, in seconds. But trying to leave the shrub-lined car parks and sleek low-rise units of the science park on the north side of Cambridge is a different story.

"It can take anything up to half an hour to reach the A14 from here," said Mr Kelly. "And it's only 500 yards away."

The explosive growth of science and technology-based businesses in Cambridge and its satellite towns and villages has thrust the area into an upheaval as painful as it is exciting, with soaring house prices and threats to rural tranquillity the price to pay for prosperity and jobs galore.

Now, as once-tiny ventures blossom with startling speed into billion-pound businesses - in the very Silicon Valley style Tony Blair sees as a paradigm - entrepreneurs, planners and conservationists alike are asking: can the medieval town of Cambridge cope?

Mr Kelly set up Gemini's headquarters in Cambridge in 1997 because the space was available, it was a recognised hi-tech hub, and the address had a cachet for customers and recruits alike. He still likes the place, but since he moved in, the pressures on the town's sclerotic transport arteries have become unpleasantly clear.

"Cambridge is just not set up to deal with an influx of people and activity," he said. "It's a small town and it lacks the infrastructure to support this massive influx of people, resources and companies. I think that's going to be a problem in the future in terms of keeping firms here.

"Public transport is unpredictable and ineffective. Communication with the villages is appalling. People are moving out of Cambridge because of the cost of living there, but public transport from the villages is atrocious. So most people have to drive. Because they have to drive, the roads get clogged up."

Last month, in a move which sent ripples of alarm through Cambridge conservationists, the environment secretary, John Prescott, acknowledged the development pressure on Silicon Fen by declaring that the government wanted to see greenfield sites released for housing.

The county, Britain's fastest growing in people terms, has already seen its population increase by 22% since 1984; it is forecast to rise by a further 25% by 2021, in an echo of the rust belt to sun belt migration seen in the US in the 1980s.

Gridlock fear

Mr Prescott's draft plan for the county called for up to 80,000 new homes. A small residential new town is already under construction in the countryside west of the city; others have been mooted for old military airfields to the north.

Surprisingly, the Prescott plan is under attack not just from conservationists, but from the new entrepreneurs themselves. New housing is no use, they point out, without the roads, buses or trains to go with it.

Barry Pearce, director of the Cambridge Preservation Society, said Mr Prescott's regional planning guidelines ignored the potential for transport gridlock.

"If you've got businessmen complaining about being stuck in the science park now, imagine what it's going to be like if the city expands further," he said.

Mr Kelly agreed. "Simply plonking new houses in small villages or building new villages is not going to solve fundamental questions of quality of transport and quality of life."

Over the road from the science park, Mike Lynch, a legendary figure in Cambridge entrepreneurial circles, was feeling the squeeze of success.

Mr Lynch's software firm Autonomy is valued on the stock market at £4bn. With 20% of the shares, he is a dollar billionaire. Not bad for an outfit which started life with a £2,000 loan from an acquaintance in a pub - and Mr Lynch is only 34.

The world's smartest internet firms are beating a path to Autonomy's door to buy licences for the company's unique text analysis software. Yet Mr Lynch has been trying for a year, without success, to find premises for a research centre in Cambridge.

For the time being, his staff are squeezed into an innovation centre designed to incubate small hi-tech start-ups. At an earlier stage in his hunt for a building, Mr Lynch found a country house outside the city which seemed perfect for his purposes. Planners turned him down.

"Many of our brilliant 22-year-olds don't own a car, so they have to be within cycling distance. But many of our 28-year-olds have started a home somewhere so it has to be accessible by car. You put these two together and you have a big absence of office space in Cambridge," he said.

Mr Lynch, a Cambridge graduate who says he would not base his company anywhere else, argues that an anachronistic culture of donnish disdain for the economic needs of the wider community prevails in the cloistered quads of the university's venerable colleges.

"The difficulty with Cambridge hasn't so much been incompetence as idealism. Cambridge is a unique place: many of the central residents don't actually drive or have cars. They cycle instead. I'm very sympathetic to that but extrapolating it to the whole world can't work. You can't apply that way of life to people who are living out in the villages of rural Cambridge.

"Rather than this being a debate about nasty business wanting to sully the beautiful spires of Cambridge, it's about making sure people who aren't philosophy dons can actually make a living in this part of the world."

The new technology firms tend to recruit bright graduates and PhDs from campuses around the world, not just Cambridge. They may be caricatured as workaholic geeks, but these young, high-salaried, ambitious workers have high expectations of their leisure time, honed in the espresso and nightclub cultures of Seattle, Paris, London or Sydney.

Cambridge, population 112,000, in the middle of a largely flat, often wet, green expanse, with its dearth of restaurants and nightlife, can come as a shock.

Robin Saxby, head of ARM Holdings, another multi-billion-pound new technology company with a strong Cambridge presence, said: "I live in the Thames Valley. It's got better restaurants and better hotels. If you live in Cambridge and you want to go out for a decent meal you have to go to London."

John Onslow and Mark Vigor are two of the men who shoulder the responsibility for trying to get Silicon Fen moving. Senior strategic planners at Cambridgeshire county council, they have the kind of problem many of their northern colleagues would envy. "The economy keeps growing," Mr Onslow said simply. "The growth doesn't need to be stimulated. It's happening anyway and I think by and large as an authority we welcome that."

Disaster scenario

Mr Vigor said the council was determined, in spite of business objections, to keep car use down, but without government help, it was going to be impossible to plug the transport gap.

He acknowledged the fears of long-established residents. "Is Cambridge going to be a smallish city with a significant international university, or is it going to become a Birmingham? That's the perception people have of the choice. And the green belt is seen as a way of keeping Cambridge a small city.

"I don't think you'd find many people who would say: 'Stop Cambridge in its tracks.' I don't think the government would let that happen anyway. Some people see a disaster scenario, where this expansion is going to be impossible to deal with, and others don't accept that there are going to have to be significant changes. But we have to find a way of accommodating this growth."

One thing unites all Cambridge's voices on the future - that it should not ape, or even see itself as a competitor with, Silicon Valley, as Mr Blair urged on a recent visit to Cambridge.

The Californian hi-tech hub has its own share of development nightmares: bumper to bumper traffic, hyperinflated house prices and conservation battles. It is now forbidden to demolish houses built before 1940.

"It's now received wisdom among the Valley elite that they've created the Florence - and are themselves the Florentines - of our times," wrote Simon Firth in the online magazine Salon.

"But if the Valley really were the Florence of our times, it would be a model of urban planning, inspiring to visit, the cultural envy of the world.

"Instead, of course, it is a sprawling mess of unremarkable development, one that struggles to match the cultural interests and output of any typical affluent American suburb."

Even the outspoken Mr Lynch, who divides his time between Cambridge and the Valley and videoconferences with his far-flung colleagues, retreats at day's end to his home in unspoiled old England, rural Suffolk.

"The really nice thing about living there is that you get away from technology," he said. "You can't go into a restaurant in San Francisco without hearing a conversation about Java. Sadly, London's getting like that. Suffolk's still safe."

fields.bodyText: Paul Kelly looks like the right man in the right place at the right time. He heads a thrusting young genetics firm on a new science park in Britain's hi-tech heartland - Cambridge, aka Silicon Fen, the hothouse of entrepreneurial flair and scientific brilliance hailed by the government as its champion in a cutthroat new world economy where IT and biotechnology reign supreme. For companies like Mr Kelly's Gemini Genomics, the new technology works fine. It is the old technology which is not working. Gemini's computers can exchange information with their offices in Uppsala, Sweden, in seconds. But trying to leave the shrub-lined car parks and sleek low-rise units of the science park on the north side of Cambridge is a different story. "It can take anything up to half an hour to reach the A14 from here," said Mr Kelly. "And it's only 500 yards away." The explosive growth of science and technology-based businesses in Cambridge and its satellite towns and villages has thrust the area into an upheaval as painful as it is exciting, with soaring house prices and threats to rural tranquillity the price to pay for prosperity and jobs galore. Now, as once-tiny ventures blossom with startling speed into billion-pound businesses - in the very Silicon Valley style Tony Blair sees as a paradigm - entrepreneurs, planners and conservationists alike are asking: can the medieval town of Cambridge cope? Mr Kelly set up Gemini's headquarters in Cambridge in 1997 because the space was available, it was a recognised hi-tech hub, and the address had a cachet for customers and recruits alike. He still likes the place, but since he moved in, the pressures on the town's sclerotic transport arteries have become unpleasantly clear. "Cambridge is just not set up to deal with an influx of people and activity," he said. "It's a small town and it lacks the infrastructure to support this massive influx of people, resources and companies. I think that's going to be a problem in the future in terms of keeping firms here. "Public transport is unpredictable and ineffective. Communication with the villages is appalling. People are moving out of Cambridge because of the cost of living there, but public transport from the villages is atrocious. So most people have to drive. Because they have to drive, the roads get clogged up." Last month, in a move which sent ripples of alarm through Cambridge conservationists, the environment secretary, John Prescott, acknowledged the development pressure on Silicon Fen by declaring that the government wanted to see greenfield sites released for housing. The county, Britain's fastest growing in people terms, has already seen its population increase by 22% since 1984; it is forecast to rise by a further 25% by 2021, in an echo of the rust belt to sun belt migration seen in the US in the 1980s. Gridlock fear Mr Prescott's draft plan for the county called for up to 80,000 new homes. A small residential new town is already under construction in the countryside west of the city; others have been mooted for old military airfields to the north. Surprisingly, the Prescott plan is under attack not just from conservationists, but from the new entrepreneurs themselves. New housing is no use, they point out, without the roads, buses or trains to go with it. Barry Pearce, director of the Cambridge Preservation Society, said Mr Prescott's regional planning guidelines ignored the potential for transport gridlock. "If you've got businessmen complaining about being stuck in the science park now, imagine what it's going to be like if the city expands further," he said. Mr Kelly agreed. "Simply plonking new houses in small villages or building new villages is not going to solve fundamental questions of quality of transport and quality of life." Over the road from the science park, Mike Lynch, a legendary figure in Cambridge entrepreneurial circles, was feeling the squeeze of success. Mr Lynch's software firm Autonomy is valued on the stock market at £4bn. With 20% of the shares, he is a dollar billionaire. Not bad for an outfit which started life with a £2,000 loan from an acquaintance in a pub - and Mr Lynch is only 34. The world's smartest internet firms are beating a path to Autonomy's door to buy licences for the company's unique text analysis software. Yet Mr Lynch has been trying for a year, without success, to find premises for a research centre in Cambridge. For the time being, his staff are squeezed into an innovation centre designed to incubate small hi-tech start-ups. At an earlier stage in his hunt for a building, Mr Lynch found a country house outside the city which seemed perfect for his purposes. Planners turned him down. "Many of our brilliant 22-year-olds don't own a car, so they have to be within cycling distance. But many of our 28-year-olds have started a home somewhere so it has to be accessible by car. You put these two together and you have a big absence of office space in Cambridge," he said. Mr Lynch, a Cambridge graduate who says he would not base his company anywhere else, argues that an anachronistic culture of donnish disdain for the economic needs of the wider community prevails in the cloistered quads of the university's venerable colleges. "The difficulty with Cambridge hasn't so much been incompetence as idealism. Cambridge is a unique place: many of the central residents don't actually drive or have cars. They cycle instead. I'm very sympathetic to that but extrapolating it to the whole world can't work. You can't apply that way of life to people who are living out in the villages of rural Cambridge. "Rather than this being a debate about nasty business wanting to sully the beautiful spires of Cambridge, it's about making sure people who aren't philosophy dons can actually make a living in this part of the world." The new technology firms tend to recruit bright graduates and PhDs from campuses around the world, not just Cambridge. They may be caricatured as workaholic geeks, but these young, high-salaried, ambitious workers have high expectations of their leisure time, honed in the espresso and nightclub cultures of Seattle, Paris, London or Sydney. Cambridge, population 112,000, in the middle of a largely flat, often wet, green expanse, with its dearth of restaurants and nightlife, can come as a shock. Robin Saxby, head of ARM Holdings, another multi-billion-pound new technology company with a strong Cambridge presence, said: "I live in the Thames Valley. It's got better restaurants and better hotels. If you live in Cambridge and you want to go out for a decent meal you have to go to London." John Onslow and Mark Vigor are two of the men who shoulder the responsibility for trying to get Silicon Fen moving. Senior strategic planners at Cambridgeshire county council, they have the kind of problem many of their northern colleagues would envy. "The economy keeps growing," Mr Onslow said simply. "The growth doesn't need to be stimulated. It's happening anyway and I think by and large as an authority we welcome that." Disaster scenario Mr Vigor said the council was determined, in spite of business objections, to keep car use down, but without government help, it was going to be impossible to plug the transport gap. He acknowledged the fears of long-established residents. "Is Cambridge going to be a smallish city with a significant international university, or is it going to become a Birmingham? That's the perception people have of the choice. And the green belt is seen as a way of keeping Cambridge a small city. "I don't think you'd find many people who would say: 'Stop Cambridge in its tracks.' I don't think the government would let that happen anyway. Some people see a disaster scenario, where this expansion is going to be impossible to deal with, and others don't accept that there are going to have to be significant changes. But we have to find a way of accommodating this growth." One thing unites all Cambridge's voices on the future - that it should not ape, or even see itself as a competitor with, Silicon Valley, as Mr Blair urged on a recent visit to Cambridge. The Californian hi-tech hub has its own share of development nightmares: bumper to bumper traffic, hyperinflated house prices and conservation battles. It is now forbidden to demolish houses built before 1940. "It's now received wisdom among the Valley elite that they've created the Florence - and are themselves the Florentines - of our times," wrote Simon Firth in the online magazine Salon. "But if the Valley really were the Florence of our times, it would be a model of urban planning, inspiring to visit, the cultural envy of the world. "Instead, of course, it is a sprawling mess of unremarkable development, one that struggles to match the cultural interests and output of any typical affluent American suburb." Even the outspoken Mr Lynch, who divides his time between Cambridge and the Valley and videoconferences with his far-flung colleagues, retreats at day's end to his home in unspoiled old England, rural Suffolk. "The really nice thing about living there is that you get away from technology," he said. "You can't go into a restaurant in San Francisco without hearing a conversation about Java. Sadly, London's getting like that. Suffolk's still safe." webTitle: Where talent and ideas meet money

fields.headline: Where talent and ideas meet money
fields.trailText: The name Silicon Valley was coined by the writer Don Hoeffler in 1972 to describe the dense concentration of electronics plants in California's Santa Clara county, near San Francisco. An area once known for its fruit orchards was transformed by an outflow of entrepreneurs from Stanford university.
fields.body:
The name Silicon Valley was coined by the writer Don Hoeffler in 1972 to describe the dense concentration of electronics plants in California's Santa Clara county, near San Francisco. An area once known for its fruit orchards was transformed by an outflow of entrepreneurs from Stanford university.

The Silicon Valley model was the inspiration for a host of coinages - Silicon Glen, Silicon Alley, Silicon Polder and, in Cambridgeshire, Silicon Fen - all applied to areas where a crossflow of talent and ideas, fuelled by venture capitalists, began between the academic and business worlds. Professors would encourage students to turn their ideas into small businesses, rather than seeking jobs in long-established firms. These student entrepreneurs would, in turn, recruit from and fund research at their alma mater.

Cambridge university's expertise in science and proximity to London made it a natural home for such a hi-tech cluster. Yet despite the exponential growth of genetics and computing-based firms, it has yet to generate firms of the world stature of Valley companies like Intel, Sun Microsystems or Hewlett Packard.

Santa Clara, with the cities of San Jose and Palo Alto, has a population of 1.6m, more than twice as many as the English county.

The valley has a gross domestic product in excess of £40bn, about the same as Chile, compared with Cambridgeshire's £7bn. With a semi-detached house in Cambridgeshire now averaging £85,000, locals may feel they are being priced out of the market. But Silicon Valley prices are in another league: in 1998 homes there were the most expensive in the US, at an average of £200,000.

fields.headline: The brains behind the technology
fields.standfirst: Low speed world threatens to hold back a hi-tech hub
fields.trailText: The report yesterday that Microsoft was speeding up its plans to build a £60m research centre in Cambridge was the latest episode in the apparently inexorable rise of the city and the surrounding county as Britain's pre-eminent cluster of high technology companies.
fields.body:
The report yesterday that Microsoft was speeding up its plans to build a £60m research centre in Cambridge was the latest episode in the apparently inexorable rise of the city and the surrounding county as Britain's pre-eminent cluster of high technology companies.

To call it Silicon Fen is to ignore the other cutting-edge technologies which are bringing jobs, geniuses, venture capitalists, hopeful young fortune-seekers and international lawyers to Cambridge - particularly biotechnology, influenced by the work of the Wellcome Trust-funded Sangar Centre in decoding the mysteries of human genes.

Prominent among the movers and shakers of Cambridge is David Chiswell, head of the biotechnology company, Cambridge Antibody Technology. CAT makes libraries of human antibodies for use by drugs companies. In March, after a tie-up with one of the most aggressive new US biotech companies, Human Genome Sciences, its stock market value broke through the £1bn barrier.

Peter Fellner heads another biotech billion-pound firm, Celltech, a survivor from an earlier wave of biotech start-ups, which is unusual among companies of its kind in generating revenues from a local anaesthetic called Chirocaine. Recent drugs licensing problems in the US are a reminder that Silicon Fen trades on risk.

Adam Twiss and Damian Reeves, who set up their internet software firm, Zeus Technologies, while they were students at Cambridge and are still in their early 20s, are the favourite duo for those who like to claim that Silicon Valley's campus-to-enterprise culture really is at work in East Anglia.

ARM Holdings, headed by Robin Saxby - who does not live in Cambridgeshire, preferring to live closer to Heathrow airport, but still runs a sizeable part of his operation there - is one of the most solidly-based success stories of Silicon Fen. Its power-frugal microchips are to be found in many of the world's mobile phones. Two years after it was floated, it is worth almost £8bn.

Perhaps the most remarkable rise of all the firms in the Cambridge cluster is that of Autonomy and its founder, Mike Lynch, 34.

Text analysis software based on the maths of an 18th century clergyman trying to prove the existence of God does not sound to the layman like a realistic business proposition.

And that's exactly what Lynch found when he took his idea to bankers and venture capitalists. But at the age of 23, a former pop promoter lent him £2,000 on a hunch, and the rest is history.

Lynch's company is worth about £4bn, with a fifth of that owned by Lynch himself.

Autonomy illustrates one of the paradoxes of Silicon Fen: the tiny number of employees in many of the firms. For all its paper value, the company has just 160 employees.

Lynch, who wears his wealth lightly, is confident. "The model is very clean. To double our revenues, we just have to ship two CDs of software."

But there have been failures in Cambridge.

From his office, Lynch can see the empty hulk of the Ionica building, headquarters of a company with an innovative idea for cable-free fixed phone lines, which in 1997 floated on the stock market, soared in value to hundreds of millions of pounds, and went bust 15 months later.

Some entrepreneurs sold out while the going was good and linger on in the county, passing acid comments on the new wave.

Peter Dawe, who made a relatively modest £36m when he sold his share in the internet service provider, Unipalm Pipiex, four years ago, was dismissive of the virtues of Silicon Fen when Microsoft first announced their research centre in 1997.

"Anyone who has been to Silicon Valley, which was once one of the most beautiful valleys in the world, will know this is not a good thing."

Silicon Fen

fields.headline: MPs to challenge breastfeeding ban
fields.trailText: Margaret Hodge, the equal opportunities minister, is to press the Speaker, Betty Boothroyd, to reconsider her ban on women MPs breastfeeding their babies during Commons committee meetings.
fields.body:
Margaret Hodge, the equal opportunities minister, is to press the Speaker, Betty Boothroyd, to reconsider her ban on women MPs breastfeeding their babies during Commons committee meetings.

The MP for Swindon South, Julia Drown, was last week told she should not feed her son, Harvey, in committee on the grounds that MPs were not allowed to eat during the committee meetings either.

A delegation of Labour women MPs is expected to demand that the Speaker rethink. Ms Drown is said to have the support of Ms Hodge, Tessa Jowell, the minister for women, and the former social security secretary, Harriet Harman.

Women MPs are becoming increasingly restive at the slow process of modernisation of the Commons. A meeting of the Parliamentary Labour party this week heard complaints about working hours, the lack of facilities for women in the Commons and the gentlemen's club atmosphere.

However, some MPs resent the lobbying by what they regard as southern middle-class women MPs who think the job is nine to five.

Ms Drown said last night that the Commons should have the same kind of facilities as a contemporary private company.

Ms Hodge said: "It shouldn't be an issue. We have got to modernise. We want more mums in. Mothers will act as sensibly as anyone else."

fields.headline: Portillo plans tax retreat
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, is planning a major policy reverse over the Conservative party's much ridiculed guarantee to cut tax as a proportion of national income.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, is planning a major policy reverse over the Conservative party's much ridiculed guarantee to cut tax as a proportion of national income.

He wants to make the policy more credible by changing the time frame in which to meet his party's commitment.

With the enthusiastic backing of rightwing frontbenchers, Mr Portillo wants to change the commitment to one of cutting income tax as a proportion of GDP over the economic cycle, rather than over a parliament.

One rightwinger claimed: "The current policy is economically illiterate. What happens if a parliament is only one year, or the parliament starts midway through an economic cycle? What happens if the world economy goes haywire and we are left on some ideological autopilot?

"We will be burned alive if we go into the election with a policy like this."

Mr Portillo, who has been reported in the past as wanting to drop the pledge altogether, is understood to be pressing the compromise on his leader, William Hague, believing that it will withstand the rigours of an election campaign as well as be credible with economists. A proposal is likely to be put to the shadow cabinet economic sub-committee shortly.

An economic cycle is seen as less inflexible than a commitment to cut spending over a parliament. Economists may differ among themselves as to when an economic cycle has begun or ended, making it easier for the Conservatives to say they are on course to honour their pledge. A commitment, or even a guarantee to cut tax over the cycle, rather than the parliament, is also seen to fit in with golden rule commitments of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to contain current spending over a cycle.

Mr Portillo's friends on the frontbench recognise that the party needs to say something dramatic on tax to win back its credentials on an issue traditionally seen as the stronghold of Conservatism.

Mr Hague resisted a move by Mr Portillo to abandon the guarantee altogether when the latter entered the shadow cabinet following his re-entry to parliament in a byelection, though he was allowed to have two other policy u-turns - acceptance of both the national minimum wage and the independence of the Bank of England.

fields.headline: Celtic revival
fields.standfirst: Twenty years ago The Romans in Britain shocked the nation with its scenes of nudity and male rape. And now?  Lyn Gardner  reports
fields.trailText: Twenty years ago The Romans in Britain shocked the nation with its scenes of nudity and male rape. And now? Lyn Gardner reports
fields.body:
'A nauseating load of rubbish from beginning to end," was critic James Fenton's response when The Romans in Britain premiered at the National Theatre in 1980. He was not alone in his outrage. Like Edward Bond's Saved before it, and Sarah Kane's Blasted since, Howard Brenton's Romans fell victim to critical blindness, moral outrage and tabloid titillation. Few could see beyond the play's most famous scene: the anal and oral homosexual rape of a naked young Celt by soldiers in the invading Roman army.

That self-styled moral guardian of the nation, Mary Whitehouse, had neither seen nor read the play, but that didn't stop her launching a private prosecution against the director, Michael Bogdanov, accusing him of effectively acting as a pimp by procuring people to perform immoral acts.

After a year as a cause célèbre, the case was withdrawn. The hue and cry subsided, and The Romans in Britain faded into obscurity as a footnote to British theatre history.

Twenty years on, it is hard to see what the fuss was all about. The Romans in Britain - getting its first London revival at the tiny Man in the Moon theatre in Chelsea - is still shocking; but it is not the onstage buggery that makes you reel and want to cover your face with your hands. After all, anal sex is all the rage on the London stage, with Giuseppe Manfridi's painful farce Cuckoos packing them in at the Gate.

No, the thing that makes you push yourself back in your seat as far as you can go is the relentless agony of a play that is suffused with sorrow at the inhumanity of mankind - our self-perpetuating, self-destructive violence and our wicked, wicked hearts.

This is an intensely moral play, and there is a strange kind of beauty in its ferocity. As with the stoning of the baby in Bond's Saved, and the obscenities of Kane's Blasted, the acts of appalling violence are not gratuitous but organic. The rape has little to do with sex and everything to do with power. "Nig-nogs" is how the invading Romans refer to the Celts, robbing them of their humanity. Things not people.

What Brenton captures is the terror of living constantly on the edge and with the expectation that the world you know could end at any moment - that your way of life, all your beliefs, could be snuffed out almost overnight by an occupying force. On mainland Britain, where we have lived for hundreds of years free from invasion, that may be hard for us to get our heads round. But if you live in Ireland, the Balkans, Africa or many other parts of the world, that fear becomes part of your psyche. As the young girl abducted and sold into slavery points out, fear breeds violence. "Now home is where I have a stone in my hand," she says. There is no room for compassion in this world.

Brenton picks over these bones of history - and the "get off my land" mentality - with a ravenous intensity, only faltering when he attempts to make direct links with England's involvement in Ireland. The modern scenes, set in an Irish field where British soldiers patrol and Republicans hold sway, are much more crudely written, and while you applaud Brenton's political fervour, you wish it were not at the expense of his playwriting skill. If this work has failed to become a classic, like Saved and Blasted, it is because its specificity to Ireland makes it both less universal and more dated.

But it is undoubtedly worth reviving, not least for its huge sweep and its grim humour. The evening ends on a joke as two cooks, realising that their employment prospects in a time of war are slim, turn storytellers and invent the myth of King Arthur. The unknowability of history and the way it is manufactured have seldom been better demonstrated on stage. There are good things too in David Craik's production: the intimate space makes this epic a genuinely full-frontal experience, and there are some some impressive performances, particularly from Michael Hucks (who plays both Caesar and a British intelligence officer) and Michael Kurchener (the rape victim Marban).

It is worth remembering that The Romans in Britain was premiered in 1980, closer chronologically to the era of censorship (abolished in 1968) than to the 21st century and our ready acceptance of such sexually explicit plays such as Shopping and Fucking. Perhaps it is a sign of how much audiences' sensibilities and concerns have changed that the show's programme does not warn us of nudity, violence, strong language or buggery. Instead, it cautions that "this show contains strobe lighting".

 At the Man in the Moon, London SW3 (0171-351 2876), till May 6.

On mainland Britain, where we have lived for hundreds of years free from invasion, that may be hard for us to get our heads round. But if you live in Ireland, the Balkans, Africa or many other parts of the world, that fear becomes part of your psyche. As the young girl abducted and sold into slavery points out, fear breeds violence. "Now home is where I have a stone in my hand," she says. There is no room for compassion in this world. Brenton picks over these bones of history - and the "get off my land" mentality - with a ravenous intensity, only faltering when he attempts to make direct links with England's involvement in Ireland. The modern scenes, set in an Irish field where British soldiers patrol and Republicans hold sway, are much more crudely written, and while you applaud Brenton's political fervour, you wish it were not at the expense of his playwriting skill. If this work has failed to become a classic, like Saved and Blasted, it is because its specificity to Ireland makes it both less universal and more dated. But it is undoubtedly worth reviving, not least for its huge sweep and its grim humour. The evening ends on a joke as two cooks, realising that their employment prospects in a time of war are slim, turn storytellers and invent the myth of King Arthur. The unknowability of history and the way it is manufactured have seldom been better demonstrated on stage. There are good things too in David Craik's production: the intimate space makes this epic a genuinely full-frontal experience, and there are some some impressive performances, particularly from Michael Hucks (who plays both Caesar and a British intelligence officer) and Michael Kurchener (the rape victim Marban). It is worth remembering that The Romans in Britain was premiered in 1980, closer chronologically to the era of censorship (abolished in 1968) than to the 21st century and our ready acceptance of such sexually explicit plays such as Shopping and Fucking. Perhaps it is a sign of how much audiences' sensibilities and concerns have changed that the show's programme does not warn us of nudity, violence, strong language or buggery. Instead, it cautions that "this show contains strobe lighting".  At the Man in the Moon, London SW3 (0171-351 2876), till May 6.

fields.headline: Bring on the dancing hippos
fields.trailText: Wave Riding
fields.body:
Waiting for a lecture to start on the radio is akin to sitting in the theatre before a play begins. The murmurs of the audience rise and fall - brief conversations spoken in deep whispers and illustrated with exaggerated body language. Expectation hangs in the air, and you can almost feel the red velvet seat beneath you as the auditorium falls silent. Just before Kate Adie welcomed us to the first of this year's Reith Lectures (Radio 4, Wednesday), the house lights dimmed, even if only in my head.

This year's theme is Sustainable Development, and Chris Patten kicked off with an ode to good government and how democracy is "the least worst way" to protect the environment. "Dictators are rarely friends of the earth," he mused.

Like all accomplished public speakers, he began with a personal story - of how, when he was minister for overseas development, he visited a refugee camp in Ethiopia - and extrapolated from there. With references ranging from Isaiah through A Man for All Seasons to a Chinese sage of 6000BC, Patten's speech, though heavy on political science, was stimulating.

His views were only ever going to be the start of a debate (the series runs for five more weeks). But while some of his points were highly dubious - his near-demonisation of some non-governmental organisations and the rewriting of how great for the environment his own party was when in government - his talk struck the right balance between appealing to the specially invited, especially interested, audience and to the just-tuned-in radio (or, indeed, internet) listener.

Having learned about political ecosystems from Patten, Leading Edge (Radio 4, Thursday) revealed all about another baffling science - particle physics. Since the sum total of my knowledge of physics is derived from watching Star Trek and The X-Files (which, I admit, may not be the most reliable teachers), Geoff Watts telling all about dark matter was a revelation. Deep inside an Italian mountain, scientists are attempting to detect the signatures created by particles of dark matter. Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (Wimps), probably constitute 90% of the matter in the universe (hence the Massive) but since they are almost impossible to detect (hence Weakly Interacting), no one is quite sure.

For some reason, this analysis made me think of the balletic hippos in Fantasia, invisible to the naked eye but swirling around, swathed in acres of taffeta.

Probably happily (for I always thought dark matter was bad because that's what Agent Mulder said), the Italians think they have found Wimps, and in significant numbers too (a host of hippos, as it were). They were giddy at the prospect and the potential: Italian scientists and invisible hippos dancing a celebratory jig beneath a 1,400ft mountain. You see what happens when you rely on popular culture for your education?

 Anne Karpf is away.

fields.headline: The incredible journey
fields.standfirst: Did St Thomas found a church in south India?  William Dalrymple  unravels a Christian mystery
fields.trailText: Did St Thomas found a church in south India? William Dalrymple unravels a Christian mystery
fields.body:
The rains come to Kerala for months at a time. It is the greenest state in India: hot and humid, still and brooding. The soil is so fertile that as you drift up the lotus-choked waterways, the trees close in around you, as twisting tropical fan vaults of palm and bamboo arch together in the forest canopy. Mango trees hang heavy over the fishermen's skiffs; pepper vines creep through the fronds of the waterside papaya orchards.

In this country live a people who believe that St Thomas - the apostle of Jesus who famously refused to believe in the resurrection "until I have placed my hands in the holes left by the nails and the wound left by the spear" - came to India from Palestine after the Resurrection, and that he baptised their ancestors. Moreover, this is not a modern tradition: it has been the firm conviction of the Christians here since at least the sixth century AD.

In 594 AD, the French monastic chronicler Gregory of Tours met a wandering Greek monk who reported that, in southern India, he had met Christians who had told him about St Thomas's missionary journey to India and who had shown him the tomb of the apostle. Over the centuries to come, almost every western traveller to southern India, from Marco Polo to the first Portuguese conquistadors, reported the same story.

The legend of St Thomas led to the first-ever recorded journey to India by an Englishman: according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, King Alfred (he of the burned cakes) sent Bishop Sighelm of Sherborne "to St Thomas in India"; years later, the bishop returned, carrying with him "precious stones and the odiferous essences of that country".

The stories that the travellers brought back with them varied little: all said how in India, St Thomas was universally believed to have arrived in AD 52 from Palestine by boat; that he had travelled down the Red Sea and across the Persian Gulf, and that he landed at the great Keralan port of Cranganore, the spice trading centre to which the Roman Red Sea merchant fleet would head each year, to buy pepper and Indian slave girls for the Mediterranean market.

In Kerala, St Thomas was said to have converted the local Brahmins with the aid of miracles and to have built seven churches. He then headed eastwards to the ancient temple town of Mylapore, now in the suburbs of Madras. There the saint was opposed by the orthodox Brahmins of the temple, and finally martyred. His followers built a tomb and monastery over his grave which, said the travellers, was now a pilgrimage centre for Muslims and Hindus, as well as Christians in southern India.

Although the historicity of the legend is unprovable, the modern St Thomas Christians - as they still call themselves - regard this tradition as more than a myth: it is an article of faith which underpins religious beliefs, identity and their place in Indian society. It is a tradition they go to extraordinary lengths to preserve and to propagate - not least by establishing what is almost certainly Christianity's only troupe of dancing nuns.

Moreover they are agreed - as are many of their Hindu neigh bours - that St Thomas is not dead: that he is still present in Kerala, guarding his followers and guiding his church. This was palpable at the small "miracle church" of Putenangadi, south of Cochin. At a time when the violent conflict between Hindus and Christians in north India was making headlines across the world, members of both faiths could be found side by side crammed into the same church, all convinced that St Thomas was present in the building to answer the prayers of his devotees.

At the back of his church, I came across an old Hindu woman named Jaya. I asked her why she chose to pray in a Christian church: "So that I can be relieved of all my troubles," she replied. "It is that faith that brings me here. If there's anything I need, I ask St Thomas for it."

"But, as a Hindu, why would you come to a Christian church?," I asked. "Why not go to the temple?" "Because I have faith," she repeated simply. "When I have difficulties, St Thomas solves them for me. Of course, I go to the temple too. But any big problem I have, I come here and I pray, and my prayers are always answered. For me, St Thomas is definitely alive."

Later, Jaya introduced me to her Christian friend, Miriam. "In my experience, praying to St Thomas here is always effective," said Miriam. "Whatever I need I pray for and my prayers are heard and answered. Of course, there is God, but it is St Thomas's name that we call. He is all I have."

The trail of St Thomas's journey to India begins thousands of miles from Kerala in the deserts of the Middle East. In the sixth century, the Byzantine empire was beginning to crumble under a wave of attacks, and the great classical cities of the east Mediterranean were falling into ruin and decay. As their libraries and universities were burned down or deserted, many of the most important manuscripts were preserved in the library of a remote monastery in the deserts of the Sinai now known as St Catherine's.

Its great walls and sheer isolation preserved it from attacks for centuries. Protected from their enemies, the monks accumulated one of the greatest treasuries of icons and illuminated manuscripts in the Christian world. Scholars who penetrated the region in the 19th century were astonished to find in the monastery a library of unmatched richness, containing lost works by great classical authors and the oldest extant copy of the New Testament.

But perhaps the strangest discovery of all was a previously unknown early Christian text dating from the fourth century AD entitled the Acts of St Thomas. The manuscript told a story that had been forgotten in the traditions of the western Church. According to the Acts, St Thomas was Jesus's twin (the Syriac for Thomas - Te'oma - means twin, as does his Greek name, Didymos); like his brother, he was a carpenter from Galilee.

After Jesus's death, according to the Acts, the apostle had been summoned to India - and his martyrdom - by a mysterious king, Gondophares. Biblical scholars of the 19th century were at first very sceptical of the Acts of St Thomas. They correctly pointed out that the story contained many clearly apocryphal Gnostic elements, and that the earliest surviving version of the text, written in fourth century Mesopotamia, dated from at least two centuries after the events described; up to the beginning of this century, the document was sometimes dismissed as a pious romance.

Nevertheless over the past 100 years, as research has progressed both into ancient Indian history and the links between India and the Roman Middle East, a series of remarkable discoveries have gone a long way to prove that the story contained in the Acts seems to be built on surprisingly solid historical foundations. First, British archaeologists working in late 19th-century India began to find hoards of coins belonging to a previously unknown Indian king: the Rajah Gondophares, who ruled from AD19 to AD45. If St Thomas had ever been summoned to India, it would have been Rajah Gondophares who would have done it, just as the Acts had always maintained.

The fact that the Acts had accurately preserved the name of an obscure Indian rajah, whose name and lineage had disappeared, implied that it must contain at least a nucleus of genuine historical information. Archaeological discoveries have since confirmed many other details of the story, revealing that maritime contacts between the Roman world and India were much more extensive than anyone had realised.

In the 1930s, Sir Mortimer Wheeler discovered and excavated a major Roman trading station on the south Indian coast, while other scholars unearthed references showing that in Thomas's time, the trick of sailing with the monsoon had just been discovered, reducing the journey time from the Red Sea to India to just under 40 days. According to a previously overlooked remark by Strabo, first- century geographer and historian, 200 Roman trading vessels a year were making the annual journey to the bazaars of Malabar and back.

More intriguing still, analysis of Roman coin hoards in India has shown that the Roman spice trade peaked exactly in the middle of the first century AD. All this showed that if St Thomas had wanted to come to India, the passage from Palestine, far from being near-impossible, would in fact have been easier, more frequent and probably cheaper than at anytime in the next 1,500 years - until Vasco da Gama discovered the sea route to the Indies in 1498.

Scholars discovered further confirmation of the Acts in the practices of the St Thomas Christians. Since the second world war, theologians have become increasingly aware of the Jewishness of Jesus and his first disciples: it has become apparent, for example, that the first Christians of the early church- those who knew Jesus and his teaching personally - would have carried on going to the temple in Jerusalem, performing sacrifices and circumcisions, and obeying the Jewish food laws.

If St Thomas had carried Christianity to India, it is likely that he would have taken a distinctly more Jewish form than the Gentile-friendly version developed for the Greeks of Antioch by St Paul and later exported to Europe. Hence the importance of the fact that some of the St Thomas Christian churches to this day retain Judeo-Christian practices long dropped in the west - such as the celebration of the solemn Passover feast.

Hence also the significance of the St Thomas Christians still using the two earliest Christian liturgies in existence: the Mass of Addai and Mari, and the Liturgy of St James, once used by the early Church of Jerusalem. More remarkable still, these ancient services are still partly sung in Aramaic, the language spoken by Jesus and St Thomas.

The more you investigate the evidence, the more irresistible is the conclusion that whether or not St Thomas himself came to India, he certainly could have. And if he didn't make the journey, it seems certain that some other very early Christian missionary did, for there is certainly evidence for a substantial Christian population in India by at least the third century.

And if there is no documentary proof to clinch the case, there is at least a very good reason for its absence: for the entire historical documentation of the St Thomas Christians was reduced to ashes in the 16th century - not by Muslims or Hindus, but by a newly arrived European Christian power: the Portuguese. As far as the Portuguese colonial authorities were concerned, the St Thomas Christians were heretics, an idea confirmed by their belief in astrology and reincarnation, and the Hindu-style sculptures of elephants and dancing girls found carved on their crosses.

Notions that they might also have maintained early Christian traditions predating the arrival of the faith in Europe were dismissed out of hand. The Inquisition was brought in, and the historical records of the St Thomas Christians put to the flame. Yet the old stories did survive, locked in the minds and memories of Christians in inaccessible Keralan backwaters.

In songs and dances passed on from father to son and teacher to pupil, they preserved intact many of their most ancient traditions. Scholars now believe that if the answer to the riddle of the legends of St Thomas lies anywhere, it is in this rich and largely unstudied Keralan oral tradition.

The man who has done more than anything to preserve this heritage is a plump catholic priest and village schoolteacher named Father Jacob Vellian. Working in isolation in his spare time, with little help and pitiful resources, Fr Jacob has since 1973 single-handedly travelled from village to village in Kerala systematically collecting Christian songs and dances about St Thomas's travels and exploits in India.

On two occasions, hidden in remote villages, he stumbled across palm-leaf books from the 16th century, which preserved other fragments of the songs and ballads in tiny Malayalam lettering: the oldest surviving documentation of the St Thomas Christians. There were, he discovered, still current in the Keralan countryside, hundreds of songs recording the deeds of St Thomas, as well two ancient full-length ballads, the older of which, The Margam Kali Pattu or Song of the Way, was of epic proportions.

Both these ballads predated the coming of the Portuguese and both, from their very archaic language, showed every sign of dating from the earliest centuries AD.

Almost everywhere Fr Vellian found the oral tradition on the verge of extinction, with the young people unwilling to carry on the job of learning by heart the complex stanzas. In several places he was able to record lost fragments of the epics just weeks before the last of the asans (or village bards) died, taking their songs to their grave. "Over the years I have tried to meet with every Christian asan in Kerala," Vellian told me. "Most of them were illiterate: isolated old men who were only barely aware of the importance of what they were clinging on to. Some had a few disciples and were very eager to teach what they knew; others had none. But no one was trying to write down what they had preserved. No one was promoting them or rewarding them for their work.

"As a result much must have been lost: not one asan knew the whole of the two longest ballads: some knew 20%; some 70%. But the 14 sections that we now have seems to be the whole of The Song of the Way, and the job now is to study this and to make sure it is passed on." To that end, Vellian has been building on another, almost lost Keralan tradition: the dancing nuns of Malabar. Fr Vellian has spent the last few years training up some of the many hundreds of nuns of Kerala to dance the ancient dances of St Thomas, and groups of wimpled sisters can now be seen swaying uncertainly to the beat of the tabla as they attempt to master the dances which tell of the apostle's travels. In this way, what may be the last surviving link with the tradition of the apostles is now being preserved by a group of south Indian Whoopi Goldbergs.

Fr Vellian is adamant that the oral traditions have accurately preserved a series of texts that may well hold vital clues which could help prove the St Thomas legend: "The palm-leaf documents that we have collected show how accurately the bards have preserved the text," he says. "Here or there a word may have changed, in the 300 years since the earliest was written down, but by and large the versions we have collected in the fields are consistent both with each other and these palm leaf-texts. These traditions are an authentic and incredibly valuable and ancient source of Christian history, and should be respected as such."

Vellian is right. For while Christianity has never been a major faith in India, it is a religion with deep roots, which has clung on with incredible tenacity, despite all the odds. Above all, the church here has remained faithful to the tradition of St Thomas's journey from Palestine to India. It is a story long forgotten in a west which has come to regard itself as the true home of the faith, forgetting that in essence, Christianity is an eastern religion.

Before leaving Kerala, I asked Dr Vellian whether he really believed his work would eventually provide some conclusive evidence to prove St Thomas's journey. "In the end, we are the evidence," he said. "We have a very ancient, unbroken tradition that St. Thomas was the founder of the church in India. Our traditions are unanimous that he came here, and that is something we have held on to, despite persecution, for 1,700 years. Our spirituality is very close to that of the early church and we believe our church is as old as any Apostolic Church in the world. Our songs and traditions are quite clear about this. In the end it is these traditions that we base our belief on: not something on paper or stone which is secondary. It is our fidelity to St Thomas that is most important to us."

 William Dalrymple's film, Doubting Thomas, the third in his series Indian Journeys, will be shown on BBC2 on Monday at 7.10pm.
