webTitle: Where to source the best British cheeses

fields.headline: Where to source the best British cheeses
fields.standfirst: The typical supermarket version of British cheese is a vacuum-packed slab of rubber. But, says Claire Phipps, there is another option
fields.trailText: The typical supermarket version of British cheese is a vacuum-packed slab of rubber. But, says Claire Phipps, there is another option
fields.body:
So, I'm standing in Neal's Yard Dairy in Covent Garden while around me several cheeses lounge about, humming gently to themselves, and I'm looking for that rarity, the traditional Caerphilly. What's more, I'm looking for one that topped the league of Welsh cheeses at last year's British Cheese Awards. Fortunately, Geoffrey can help. He points me in the direction of the two Caerphillys stocked by Neal's Yard Dairy (020-7379 7646), one by Chris Duckett, Somerset cheesemaker and bestower of the Caerphilly baton to one Martin (known as Todd) Trethowan, whose cheese I've come in search of today.

Maugan Trethowan, brother and business partner of Todd, describes their cheese as having "a fresh, lemony taste, slightly salty and well-rounded; it lasts in your mouth", which is better than I could have phrased it. Todd and two enthusiastic employees turn out 114 8lb cheeses every week, all made by hand, from their farm tucked under the Cambrian mountains in Ceredigion.

So far, so authentic. They use traditional methods to a traditional recipe to produce a traditional Caerphilly of the type lugged underground by Welsh miners in generous, cake-like wedges. It's a surprise, then, to discover that the gold medal-winning Gorwydd Caerphilly business is all of four years old, and that the brothers (whisper it) aren't actually Welsh. Maugan joined the fledgling family firm only two years ago, turning his back on a career in archaeology to get his hands stuck into the curds and whey business. "I'd been involved in helping out before," he says, "so it was the logical step to join full-time. I was enjoying archaeology, but the prospect of my own business, making an award-winning cheese, was a challenge." Besides, he says, the two aren't so different: "I always enjoyed the physical side of archaeology, the digging, the hands-on work, being out and about. Cheesemaking is very similar. There's the same sense of satisfaction."

Founding partner Todd had solid reasons for choosing the Welsh countryside to try his hand at making a Caerphilly, though. The Trethowans have their links with the country, admittedly via Cornwall, but, more important, after 10 years of working with cheesemakers the length of Britain, Todd had realised that Welsh-made Caerphilly was something of an endangered species. A former Neal's Yard Dairy employee himself, he'd been sent out to learn life at the stickier end of the business, and found himself happier amid the rennet. Armed with the Caerphilly recipe divulged to him by Duckett (with "certain modifications"), Todd decided to go west.

Ask why a Welsh Caerphilly should be better than a Wherever Caerphilly, and the reasons come thick and fast. A territorial cheese such as Caerphilly thrives in certain environmental conditions - rainfall (presumably lots of), mould and soil types, humidity - which Todd found in abundance at Gorwydd Farm, wedged between the shadow of the Cambrians and the banks of the Teifi. Pitching up here meant a ready supply of real Welsh milk from real Welsh cows belonging to real Welsh farmers - who, unsurprisingly, are thrilled at the revival of the dairy tradition on their doorstep. "Our local ties are important to us," Maugan says. "The farmers are pleased that we've decided to do this here."

Help was also forthcoming from various Welsh business agencies, keen to see Caerphilly re-established in its homeland. In an EC Objective One area (categorised as being in need of financial assistance to reach European levels of investment and employment), the Trethowans are doing their bit to keep the area's dairy heritage healthy. And, despite plans to boost production of their Caerphilly, they have no intention of moving out of Ceredigion.

"We're definitely staying," says Maugan. "We've got a good system, with enthusiastic people who care about the cheese. We've no plans to go global." So, despite ferrying their cheeses to all corners of the kingdom, and even over the waters to America, the team at Gorwydd Farm will continue to cut the curd and texture the cheese with minimal mechanical intervention, and to set up stall at London's Borough Market every weekend to sell big wedges of Welsh heritage to the vacuum-packed Cheddar generation.

And my description of the Gorwydd Caerphilly to a member of the aforementioned generation? I could laud the creamy outside (known as the "breakdown"), which changes subtly in flavour as the cheese matures, or enthuse about the firmer, flakier centre, which has more of a kick. But, most of all, it tastes like cheese - hand-textured, hand-moulded, hands-on cheese.

fields.headline: Crowning glory
fields.standfirst: With two star-studded productions of Richard II now thrilling audiences  Michael Billington  reflects on what makes the play a profound political work
fields.trailText: With two star-studded productions of Richard II now thrilling audiences Michael Billington reflects on what makes the play a profound political work
fields.body:
Comparisons, says Dogberry, are odorous. They are also sometimes inevitable. And when you see a pair of kings in a fortnight - Richard II at the Gainsborough Studios in Shoreditch, east London and at The Other Place in Stratford- upon-Avon - it's difficult not to start ruminating on acting, politics, Shakespeare and even the state of England itself.

Space, of course, is a determining factor on performance, something critics rarely acknowledge. In opening up a former film studio and Edwardian power station for the Almeida's Gainsborough Studios Richard, Jonathan Kent and his team have come across a magnificent ruin: one in which the walls are not so much distressed as in a very bad way. But, though we gaze in awe at this dilapidated industrial cathedral, its sheer scale sometimes leads the actors towards anonymous rhetoric. Cut to Stratford where Steven Pimlott is staging Richard II in an intimate 200-seater. The great advantage is that the actors can converse rather than bellow: the problem is, the production is sold out. Small may be beautiful. It is also, by definition, exclusive.

Acting areas dictate style. They also explain some of the key differences between Ralph Fiennes's Shoreditch Richard and Samuel West's Stratford one. Fiennes has to use expressive body language and an extensive vocal palette to get his points across: West can afford to be quietly sardonic. But what fascinates me is how both strenuously avoid lyricism and sympathy. Richard always used to be seen as irresponsible in the first half and elegiac in the second. But such is our modern cynicism about kingship that neither actor craves our indulgence. You can't help but feel for the deposed, humiliated Richard. But both Fiennes and West imply that Shakespeare's hero is as much imprisoned by monarchy as by literal incarceration.

The real difference, however, lies in the directors' approaches to the play. For Kent, politics seem marginal: for Pimlott, you feel, they are the main reason for doing the work. And what hit me like a thunderclap is that the real key to Richard II lies in how you interpret Bolingbroke: the man who seizes the throne. In the old days you cast your smooth actor as Richard, your hairy one as Bolingbroke. It was John Barton who shattered the stereotype in 1973 by having Ian Richardson and Richard Pasco alternate the two roles - suddenly they became a mirror image of each other. Deborah Warner picked up on the idea in her 90s National Theatre production by suggesting a strange sibling kinship between Fiona Shaw's Richard and David Threlfall's usurper.

What is clear is that both are awoken to the isolation and fragility of power. Richard is unseated by Bolingbroke - the latter discovers that illegality opens the door to rebellion. But Pimlott takes this much further. West's Richard is a heedless tyrant, David Troughton's Bolingbroke is a purposeful one. What both have is the absolutist's ability to hide behind the sanctity of God and nationhood. In the Westminster deposition scene West, quite literally, wraps himself in the national flag. Troughton meanwhile, appealing to a divine right he himself has shattered, at one point asks the audience to rise in prayer. This brilliantly pins down the tendency of dictators, and even democratic politicians, to cloak themselves in convenient abstractions - a point Pinter has tirelessly made in his recent political plays.

Shakespeare's history plays are not just about the Tudor myth: they are actually about the daily practice of power. In that sense, they are the greatest political plays ever written. What you can't do today is ignore their ramifications. I would not claim Kent does that at Shoreditch. He reflects our scepticism about monarchy, and in David Burke's John of Gaunt and Oliver Ford Davies's Duke of York he depicts the extremes of passion and vacillation.

But his failure lies in leaving Bolingbroke an enigma. What on earth is Linus Roache up to? Is he suggesting Bolingbroke returns from exile simply to claim his lands? Or does his quietude imply he is a crafty opportunist hoping the crown will fall into his lap? The fact is we simply never know. Having gained power, this Bolingbroke also never seems to exercise it. He casually condemns Richard's favourites to death. Troughton personally puts a bullet through their brains.

Audiences, I suspect, are drawn to Richard II by the prospect of a star performance - they certainly get that in spades from the richly expressive Fiennes. The reality is, however, that it is Bolingbroke who motors the play from the initial appeal against Mowbray to the final remorse over Richard's death. Put Bolingbroke at the centre, as they do at Stratford, and you have a profoundly political work. Make Richard the spotlit focus, as they do in Shoreditch, and you have the lesser form of tragedy.

 Jonathan Kent's Richard II is at the Gainsborough Studios, London N1 (0171-359 4404), till May 20. Steven Pimlott's Richard II is at The Other Place, Stratford-upon-Avon, (01789-403403), till October 5.

fields.headline: Bohemian rhapsody enchants the US
fields.standfirst: Americans are turning their backs on mainstream morals, a new study claims
fields.trailText: Bohemia is alive and well in the United States, according to a new study which claims that bohemianism has changed everything from the face of the family to the way America thinks about work.
fields.body:
Bohemia is alive and well in the United States, according to a new study which claims that bohemianism has changed everything from the face of the family to the way America thinks about work.

A new book by the US cultural critic and pop writer Ann Powers claims that, far from being a dead concept, bohemianism has burrowed deep into the American psyche, and that the "bohemian diaspora moves on all fronts".

Ms Powers, who has worked both as a pop critic for the New York Times and as an editor at the Village Voice, suggests that "the plentiful evidence that bohemian values have affected the mainstream is often overlooked".

She says that bohemianism has created new frameworks for the family and the workplace, given people different ways to deal with the consumer culture, opened up the cultural conversation about sex and drugs, and "refigured adulthood" to better suit people's lives.

Her book comes as conservative critics attack the way they claim the arts have undermined American values to such an extent that a film such as American Beauty, which mocks suburban lifestyles and morals, can win a batch of Oscars.

The term bohemia was coined to describe Paris's cafe society rebels of the 1830s. It was used by the writer Henri Murger in his novel Scènes de la Vie de Bohème in 1849 and achieved its greatest fame through Puccini's opera La Bohème at the turn of the century. The term has since become shorthand for unconventionality, whether social, sexual or cultural.

Ms Powers believes that the US is now witnessing the triumphant resurrection of bohemianism in such a way that its credos have been adopted almost unquestioningly by the mainstream.

"The counter-culture made lifestyle experiments mass phenomena, and 40 years later there are Bob Dylan seminars at universities and New Age health spas at the mall," says Ms Powers. "Some bohemian challenges have always been adopted in the mainstream, but the general refusal of conventionality remained a lonely choice. Now, however, this oppositional style has become another norm."

Ms Powers notes that the reason that bohemianism's success has not been acknowledged is that "as left politics founder, with no over-arching radical movement in sight and with liberalism moving ever rightward, setting aside public matters for private ones can seem like a cop-out. Many on the left feel that turning inwards signals only laziness and narcissism".

But she concludes that "from the sketch artists of Henri Murger's time to today's website iconoclasts, bohemians have preoccupied themselves with a challenge that outlasts the milieu's changing costumes and crazes, to confront and reinvigorate the premises of society, the definitions of kinship, labour, love, leisure, consumerism, and identity itself.

"It is time now for these serious matters to overshadow the flashy performances of the past," Ms Powers writes. Conservative cultural critics believe that her thesis is all too true.

The Newsday columnist James Pinkerton argues that "American beauty is more than just another best picture winner, it's a cultural breakout: a magnetic chunk of bohemia plunked down in every suburban multiplex.

"There it lies alluringly - all ripe red roses, cool video blues and nude pink flesh."

He claims that increasingly a "glamorous nihilism" is seeping into the popular culture.

Other commentators have noted the arrival of what was once seen as a bohemian lifestyle into the mainstream.

David Frum, writing in the New York Times on the death of Alex Comfort, the author of The Joy of Sex, notes that the sexual behaviour of Americans has changed enormously in the last few decades. What was once regarded as bohemian is now the norm.

"Only 2% of women who came of age in the 1950s had slept with as many as five men by their 30th birthdays; 22.5% of the post-Vietnam group had carved that many notches in their bedposts."

webTitle: Police hold suspected global serial killer

fields.headline: Police hold suspected global serial killer
fields.trailText:
In a macabre milestone in the inexorable spread of globalisation, police in Detroit say they have arrested the world's first international serial killer. A former US navy sailor is being linked with at least 15 mainly female victims in seven 
 countries on three continents.
fields.body:
In a macabre milestone in the inexorable spread of globalisation, police in Detroit say they have arrested the world's first international serial killer. A former US navy sailor is being linked with at least 15 mainly female victims in seven countries on three continents.

John Eric Armstrong, a 26-year-old married man was arrested on Wednesday after the bodies of three prostitutes were found. He was due to appear in court yesterday.

webTitle: Love and sunshine succeed where soup kitchens fail

fields.headline: Love and sunshine succeed where soup kitchens fail
fields.trailText: The first Mary Di Corretto knew of the jubilee celebrations was when police with flashlights entered her tunnel beneath Termini railway station and shooed her out.
fields.body:
The first Mary Di Corretto knew of the jubilee celebrations was when police with flashlights entered her tunnel beneath Termini railway station and shooed her out.

The tunnel may have been smelly and dark but it was home, and she hollered in protest before stuffing her possessions into two sports bags and shuffling outside.

Accommodation choices were limited for a penniless 40-year-old Nigerian vagrant so she settled for a bench on the west side of Termini and found someone who could explain the jubilee.

The Vatican calls it the Great Jubilee: a year of Catholic commemoration, celebration and contemplation. Rome has hosted one roughly every 25 years since Pope Boniface VIII summoned pilgrims in 1300.

This jubilee is the biggest ever. Pope John Paul II persuaded the city to spend more than £1bn in preparation for an expected 26m pilgrims.

Termini station had to be expanded, so police evicted vagrants, prostitutes and drug addicts from its tunnels. That was last October. Little was done to help the evicted: just 800 beds for a homeless population of up to 4,000.

I first met Mary in January, her third month sleeping outdoors on the bench. She was covered in four blankets and four layers of clothing. Her eyes were bloodshot, her skin grey and her words slurred. She wanted a bottle of wine - and to be allowed back into her tunnel.

Although she didn't know it, that day the Vatican and city had made a better offer. Soup kitchens were to be set up and shelters with hundreds of beds were to be provided. The move followed the news that nine vagrants had frozen to death in two weeks in a travesty of the jubilee's theme of compassion.

Mary was suspicious. "I can just go there and eat and sleep? How come?" She would have to think about it.

Pilgrims and tourists have poured in since then. Sunshine and Easter ceremonies have doubled the number of visitors to more than 2m a month. They pass through Fiumicino airport's new extension, hop on trains and arrive at a bright and airy Termini. Beyond lies a city gleaming with restored monuments.

Last week at Termini, a woman wearing blue jeans, a yellow shirt and a hair ribbon waved as I passed. Mary. She smiled, showing perfect teeth, and marvelled at the sunshine. Her eyes were clear and her skin smooth. Winter was a memory and she was happy.

The shelters found her a home? "Nah, I never went. I didn't have anywhere to leave my stuff. I'm still here." She pointed to her sports bags beneath a bench.

"It's not so bad. I watch the tourists coming, I've got friends, it's warm." Her voice lowered. "I've met someone. We're together now." Mary was in love.

It may not last, she still craves wine, and winter will return. But Mary has rediscovered human companionship, another theme of the jubilee. And for now at least, she feels part of it.

webTitle: This gravy train is second class, EU officials say

fields.headline: This gravy train is second class, EU officials say
fields.trailText: The enduring image of Brussels Eurocrats as a bunch of feather-bedded fat cats riding an everlasting gravy train took a knock yesterday after an independent study which shows that they often earn around £20,000 a year less than their peers in multinationals.
fields.body:
The enduring image of Brussels Eurocrats as a bunch of feather-bedded fat cats riding an everlasting gravy train took a knock yesterday after an independent study which shows that they often earn around £20,000 a year less than their peers in multinationals.

Although the report was written at the behest of the European commission, it was drawn up by a Danish firm which pledges that its findings are entirely "objective and independent".

The commission, while careful not to be seen to be pleading poverty, said the report shattered the myth of overpaid EU officials.

"The report shows that some of the exaggerated stories banded about describing overpaid Eurocrats wallowing in tax-free allowances are just not true," one source said.

"There are plenty of people in comparable jobs who earn just as much, contrary to what some would have you believe."

The report shows that a top commission official without dependants takes home about £78,000 a year after tax. This is about the same as officials earn in organisations such as Nato and the United Nations.

However, their counterparts at a large multinational corporation can expect to make just over £100,000 a year.

If an official is married and has children there are special allowances which inflate these figures - but the equivalent private sector job still pays better.

"We're not making out that we're poor or badly paid", another official said, "but we do need a measure of objectivity in this debate." He added: "There are people in several high-profile departments who could leave the commission tomorrow and double their salaries."

The report does show that EU functionaries do considerably better than civil servants in most member-state countries, often raking in twice as much as their national counterparts do.

But, according to Peter Guilford, a senior spokesman at the commission, calls to cut officials' salaries are ill-judged and, if heeded, would backfire.

"If you attack the salary structure you'll end up with a lower quality European civil service. Wages are higher than national civil servants, but you wouldn't be able to get people to come to Brussels otherwise."

In June Neil Kinnock, in his capacity as commission vice president, is expected to suggest the commission's existing salary structure be left in place for a further 18 months.

fields.headline: Island rebellion risks religious war
fields.standfirst: Rebels are mobilising in the Philippines as a ceasefire lies in tatters
fields.trailText: The long single file of soldiers heading for the front line conjured up images of the first world war. Wearing neatly pressed uniforms, guns cradled in their arms or slung over their shoulders, the young men looked eager for the fight.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  in Camp Abu Bakre, Mindanao
fields.body:
The long single file of soldiers heading for the front line conjured up images of the first world war. Wearing neatly pressed uniforms, guns cradled in their arms or slung over their shoulders, the young men looked eager for the fight.

But this was not the battlefields of Flanders in 1914 - it was this week, on the southern Philippines island of Mindanao. The soldiers belong to the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (Milf), an Islamic separatist group that is fighting to establish a separate country in western Mindanao.

The latest flare-up in the conflict with Manila, which has been going on for nearly 30 years, has revived fears that the island could succumb to the kind of internecine violence wracking parts of neighbouring Indonesia.

A ceasefire signed by the rebels and the Manila government might as well be torn up. Fighting erupted a month ago and is escalating, particularly in northern provinces where more than 100,000 people have fled their homes.

The Philippines military is using bombers, helicopter gunships, tanks and thousands of men, while the rebels are retaliating with anti-tank and anti-aircraft weapons, rocket-propelled grenades and a motley collection of machine guns.

It is impossible to gauge exactly how many people are involved in the fighting. Captain Erwin Rommel Lamzon, a Philippines army spokesman, said 45% of the country's armed forces were deployed in the island - about 50,000 personnel. He estimated the rebel strength at about 12,000 men.

But the rebels' chairman, Salamat Hashim, who runs operations from his headquarters in Camp Abu Bakre, 40 miles north of Cotabato City, said he had more than 110,000 fighters ready to die for the dream of an Islamic state.

"It's ridiculous to suggest that we have only 12,000 men," he said. "How could we be doing so well if so few men were up against so many soldiers?"

He added: "We have better training than them and we are fighting for a just cause that we believe in. So, God willing, we do not have to be afraid of them militarily."

The Philippines military is not only fighting the Milf but also other Islamic insurgents, bands of vigilantes and the New People's Army (NPA), a communist group that is also active on several other islands of the archipelago.

Another large rebel grouping, the Moro National Liberation Front - from which the Milf broke away - has officially been at peace with Manila since a 1996 agreement. But some of its commanders are dissatisfied with the leadership and are threatening to renew hostilities over Manila's alleged failure to aid Mindanao's ravaged economy.

Army generals also have to contend with the schizophrenic policy of President Joseph Estrada, who will resume peace talks with the Milf on May 2 - but only for two months. He has repeatedly said that if an agreement is not reached by the end of June he will order and all-out attack on the rebel group's camps.

"Our approach [to Mindanao] is simple we will use force against those who use force and we will not allow any peace talks to give any adversaries the time and the opportunity to prepare for war," he said. "But our approach is not to win against them, but to win them. Our approach is to address, totally and holistically, all the root causes of their grievances."

Observers despair at the way events are unfolding. One western diplomat said: "He [Estrada] hasn't thought things through. If you're serious about negotiations you don't go round threatening all-out war. He's painted the government into a very tight corner."

The Milf is becoming increasingly militant. It has yet to launch terrorist strikes outside Mindanao, but earlier this week it blew up power lines, plunging the entire island into darkness for several hours.

Half an hour after the attack Mr Hashim was preaching peace. "We are respecting the ceasefire and the Geneva convention. We are not launching any offensive operations, but only defending ourselves where necessary," he said.

Such statements are also hard to fathom when other Milf leaders admit that there are numerous child soldiers in their ranks. "Many boys and girls have seen their fathers killed," a senior spokesman, Mohager Iqbal, said. "They cannot be blamed if they take up arms and seek revenge."

The communist NPA has an even greater penchant for using children in its ranks. When Edfu de la Cruz, 12, was captured last month in an army raid in which his parents were killed and was paraded before the press, he told his fellow young guerrillas: "Do not surrender. Continue the fight."

Going unnoticed amid the propaganda from all sides is the plight of the Christians and animist highlanders. Few of them are fighting, but a Catholic priest in Iligan City said: "My worry is how long they will remain so silent and just take the punishment from both sides."

Others agree. "The potential really does seem there for inter-communal strife to kick up," the western diplomat said. "What we could be heading to is another Ambon scenario."

In Ambon, eastern Indonesia, thousands have been killed in fighting between Christians and Muslims in the last 15 months. Peace talks are making little progress.

It is not like that yet in Mindanao, but the young men who are lining up to fight vow that they will not stop until total victory is theirs.

Decades of conflict

 Population: 16m

 Nominally 60% Christian, 40% Muslim, but there are several thousand animists

 Never formally conquered by the Spanish or American colonisers. This is the basis of the separatists' claim for independence

 Fighting started in earnest in 1972. The rebel MNLF signed a peace deal in 1996, but this has yet to be ratified by the Philippines congress

 Almost all local politicians and big businessmen have their own private armies

 The island is rich in natural resources but the conflict has destroyed the economy

webTitle: French lion stands firm as giant roars

fields.headline: French lion stands firm as giant roars
fields.trailText: When Michel Vachez set up his small ski-hire shop in the resort of L'Alpe-d'Huez nearly 20 years ago, he did not think twice about its name. The three partners in the business were himself, his father Gaston and his wife Michèle - M, G and M.
fields.body:
When Michel Vachez set up his small ski-hire shop in the resort of L'Alpe-d'Huez nearly 20 years ago, he did not think twice about its name. The three partners in the business were himself, his father Gaston and his wife Michèle - M, G and M.

When it came to choosing a logo, he did not ponder long either. Astrologically speaking, the entrepreneurial Frenchman was born under the sign of Leo, so what better symbol than a lion? For good measure he painted two of the beasts, rampant, along his shopfront.

He swears he never dreamed that one day he would find himself facing a multi-million franc lawsuit from Hollywood film giant Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The film giant argues that if it wanted to expand in France, its plans would be stymied by the fact that back in 1982, Mr Vachez registered both the name MGM and the lion logo as his property.

"The whole world knows Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which has produced some of the greatest masterpieces in the history of the cinema - think of Ben-Hur, Gone with the Wind and West Side Story," said Gerard Lamoureux, the US firm's lawyer, at a court hearing yesterday in Grenoble.

"This man cannot pretend that he had never heard of us when he registered his company's name. His choice of logo, even though it is not a roaring lion like ours, underlines his bad faith. He is profiting from the fame and reputation of a third party, and we demand he be denied the use of the brand name MGM."

But Mr Vachez's lawyer said: "French law governs brands, trademarks and industrial property. It doesn't matter whether you are large or small, one-man band or multinational, you have to obey. My client is the legal owner of the MGM brand, which he registered nearly 20 years ago, and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will just have to give in."

The US giant, which has failed in two previous attempts to take Mr Vachez to court, said it had no specific plans yet to develop businesses in France. But it argued that if it were to try to set up a theme park in France, with hotels and restaurants, it would run into legal problems.

It seems that Mr Vachez registered his MGM as being engaged not just in ski-hire but in flat rental and catering. He recently opened a fast-food joint in his shop called Planet MGM - in Metro's eyes, a clear reference to the Planet Hollywood restaurant chain.

But Mr Vachez, who called his struggle "Asterix against the cowboys", was confident. "I'll win," he said. "Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have never registered their name in France. That's their fault. But if they want to sit down and discuss things calmly, - I might be open to overtures."

The ruling is expected early next month.

webTitle: Samoan cabinet ministers get death sentence for killing

fields.headline: Samoan cabinet ministers get death sentence for killing
fields.trailText: Two former cabinet ministers in the South Pacific islands of Samoa have been sentenced to death for plotting the assassination of a political rival, a plot of intrigue and jealousy worthy of the short stories Somerset Maugham wrote around the steamy Samoan capital, Apia.
fields.body:
Two former cabinet ministers in the South Pacific islands of Samoa have been sentenced to death for plotting the assassination of a political rival, a plot of intrigue and jealousy worthy of the short stories Somerset Maugham wrote around the steamy Samoan capital, Apia.

Justice Andrew Wilson of the supreme court upheld the jury's four to one verdict that the former women's affairs minister Leafa Vitale, 57, and the former communications minister Toi Aukuso, 68, were guilty of planning the murder of their colleague, Luagalau Levaula Kamu.

Death by hanging is the mandatory sentence for murder in Samoa, but has never been carried out since the former German and New Zealand territory, which is still largely ruled by chiefs with traditional powers, became independent in 1961.

Kamu was shot in the back while he spoke into his mobile telephone during a political gathering on July 16 last year. Vitale's son Alatise, 34, was convicted at an earlier hearing of shooting him with an M16. Alatise's death sentence was, as is customary, commuted to life imprisonment.

Kamu was a popular younger politician who was trying to clean up the incestuous and often corrupt nature of Samoan public life.

His murder was seen as an attempt to prevent publication of reports on corruption which were believed to implicate former ministers and MPs.

The prosecution also alleged that Vitale and Aukuso had him killed out of jealousy, because he had been appointed minister of public works, a job whose holder was known to receive bribes from local companies competing for government funded contracts.

The trial, which began in Apia on January 17, heard from 65 witnesses, including Alatise, who testified that his father and Aukuso ordered him to carry out the killing.

Vitale denied ordering the murder and described Kamu as a "very good friend". Aukuso testified that Vitale asked him to shoot Kamu and the prime minister, Tuilaepa Sailele Malielegaoi, but that he refused after Vitale failed to pay him as promised.

Kamu's widow, Maiava Visekota Peteru, asked for clemency, saying outside the court that she did not support capital punishment.

The trial shocked the strongly Christian Samoan population of about 164,000.

Aukuso testified that Vitale asked him to shoot Kamu and the prime minister, Tuilaepa Sailele Malielegaoi, but that he refused after Vitale failed to pay him as promised. Kamu's widow, Maiava Visekota Peteru, asked for clemency, saying outside the court that she did not support capital punishment. The trial shocked the strongly Christian Samoan population of about 164,000.

webTitle: Mobile chatter the new curse of Spain

fields.headline: Mobile chatter the new curse of Spain
fields.trailText: The Spanish penchant for gabbling on mobile phones at the top of their voices, has sent noise levels soaring and generated calls for legislation.
fields.body:
The Spanish penchant for gabbling on mobile phones at the top of their voices, has sent noise levels soaring and generated calls for legislation.

The use of mobile phones has increased faster in Spain than in any other European country. Five years ago there were 1m subscribers; now there are 18m. Half the adult population regularly talks on mobiles; more than use the land lines.

Children as young as four are given them when they start school.

"It's a healthy sign that our economy is booming, but the effect on the environment can be deadly," a spokesman for the Noise Control Association warned.

"In the mid-90s we were considered the noisiest country in Europe, mainly due to traffic. That improved as our cars got better, but now mobiles are taking over and turning into a real curse."

According to the Centre for Scientific Investigation, the country's main research institute, noise levels in public places frequently break the 55 to 65 decibel guidelines established by the World Health Organisation. The centre is backing calls for legislation to tackle the problem.

"Our pollution laws date back to 1972 - before we were really aware of how damaging the affect of too much noise can be," said Isobel Lopez of the centre's acoustics unit.

Spaniards indulge in the national pastime of la charla - conversation for conversation's sake - using their mobiles at any opportunity, and causing not just noise pollution but verbal attacks and even fisticuffs. The prime minister's wife was criticised recently when her phone interrupted a classical concert.

"We need to learn the value of peace and quiet, like the northern Europeans," said Ms Lopez, who is urging the creation of "silence islands".

Hoping to avert legislation, the mobile phone companies have decided to take action. One of Spain's biggest, The Phone Company, has issued guidelines to its subscribers, which suggest switching off their mobile phones whenever possible and using the text message system instead.

fields.headline: 20 injured in Congo airport blasts
fields.trailText: A series of explosions at Kinshasa's international airport yesterday was set off by a military plane crashing into a petrol tanker during take-off, causing a fire which spread to arms depots, witnesses said.
fields.body:
A series of explosions at Kinshasa's international airport yesterday was set off by a military plane crashing into a petrol tanker during take-off, causing a fire which spread to arms depots, witnesses said.

At least 20 people were hurt, and one injured soldier said that his commander had been killed.

"We have taken in around 20 wounded, for the most part people with burns or with limbs missing," said a doctor at the Mamayemo hospital in Kinshasa.

Witnesses said that other planes may have been destroyed in the incident.

The noise of the explosions caused panic in parts of the city. The army appealed for calm in a statement read out on state television, saying only that "the explosions... were due to a fire in the munitions depots at the international airport of Ndjili".

The phone network appeared to go down shortly after the explosions, feeding the rumour mill and the general nervousness.

The explosions also set off a brief panic over the border in Brazzaville, where residents gathered along the Congo river to watch flames from the blasts shooting into the air.

A United Nations spokeswoman said the UN had offered to help transport the injured.

fields.headline: Britons involved in arms running
fields.trailText: British pilots and air cargo companies are been used to supply weapons to both sides in the civil war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, according to Guardian inquiries and research commissioned by human rights groups.
fields.body:
British pilots and air cargo companies are been used to supply weapons to both sides in the civil war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, according to Guardian inquiries and research commissioned by human rights groups.

Despite the 1993 EU embargo on arms sales to Congo, and Britain's promise earlier this year to tighten control on exports to all combatants in the conflict, weak UK laws make the government powerless to intervene.

The evidence highlights the dilemma in drawing up a new UK law on brokering and trafficking arms, which is expected to be announced shortly. It also shows that after the Lusaka peace accord agreed between the parties last August - which was renegotiated in Kampala at the weekend and began yesterday - the flow of weapons continued.

In the 20 months of war, Zimbabwe, Namibia and Angola have supported President Kabila of the Congo against rebels forces backed by Rwanda, Uganda and elements of Angola's Unita movement.

Zimbabwe has 11,000 troops deployed, many of them defending the rich diamond mines, whose profits are now being managed by a coalition of Congolese and Zimbabwean generals.

A British pilot, Brian "Sport" Martin, has described flying AK47 assault rifles - as well as Unicef medical aid and offi cials - from Rwanda and Uganda last year and early this year into the rebel-held town of Kisangani.

Mr Martin, a freelance pilot for more than 20 years, says he flew planes registered in Swaziland for two Congolese carriers, Planet Air and New Goma Air, from Entebbe in Uganda, and Kigali in Rwanda. Last year the US state department's bureau of intelligence and research identified Planet Air as one of several airlines supplying the eastern Congo.

In a transcript of an interview he gave to Oxfam in February he said: "Mostly the stuff we carried were brand new AKs plus the ammunition. They're all packed in plastic bags and in beautiful condition. It's quite a standard operation for us. We know there is a war on. We are not in volved in it because we're just charter pilots."

Mr Martin said he was flying 80 to 90 hours a month. "It is very easy. Leave the hotel, do a little hour there and two hours on the ground and you are back in time for dinner."

Research by the Guardian and the pressure group Saferworld has identified an ageing Boeing 707 which has been contracted to fly arms from Bulgaria and Slovakia to Harare for transit to the Zimbabwean forces in the Congo.

The plane's handlers used the offices and facilities of a UK cargo company in Ostend, without the knowledge of its owners. The story of the B707 registered in Liberia as EL-ACP illustrates the complexity of the "grey" cargo business, where a company can lease out a plane without being aware of its movements. It is owned by Air Cargo Plus, run by two Scandinavians based in Luxembourg. For two years until last October it was operated by the Ostend branch of a UK cargo company, Air Charter Service (ACS), based in Kingston, Surrey. When the contract ended ACS agreed to use it on an ad hoc basis.

Flight documents obtained by the Guardian show that on November 3 last year the plane left Ostend empty for Burgas in Bulgaria and arrived at Harare the next day carrying "technical equipment". It was flown by an American with a British first officer.

According to a member of the crew the cargo was then transferred to an Ilyushin 76TD freighter and flown to Kinshasa. Military experts believe the cargo was a Bulgarian Igla portable surface-to-air missile system.

The shipment was organised by a group of Dutch brokers. The documents say the plane was leased from Air Cargo Plus by an established Amsterdam company called TransBalkan Cargo Service, whose air operations manager in Ostend was Herbie Proost.

Mr Proost, according to ACS's Ostend boss, Nick Leach, had been allowed to run his office at the airport while he was setting up his new home in Belgium.

Saferworld's researches and an inspection of Mr Proost's files alerted Mr Leach to the true nature of the flight. "We were lied to and I was really pissed off. The plane had become a renegade." he told the Guardian yesterday. "It is company policy never to fly arms."

Further documentation, in the possession of the Guardian, then came to light, which showed that the plane was planning a similar delivery last month of "technical equipment and industrial machinery" from Bratislava in Slovakia to Zimbabwe Defence Industries, the government's procurement arm, in Harare.

Under the proposed tightening up of arms transfers the British government is suggesting a register of UK brokers, based at home or abroad. It would be illegal to broker arms to countries under UN, EU or national embargoes.

But this falls short of a licensing system for every transaction, which is what Saferworld is calling for.

webTitle: Hawksbill turtle faces extinction despite years of conservation efforts

fields.headline: Hawksbill turtle faces extinction despite years of conservation efforts
fields.trailText: A report showing that six of the world's seven species of marine turtles are still in danger of extinction was presented to delegates of 140 countries in Nairobi yesterday. It makes a strong case for continuing the international ban on trade in turtle products.
fields.body:
A report showing that six of the world's seven species of marine turtles are still in danger of extinction was presented to delegates of 140 countries in Nairobi yesterday. It makes a strong case for continuing the international ban on trade in turtle products.

The delegates are attending the 11th Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, which is considering an application from Cuba and Dominica to reopen the trade in tortoiseshell. The shells are bought by Japan, where expert craftsmen turn them into jewellery.

The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), which is involved in many international schemes to save the turtle, says that despite some successful interventions to protect breeding grounds, all the species are still endangered including the hawksbill which Cuba particularly wants to trade. Turtles are still much in demand worldwide to be stuffed, varnished and mounted. The shells are sold openly to tourists in Vietnam, Cambodia and the Caribbean, despite the international ban.

Although tourists carrying such trophies back to Britain will have them confiscated by customs, the WWF does not believe that international policing efforts are good enough elsewhere. If the ban is lifted, it argues, smuggling and illegal killing will rise.

Elizabeth Kemf, for the WWF, said: "Controls in the main importing country, Japan, are inadequate. The status of the turtle populations in the Caribbean is unclear. Hawksbill turtles are facing an ever growing number of threats."

Up to 300,000 turtles are killed each year as a "bycatch" in trawling and shrimp nets, and on long lines used to catch tuna and swordfish. Tourism is also a threat because some of the species' favourite sandy breeding beaches have been taken up by hotels and blocked by sea walls.

The WWF believes that despite conservation efforts the future of this reptile, which has existed on the planet for 100m years, remains in doubt.

Although it is known where turtles breed, exact numbers are hard to calculate because after hatching they disappear for 10 years until they reach sexual maturity. Arguments about "sustainable harvesting" are difficult because no one knows how large the replenishment stock is. Turtles live for 30 years, so the same adults can be recognised returning to home beaches to breed.

fields.headline: 100,000 protest against Milosevic
fields.trailText: More than 100,000 people filled Republic Square in central Belgrade yesterday to protest against the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
More than 100,000 people filled Republic Square in central Belgrade yesterday to protest against the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

It was the first rally by all Serbian opposition parties in the capital since last August and a litmus test of support.

The high turnout will boost the beleaguered opposition leaders. Political analysts believe that because Belgrade is the intellectual and political centre of the country, it must provide the impetus for change.

The leader of the Democratic party, Zoran Djindjic, and his long-time rival Vuk Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, shared a stage to call for free and fair elections at all levels: local, republic and federal.

In their excitement, the protesters barely registered a moment at the start of the rally, when Mr Djindjic and Mr Draskovic shook hands unenthusiastically.

"The regime are the traitors," Mr Draskovic said. "They have betrayed everyone. They have made 1m citizens beggars."

Sixteen leaders of different opposition parties spoke during the course of the rally, which lasted for more than three hours.

"It is very important that so many people are here. It's a message to the opposition leaders that they have to stop their eternal bickering," said one doctor who attended.

Police kept a low-profile presence during the protest. A helicopter hovered overhead for a while and small groups of police stood a distance away, but offered no provocation.

Members of the student's resistance organisation Otpor walked for a day from the northern city of Novi Sad to attend the rally.

Protesters blocked key roads in the centre of the capital and young people waved flags of support for the main opposition parties.

At the time of the rally, the state-controlled television Politika was running a major movie marathon, showing films such as American Beauty, which many interpreted as an attempt to keep people at home.

Foreign journalists who attempted to enter Serbia to cover the rally were held at the airport and refused entry, according to the independent radio station B292.

Local radio also reported that a number of opposition supporters who were coming to the capital by coach were stopped by police, who delayed them by carrying out technical inspections of their vehicles.

The only non-government television station, Studio B, which tried to broadcast coverage of the rally, was jammed and went off the air when its transmitter suffered an unexpected power failure.

fields.headline: International news in brief
fields.trailText: Chechen forces chief captured
fields.body:
Chechen forces chief captured

Russian commandos captured the military chief of staff of the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, and took him to Moscow for questioning.

Apti Batalov, a brigadier general in the rebel army, was seized by a squad of security service troops in the town of Shali on Thursday, an agency spokesman said.

He was taken to prison, where he will be questioned about his role in the Chechen war, the spokesman added.
AP, Grozny

False leg sold to pay rent arrears

A one-legged Frenchman is trying to recover his artificial leg, which was auctioned off for 70F (£6.50) to help pay his debts while he was in jail for drug-trafficking, his lawyer, Christian Etelin, said yesterday.

Enrique Vilageliu's false limb was sold with his other belongings to cover 29,000F in rent arrears. He was given another artificial leg in prison, but says the original one was more comfortable.
Reuters, Paris

fields.headline: Violence returns to Niger delta
fields.trailText: Military police are believed to have killed five people, wounded others and razed many houses in three days of violence directed at the leadership of the organisation formerly led by Ken Saro-Wiwa in Ogoniland, Nigeria.
fields.body:
Military police are believed to have killed five people, wounded others and razed many houses in three days of violence directed at the leadership of the organisation formerly led by Ken Saro-Wiwa in Ogoniland, Nigeria.

Ledum Mitee, head of the Movement of the Survival of the Ogoni People (Mosop), was arrested and his house was burned down. He has been accused of gunrunning and corruption. The killings occurred after resistance was mounted to a road being built by the Shell oil company as part of a programme of reconciliation with poor communities in the region.

Yesterday more than 200 police officers were occupying Mr Mitee's village, K-Dere, the heartland of opposition to Shell's presence in Ogoniland. At least 20 houses have been burned down and many people are reported to have fled.

International said yesterday that it was concerned about the military violence, the first since 1994, when the area in the delta region of the Niger was occupied by state forces and up to 2,000 people died.

This led to Shell's withdrawal from the area, the execution of Mr Saro-Wiwa and eight others, and Nigeria's suspension from Commonwealth membership

"There is considerable fear [that the sort of violence seen in 1994] could happen again. We have heard of ill-treatment of people arrested," Amnesty said.

"Individuals appear to have been specifically targeted. Reports indicate that the police were accompanied by a senior local government official and associates who identified individuals to target and homes to destroy."

Shell International in London extended sympathy to the relatives of the dead. "We are saddened by the events. Our understanding is that this is an inter-community conflict. We are not present in Ogoni. We will continue our commitment and efforts to seek peaceful reconciliation," its spokesman said.

The focus of the present trouble is a 10-mile road which Shell's subcontractors have been building in the area. Mosop and some Ogoni communities had complained that there was little consultation and that it was not a development priority.

Shell withdrew the contractors at the first sign of trouble three weeks ago. Earlier this week armed police entered K-Dere and were resisted by a group of youths.

"It is clear that pressure from some local authorities to invite Shell involvement in a development project has aroused tensions between local residents and those employed on or profiting from the project," Amnesty said.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Hillsborough Family Support Group's private prosecution of two police officers in connection with the 1989 tragedy at Sheffield Wednesday's football ground is due to open on June 7, not August 24, as reported on page 10, Online, April 13. Jimmy McGovern, who wrote the docu-drama Hillsborough and was reported as supporting a website mounted by another group representing family members, says he was unaware of this site when we went to press.
fields.body:
Hillsborough Family Support Group's private prosecution of two police officers in connection with the 1989 tragedy at Sheffield Wednesday's football ground is due to open on June 7, not August 24, as reported on page 10, Online, April 13. Jimmy McGovern, who wrote the docu-drama Hillsborough and was reported as supporting a website mounted by another group representing family members, says he was unaware of this site when we went to press.

Our André Deutsch obituary, page 24, April 12, listed among the publisher's successes Norman Mailer's 1948 novel The Naked and the Dead. But the book was not, as we said, a soldier's account of the Korean war in the 1950s. It was a second world war story set in the Pacific.

Academic affiliations: Richard Ashcroft - quoted in a page 1-2 story yesterday, Gene test drugs pose ethics dilemma - is now at the medical ethics unit of the Imperial College School of Medicine in London, and not at Bristol. Keith Dixon, the writer of a letter, page 23, April 13, has retired as a professor at Simon Fraser University in Canada. We missed out the retired.

fields.headline: From cabbage patch to classics
fields.standfirst:
Brand values: Penguin Books
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Allen Lane wanted a "dignified but flippant" name for his new publishing venture. His secretary came up with the name Penguin, and a member of staff was sent to London Zoo to sketch the now famous logo.
fields.body:
Allen Lane wanted a "dignified but flippant" name for his new publishing venture. His secretary came up with the name Penguin, and a member of staff was sent to London Zoo to sketch the now famous logo.

It was typical of the company's cost savings in its early days. It was, after all, planning to sell paperback books for 6d (2p) - about the price of a pack of cigarettes.

Penguin Books was founded in 1936. Its first premises were in a church crypt and staff had to be quiet during services. They were also paid an extra 1p a day so they could use the loo at a nearby station.

When staff moved to a new building, they found the floor was still a cabbage patch. The floor was only laid when the cabbages were picked and sold - to help offset moving costs.

Lane had realised there was a market for cheap classics when, returning from Agatha Christie's home, he found only magazines and Victorian novels on Exeter station bookstall.

He was no newcomer to publishing, having left school at 16 to join his uncle's publishing firm, the Bodley Head, and rose to become managing director. Other directors were not prepared to fund his new venture, though they agreed to distribute its books. At that time hardbacks cost about eight shillings and were a success if they sold 2,000 copies - whereas the new Penguins would cost just 6d and would need to sell at least 17,000 copies to break even.

Other publishers were equally reluctant to sell paperback rights to Lane. The first to break ranks was Jonathan Cape, who thought he might earn £400 before the new venture went bust.

The first 10 Penguins, published in 1935, included Hemingway's A Farewell to Arms, Compton Mackenzie's Carnival and Agatha Christie's The Mysterious Affair at Styles. Within five months the firm had sold a million copies.

After success with reprints, Penguin started to commission new works. Nikolaus Pevsner's famous series, The Buildings of England, was commissioned by Penguin, which provided him with a car and petrol - which was still rationed at the time - to research the first volume.

Sets of books around a specific topic were labelled Penguin Specials which were to develop into the Pelican, Puffin and Peregrine ranges. The idea was triggered when Lane overheard a lady mistakenly ask for a "pelican book".

The traditional typographical covers were replaced by illustrations - some by Len Deighton - by the 1960s.

Penguin's stock market flotation in 1962 was 160 times oversubscribed. But new ventures such as educational and hardback books took their toll on the company's finances, and it was taken over by Pearson Longman in 1970.

The company, which this week emerged victorious from the libel action by David Irving, is no stranger to the courts. In 1960 it was charged under the Obscene Publications Act when it published an unabridged version of DH Lawrence's Lady Chatterley's Lover.

The resulting court case gripped the public. The jury acquitted the company and ushered in the permissive Sixties. And Penguin had a best seller on its hands.

webTitle: A cautionary tale in one act

fields.headline: A cautionary tale in one act
fields.trailText: The scene: It's a bright spring day and the sun is just starting to set as worn-out City workers board a train at London Bridge Station.
fields.body:
The scene: It's a bright spring day and the sun is just starting to set as worn-out City workers board a train at London Bridge Station.

Dramatis personae

Mr IN Money: a private investor
Mr NO Idea: a professional fund manager at Poor Performance Asset Management
Ms B Spark: an IT analyst at DotComsRus Securities Ltd.

Mr Idea and Ms Spark take seats near each other

Idea: The evenings are getting so light now.

Spark: Great isn't it? Not long now, and we will sitting outside sipping Pimms as the sun sets.

[The train starts to pull slowly out of London Bridge Station, when the compartment door opens and a half-mad straggler hauls himself onto the train. Red-faced and unpleasantly clammy, the late arrival makes a beeline for the seat between Mr Idea and Ms Spark. Much to their dismay, it is Mr Money.]

Money: Evening all [as he squeezes into a seat designed for someone about a third his size] How are you both?

Spark: Pretty exhausted - the volatility of these hi-tech markets is becoming a real bugbear. All I get is phone calls - clients wanting to know if this is the end of the internet bubble, market makers wanting to know what a particular stock is going to do tomorrow, and corporate finance panicking about the up-coming flotations! To be honest I can't wait for the weekend.

Idea: Serves you right for peddling the internet story. You've enjoyed the good times - now it's payback time. This last month has been great for my portfolio. The value plays have really come into their own, up just under 10% in the last month against a 30% drop in tech stocks, so I'm feeling pretty damn good at the moment.

Money: But surely some of that is just catch up. After all, one of the tech funds I've invested in is still up 105% over the last 12 months - and that's after losing 30% in the last month.

Spark: Exactly. I'm glad someone understands that. Everybody just keeps talking about how these stocks have fallen rather than how much they've gone up previously.

Idea: But this is the beginning of the end. At long last the investing public has come to its senses and is heading back into shares of firms that actually produce something. Corporate financiers are running for cover, dot.com IPOs are being pulled or having their prices slashed.

Spark: Rubbish, this is just froth coming off the markets. For sure, some investors had become a little carried away with concepts and bought any dot.com. But their mass selling is now creating opportunities to pick up quality issues at reasonable prices.

Money: I was reading something the other day that compared the internet sector to the US auto industry in the early 20th century. What was that all about?

Spark: Well in the early stages of the popularisation of the car, the number of producers was massive. Today there are only really three big companies left producing cars. It could well prove to be a business model for some of the internet stocks. Consolidation in the sector is inevitable.

Idea: I heard that a number of dot.com stocks were cash-strapped and that would drive consolidation.

Spark: Some of the reports on the financial vulnerability of internet stocks have been overdone. Most of the analysis is based on outdated accounting standards that bias the profits and cash position of internet stocks down.

Idea: Sounds like smoke and mirrors to me.

Spark: Not really. Accountants say that to be a capital investment, a project must yield returns over many time periods. If establishing a brandname via, say advertising, doesn't meet that criterion then I don't know what does. But the accountants won't have any of it.

Idea: umm...

Money: I was in an internet chatroom the other day [Spark and Idea exchange knowing looks] and someone was talking about e-nabling firms, and saying they were the way forward.

Idea: E-nabling?

Spark: Yes, firms that provide e-commerce solutions to existing firms. Transforming them from "bricks and mortar" to "clicks and mortar".

Money: Why bother with bricks and mortar firms at all? Surely the death of the high street is upon us?

Spark : But think about the power of extending a well-known high street brand online. The bond of trust with the customer base already exists. Everybody knows Marks & Spencer - think about the impact of turning them into a "clicks and mortar business".

Idea: Now that does sound interesting.

Spark: So investing in e-nabling firms allows an exposure to both old and new economy firms. These kind of firms are my tip for the top.

Idea: Bit late to talk top in terms of hi-tech stocks, surely.

Spark: As I said earlier, I don't think so. There is still life in this bull market yet. Leadership within the tech sector rotates far faster than other sectors - B2C, B2B, WAP and now I think e-nablers. My advice is so long as you buy quality, hang on for the ride.

[Much to the relief of the rest of the passengers, the train pulls into East Croydon. Idea and Spark depart, leaving everyone to enjoy the silence - at least until somebody's mobile phone starts going.]

 James Montier is Global Strategist at Albert E Sharp Securities

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Rotherham, South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: My ten-year-old daughter and her friend Philip have taken an interest in the wide range of aquatic creepy crawlies to be found locally. They are running a project to survey local streams and watercourses, checking the quantity and diversity of species. This gives me an excuse to accompany them with net and tubs.
fields.body:
My ten-year-old daughter and her friend Philip have taken an interest in the wide range of aquatic creepy crawlies to be found locally. They are running a project to survey local streams and watercourses, checking the quantity and diversity of species. This gives me an excuse to accompany them with net and tubs.

Sarah and Philip have carried out several chemical tests on watercourses, and plan further ones, looking especially at ammonia levels. They hope to lobby the council, water company and environment agency to get them cleaned up. In May they will present their findings to the International Children's Conference on the Environment at Eastbourne.

All of our streams have sewer overflows discharging into them, which affects the range of freshwater life. On our recent foray, pollution tolerant species such as hoglice, freshwater shrimps and tubiflex worms were common. In the cleaner areas, upstream of discharging pipes, mayfly larvae were abundant. Caddis fly larvae, of which there are many different species, were elusive, but we found some. Philip insists on calling them cactus flies. Given the extremes of some of the habitats we sampled, this may be quite fitting.

There is a clean stretch of old goit, dating back to the 17th century, which once provided water for Walker's canon-making factory. Here we found a much wider range of wildlife. There were three species of diving beetle, some more discerning caddis fly larvae and two species of rams-horn snail. One of the latter has a red body (unlike other snails, their blood contains haemoglobin). This one was an albino, lacking brown body pigment, so the red shone through spectacularly.

Further down the goit, immediately below the sewer overflow, the water was almost devoid of aquatic animals. There were a few wandering snails and sticklebacks, and to our surprise, several damselfly nymphs. We perhaps should not be surprised: damselfly nymphs are carnivores and tiny sticklebacks and the larvae of mosquitoes are sufficient prey for them to survive.

webTitle: Niche toymaker Hornby up for sale

fields.headline: Niche toymaker Hornby up for sale
fields.trailText: After 99 years, model railway maker Hornby could be steaming towards the end of the line as an independent company.
fields.body:
After 99 years, model railway maker Hornby could be steaming towards the end of the line as an independent company.

Sales have been derailed by destocking at big toy shops and Hornby yesterday admitted it was ready to listen to bid approaches.

The news sent Hornby's shares up 26p to 170p, valuing the business at £14.2m.

Chairman Peter Newey said: "There's a very stable future ahead for our products but it's a niche. The problem with being in a niche is that once you've filled the gap, there's not much else you can do apart from find other niches."

Hornby also makes Scalextric racing cars - students rate them "ironic".

Hornby will look for opportunities to merge with other European toymakers. Mr Newey said: "There are lots out there which are still family controlled. We have a stock market quote, which could be of interest."

Frank Hornby, who invented Meccano, set up the company in 1901. In 1920 it diversified into model railways (pictured on display in 1954 at the Horticultural Halls, London).

Hornby's shares peaked at 258p two years ago but retailers' changed stocking habits forced relocation of most manufacturing to China, slimming down the workforce to 200 at its factory in Margate, Kent.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Pearson eyes Mel and Griff
fields.body:
Pearson eyes Mel and Griff

Pearson TV is understood to be close to a £70m deal to buy Talkback, the television production company founded by comedians Mel Smith and Griff Rhys-Jones. A deal that will make the comedy duo multi-millionaires is expected to be completed after Easter if due diligence goes to plan.

Talkback's output includes the Ali G series and Smack the Pony. Pearson TV, which is merging with CLT-Ufa of Germany, produces 160 programmes - including Home and Away and Blind Date.

Bentalls profits sharply down

Department store group Bentalls is to revamp its flagship Kingston-on-Thames outlet after a big fall in profits. The company made just £900,000 in the year-end to January, down from £2.7m a year earlier. Turnover climbed nearly 10% to £121m.

Chairman Edward Bentall, whose family owns 38% of the company, said a poor first half had done the damage, but in the last ten weeks sales were up 2.2%. Much of the drop in profits was due to losses at the Bristol store.

The company said it had raised its sights since the collapse of merger talks with Allders last year. It has installed a new management team, intends to modernise its image, expand and update the Kingston store. The shares closed down 4p at 58.5p.

Kleinwort 'a virtual bank'

Dresdner Kleinwort Benson is to be run as a "virtual" investment bank, its parent company Dresdner confirmed yesterday. But the German bank, under pressure since its merger with its rival Deutsche fell apart this month, made no reference to suggestions that it might spin the unit off into a separate entity.

Meanwhile Deutsche has called an extraordinary meeting for later this month, fuelling speculation that Rolf Breuer, the chief executive, would be forced to resign.

Serbs step up web attack

Mgm.com and manutd.com are among 2,000 websites around the world that have been targeted by Serbian hackers, raising new concerns about internet security. The unidentified cyberterrorists gained access to e-mails and financial details of customers.

Network Solution, a domain name registration business, said it was powerless to stop the raids: "We are looking at longer-term solutions. It is challenging and we know it is something we have to deal with."

Lafarge mulls higher bid

Lafarge, the French cement maker, is expected to raise its £3.4bn bid for Blue Circle after winning support from only 2.59% of shareholders. The company must make any increased offer by Wednesday under UK takeover rules.

Company insiders insisted it was still confident its 420p per share offer could win the day even though Blue Circle shares ended the day up 4.5p at 429.75p. But Blue Circle said the level of support underlined its belief "that the value of Blue Circle is way above Lafarge's meagre offer".

Analysts say Lafarge needs to increase its offer to between 450p and 475p per share.

webTitle: Television providers say no to Yes

fields.headline: Television providers say no to Yes
fields.standfirst: Juggling act by would-be floater
fields.trailText: To lose one major contract in the run up to flotation might be considered unfortunate, to potentially lose a second smacks of the ambitiously named Yes Television, which is due to join the stock market in less than two weeks with an ever-so-affirmative price tag of £600m has had an inauspicious start. After losing one of its three contracts earlier this week (to supply video-on-demand to cable company NTL), it now looks perilously close to suffering a similar fate with Kingston.
fields.body:
To lose one major contract in the run up to flotation might be considered unfortunate, to potentially lose a second smacks of the ambitiously named Yes Television, which is due to join the stock market in less than two weeks with an ever-so-affirmative price tag of £600m has had an inauspicious start. After losing one of its three contracts earlier this week (to supply video-on-demand to cable company NTL), it now looks perilously close to suffering a similar fate with Kingston.

These are not bit-players in the world of media. NTL is the biggest cable company in Britain, while Kingston's high-speed data line service in Hull has some heavyweight backing in the form of BSkyB and is likely to be rolled out nationwide.

Yes TV is attempting a difficult juggling act. The company's shares are being marketed on the credibility this young venture has gained from providing video-on-demand to NTL, Kingston and Eircom in Ireland.

At the same time it has clearly set out its stall as a future rival to all three. It aims to offer a "Total Television" package, including high speed internet access and a full service of free-to-air and pay TV channels using ADSL over British Telecom's networks when they are jemmied opened for competition next year.

In other words, Yes wants to raise money off the back of its relationship with existing operators explicitly to fund its competition against them further down the line.

After this week's developments, with both NTL and Kingston turning on their erstwhile partner, Yes may well prove to have had a rather inflated view of its future place in the pantheon of Britain's media companies. The affair is also acutely embarrassing for investment bankers Robert Fleming, which are handling the Yes float after having brought Kingston Communications to the market. Before long, someone is going to shout "conflict of interest".

Total tripe

Nationwide was memorably targeted by butler Michael Hardern, while Bradford & Bingley was taken on by plumber Stephen Major. Now an even more unlikely carpetbagger has attempted to mount an assault on one of Britain's biggest building societies, the Chelsea.

Yesterday saw Chelsea reject a hostile merger proposal from Totalise, a tiny, loss-making internet company which launched just nine months ago and is best known for giving away free shares to its users and flogging cars on the cheap.

The 125-year-old building society, Britain's eighth largest, with 500,000 members and assets approaching £5bn, described the proposal as "absurd" and "lacking credibility". It is not hard to see why.

Totalise is an internet service provider with no obvious record in financial services. It reported a loss of £922,000 in its first seven months of trading, and has lost almost a quarter of its value in two days, with the share price sliding from 54.5p on Thursday morning to 42.5p yesterday.

There is also the small matter of its recent acquisition of the company that owns Carpetbagger.com - the windfall-hunters' website which only four months ago coordinated an assault on the Chelsea, demanding that the society take steps to demutualise, giving windfall payments to members. This was not a move that was likely to go down well with executives at the fiercely pro-mutual building society, and one that gives more than a little credibility to their view that the proposal amounts to nothing more than blatant opportunism.

Totalise's business strategy is opaque, to say the least. It was set up by former GP Peter Gregory and launched on the Ofex market last July, an event promoted with photos of Mr Gregory astride a surfboard surrounded by young women in their beachwear.

It is one of a number of companies effectively paying people to surf (on the internet, that is) by offering free tradeable shares to its users. The company, based in Leeds, attracted more head lines with the launch of Totalise Eurekar, a website that helps people to import cars from the continent and claims to offer savings of up to 40% on British prices. This week the company said it had taken £7m worth of orders in two weeks.

Meanwhile, there was a move into floristry with the launch of online retailer flowers2send, but none of this seems to have made much of an impression on the company's market worth, which stands at a paltry £6m.

Unfazed, Mr Gregory yesterday said that he was planning to launch an internet bank in four months' time. He reckons that there is a strong business case for bringing Chelsea into his fold - arguing, even, that Totalise is already a "mutual" in that it gives shares to its users.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Signs of inflation in the US and continuing volatility among technology, media and telecoms stocks combined to drag the FTSE to a six-week low.
fields.body:
Signs of inflation in the US and continuing volatility among technology, media and telecoms stocks combined to drag the FTSE to a six-week low.

Figures from the US consumer price index - traditionally a big influence on central bank thinking on interest rates - showed that energy and transport costs have risen sharply, which forced Wall Street down in early trading.

The report gives the Federal Open Market Committee all the evidence it needs to raise short-term interest rates by half a percentage point at their next policy meeting on May 16, analysts said.

The benchmark FTSE 100 index closed 178.9 points or 2.8% lower at 6,178.1 on a volume of 1.5bn shares. Rentokil Initial, BP Amoco, Shell and Diageo were all heavily traded.

Dealers are becoming nervous about market levels, with many predicting that the tough trading will last the whole second quarter. Selling is becoming increasingly indiscriminate, driven by emotion rather than rationale, one dealer said.

Vodafone AirTouch accounted for 63 points of the FTSE's drop, with a 7% fall of its own. Baltimore Technologies was heaviest hit, losing 25% to close at £52 after heavy early selling on Nasdaq. Baltimore now stands at a third of its February high. Other hi-tech losers included Kingston Communications, off 83p at 686p, Logica, down 171p at £16.16 and Sema, down 53p at 973p.

Bookham Technology, the market's darling since this week's flotation, also lost some ground. It closed down 17.6% at £20.50 after a 150% gain on Tuesday, its first day of trading.

The Techmark 100 fell 5.2% to 3,528, ending the week 20% down.

Old economy stocks proved more hardy. Reckitt Benckiser climbed 42.5p to 660.75p, while Severn Trent edged up 42p to 707p as some dealers switched out of new economy plays. Cadbury Schweppes benefited from an investor switch out of Nestle after the latter's latest figures. Cadbury edged up 16.5p to 450.5p.

Mid and small caps were more resilient. Romtech shot up 15p to 88p on news of a 91p per share offer from Total Research. RJB Mining put on 3.5p to close at 36p with the coal industry on the verge of being granted £100m government aid.
