fields.headline: Sharp pressed man
fields.standfirst: Interview: Sir John Browne, chief executive, BP Amoco
fields.trailText: You have just emerged from 380 days of desk-chewing negotiation with American regulators, who are worried that you might put the cost of cruising California's highways up a few cents a gallon. A £17bn deal, on ice all that time, can finally be completed, sealing an £70bn asset shuffle that has positioned your company within the top three of your sector -- globally.
fields.body:
You have just emerged from 380 days of desk-chewing negotiation with American regulators, who are worried that you might put the cost of cruising California's highways up a few cents a gallon. A £17bn deal, on ice all that time, can finally be completed, sealing an £70bn asset shuffle that has positioned your company within the top three of your sector -- globally.

Yet back in London, an extraordinary alliance has sprung up between environmental activitists and middle English shareholders. One lot are fuming about your polar ambitions; the others just want to know, exactly, how you might possibly have the time both to run their company and spend your eye-popping salary. The result is a small, but noticeable "no confidence" vote at your firm's annual general meeting.

Just to add some pepper to the mix, a government minister has taken to the news wires, postulating on how various companies' commercial decisions might be remoulded so as to coincide with the country's declared foreign policy. Your job, it seems, is in danger of partial nationalisation.

So, how do you look the next morning? In the case of Sir John Browne, chief executive of BP Amoco, there is no sign of the sleepless night. The regimental flash of gold at the sharply-pressed cuffs is still there. The voice is textured and smooth. There is no flap. The John Browne show, running at BP's understated City of London headquarters, goes on.

It has been rolling for four years now and, whatever portion you put down to the man himself rather than circumstance, personal fortune or corporate prowess, the change really does show. In 1996, BP was emerging from 1992's cut dividend and the departure of chief executive Robert Horton. The company had been lucky to remain independent.

Expat childhood

David Simon (now Lord and a government minister) had worked at rebuilding morale before handing over to Browne, an engineer turned financier who, despite an expat childhood, had followed his father into the oil company.

Browne junior won his corporate spurs in the mid-80s, devising a (legitimate) tax dodge which revitalised North Sea exploration, but cost the Treasury hundreds of millions. In September 1996, freshly ensconced as chief executive, he led BP's front bench on an away-day (for two days) to the Four Seasons hotel in Berlin. There Browne mapped out his vision.

BP would cut its fixation with assets and concentrate on profits. It would fix its business mix, both geographically and between oil and gas. It would also stop being a simple, insular "British" company.

Four years on, the market capitalisation has grown five-fold and by the time BP completes its takeover of Atlantic Richfield early next week its value will stand at something like £130bn. Now the immediate work is towards a fresh rebranding - the famous green shield is out (much too oilly) and the Amoco suffix which BP gained with last year's £30bn takeover of its Chicago-based rival will also disappear.

This clean, self-declared socially responsible multinational will be known simply as BP - the "b" and "p" standing for nothing in particular other than those ubiquitous corporate declarations of "customer service" and "shareholder value."

The fuel driving the man, driving this new version of BP amounts to "challenge, excitement and passion - passion for the company, passion for its future because I think we can do something different."

"We can grow and perform and do our business respectably," says Browne. "I think that's the right word."

He claims to have had an "interesting day" at Thursday's AGM. "I have to make the point that while 13% voted for the Greenpeace resolution (for BP to halt its Alaskan Northstar development), 87% voted against. In a representational democracy one has to think about that." Browne and his colleagues have "lots of dialogue" with Greenpeace and he hopes it continues. But coming face to face with shareholders lambasting his £4m salary last year clearly taught the chief executive a thing or two. And yes he will continue running BP - if only because "it's fun".

Four years ago the "product portfolio didn't make sense. We didn't have the capability to spread our learning around the world - BP felt like a two-pipeline company." Browne is now thinking about how the company really will grow. "New ideas, new ways of doing things - some of which are to do with the so-called new economy - which is mainly to do with efficiency."

He has a serious dose of this new economy thing. BP was a "pretty British company," where the Brits are now in the minority. It was also "quite male dominated".

Reform has been fast and deep, and extends now to deciding whether the company really needs so many prime location office blocks around the world.

Occupancy levels on the two executive floors at Britannic House in the City are said to be around 20% at any one time; "people are always connected, but they are out there working."

"What you can say about the new economy is that it changes the way we work. Email has long been mission critical, but six months from now you will have to be web-literate to even survive within BP."

Yet he insists that, whatever the technology, whatever the rebranding, BP will retain its Britishness. "We are very clearly headquartered in UK. This is our home and it is a great place to do business from. Sure, there are some annoying things, such as the government's changes on double taxation - but this is our home even though less than 25% of the company is now in the UK."

Invest in understanding

The double taxation issue, slipped into last month's Budget and reckoned to have landed a multi-billion pound bill on the mat of numerous British-based multinationals, rankles. "What is annoying is that it happened without consultation. It was a surprise. This is supposed to be a country which attracts multinationals and we should remember that the economy here is too small just to have people working in the UK. Will it mean everyone leaves the UK? That is extreme, but it does corrode people's confidence in the UK as a place to do business."

Browne moves on to what he sees as the political fringe - non-governmental organisations that would like to dictate how BP goes about its business and individuals who would prefer that BP did not exist at all. "There is no doubt it is an issue. You have to - how can I put this? - invest in understanding the issue and not add to the issue inadvertently.

"Inside the company we have people who spend their whole time worrying about human rights, checking how we are performing against our promises. We have to look at how you keep investing in a community where you are operating, without absorbing the role of the government," Brown declares, before adding that a current 1.25% of BP's post-tax profits (£67m at the last count) is channelled directly into "social investment."

His point is that the 80,000 or so who work for BP do not leave their humanity at home when they head for the office or the oil field. For Browne himself, striding between deals and regulators and governments, and being careful to miss the political landmines along the way, it is not clear anymore what "home" means.

fields.headline: Mobile licence auction hits £20.2bn
fields.trailText: The government auction of new mobile phone licences broke through the £20bn mark last night as seven companies led by BT continued to battle it out for five concessions.
fields.body:
The government auction of new mobile phone licences broke through the £20bn mark last night as seven companies led by BT continued to battle it out for five concessions.

The 129th round will start on Monday with industry experts refusing to forecast the potential size of the Treasury windfall, which will be used to reduce the national debt.

Bids for the third generation licences have already smashed through every previous estimate. Some analysts now question whether bidders will be able to make enough money from charges to justify their outlay.

The combined total of £20.2bn reached at close of play yesterday was five times what the Treasury was understood to have estimated when it fired the starting pistol six weeks ago.

BT beat off a challenge from rival Vodafone for licence B, offering £5.3bn by the end of the 128th round. Earlier in the day Vodafone had snatched temporary victory from BT with a £5.1bn bid. Both companies are desperate to ensure they can continue adding subscribers long after they use up their existing spectrum towards the end of 2003.

Licence A brought the next highest offer, with cable operator NTL, backed by France Telecom, bidding £4.3bn to keep it ahead of Canada's Telesystem International Wireless (TIW). Licence A is reserved for a new operator.

BT initially led the bids for Licence C but by the end of the day Spain's Telefonica had won poll position with a £3.4bn offer. Orange led the field for licence E with a £3.7bn bid. The fifth concession, licence D, was in the hands of TIW at the end of yesterday's auction. It had put in a bid of £3.6bn.

The auction began with 13 bidders and goes on until only five companies are left. Third generation technology will allow customers to access the internet and watch video images on hand-held devices.

webTitle: Kingston Communications angered by Yes TV 'hype'

fields.headline: Kingston Communications angered by Yes TV 'hype'
fields.trailText: The £600m stock market flotation of Yes Television was shaken further yesterday when it became embroiled in a row with Kingston Communications, with which it has a deal to supply video-on-demand services.
fields.body:
The £600m stock market flotation of Yes Television was shaken further yesterday when it became embroiled in a row with Kingston Communications, with which it has a deal to supply video-on-demand services.

Yes was forced to issue a statement admitting there have been no "substantive" talks about extending the deal with Kingston beyond June. Kingston, the Hull-based telecoms company, is understood to have exerted pressure on Yes over the past week to publicly clarify the extent of their relationship.

Kingston is said to be furious that the deal between the two had been "over-hyped" in the Yes prospectus ahead of the flotation of the business in less than two weeks time.

The events place a question mark over the role of Robert Fleming, the investment bank which acts as advisor to both Kingston and Yes.

"Kingston has taken exception to the attempt by Yes to leverage its relationship with the company only to enhance its ability to compete with them in the future," said one source.

Yes has a pilot agreement to provide video-on-demand over Kingston's telephone network as part of the telecom company's new pay-TV operation.

The rift could prove incendiary for Yes, which earlier this week lost a key contract to supply video-on-demand to NTL, Britain's largest cable company.

Yes provides video-on-demand services but aims to set itself up as a fully fledged rival to Kingston and NTL when British Telecom's networks are opened for broadcast services next year. The company hopes to offer video-on-demand, internet access and ultimately conventional television. It has a three month pilot with BT in west London.

The Yes prospectus details the Kingston service as one of three existing operations. One of the others was NTL and the third is in Ireland.

The statement from Yes said that directors "believe they enjoy a good relationship with Kingston but there have been no substantive discussions on extending the relationship in time or geographic coverage. Accordingly there is no certainty in the continuity of the relationship."

A spokesman added that bookbuilding for the company's shares, which closed yesterday, had been oversubscribed. He said the flotation would go ahead and pointed to last week's deal to provide video-on-demand software to Norway's Telenor as an example of future revenue streams. A spokesman for Kingston declined to comment.

Yes has a pilot agreement to provide video-on-demand over Kingston's telephone network as part of the telecom company's new pay-TV operation. The rift could prove incendiary for Yes, which earlier this week lost a key contract to supply video-on-demand to NTL, Britain's largest cable company. Yes provides video-on-demand services but aims to set itself up as a fully fledged rival to Kingston and NTL when British Telecom's networks are opened for broadcast services next year. The company hopes to offer video-on-demand, internet access and ultimately conventional television. It has a three month pilot with BT in west London. The Yes prospectus details the Kingston service as one of three existing operations. One of the others was NTL and the third is in Ireland. The statement from Yes said that directors "believe they enjoy a good relationship with Kingston but there have been no substantive discussions on extending the relationship in time or geographic coverage. Accordingly there is no certainty in the continuity of the relationship." A spokesman added that bookbuilding for the company's shares, which closed yesterday, had been oversubscribed. He said the flotation would go ahead and pointed to last week's deal to provide video-on-demand software to Norway's Telenor as an example of future revenue streams. A spokesman for Kingston declined to comment.

fields.headline: Panic selling on Wall Street
fields.standfirst: Fears of higher US interest rates send stocks plunging in London and New York
fields.trailText: Panic selling on Wall Street sent share prices tumbling on both sides of the Atlantic last night as fears of higher US interest rates sent tremors through the markets.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott  and  Jane Martinson  in Washington  and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Panic selling on Wall Street sent share prices tumbling on both sides of the Atlantic last night as fears of higher US interest rates sent tremors through the markets.

Both the blue-chip Dow Jones Index and the technology-based Nasdaq index suffered huge losses after official figures showed that America's longest-ever boom is pushing up prices in shops and stores.

By lunchtime in New York, the Dow had fallen more than 350 points, while the Nasdaq was suffering its fifth successive decline and was down by more than 200 points.

Wall Street jitters quickly spread to London, sparking broad-based selling which left the FTSE index of leading shares down 178.9 points at 6178.1. The Techmark 100 index dropped 5.2% to 3,528, ending a miserable week during which it lost nearly 20% of its value from the previous Friday's close.

In New York, where the Nasdaq has dropped 1,000 points in a week and lost almost a third of its value since early March, analysts said many small investors were being forced to liquidate holdings to pay margin calls - shares bought with borrowed money.

Recent data showed a hefty increase in margin calls over the past six months, but the trend has left investors vulnerable to a bear market, with on-line brokerages automatically selling shares bought on credit as prices have fallen.

Analysts said the enforced sales and the new mood of fear meant that the declines were becoming self-feeding. "It was a momentum market on the way up, it is a momentum market on the way down," said Nick Sargen, chief investment strategist for JP Morgan.

Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, made no mention of the recent market turbulence during a speech in Washington.

However, the 22% drop in the Nasdaq during the past week - bigger than the fall in the Dow Jones Index during the 1987 stock market crash -will cast a shadow over the meeting in Washington today of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrial nations.

The International Monetary Fund warned earlier this week that "very high stock market valuations around the world" posed one of the biggest threats to continued global growth, noting that the high valuations put on technology stocks might "reflect unrealistic expectations of future earnings growth that have been nourished by the now record-long expansion in the US".

The trigger for yesterday's meltdown was the release of inflation figures by the US government showing consumer prices in March rose 0.7% - higher than the 0.5% the markets had been expecting.

Although part of the increase was due to dearer fuel as a result of higher oil prices, the underlying increase of 0.4% was double what dealers were anticipating, and prompted speculation that Mr Greenspan might raise interest rates by half a point when the Fed meets next month.

At its peak in March, the Nasdaq stood at 5,048.62 following an 86% rise in 1999. Analysts said there was now a belated recognition that valuations had become unrealistic.

But red arrows on screens did not deter the planned demutualisation of the Nasdaq. The National Association of Securities Dealers, parent of the hi-tech market, said yesterday the majority of its member firms had voted in favour of spinning off the Nasdaq.

webTitle: £40m for founder of mobile store chain

fields.headline: £40m for founder of mobile store chain
fields.trailText: A Merseyside entrepreneur who began selling phones as a sideline to his car business enjoyed a £40m windfall as his Mobile Phone Store chain was snapped up by BT Cellnet.
fields.body:
A Merseyside entrepreneur who began selling phones as a sideline to his car business enjoyed a £40m windfall as his Mobile Phone Store chain was snapped up by BT Cellnet.

Mike McComb, 42, established the business with a single shop in Southport seven years ago, and has since rolled it out to 129 stores. BT Cellnet acquired a 40% stake three years ago, and took full control yesterday in a deal valuing the business at £67m.

Mr McComb said: "BT Cellnet has already shown itself to be a good partner for us, and I'm convinced that it is the right company to take the Mobile Phone Store to the next stage of development."

The purchase means that BT Cellnet has 286 shops; BT also has about 100 outlets selling a variety of telecoms equipment, and owns 40% of The Link. BT Cellnet wants more shops to sell its internet-compatible WAP phones and recently launched Britain's first pre-paid WAP phone.

About 80% of sales at the Mobile Phone Store are of Cellnet phones. The chain claims to offer a more personal service than its rivals, with staff sitting at desks, rather than counters, offering a consultation to each customer. Sales this year are expected to reach £50m.

BT Cellnet said the group was unlikely to make any big changes to the Mobile Phone Store. "They've built up a solid reputation the branding works, and we're not going to change it," said a spokesman.

Mr McComb will stay to oversee the transition. Colleagues say he then wants to spend more time with his young family.

webTitle: Italian snub signals US growth for BAE

fields.headline: Italian snub signals US growth for BAE
fields.trailText: BAE Systems could be forced to concentrate on expanding its already significant US presence after being left out of the latest restructuring of the European defence and aerospace industry.
fields.body:
BAE Systems could be forced to concentrate on expanding its already significant US presence after being left out of the latest restructuring of the European defence and aerospace industry.

The Italian state-owned defence and engineering group Finmeccanica opted to join a joint venture covering civil and military aircraft with EADS, choosing the Franco-German-Spanish company in preference to BAE.

A key factor in the deal was EADS's offer of a 5% stake in Airbus Industrie, Europe's civil airline maker.

However handing over an Airbus stake will need the agreement of BAE which is also an Airbus partner. That could give BAE greater leverage in its negotiations with EADS about turning Airbus from a partnership to a conventional company structure.

Yesterday BAE shrugged off the Italian decision: "An agreement with Finmeccanica would have been nice to have but it was never seen as strategically important. We were not prepared to throw away shareholder value to complete this deal or any other."

Many analysts see the failure to sign up with Finmeccanica as likely to give BAE's US ambitions a fillip. Brian O'Keefe, aerospace analyst at Commerzbank, said: "The deal will have no material impact on the company and in the short term it'll help them focus more on the United States".

He noted that BAE already had more contracts with the Pentagon than Whitehall and that it had a strong enough cash position to step up its search for U.S. acquisitions.

fields.headline: Bank warns of dearer borrowing
fields.standfirst: Deputy governor says economic growth may be out of control
fields.trailText: The Bank of England warned homeowners and businesses yesterday that higher borrowing costs were on the way unless the pace of economic growth slackens.
fields.body:
The Bank of England warned homeowners and businesses yesterday that higher borrowing costs were on the way unless the pace of economic growth slackens.

Mervyn King, the Bank's deputy governor, told an audience in Plymouth last night that the Bank had to strike before inflation got out of control. "It is important not to let domestic demand grow too rapidly for too long. The longer the correction is left, the sharper the adjustment will be."

Threadneedle Street has raised the cost of borrowing four times in the past eight months, but left rates on hold at 6% this month, despite speculation in the City that last month's budget would spark retaliatory interest rate rises from the Bank.

Mr King said there were serious imbalances between domestic and external demand. "The trade deficit cannot continue to widen indefinitely," Mr King said.

"Hence at some point, domestic demand will have to grow at below its sustainable trend level rather than significantly above as it has done for some time."

Mr King leads the group on the Bank's monetary policy committee which prefers to act before inflation shows signs of taking off. Others, chiefly the former British Airways economist, De-Anne Julius, argue that technological developments may mean it is possible for the economy to grow faster than before without sparking inflation.

Yesterday Mr King underlined his hawkish credentials, noting that pre-emptive action would avoid the need for "a larger and more painful adjustment at a later date". This stitch in time theory of setting rates is angering manufacturers who see rate rises as an unnecessary boost to sterling.

Inflation has been below the government's target of 2.5% for nearly a year. A poll of 15 Reuters economists shows they expect the March underlying inflation rate to come in at 1.9%. This would be the first time in 24 years that inflation has fallen below 2%.

fields.headline: A rock'n'roll revenger
fields.trailText: A genuine survivor of the rock'n'roll era salutes Liza Cody's entertaining Gimme More
fields.body:
Gimme More
Liza Cody
Bloomsbury, £9.99, 314pp,
Buy it at BOL

Rock'n'roll? I knew it well. I am fairly confident that I am the only novelist to have been photographed in his underpants, together with my paymaster Richard Branson, for the launch of the immortal Rock Stars in Their Underpants. I later compounded my rock infamy by coming up with the idea of a Sid Vicious family-album scrapbook in the wake of the Sex Pistols bass player's untidy demise. Those were the days! Today, any old Salman Rushdie can openly acknowledge the influence of rock music on his writing, and most authors under 50 will be as familiar with Dylan and the Stones as they are with Dickens.

No wonder, then, that the follies of the rock'n'roll world attract our modern fabulists like bees to honey, and that every passing year sees further attempts at "the great rock novel" fail abysmally to capture the essence, colour, chaos and seduction that music and its personalities have to offer. In trying to capture the emotion of rock'n'roll, writers strive for a universal experience distilled from personal memories and tend to fall flat on their faces. Which makes Liza Cody's new book - a rock novel that has no message to offer, but entertains with wit, cunning, malice, and a wicked twist in the tale - a pleasant surprise.

Birdie Walker is an amalgam of all the famous rock groupies and courtesans rolled into one. Once her musician lover, Jack, was the Jim Morrison of his era; and there she was by his side, muse, sex symbol and splendid adornment. Following Jack's death, Birdie has been consigned to the dustbin of history: shunned by the music business, losing her looks but still full of fire, reduced to petty scams and working for a small private detective agency. The hangers-on and leeches of yesteryear now control the industry, and Jack's heritage still shifts records by the ton. When rumours surface of hitherto unheard-of recordings and a home movie, Birdie is determined to get her own back.

How this rock widow and ageing wild child cons, manipulates and exploits all the sharks makes for a delightful tale of revenge by a writer well known for her feisty female-led crime novels. Every detail rings true: the mad producers and impresarios, the financial tricksters, the naive musicians, the greed, the drugs and the excitement. Cody doesn't miss a trick. I know - I was there. Like Birdie Walker, I survived, but that's another story.

fields.headline: Listen to this
fields.standfirst: Susan Schwartz Senstad's thrilling war-torn novel, Music for the Third Ear, entrances  Anne Karpf
fields.trailText: Susan Schwartz Senstad's thrilling war-torn novel, Music for the Third Ear, entrances Anne Karpf
fields.body:
Music for the Third Ear
Susan Schwartz Senstad
Doubleday, £12.99, 208pp
Buy it at BOL

I had wanted to campaign for a moratorium on fiction about the Holocaust until I read this book. After a seemingly definitive pair of novels (David Grossman's See Under: Love and Anne Michaels's Fugitive Pieces), along with the memoirs and testimony, do we really need more? The Holocaust has become a fashionable plot device: our generation has juiced it dry.

But Susan Schwartz Senstad, an American-born family therapist living in Norway, has taken as the subject of her fine and powerful first novel not so much the Holocaust as its consequences across the generations and their repetition in the Balkan war.

Mette, infertile daughter of Hungarian Auschwitz survivors living in Norway, persuades her Norwegian husband that they should take in a Balkan refugee couple. But instead of showing the requisite gratitude, Mesud and Zheljka - he a Bosnian Muslim, she a Croatian Catholic, both brutalised by the war - unsettle their hosts' routine, and eventually move out.

Yet Mette craves acknowledgment of her own from Zheljka, and when the two women meet up again, she extracts from the Croatian the admission that, after being mass-raped by Serbs, Zheljka had borne a child she'd named Zero. When, four years later, she was reunited with Mesud, he was repelled by the existence of the boy and Zheljka excruciatingly gave him up for illegal adoption.

Mette, intercepting a letter which reveals that the adoption has been disastrous, conceives an obsessive plan to acquire Zero for herself. And so is initiated the extraordinary cross-border transportation of a child cargo.

Thus summarised, the novel sounds like a thriller. And indeed it is, but of conflicting moral constraints, psychic needs and political pragmatism. Senstad is also an artful mistress of the regular thriller's coups de thétre. There's a shoplifter in the novel, introduced with the same nonchalant stealth as the character uses to spirit away her booty. The book's many scenes of anguish are made physical, taking place in an embodied, materially precise world: Senstad uses striking, almost cinematic, tableaux to explore the prising apart of parent and child.

Among the most electric passages in the book are the meetings between Mette, the needy, calculating and often insensitive "war tourist", and Zheljka, a woman who has learned to vacate her body in order to survive. Each wants her own tragedy to register with the other: the complexity of need and counter-need is caught and pinioned with a steely sensibility.

Inevitably, there are flaws. This is a book driven by psychological insight, with the author as therapist: just occasionally it's difficult to tell if the deep awareness is the author's alone or if it is also being imputed to the characters. And however nuanced her characterisation, Senstad does sometimes fall back on stereotype. Her Holocaust survivors are weeping, howling ghosts; her infertile women (there are two) are crazed, irrational baby-thieves.

Senstad is highly ambitious and risk-taking. Zheljka is a piano student, and the opening chapters try to tune in not just to words but also to the sounds between them (hence the book's title). This is too self-conscious to be really illuminating, and thankfully the author jettisons the device for most of the rest of the book.

Elsewhere, in one short, audacious chapter, Senstad describes Zheljka's profoundly split feelings about her pregnancy - "that jellyboned growth like some cancer, her - she retches up the word - her - oh God must have had something else in mind when creating such a thing, her - please, die! - son". This is fine writing in the style of Anne Michaels, in which the language seems to have been threshed directly from the feelings rather than from the usual literary sources.

Later in the book, Senstad attempts to pin down the actual experience of Serb brutality. Fictionally speaking, there is not a lot that one can do with torture, apart from shaming the reader for not having shared the character's suffering and daring to sit there simply reading about it. Torture lends the author a cheap power, against which, as a reader, I always bridle.

Indeed, there are places in the early part of Music for the Third Ear where the mix of chronology, location and atrocity begins to wear one down. But then Senstad's lighter touch comes into play. She is herself married to a Norwegian and is a wry guide around cultural assumptions (her contrasting sketches of the self-deceptions of Norwegian and Italian society are delicious), and gendered reactions: at least two of her main male characters "feel with their thoughts".

Ultimately, Senstad offers a remarkable and highly subtle exploration of the aftermath of brutality and Europeans' successive experiences of exile. And to think that this is only her first published work.

 Anne Karpf is the author of The War After, published by Mandarin.

fields.headline: Mushrooms in Stockport
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: My love affair with Pamela moved into a sexual stage tonight, though "full union", as she calls it, has yet to take place.
fields.body:
Monday, April 3, 2000, Arthur Askey Way

My love affair with Pamela moved into a sexual stage tonight, though "full union", as she calls it, has yet to take place. Pamela is a fan of the female condom, but, after examining one she took out of her briefcase, we discovered that it had been issued in 1998.

We decided not to risk it. Pam was keen to consummate, saying, "I just want to get it out of the way, Adrian." I explained that I hadn't kept condoms in the house since William took one to nursery school as his contribution to the hot-air-balloon mural. It was an eagle-eyed Ofsted inspector who spotted the "big boy arouser" rising between the cotton-wool cloud.

Pamela asked me if I'd like to go to Stockport next weekend to meet her parents. I lied and said, "Yes, Wiggly." She asked me to call her Wiggly. She calls me Snuffly. I've had a slight head cold since we met.

Tuesday, April 4

The Ludlows held a welcome home from prison party for Vince tonight. I went next door at 10pm, after William and Glenn had gone to bed. I don't want my boys to associate the word "prison" with the word "party".

Vince said he had seen Jonathan Aitken in the prison chapel, and had witnessed Mr Aitken's religious fervour. Vince said, " 'e was shakin' 'is tambourine so 'ard that 'is Rolex fell off".

Vince told me to back Papillon in the Grand National. I said it was highly unlikely that another son/jockey and father/ trainer combination would win. I rang Pamela as soon as I got home. She said she was in bed with a Trollope. "Anthony or Joanna?" I asked. Pamela laughed, as though I'd made a joke.

Thursday, April 6

The Piggs' don't like children, so my mother is babysitting William for the weekend and Glenn is going to his mother's. Pamela warned me tonight not to tell her father that I am an unpublished poet and novelist. I pointed out that I have published two cookery books: Offaly Good and Offaly Good Again. She told me that her father was a militant vegetarian and a former RAF kayak instructor. I dread meeting Mr Pigg.

Friday, April 7, The Olde Forge, Stockport

He is even worse than I feared. "Call me Porky!" he boomed. He was wearing a sort of fleecy Babygro garment and rubber socks. He had just returned from a training session on an artificial slalom course on the River Tees. He has offered to take me down the rapids in his double kayak on Sunday. Mrs Pigg was loading her van in preparation for a country fayre, at which she sells the hedgehog boot scrapers she makes out of pine cones and plastic bristles.

As Mrs Pigg was showing me to my single bed, she asked me to call her Snouty. When I enquired what her real Christian name was, she glared and said, "Why are you presuming that my parents were Christians?" I told her I'd seen the photograph on the mantelpiece of her parents' wedding, which had been taken outside a church and been attended by a vicar holding a copy of the Old Testament. She said that I "mustn't bother" Pamela in the night, as Mr Pigg did not approve of sex before long-term commitment.

Saturday, April 8

The Piggs took me to a Beefeater restaurant for dinner tonight. A cardboard cut-out of the TV chef Brian Turner welcomed us in. The conversation ground to a halt over pre-dinner drinks, when Porky discovered that I am a single father living in a council house. The tension was palpable. Pamela developed a most unflattering tic in her left eye.

But all was not lost because Porky and I chose the lightly breaded deep-fried mushrooms at £2.95 (with a choice of two dips). Porky and I now have something in common: we will talk about our Beefeater experience for many years to come. Thank you, Mr Turner.

fields.headline: The prime suspects
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  wills Apostolos Doxiadis' mathematical detective to succeed in Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture
fields.trailText: Steven Poole wills Apostolos Doxiadis' mathematical detective to succeed in Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture
fields.body:
Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture
Apostolos Doxiadis
Faber, £9.99, 208pp
Buy it at BOL

Like all the best puzzles, Goldbach's Conjecture is easy to state: every even number greater than two is the sum of two primes. Computers have found this to be true for numbers so large you couldn't speak all their digits aloud before you died (of old age, not boredom). But there might still be some titanic digit-string for which it doesn't hold; for three centuries, no one has managed to nail it down with a logical proof.

Old Uncle Petros is the black sheep of his family: he spends all his time tending his garden and playing chess, earning the contempt of his brothers. But his nephew cunningly discovers that Petros used to be an eminent mathematician who devoted his working life to trying to prove Goldbach's Conjecture. This is his story.

Compared with its bloody sibling, chess, cold and solitary mathematics seems a rebarbative subject for literature. It can work well as evocative secondary texture, as in William Boyd's Brazzaville Beach and Don DeLillo's Ratner's Star, but the only novel primarily about maths that is generally considered a success is Edwin A Abbott's 1880 classic Flatland. That has one big idea to explain: the concept of higher dimensions. Goldbach's unproven Conjecture, on the other hand, is simple enough to relate, and Doxiadis's concern in this slight tale is certainly not a pop course in number theory; he mostly luxuriates in the "music" of theorems without explaining them in detail.

So surely we need a pinch of human drama? Well, Doxiadis gives us a great central quest: Petros's obsession, during his prime of life as a Munich professor, with proving Goldbach, refusing to publish valuable interim results lest someone else beat him to a proof. Such paranoid acuity is mirrored in Simon Singh's true-life account of another loner working on a famously "unsolvable" problem, Andrew Wiles in Fermat's Last Theorem. The two books graph similar emotional turmoil for their heroes: calm plateaux, deceptive gradients and despairing troughs.

But Doxiadis otherwise offers little beyond the facts of his story except clunky platitude. He trumpets the unsurprising claim that mathematicians are not "motivated exclusively by the Pursuit of Truth for the Good of Mankind" (he has a Very Annoying Capitals Habit); meanwhile a woozy religio-metaphysical thread burbles about such dubious concepts as "the dangers of coming too close to Truth in its absolute form".

Doxiadis weaves some real mathematicians - GH Hardy, JE Littlewood and Srinivasa Ramanujan - into the story, but the characterisations are nugatory, and there is one disgracefully fatuous statement to the effect that Alan Turing committed suicide because of the unbearable melancholy of mathematics.

The novel certainly improves about halfway through: one image, in which Petros sees his fugitive numbers in a dream, illuminates gorgeously its drab surroundings, and Doxiadis engineers an unusually satisfying ending. Uncle Petros is overall rather sketchy, but gripping nonetheless. Even mathematicians and philosophers love cheap detective novels: the desire to follow a primal quest, willing the hero to succeed, seems hard-wired into all our brains.

fields.headline: Original fiction
fields.trailText: Okay, so it doesn't sound very likely, we know, but truth is stranger, and all that. This week's top-selling original fiction is the tale of two teenage girls, both of them pregnant...
fields.body:
Okay, so it doesn't sound very likely, we know, but truth is stranger, and all that. This week's top-selling original fiction is the tale of two teenage girls, both of them pregnant. So far, so good. Wait a minute, they're both virgins! Wait another, one of them is up the duff with the child of Christ, the other with the spawn of Satan! But which one is which? If you can suspend your disbelief long enough to finish Cradle and All, you might just find enlightenment (with the help of a Vatican priest and a nun-turned-private-dick).

Elsewhere on the chart, things are much more mundane. Toby Litt simply has a contract killing, Douglas Coupland an everyday plane crash, and Peter Farrelly a screenwriter plagued by a psychotic woman. Time was when all we complained about was the rise of the Hampstead novel. Bring back those anguished conversations about private education and ciabatta before we die of overexcitement.

fields.headline: Haunting across the generations
fields.standfirst: The multi-faceted Lisa Appignanesi tells Alex Clark about her mother's stories
fields.trailText: The multi-faceted Lisa Appignanesi tells Alex Clark about her mother's stories
fields.body:
If you want a crash course in Lisa Appignanesi's work, now is a good time to get started on your researches. A new novel, Sanctuary, has just been published, alongside the paperback edition of her last, The Dead of Winter; Penguin are bringing out a second edition of Freud's Women, the highly acclaimed study that she wrote with her partner, John Forrester; and there is also the paperback of Losing the Dead, a memoir of her family's experience of life as Polish Jews in the second world war.

But that's only the tip of the iceberg, as Appignanesi has also written a study of Proust, Henry James and Robert Musil, a history of cabaret and a portrait of Simone de Beauvoir, as well as making films for television and editing books on French thought and postmodernism. Oh yes, and she was a university lecturer and Deputy Director of the ICA for several years.

Most writers would preen themselves on such a prodigious work-rate and formidable array of interests, but Appignanesi wears her achievements rather lightly - possibly because she came to the business of writing early on, publishing her first books in her early 20s.

Much of her work, and all of her novels, however, have appeared since she left the ICA 10 years ago. Freud's Women, first published in 1992, required an immense amount of research, although she wryly remembers the difference in styles between her and her academic co-author: "He'd have eight footnotes a sentence, and I'd have one footnote every eight pages," she laughs, also recalling how they would lie in bed every night discussing Freud. It worked, she says, but that will be the one and only collaboration.

That book written, Appignanesi turned her attention to fiction. Her six novels could loosely be called thrillers, although it is the process of investigation and of excavating the past that appeals to her sensibility, rather than the hard-boiled construction of police procedurals or straightforward whodunnits. She herself likes to think of her novels as "crossover fiction", popular forms invested with serious ideas and an intense curiosity in "cusp moments" - those pockets of time in which a crime is committed, or in which the boundary between sanity and insanity is broken down.

Sanctuary is particularly concerned with madness, or at least, psychological disturbance. At its heart is a woman who goes in search of her vanished best friend, and, discovering that she had been seeing an analyst, offers herself up as a patient. Appignanesi confesses to being fascinated by the analytic process, by the idea that "two strangers meet in a room and suddenly they're haunted by each other". Her central character, a woman in mid-life whose frantic quest is emblematic of her larger, less answerable anxieties, is caught up in that "analytic twosome", with ambiguous and problematic results. But an equally significant part of the novel derives from Appignanesi's insistence that the past, however diligently we might seek to uncover it, frequently resists our interpretations.

It was specifically her parents' past that was under discussion in Losing the Dead: A Family Memoir. For almost 20 years, Appignanesi had struggled to put out of her mind her father's last few hours, when, in a diabetic delirium, he became convinced that the hospital ward he lay in was an SS camp, his doctors its guards, his oxygen mask a conduit for poison gas.

He had not spoken of the war for years, not since shortly after he had transplanted his family from Warsaw to Canada in 1951. It was a time of great hope and new beginnings, her father joking that when Moses talked about the promised land, he had meant to pronounce Canaan as Canada. In the memoir, Appignanesi notes that: "My parents and their friends only talked of their great good luck. If the baggage they carried with them was weighty with loss, they were still prepared to trade it in for the future. History was something one left behind, something to be endlessly repeated only in stories."

Those stories came largely from her mother, a great raconteur and embroiderer who frequently enjoined her daughter to write her life. When her mother succumbed to Alzheimer's, and to the miserable repetition of a garbled past, Appignanesi was moved to take her "reduced narratives" and to "give this past back to her".

It was a painful book to write, especially against the backdrop of her mother's drowning mind, but the result is a deeply affecting portrait of family life during a terrible time. She had wanted, she says, to write a small, particular story, something that would make the point that not all Holocaust narratives had the same ending. And yet her mother's compulsive storytelling - much of it tinged with the victory of escape - was a way of talking out the past. "My mother's fictions," writes Appignanesi, "were acts of star-quality diplomacy, a manipulation of human events aimed at a kind of social peace or place."

As a child, Appignanesi felt herself cast in the role of family truthteller, as the necessary complement to her mother's garrulousness and her father's taciturnity. As an adult, and as a writer, fiction and non-fiction have been as important as one another in shaping her career, but it's noticeable that the possibility of telling her own stories came to her relatively late on. She makes much, in conversation and in her work, of the notion of "transgenerational haunting" and that "forgettings and rememberings pace themselves through time". There may well only be room for one storyteller in each family, but it seems that Appignanesi has assumed that mantle with ease.

fields.headline: On thin ice
fields.standfirst: Justine Jordan  finds Helen Dunmore settling for style over content in Ice Cream
fields.trailText: Justine Jordan finds Helen Dunmore settling for style over content in Ice Cream
fields.body:
Ice Cream
Helen Dunmore
Viking, £15.99, 218pp
Buy it at BOL

Helen Dunmore excels at dysfunctional family thrillers: transportative, page-turning, up-till-three, miss-your-stop novels rich in dark secrets, incestuous kin and unflinching physical immediacy. Her short fiction is a different story; the first collection, Love of Fat Men, takes place in the muffled, snowbound world of a Scandinavian winter, like Narnia before the Ice Queen's spell is broken. Its characters are solitary figures, tiny against the landscape, in the final piece skating off into invisibility across a frozen lake, "darker splodges on a pale background, like a graze on the paper".

Sadly, in Ice Cream, her second short-story collection, many of the narrators really do dwindle into insubstantiality. Dunmore is mouth-wateringly good on food, and brilliant on nature, but her prose overwrites her structure.

The subject of the title story is a beautifully described pudding, the model trying to resist such temptation merely a shadowy mouth. "Be Vigilant, Rejoice, Eat Plenty" (the Delphic advice of a parking meter to an unhappy woman) writes its way towards a particularly nice breakfast. "The Fag", in which a woman smokes as she drives through the countryside, is an object lesson in what can be achieved in three pages - like Beckett or Georges Perec, Dunmore knows the intimate, unsettling effect of the second-person address and uses it with quiet relish - but, a few stories in, it reads like the writer giving herself yet another opportunity for a Country Diary.

Several of the stories in Love of Fat Men dealt with Ulli, as eager child, carefree student and solitary adult. She appears again here, but has become almost a default setting for the Dunmore short story: Ulli is pregnant and unhappy on a French exchange (lovely flora and fauna, though). Ulli goes home with a strange man whose room is crammed with religious icons. In addition to Ulli, there is a succession of rather similar adolescent girls; the blending of character and consistency of much of the descriptive tone make the stories blur into vagueness.

When Dunmore goes for something radically different, the effect is jarring. "Leonardo, Michelangelo, Superstork", an SF idea-driven piece - cloned embryo implantation has replaced natural conception and all women must be fitted with a wonderfully named "rubicon" to block genetically inferior sperm - has a Roald Dahl-esque showiness to it. Likewise "Mason's Mini-Break", in which a pompous writer ends up patronising the ghost of Charlotte Brontë on the moors, the penny dropping when his wife returns from the parsonage with her portrait, commenting on her exclusion from the literary establishment of the time. "Amazing how some people don't see what's under their noses, isn't it?... Dick, whatever's the matter? Has something happened?"

The best stories feature neither nature nor the supernatural. In "Swimming into the Millennium", a middle-aged woman escapes whining family and Y2K pressure for a "sleek, still" pool and the aquatic friendship of a young male couple, full of love and free of responsibility for Christmas shopping and ex-mothers-in-law, who "have so much that it spills over on to me". "My Polish Teacher's Tie" sees a school dinner lady jettison shame and self-consciousness to recover her past and her possibilities. The voices are utterly convincing, the structural arcs pleasing and accomplished without the kerplunk of laboured epiphany.

Elsewhere, though the sentences sing, style is not enough. With Your Crooked Heart, a daring exploration of love and alcoholism, is released in paperback with Ice Cream; set against the wisdom and perception of the novel, a collection which would suggest potential in a lesser talent looks workmanlike.
fields.bodyText: Ice Cream Helen Dunmore Viking, £15.99, 218pp Buy it at BOL Helen Dunmore excels at dysfunctional family thrillers: transportative, page-turning, up-till-three, miss-your-stop novels rich in dark secrets, incestuous kin and unflinching physical immediacy. Her short fiction is a different story; the first collection, Love of Fat Men, takes place in the muffled, snowbound world of a Scandinavian winter, like Narnia before the Ice Queen's spell is broken. Its characters are solitary figures, tiny against the landscape, in the final piece skating off into invisibility across a frozen lake, "darker splodges on a pale background, like a graze on the paper". Sadly, in Ice Cream, her second short-story collection, many of the narrators really do dwindle into insubstantiality. Dunmore is mouth-wateringly good on food, and brilliant on nature, but her prose overwrites her structure. The subject of the title story is a beautifully described pudding, the model trying to resist such temptation merely a shadowy mouth. "Be Vigilant, Rejoice, Eat Plenty" (the Delphic advice of a parking meter to an unhappy woman) writes its way towards a particularly nice breakfast. "The Fag", in which a woman smokes as she drives through the countryside, is an object lesson in what can be achieved in three pages - like Beckett or Georges Perec, Dunmore knows the intimate, unsettling effect of the second-person address and uses it with quiet relish - but, a few stories in, it reads like the writer giving herself yet another opportunity for a Country Diary. Several of the stories in Love of Fat Men dealt with Ulli, as eager child, carefree student and solitary adult. She appears again here, but has become almost a default setting for the Dunmore short story: Ulli is pregnant and unhappy on a French exchange (lovely flora and fauna, though). Ulli goes home with a strange man whose room is crammed with religious icons. In addition to Ulli, there is a succession of rather similar adolescent girls; the blending of character and consistency of much of the descriptive tone make the stories blur into vagueness. When Dunmore goes for something radically different, the effect is jarring. "Leonardo, Michelangelo, Superstork", an SF idea-driven piece - cloned embryo implantation has replaced natural conception and all women must be fitted with a wonderfully named "rubicon" to block genetically inferior sperm - has a Roald Dahl-esque showiness to it. Likewise "Mason's Mini-Break", in which a pompous writer ends up patronising the ghost of Charlotte Brontë on the moors, the penny dropping when his wife returns from the parsonage with her portrait, commenting on her exclusion from the literary establishment of the time. "Amazing how some people don't see what's under their noses, isn't it?... Dick, whatever's the matter? Has something happened?" The best stories feature neither nature nor the supernatural. In "Swimming into the Millennium", a middle-aged woman escapes whining family and Y2K pressure for a "sleek, still" pool and the aquatic friendship of a young male couple, full of love and free of responsibility for Christmas shopping and ex-mothers-in-law, who "have so much that it spills over on to me". "My Polish Teacher's Tie" sees a school dinner lady jettison shame and self-consciousness to recover her past and her possibilities. The voices are utterly convincing, the structural arcs pleasing and accomplished without the kerplunk of laboured epiphany. Elsewhere, though the sentences sing, style is not enough. With Your Crooked Heart, a daring exploration of love and alcoholism, is released in paperback with Ice Cream; set against the wisdom and perception of the novel, a collection which would suggest potential in a lesser talent looks workmanlike.

fields.headline: A revolutionary feast
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard gets his knives out for an unlucky bovine after consulting Ovid's Fasti
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard gets his knives out for an unlucky bovine after consulting Ovid's Fasti
fields.body:
Fasti
Publius Ovidius Naso, trs, ed and int AJ Boyle and RD Woodard
Penguin Classics, 360pp, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

Today is the feast of Fordicidia Ludi Nefastus Publicus, and if you want to celebrate it properly you are going to need to find a priest who is prepared to sacrifice a pregnant cow: "When the acolytes have ripped the calves from the wombs/And dropped the sliced guts on the smoking hearths,/ The eldest virgin cremates the calves in the fire/To cleanse folk with this ash on Pales' day."

This you learn from reading Ovid's Fasti, which was revised during the period of his banishment from Rome by a cranky and autocratic Augustus. This would have been horrible for Ovid: he was sent to the furthest limit of the Roman Empire, a shithole called Tomis situated in what is now Romania (once a dump, always a dump, it would appear). The inhabitants didn't even speak Latin: they spoke comedy languages like Getic and Sarmartian.

Fasti is, on the surface, a day-by-day account and explanation of the extremely numerous feast-days and celebrations of the Roman world. "Times and their causes, arranged through the Latin year,/Stars sunk beneath earth and risen, I'll sing," it begins (although he only gets through the first six months). If this were all Ovid were up to, it would be an astonishingly rich source of haunting poetry, or, if you want to be level-headed about it, fertile material for anthropological speculation.

The editors note that "the sacrifice of pregnant cows is cross-culturally a highly uncommon rite. A striking parallel is, however, attested in Vedic India where two pregnant cows are offered to Earth and to the Maruts. Maruts are storm gods... identified as members of the third function of divine society."

And so on. You are going to learn an awful lot that you did not know before: you will even learn something of the Eleusinian mysteries, the cult that celebrated Ceres and Proserpina, in ceremonies which possibly involved the mass consumption of milk infused with poppies, maybe a human sacrifice; or something even stranger. We don't know: they're mysteries. (Today's pregnant cow sacrifice is largely for Ceres's benefit, so that crops may grow and sheep give birth.)

But this is not all that Ovid is doing. While superficially concerned with legitimizing Roman festivities and hence the Imperial order itself, it is in fact wildly subversive. Augustus is praised in the most bizarre fashions; the information becomes confused, unreliable, bizarre. When he asks how the month of May got its name, he confesses ignorance and, when he asks the Muses, even they disagree. Divinity and order are continually undermined; he omits crucial dates from the calendar, and while he celebrates a huge number of battles and their anniversaries, half of them are defeats. It is a jab in the Augustan eyeball. "Ovid's Fasti," say the editors, "is a revolutionary act."

We're coming in on the joke a bit late, though, and this is why we should salute not only Ovid - the guy sure could write - but the editors, who have translated the original line by line (with very few exceptions, they add; but always couplet by couplet) while managing to keep something of Ovid's metre and versification. It is an extraordinary technical accomplishment, and when you consider the amount of work that must have gone into the exceptionally informative notes, one can only feel a kind of awe at the quantity and quality of scholarship involved. And Penguin have done it all for us, and all for only a tenner. I think this calls for a sacrifice. Anyone got a pregnant cow?

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Alain de Botton picks out strands of the thought of some dead white males and tells us what we feel we should know already in his tenor register.
fields.body:
The Consolations of Philosophy
written and read by Alain de Botton
Penguin, £8.99, 180 min
Buy it at BOL

First Proust, now half a dozen other dead big bonces - Socrates, Epicurus, Seneca, Montaigne, Schopenhauer and Nietzsche. Although the book has taken a mauling, De Botton has the felicitous knack of selling us stuff we feel we should know but haven't read. The advantage here is that without knowledge of these men's philosophies we won't know what sort of pup we're being sold.

The cassette sleeve calls it "wonderfully witty", which shows what a sheltered life blurb-writers lead. From each thinker, De Botton fillets a couple of strands he thinks useful to us today. Whether they fairly relay the original authors' thoughts, I've frankly no idea. But they are simple enought to take in while negotiating heavy motorway tradffic, which is presumably the aim. The unrelieved tenor register of De Botton's voice, though, with no bass bourdon, wearies the ear.

fields.headline: Autobiography on ice
fields.trailText: Matthew Parris goes to the ends of the earth in search of peace and quiet, plus love blooms in Covent Garden and a dialogue on Sylvia Plath
fields.body:
 We all know that writers need peace and quiet, but news of the sharp-witted Matthew Parris's plans to write his autobiography are somewhat surprising. Five months in Antarctica should see the manuscript knocked into shape for Penguin.

But what of Parris's chances of achieving unearthly calm? A quick call to a South Pole boffin reveals some potential snowclouds on the horizon. Apparently, long-stayers frequently find themselves indulging in "adult versions of boarding-school relationships", features of which include painting one another green, playing darts and re-enacting episodes of Prisoner Cell Block H. Added to which, the very danger of the place means that "there is less solitude in Antarctica than anywhere else in the world", while the weirdness of the climate increases one's time asleep. Ideal, absolutely ideal.

 Pearson CEO Marjorie Scardino might have spent £311 million acquiring the ailing Dorling Kindersley last week, but she wasn't too preoccupied with examining its threadbare books to forget her new staff. In a heartwarming letter to DK's Covent Garden personnel, Scardino welcomed them to the fold with all the tenderness of a nervous lover: "We have to wait a month or so before we can begin the serious business of getting to know each other better. But we wanted you to know how eager we are for that day."

No doubt James Middlehurst, the hapless former exec whose Star Wars boob was responsible for £3 million in losses, and a further £14 million of DK's projected £19 million shortfall, wishes he'd hung on to his job long enough to enjoy the protective Pearson embrace. Meanwhile, over at Penguin, there are rumours of an imminent removal from Kensington High Street to the Strand - bringing the extended workforce ever closer together.

 Swindon is perhaps best known as the home of roundabouts and WHSmith, but the Loafer was charmed to receive a letter from the town's very own Festival of Literature. "We are a little Festival but keen," writes its director, Matt Holland. "We like words at work and at play. There are surprises in Swindon!" We're sure there are, but to check it out for yourselves, roll up between May 1 and 13 (01793 771080 for details).

 In the Loafer's view, all reported conversations with black-cab drivers should be the subject of an embargo on the grounds of cliche, but sometimes... Amid all the fuss over Sylvia Plath's journals, it was refreshing to hear a lone voice of dissent as the taxi idled beneath a large window display in Books etc. The dialogue ran as follows:

Cabbie: Who the hell is Sylvia Plath?

Loafer: Erm - she was a poet. She killed herself.

Cabbie: What, her poems were so terrible she had to top herself?

Loafer: Erm - she was awfully depressed.

Cabbie: So would I be if I wrote bloody poetry. Sodding intellectuals, they do it for the attention, you know. I bet no one read a word until she'd gone. Like that mad woman with the cello and the sister.

Loafer: Erm - I think she had multiple sclerosis, actually.

Cabbie: Yeah, yeah, whatever. What do you do, anyway?

Loafer: I'm unemployed.

fields.headline: Deus ex machina
fields.standfirst: The Cogwheel Brain: Doron Swade's tale of a lone genius, Byron's daughter and the 19th-century computer
fields.trailText: The Cogwheel Brain: Doron Swade's tale of a lone genius, Byron's daughter and the 19th-century computer
fields.body:
The Cogwheel Brain: Charles Babbage and the Quest to Build the First Computer
Doron Swade
Little Brown, £14.99, pp288
Buy it at BOL

In publishing terms, The Cogwheel Brain is Longitude mark two: a lone genius, not the best of diplomats, struggles with the establishment to win recognition. Like John Harrison, Charles Babbage (1791-1871) quarrelled with the Astronomer Royal, had a royal sympathiser (Prince Albert) and often failed to finish a machine because he had moved on to something else. This book, again like Longitude, features a coda in which the original machines are restored to working order - though it has the added distinction that its author, the assistant director of the Science Museum, is the man who masterminded the rebuilding.

Unlike Harrison, Babbage was relatively well off, and, some of the time at least, was at home in fashionable society. But he was inclined to be self-destructive - a streak which showed itself early when he flunked his Cambridge exams by committing blasphemy. The pinnacle of his lack of diplomacy was a meeting with prime minister Robert Peel which ended official support for the project for ever.

The genesis of Babbage's attempt to mechanise maths lay in the drudgery necessary to produce mathematical tables; in the early 19th century a "computer" was a human operator who performed such calculations. In 1821 Babbage was working on mathematical tables for the Astronomical Society. Finding too many errors, Babbage exclaimed: "I wish to God these tables had been executed by steam."

Babbage soon set to work to produce a mechanised calculating machine or "Difference Engine", to be run not by steam but by turning a handle to actuate gearwheels, ratchets and other devices. By 1822 he had produced a small working model and serious fundraising began. Despite the fact that the Astronomer Royal, George Biddell Airy, never saw the point of Babbage's engines, the government did award funding: £17,478 (over £1m in today's money) was disbursed before it despaired of the project in 1842.

It took 10 years to produce a part of the great engine - and it did work - but Babbage never finished the rest of it because he had had a better idea. It is this better idea on which his fame mostly rests, because where the Difference Engine was the forerunner of the electromechanical adding machines of the 30s, the later "Analytical Engine" presaged the modern programmable general-purpose computer.

Or did it? The Analytical Engine was never built; Babbage's prescience came to light only when his papers were explored in the 1970s. The only computer pioneer of the 40s who knew his work was Harold Aiken, who built the Harvard Mark 1 for IBM in 1943 (he had seen a small machine that Babbage's son Henry sent to Harvard in 1886, and fulsomely acknowledged his debt to Babbage). There is no sign that Babbage realised, as Alan Turing did 100 years later, that such a computer would be able to handle not just mathematical and logical problems but every form of information that exists.

At this point an intriguing person enters the story: Ada Lovelace, Byron's daughter, who became a friend and collaborator. She had huge intellectual ambitions and a prophetic feel for the importance of Babbage's work, and went beyond him in seeing the potential for processing more than numbers: "Supposing for instance that the fundamental relations of pitched sounds in the science of harmony and of musical expression were susceptible of such expression and adaptations, the Engine might compose elaborate and scientific pieces of music of any degree or extent." This was in fact a prediction of modern "generative" computer music software - although Babbage would probably not have approved of this application, his last years being dedicated to waging a campaign against street music which led to musicians deliberately pestering him at home.

Part of The Cogwheel Brain is devoted to Swade's account of building a working version of Babbage's Difference Engine No 2 (designed in 1846 using the knowledge gleaned from the Analytical Engine, but never built) for the Babbage bicentenary in 1991. It is a gripping episode: Swade details the power meetings, the bankruptcy of the key contractor, all of the jostling with sponsors, media and government policy that characterise the modern world of curatorship, and the race against time to complete the engine for the anniversary. It stands in the Science Museum, a beautiful helical motion coursing through the apparatus as it performs its carry-10 function. The second phase of the restoration, the printing mechanism, will coincide with the launch of this book.

A theme that hangs heavily over the whole book is one that Babbage himself addressed in a paper of 1852: "Propose to an Englishman any principle, or any instrument, however admirable, and you will observe that the whole effort of the English mind is directed to find a difficulty, defect, or an impossibility in it." The obstruction encountered by John Harrison with his chronometers, Babbage with his Difference and Analytical Engines and Whittle with his jet engine is essentially the same story: a complacent and unimaginative civil service and government and an old-fashioned and ill-equipped engineering industry divided from science by barriers of class and educational snobbery.

 Peter Forbes is the editor of Scanning the Century: The Penguin Book of the Twentieth Century in Poetry.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A highly readable lesson in the realities of war plus The Second Prison, Low Life and The Painted Room
fields.body:
Triage
Scott Anderson
Pan, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Though the moral of the story - that in war there are no spectators, only participants - comes home with the force of an artillery shell, Anderson's lesson is highly readable. Mark Walsh is a photojournalist recording civil war in Kurdistan with gung-ho nonchalance for his safety until an explosion puts him in a guerrilla hospital where survival is decided by a coloured tag. Back home in New York, he cannot shake off his trauma and return to normal life with girlfriend Elena until her Spanish grandfather proposes an unorthodox cure. Like his hero, Anderson has covered war for a living, and he conveys the brutality and bleak choices it offers with stylistic economy.

The Second Prison
Ronan Bennett
Review, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Prisons material are all too often transformed into prisons metaphorical, but the theme is rarely as well done as it is here. As Benny tells the hero and fellow remand prisoner, Kane, over a game of chess, "It's getting out of the second prison - that's the real challenge. Everyone gets a chance, one chance to escape from the second prison. Trouble is, hardly anyone takes it." Kane is in Brixton for "Paddy stuff" and his prisoner's dilemma - quietly contrasted with that of the thieves and fraudsters - is to find out who betrayed his Belfast unit. Bennett's republished debut mixes thriller with prison diary; the portrayal of Kane is subtle, sorrowful and nicely low key.

Low Life
Mike Duff
Crocus, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Rooftop Rafferty is no lovable rogue: he's into cheque-book fraud and would probably have your wallet and cards in the time it takes to read the back cover of this book. But despite a career as a one-man Manchester crime wave, and his belief that every good sentence should be cemented in place with an obscenity, he is an engaging character who nods knowingly towards Dickens. Duff's debut, winner of a North West writing competition, is punchy, brash and funny without being over-heavy on flat-cap grimness and urban wastelands. Duff holds together a complex narrative and never lets Rooftop or the reader get sentimental.

The Painted Room
Inger Christensen
Harvill, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

In 1460 Ludovico, Duke of Mantua invites the painter Mantegna to decorate a room in his palace. The "divine decorator", as the duke's disgruntled secretary Marsilio calls him, builds a house, brings peacocks to the palace but takes years to begin work on his fresco. When it is finally finished, the work freezes the faces of the duke's household into the plaster forever. fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: A thought-provoking insight into ant-semitism between the wars
fields.body:
Farewell Leicester Square
Betty Miller
Persephone Books, £10
Buy it at BOL

This latest rediscovery by the mail-order publisher Persephone offers a thought-provoking insight into anti-semitism between the wars - not the violent prejudice of Mosley's fascists, but the discreet discrimination of the bourgeoisie, which has played its part in shaping the intellectual heritage of the UK. Betty Miller, the mother of Jonathan Miller, was born in Cork in 1910 to cosmopolitan Jewish parents who later moved to London. In this fourth of seven novels - lusciously republished in Persephone's trademark silver - she looks at the success, and its costs, of a Jewish film-maker from a roughly similar milieu as her own.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: A mine of information that rounds up the usual suspects plus The Penguin Thesaurus of Quotations
fields.body:
The Penguin Dictionary of Clichés
Julia Cresswell
£7.99
Buy it at BOL

Not quite the dog's bollocks, but a sumptuous repast, suffice it to say. The fact of the matter is that this goes the extra mile hither and thither ("h & t" is 7th century, believe it or not) to stop us in our tracks by banging on about the first sighting of "all the rage" - circa 1785, same vintage as "the thing" and "bore". Everything you've ever wanted to know about the full monty. (Disputed origins: the complete Sunday suit from chain tailor Montague Burton, or Field-Marshal's M's brekkie of bacon-and-egg even in the western desert?) A mine of information; rounds up the usual suspects but adds new flavours of the month like "the wrong kind of snow". Often a triumph of substance over style, but a real winner. Just the job.

The Penguin Thesaurus of Quotations
ed M J Cohen
£7.99
Buy it at BOL

Ordered alphabetically by subject (glory, God, gossip and the grave most properly on sequent pages) and so rewarding to read as a surrealist collage, juxtaposing jokes and pitiless wisdom. Cried on the Tube at Dennis Potter's seeing-the-blossom farewell adjacent to Shakespeare's "fear no more the heat of the sun", both under Mortality - "see also", as Cohen profoundly cross-refs, "Life & Death, Life is Fleeting, Past Time". Moved us to consult Ecclesiastes again, and E Fitzgerald's inexorable Ruba'iyat translation. Inapt on Sex, obvious on Fools, but fresh on the Self; and rightly respects both the Marquis de Vauvenargues and Nancy Banks-Smith.

webTitle: 'I cant type like I used to'

fields.headline: 'I cant type like I used to'
fields.standfirst: Geoff Dyer  on Kerouac's long twilight
fields.trailText: Geoff Dyer on Kerouac's long twilight
fields.body:
Jack Kerouac: Selected Letters 1957-1969
edited by Ann Charters
Viking, £25, 514pp
Buy it at BOL

Books Unlimited author page

Asked at the end of last year to select my book of the century, I opted for On the Road. Considered critical judgment or rush of adolescent blood to the head? Perhaps a bit of both. The Kerouac myth urges one away from dispassionate assessment towards the intoxication of the moment; on that basis, On the Road gets my vote for the remembered rush it first induced. With each subsequent reading, however, the book gets better and better. Most surprising of all is the degree of authorial control. Any more controlled and it would been self-stifling; any less and it would have ended up like the torrent of junk that came pouring in its wake.

Jack Kerouac's own conviction that it was "a great novel" was consolidated rather than threatened by its being rejected by publishers for six years before Viking relented in 1957, the year this second volume of his letters begins. As early as 1952, in response to an editor who had called it a "thoroughly incoherent mess", he predicted what would happen: "On the Road will be published by someone else, with a few changes and omissions and additions, and it will gain its due recognition, in time, as the first or one of the first modern prose books in America." What he failed to anticipate was the sodden collapse of writer and man that would come in the wake of this prophecy's being fulfilled.

As the first helping of letters made plain, Kerouac kept revising On the Road to make it more spontaneous. The hard-won struggle to master "spontaneous prose" both enabled Kerouac to write a great book and condemned him, for the rest of his life, to banging out pretty terrible ones.

As the liberating idea of "wild spontaneous yowks" hardened into an inflexible method, Kerouac became a prisoner of the "fuckyou freedom" he had helped unleash. Occasionally he saw how spontaneity could become stale, as when, in 1962, he announced his intention of "going back to the careful writing of Town & City", his first book. Had he followed through with this, he might have accessed a deeper seam of creativity than the one depleted by his habitual reliance on "enormous overdoses of benzedrine" and phenobarbital used to "offset the benny depression eight hours after ingestion" (after eight hours of writing).

He also experimented with acid but, while his old pals Allen Ginsberg and Neal Cassady happily played their part in fomenting a psychedelic revolution, Kerouac became increasingly hostile to the narco-ideological claims of the emergent hippy movement. The fact that hippies were the progeny of the Beats, that his passionate immersion in Buddhism anticipated their own fascination with all things Eastern, served only to strengthen his befuddled reactionary resolve. As Timothy Leary recalled, Kerouac "remained unmovably the Catholic carouser, an old-style Bohemian without a hippy bone in his body". Convinced his ideas were "being lifted by Jews" such as Ginsberg, Kerouac sank into a swamp of paranoia and buffoonish alcoholism.

"Free to do anything I want," he wrote in 1962, "I've deliberately imprisoned myself, like a hair shirt, I dunno why." In style this shirt was curiously similar to one later sported in Hull by Philip Larkin. Pining for a cabin in the woods, Kerouac actually settled for the suburbs of Florida or Massachusetts, where he lived with his mother amid "endless rows of perfect new houses but all of them without exception full of flat housewives looking out of the window when someone dares to try to walk to the stores which are too far away anyway under broiling sun under flat treeless waste, ugh". Even at this distance from the limelight, word always got out that the king of the Beats was in the vicinity, and Kerouac would be lured off on week-long swill-outs, "drinking and talking with hundreds and hundreds of my acquaintances day and night in shifts".

One day, in a snapshot, he saw what "all this lionised manure has done to me; it's killing me rapidly". His situation was made doubly intolerable by the fact that the lionisation didn't stop him getting critically pilloried. Hostile reviews seen in retrospect tend to vindicate the writer and incriminate the critic; in Kerouac's case, the passage of time has served to prove many of his detractors right. Dorothy Parker's reaction to "the appalling monotony" of The Subterraneans holds good for a lot of the letters, too.

The best-known criticism of all - that On the Road was not writing but typing - was echoed poignantly by Kerouac himself when, in 1967, he confessed, "I cant type like I used to, I'm afraid I cant write like I used to neither." This was during the "most dreadful part of [his] life" when his mother was paralysed after a stroke and Kerouac had become "a big glooby blob of sad blufush". Broke and drinking "more than ever", he had been "thrown out of all poolhalls except the Negro poolhall where I'm bound to have me head bashed in some day". An earlier beating had, he suspected, given him brain damage - "maybe once I was kind drunk, but am now brain-clogged drunk with the kindness valve clogged by injury" - and there were more beatings to come before he died in 1969.

And yet, to view Kerouac's life as a tragedy of squandered talent is to think in cliches; from the time that Kerouac completed On the Road, he was indemnified against ever making a serious mistake in his life. And even if his "kindness valve" did become clogged, the vivid generosity of spirit embodied in his conception of Dean Moriarty - "that a man who can sweat fantastically for the flesh is also capable of sweating fantastically for the spirit" - courses through every line of his masterpiece.
