fields.headline: Bedtime Story for my Son
fields.trailText:
Where did the voice come from? I hunted through the rooms
For that small boy, that high, that head-voice...
fields.body:
Where did the voice come from? I hunted through the rooms
For that small boy, that high, that head-voice,
The clatter as his heels caught on the door,
A shadow just caught moving though the door
Something like a school-satchel. My wife
Didn't seem afraid, even when it called for food
She smiled and turned her book and said:
'I couldn't go and love the empty air.'

We went to bed. Our dreams seemed full
Of boys in one or another guise, the paper-boy
Skidding along in grubby jeans, a music-lesson
She went out in the early afternoon to fetch a child from.
I pulled up from a pillow damp with heat
And saw her kissing hers, her legs were folded
Far away from mine. A pillow! It seemed
She couldn't love the empty air.

Perhaps, we thought, a child had come to grief

In some room in the old house we kept,
And listened if the noises came from some especial room,
And then we'd take the boards up and discover
A pile of dusty bones like charcoal twigs and give
The tiny-sounding ghost a proper resting-place
So that it need not wander in the empty air.

No blood-stained attic harboured the floating sounds,

We found they came in rooms that we'd warmed with our life.
We traced the voice and found where it mostly came
From just underneath both our skins, and not only
In the night-time either, but at the height of noon
And when we sat at meals alone. Plainly, this is how we found
That love pines loudly to go out to where
It need not spend itself on fancy and the empty air.

fields.headline: Fight club
fields.standfirst: John Duncan's In the Red Corner tells the story of his trip to the strange world of Cuban boxing
fields.trailText: John Duncan's In the Red Corner tells the story of his trip to the strange world of Cuban boxing
fields.body:
In the Red Corner: A Journey Into Cuban Boxing
John Duncan
Yellow Jersey, £12, 240pp
Buy it at BOL

In a global sports industry dominated by big media and big money, Cuban boxing is an anomaly, but a successful one. For three decades, Cuban boxers have defied demographics to lift world and Olympic titles in nearly all weight divisions. In doing so they have displayed a technique, style and spirit rarely seen in the professional arena. Best of all, Cuban boxing gave us the sublime spectacle of heavyweight champs Teofilo Stevenson and Felix Savon spurning Don King's millions. Whatever your ideological persuasion or feelings about boxing, it's hard not to be won over by that.

Guardian journalist John Duncan travelled to Cuba bankrolled by promoter Frank Warren with the less-than-noble mission of inveigling its top boxers into the professional ring. But in due course he was seduced - not by the revolution, nor by the amateur ethos, but by the Cuban boxing fraternity.

Any sports fan will envy Duncan the rare privilege of a prolonged close-up view of one of the world's great sporting subcultures. He is one of very few foreign journalists to have attended the Copa Cardin and the Playa Giron, glitz-free tournaments at which first-rate talent struts its stuff amid second-rate surroundings.

He has also interviewed the great champions of the modern era - Stevenson, Espinosa, Horta, Savon - and stalked the ghosts of the flamboyant pre-revolutionary masters, notably Kid Chocolate and Kid Gavilan. He was even afforded a tantalising glimpse of an inebriated and unbuttoned Alcides Sagarra, the stern supremo of Cuban boxing (and member of the central committee of the Cuban Communist Party).

Duncan's conversion from would-be predator to impassioned advocate is itself a touching affirmation of the mystique of Cuban boxing. Alas, he seems unwilling to venture any analysis of this mystique, and his handling of the historical background is perfunctory. A desperate fear of being taken in inhibits the reporting, and at times dulls his response to the extraordinary people he encounters.

In the end, he remains baffled by what he has seen. When he finds himself at the gates of "the finca", the boxing elite's legendary training camp, he feels disappointed. "I had arrived at the inner sanctum of the Cuban team and I thought that somehow I was about to be let in on the secret. Sadly, there doesn't seem to be one."

He could have probed further. The austere Sagarra tells him: "Boxing is ballet with aggression and Cubans are well equipped for it." Here was the starting point for a fascinating inquiry into the links between music, dance and boxing; Duncan makes nothing of it.

In a denouement set at last year's blunder-strewn world championships in Houston, Duncan discovers that at international level, "amateur" boxing is as unsavoury as the professional sport. But this old dichotomy is not really the issue. Cuban sportspeople are full-timers, paid by the state to hone and exhibit their skills. The privileges they enjoy (a flat, a car) are modest compared to the profits reaped by their counterparts elsewhere. Their relationship to their fans is what makes them different - a relationship far more intimate than that enjoyed by England footballers or the US Dream Team.

Cuba's world-beaters are nurtured by a system which spots talent at an early age and subjects it to intensive training. But there is more at work here than Soviet-style central planning. Like baseball, boxing in Cuba is a survival of a lively pre-revolutionary popular culture. The achievement of the Cuban system is to have preserved that spirit and provided a framework within which it could blossom.

Sadly, as Duncan notes, the glory days may be over. As the privations of what Castro calls the "special period" following the collapse of the Soviet Union bite deeper, the sports infrastructure is in decline and defections are increasing. Like Welsh rugby, Indian hockey or West Indies cricket, Cuban boxing's supremacy may prove transient as the social circumstances that gave rise to it are swept away by global forces. If that happens, John Duncan's eye-witness testimony will prove a valuable reminder of an invigorating episode in the history of sport.

 Mike Marqusee is the author of Redemption Song: Muhammad Ali and the Spirit of the 60s (Verso).

fields.headline: In the lingerie shop
fields.standfirst: Roy Hattersley visits the blairite pick'n'mix in Anthony Gidden's The Third Way and its Critics
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley visits the blairite pick'n'mix in Anthony Gidden's The Third Way and its Critics
fields.body:
The Third Way and its Critics
Anthony Giddens
Polity Press, £19.95 /£7.99, 200pp
Buy it at BOL

In one significant particular, Tony Blair has stood the whole political process on its head. Instead of producing policies consistent with a guiding philosophy, he decided item by item what his programme should be and then searched for a theory which would give it moral and intellectual authority. It's not surprising that he has settled on the third way - for that can mean whatever he wants it to mean.

The most distinguished proponent of the third way is Anthony Giddens, who insists that the name is unimportant; he is merely contributing to what he calls "the renewal of social democracy". He does, however, suggest that it is being refined and implemented by politicians worldwide; that must mean that it has a unifying ideological basis. Unfortunately, Giddens does not tell us what it is. He is clear about why "renewal" is necessary - the appeal of neo-liberalism (which he overstates) and the effects of the global economy (which he exaggerates) - but the result is a ragbag of conflicting ideas. If the third way really exists, it is technique, not ideology.

This means that, from time to time, it is remarkably like the old social democracy which it aims to renew. Giddens has previously written that "a radically meritocratic society would create deep inequalities of outcome which would threaten social cohesion". That is, in effect, a paraphrase of Tony Crosland in The Future of Socialism: "Equality of opportunity and social mobility are not enough... They need to be combined with measures to equalise the distribution of resources and privileges."

But do not rejoice too soon. Here Giddens muddies those clear waters with a paragraph in which every sentence is qualified out of existence by the one which precedes it. The third way "seeks to foster a diversified society based upon egalitarian principles. Social diversity is not compatible with a strongly defined egalitarianism of outcome. Third-way politics looks instead to maximise equality of opportunity. However, this has to preserve a concern with limiting inequality of outcomes too..." And so it goes on. The third way is a lingerie store: customers mix and match to meet their personal taste.

Giddens published this book at least in part to deal with what the theory's critics (at their most charitable) call his excessive eclecticism. To the credit of his academic self-confidence, he paraphrases their objections with scrupulous accuracy. Alan Ryan claims that the third way has no answer to rising unemployment; it "would have to move either to the left or right - to raise taxes and borrow or stick to the fiscally 'responsible' position and see unemployment climb".

It is a serious challenge: fiscally, the third way belongs to anyone. But although we know that Giddens believes in employee share ownership and labour market flexibility, he does not even hint at how a third-way chancellor should behave if fiscal responsibility is destroying jobs. An egalitarian would choose a little more inflation and a little less unemployment. The Prime Minister - whose support for the third way Giddens proudly acknowledges - would not.

Yet The Third Way does contain some welcome restatements of ignored truths. "Conservative writers are fond of arguing that poverty is not an excuse... Enduring poverty is usually coupled with exclusionary mechanisms." That means that poor children are likely to do badly at school - a fact that David Blunkett denies. Perhaps we should be glad that the third way has something for everybody. In consequence, from time to time, peaks of good sense rise above the flat landscape of emollience.

fields.headline: We just love that woman
fields.standfirst: Michael Foot  salutes Rebecca West's passionate letters to her paramours and literary friends
fields.trailText: Michael Foot salutes Rebecca West's passionate letters to her paramours and literary friends
fields.body:
Selected Letters of Rebecca West
edited by Bonnie Kime Scott
Yale University Press, £25, 479pp
Buy it at BOL

West in her own words: read extracts from her letters to HG Wells, GB Shaw and George Orwell

"I just love that woman," Jill Craigie would say of Rebecca West, and Rebecca would eagerly repay the compliment. Their friendship blossomed only in the last dozen years of Rebecca's long life, but since it was chiefly on Jill's prompting that Rebecca returned to the journalism of her flaming youth, the two of them together took the century in their feminist strides. Like Jill, Rebecca was an artist in everything she touched and saw. Each had a specially sharpened visual sense, which Jill could translate into films and pictures, and Rebecca into words.

Again and again throughout our own quite lengthy lives, Jill and I found ourselves bumping afresh into some revelation of the HG Wells-Rebecca West saga. I first met him at a weekend party at Max Beaverbrook's country estate in the late 1930s. He was the hero of my early twenties, having completed my conversion to socialism with Tono-Bungay and several other of his titles. At his side on that occasion was not Rebecca but his last and maybe truest love, Moura Budberg. She became for me a heroine, too, keeping alive my connection with HG until he died eight years later.

The HG Wells of the second world war fought with all his might for the rights of man; Beaverbrook's Evening Standard played a notable part in that victory, proudly printing every one of his red-hot revolutionary words. Both Jill and I fell victims to Max Beaverbrook's charm. Outside observers could not understand the relationship, but he was a firm friend to both of us until the day of his death. No topic of conversation seemed to be banned between us - especially his interest in the worlds of HG Wells, Arnold Bennett and so forth - but in all our conversations, one name never cropped up: that of Rebecca West.

Not until years later, when HG and Max and Rebecca were all dead, did Rebecca's posthumously published novel Sunflower tell the story of how the slightly ageing HG was displaced in her affections by the magnificent young Max. It was a delicate, matchless love story, intelligently told. But no one could know about this at the time; Rebecca was presumably resolved to give offence to neither of her lovers.

What happened between Rebecca and Max in their original affair is not finally clarified either in the novel or in these letters, but every later development is honourable to them both. He helped her directly in her journalistic career, and would do his best to assist when her more outrageous friends, such as the anarchist leader Emma Goldman, were being pilloried in the newspapers.

If you have not yet read Sunflower, order your copy now. Don't be deterred by some of the jealous reviewers who dismissed the work as inferior when it did finally appear; Rebecca knew better.

Her suppression of the novel must have been all the more galling when she saw that her literary opponents showed no such reticence. Enemy number one was her own son by HG, Anthony West, who wrote a damning autobiographical novel, Heritage, while Rebecca was still alive, and pursued his vendetta even after her death with an unrelenting fury that can still turn the stomach.

In these pages she can defend herself against all his accusations. "Posterity will never forgive a bad mother," she would sometimes say to Jill. Here she is vindicated; Anthony gets his due. He had, for example, a terrible quarrel with his father in HG's last days which he wretchedly tried to blame on Rebecca; in fact, it was much more the result of his own imperfect sympathies with his father.

Along with many writers of the century, headed by HG himself, Rebecca understood the importance of Anglo-American associations - she made her name in the US in the 1920s, and ever after kept a foot on both sides of the Atlantic - so the editing of this volume by the American Bonnie Kime Scott is all the more appropriate.

Some of the best liberal spirits of the age became her closest friends. A few of them at moments of stress might have questioned her allegiance, but, if need be, she could counter-attack with all her polemical might. Her insights take command at the most appropriate moments: "The Statue of Liberty," she said at her first glance, "is a washout - she gets her stays at the same place as Queen Mary's."

A most prolific letter writer herself - she claimed sometimes to write several before breakfast - she had a special appreciation of how full volumes of letters could inform a proper judgment of the greatest writers. She had not always been as aware of Oscar Wilde's genius as might have been expected, for instance, but after his letters were published she sent his son Vyvyan Holland a glowing response, full of fresh understanding: "I don't think anyone could read the volume without liking your father more than before." These words were intended to bring comfort to Merlin, Oscar's grandson, as well as to his father. The Rebecca who wrote this letter and several more of the same quality truly knew what love was.

But what of her relationship with HG, the most significant of her life? They had their rows, but nothing to compare with the savagery of those with Anthony. For several years after their first meeting, HG drew on his own new knowledge of Rebecca to portray the new woman - from Fanny in The Dream to Helen in The World of William Clissold - and what a wonderful breed she was. The literary connection between the two was brilliantly unravelled by JR Hammond in his HG Wells and Rebecca West, published in 1991. He showed how each was indispensable to the other, and where each could claim to be innovators.

The last book I read to Jill was this collection of letters from the woman she so greatly honoured. No hardship, I can assure you: the wit pours forth on every page along with the lamentations. Jill sometimes suspected me of treating her Rebecca less kindly than I should - especially when HG was misbehaving in a big way. And yet, having read and re-read every word, the main conclusion is unchallengeable. The love between them triumphed over everything else: the reconciliations were always much more significant than the ruptures.

The last of these came in the 1940s, when they shared a vision that the England they both loved could rejoice in a victory over the forces of evil. Anthony failed to join that period of exhilaration: he even helped to spread the insinuation that his father's mind was failing. The reality was nothing of the kind: with Moura on one side and Rebecca on the other, he was celebrating the freedom which he had done as much as any of his countrymen to secure.

West in her own words

To HG Wells, 1913, a year before their son Anthony was born

"During the next few days I shall either put a bullet through my head or commit something more shattering to myself than death... I don't understand why you wanted me three months ago and don't want me now... It's something... I despise. And the worst of it is that if I despise you I rage because you stand between me and peace. Of course you're quite right. I haven't anything to give you. You have only a passion for excitement and for comfort. You don't want any more excitement and I do not give people comfort..."

To George Bernard Shaw, 1917, thanking him for sending her a copy of a life of Oscar Wilde

"I can never make out why there is all this fuss about Wilde. Of course it is impossible for people of my generation to give any just estimate of his position as an artist because you have so completely wiped him up in the theatre. And I have always been prejudiced against him because of the plea that his sentence should have been remitted because he was an artist, which seems to me unworthy of the aristocrat that an artist should be. But what an argument for Home Rule the book is. There are things in it which increase one's contempt for Ireland - notably the photograph of Sir William Wilde. A country where a man who looked like an embittered mandril could have a family in every farmhouse must be in a deplorable state."

To George Orwell, 1946

"I feel you don't understand Henry Miller as I do, an extremely offensive assumption, and I shall forgive you if you resent it. I can only offer as an excuse that possibly you haven't seen as much of him as I have... Miller is a German-American - his German origin accounts for his prose - who after a good petty bourgeois upbringing took a job with the Western Union Cable Corporation, of which he eventually became a Vice-President. He then married a lurid trollop of curiously mixed atmosphere... and she upset him and led him astray into all sorts of trouble that didn't go too well with the Western Union... It then occurred to him that there was a way of getting out of all this trouble... and that was to write obscure literature as an expatriate in Paris. He thought this out quite coolly. As part of this... stunt he froze on to a guileless pair - a young American bank representative named Guiler who was married to a beautiful woman called Anaïs Nin, whom I think the only real genius I have ever known in my life."

To her son Anthony in 1961

"You have one grievance against me, and one only: that I did not have an abortion and kill you. This seems to me a most peculiar grievance for a man who has, I imagine, had a good deal of happiness out of his life... You can't be so hopelessly stupid that you think that I, given my particular makeup, would have chosen to have an illegitimate child. I had a love affair with HG and I loved him then as I was always to love him, on the understanding that he would not give me a child, a promise he wantonly broke simply because he wanted the panache of having a child by the infant prodigy of the day. I was appalled by the situation when it arose, and the more so by the way that HG handled it... I felt I had to make every sacrifice to compensate to you for the suffering you might undergo. It was no difficulty to make these sacrifices because I loved you very much."

fields.headline: Making the cut
fields.standfirst: Movie audiences may love a bloody good serial killer, but American Psycho's Patrick Bateman just doesn't hit the mark. Michael Holden is your guide to the scariest screen slashers
fields.trailText: Movie audiences may love a bloody good serial killer, but American Psycho's Patrick Bateman just doesn't hit the mark. Michael Holden is your guide to the scariest screen slashers
fields.body:
Having made mincemeat of love and war since the earliest days of cinema, Hollywood has finally managed to give murder a bad name. And not just murder, but its hitherto cine-friendly country cousin, serial killing. What began so well with Psycho reaches its nadir this month with the release of American Psycho, and not since cheese has a word's intrinsic value suffered so badly at the hands of the prefix "American". Not that American Psycho is bad because it's tasteless, wrong, shocking or anything like that. If only. There are only two deaths worth weeping for in this movie. The slaughter of a perfectly decent book and the abduction and cold execution of an otherwise noble genre, the serial killer movie.

The real tragedy of the summer, and God help us probably the year's most controversial film, is that it's just awful. Where Norman Bates had a mother, Christian Bale's Patrick Bateman has little more than his own expensive reflection to blame. Inevitably, the nuances of Easton Ellis' novel are blunted somewhat by the transition to celluloid, but it's a shame that any surviving traces are snow-washed out of existence by what in the end is a daft 80s musical, played for laughs yet somehow devoid of humour (it should hit the West End sometime soon as Bluddy, or The Demon Barber Of Wall Street.)

Statistically, most serial killers are white heterosexual men in their 30s. A demographic they share with movie executives, who on the strength of this, are shaping up to be the greater menace. But then I would say that. I am exactly the kind of person that Patrick Bateman despises. I live in the city and I just don't give a monkey's about you, move right along the platform, you freaks. I simply couldn't care less. Truth is, me and my empty heart probably deserve to die. I'd just like to see some decent movies first. But the real shame here is the loss of cool to the killer. As the splendid history of the screen serial assassin teaches us, there's more to a good maniac than tailored shoes and an expensive-looking axe.

Let's take music. In some of the film's better scenes, Bale's psycho shows us just how nuts he is by listening to Huey Lewis, Talking Heads, and not just Phil Collins but the song Sussudio. All very funny, but all this tells us is that our (anti) hero is a dick. This is hardly the Beethoven of young Alex in the recently resurrected Clockwork Orange. Nor is it Peter And The Wolf as whistled by Peter Lorre as the child murderer in Fritz Lang's M. The last time you hear him blow that tune is benchmark horror. Each time Bateman reaches for another CD, you just want to kill him.

Inevitably, the screen slayer against whom all others must be judged is Anthony Hopkins' Hannibal Lecter. An astonishing creation that, let's face it, we've all come to love. But The Silence Of The Lambs has a curious subtext in terms of our response to killers, visible in the differences between the habits and fates of Lecter and Buffalo Bill. The message seems to be this: speak with a European accent, dress well, exhibit unnatural intelligence and you eat who you like. Keep women in pits, run around with your testicles wedged between your legs in a house full of moths and you must die like a dog. Funny, ain't it. In terms of people doing really out-of-order, degrading things for truly mad reasons, the award goes to Kevin Spacey's John Doe in Seven. Not only does he keep a man half-starved and on the very margins of death for an entire year, but he does it to prove what a dumbass Brad Pitt is. Now that's killin'.

The idea of serial killer as malevolent genius with a good sense of humour reached an apex in the 80s with The Hitcher. Here, an all-powerful euro sophisticate (Rutger Hauer) dupes a confused American teenager by killing everyone around him, and wins our affections by placing the severed finger of the boy's dead girlfriend in a bag of chips. Pure class. While American Psycho as first-person narrative cannot access the suspenseful whodunnit heights of Seven, it somehow sidesteps the potential of its own content (having omitted the worst/best excesses of the novel), and so broaches the concept of non-horrific horror, murder-lite.

For many of us, the first taste of true screen serial slaughter came with the supremely ugly couplet of 70s "mad family" movies, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Hills Have Eyes. Both traded on the (strangely plausible) notion that there are groups of people out there who, if you break down near their shack/caravan, will hunt you down and eat you alive for no reason. Both employ deformed offspring (Leatherface and Jupiter respectively) as engines of senseless death, and both trade on the fact that everyone grows up near an area where other children insist that such things actually happen, and both as a result are duly fearful.

In recent years, two films have notably explored serial murder in such a way as to make us examine why it generally makes for such damned fine viewing. Tellingly, both accomplish this by making us uncomfortable about watching pain and death as opposed to making the deaths look painful for the slain. 1989's Henry, Portrait Of A Serial Killer did exactly what it said on the tin, by showing us the horrible basics of going around eating people and how your mates get roped in for the ride. More shocking still is Michael Henke's Funny Games, in which two German youths in tennis shorts and surgical gloves torture a German couple beyond the limits of visual endurance simply because they wouldn't lend them some eggs. Meantime, Bateman's crazed tidiness is a relief when viewed against Henry's attitude to bodies, which mirrors most students' approach to washing up. But however well-presented Bateman is, he lacks the sinister nerd chic of Henke's killers. And despite his Wall Street existence he is bereft of even the cold media savvy of hick supreme and walking apocalypse Mickey Knox from Natural Born Killers. "Killing you and what you represent is a statement," says Mickey, "I'm not exactly sure what it's saying but"

There are clear lessons here for anyone figuring on redeeming the genre from the fallout of this latest dud. Choose your homicidal wingnut wisely. Killing people is bad on its own, making your killer a pain in the ass on every other level is unlikely to help. Particularly if the goon makes it to the end of the picture. Bad serial killer movies serve to remind us of just one thing. If once in a while these people felt suicidal then they might be less of a problem. There is a school of thought in psychiatry that anger, and by association murder, takes place because people's expectations of one another are just too high. We should be grateful that frustrated expectations of films don't affect us the same way. There would be none of us left. As Bateman says at the end of the movie, "this confession has been a waste of time". You can say that again.  American Psycho is released on Friday

Inevitably, the nuances of Easton Ellis' novel are blunted somewhat by the transition to celluloid, but it's a shame that any surviving traces are snow-washed out of existence by what in the end is a daft 80s musical, played for laughs yet somehow devoid of humour (it should hit the West End sometime soon as Bluddy, or The Demon Barber Of Wall Street.) Statistically, most serial killers are white heterosexual men in their 30s. A demographic they share with movie executives, who on the strength of this, are shaping up to be the greater menace. But then I would say that. I am exactly the kind of person that Patrick Bateman despises. I live in the city and I just don't give a monkey's about you, move right along the platform, you freaks. I simply couldn't care less. Truth is, me and my empty heart probably deserve to die. I'd just like to see some decent movies first. But the real shame here is the loss of cool to the killer. As the splendid history of the screen serial assassin teaches us, there's more to a good maniac than tailored shoes and an expensive-looking axe. Let's take music. In some of the film's better scenes, Bale's psycho shows us just how nuts he is by listening to Huey Lewis, Talking Heads, and not just Phil Collins but the song Sussudio. All very funny, but all this tells us is that our (anti) hero is a dick. This is hardly the Beethoven of young Alex in the recently resurrected Clockwork Orange. Nor is it Peter And The Wolf as whistled by Peter Lorre as the child murderer in Fritz Lang's M. The last time you hear him blow that tune is benchmark horror. Each time Bateman reaches for another CD, you just want to kill him. Inevitably, the screen slayer against whom all others must be judged is Anthony Hopkins' Hannibal Lecter. An astonishing creation that, let's face it, we've all come to love. But The Silence Of The Lambs has a curious subtext in terms of our response to killers, visible in the differences between the habits and fates of Lecter and Buffalo Bill. The message seems to be this: speak with a European accent, dress well, exhibit unnatural intelligence and you eat who you like. Keep women in pits, run around with your testicles wedged between your legs in a house full of moths and you must die like a dog. Funny, ain't it. In terms of people doing really out-of-order, degrading things for truly mad reasons, the award goes to Kevin Spacey's John Doe in Seven. Not only does he keep a man half-starved and on the very margins of death for an entire year, but he does it to prove what a dumbass Brad Pitt is. Now that's killin'. The idea of serial killer as malevolent genius with a good sense of humour reached an apex in the 80s with The Hitcher. Here, an all-powerful euro sophisticate (Rutger Hauer) dupes a confused American teenager by killing everyone around him, and wins our affections by placing the severed finger of the boy's dead girlfriend in a bag of chips. Pure class. While American Psycho as first-person narrative cannot access the suspenseful whodunnit heights of Seven, it somehow sidesteps the potential of its own content (having omitted the worst/best excesses of the novel), and so broaches the concept of non-horrific horror, murder-lite. For many of us, the first taste of true screen serial slaughter came with the supremely ugly couplet of 70s "mad family" movies, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Hills Have Eyes. Both traded on the (strangely plausible) notion that there are groups of people out there who, if you break down near their shack/caravan, will hunt you down and eat you alive for no reason. Both employ deformed offspring (Leatherface and Jupiter respectively) as engines of senseless death, and both trade on the fact that everyone grows up near an area where other children insist that such things actually happen, and both as a result are duly fearful. In recent years, two films have notably explored serial murder in such a way as to make us examine why it generally makes for such damned fine viewing. Tellingly, both accomplish this by making us uncomfortable about watching pain and death as opposed to making the deaths look painful for the slain. 1989's Henry, Portrait Of A Serial Killer did exactly what it said on the tin, by showing us the horrible basics of going around eating people and how your mates get roped in for the ride. More shocking still is Michael Henke's Funny Games, in which two German youths in tennis shorts and surgical gloves torture a German couple beyond the limits of visual endurance simply because they wouldn't lend them some eggs. Meantime, Bateman's crazed tidiness is a relief when viewed against Henry's attitude to bodies, which mirrors most students' approach to washing up. But however well-presented Bateman is, he lacks the sinister nerd chic of Henke's killers. And despite his Wall Street existence he is bereft of even the cold media savvy of hick supreme and walking apocalypse Mickey Knox from Natural Born Killers. "Killing you and what you represent is a statement," says Mickey, "I'm not exactly sure what it's saying but" There are clear lessons here for anyone figuring on redeeming the genre from the fallout of this latest dud. Choose your homicidal wingnut wisely. Killing people is bad on its own, making your killer a pain in the ass on every other level is unlikely to help. Particularly if the goon makes it to the end of the picture. Bad serial killer movies serve to remind us of just one thing. If once in a while these people felt suicidal then they might be less of a problem. There is a school of thought in psychiatry that anger, and by association murder, takes place because people's expectations of one another are just too high. We should be grateful that frustrated expectations of films don't affect us the same way. There would be none of us left. As Bateman says at the end of the movie, "this confession has been a waste of time". You can say that again.  American Psycho is released on Friday

webTitle: The end of a life of crime

fields.headline: The end of a life of crime
fields.standfirst:
Noye gets life sentence for M25 road-rage murderFiancée's tale
Policeman's tale
Killer's tale
fields.trailText: Yesterday Noye, one of the most powerful and clever criminals of his generation, was sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of Stephen Cameron, a 21-year-old electrician he stabbed to death in a pointless road-rage row.
fields.body:
This time around, Kenneth Noye kept his thoughts to himself. At 12.26 yesterday, when the jury forewoman said "guilty" in a voice broken by nerves, Britain's most notorious villain stared ahead at the judge in court two, his hands clasped in front of him. He was expressionless.

On a previous occasion at the Old Bailey, he told a jury that had convicted him: "I hope you die of cancer."

Yesterday Noye, one of the most powerful and clever criminals of his generation, was sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of Stephen Cameron, a 21-year-old electrician he stabbed to death in a pointless road-rage row.

It was the climax to an extraordinary two-week trial that put the criminal justice system under severe pressure.

Noye claimed he could not get a fair trial for the murder because of his reputation. It was this "reputation" as a ruthless underworld boss which led the judge, Lord Justice Latham, to give the 12 jurors 24-hour police protection. They did not have to read their names out in court, as is normal.

The verdict was also vindication for Kent police, who mounted their biggest-ever operation to trace Noye and bring him back from Spain, where he fled within 24 hours of the stabbing, and for the crown prosecution service, which ignored Noye's repeated attempts to scupper proceedings by claiming abuse of process.

Detective Superintendent Dennis McGookin, who led the investigation, said: "Kenneth Noye ran, but he couldn't hide."

Although the judge did not set a tariff yesterday, Noye is unlikely to be freed until he is a very old man.

As he prepared to be led to the cells, the silence and tension was shattered by cheers from Stephen Cameron's parents, Ken and Toni, who were sitting behind him at the back of the court.

They had heard Noye admit stabbing Stephen in the heart and liver. He claimed their son had started the fight at the Swanley interchange of the M25 on May 19 1996.

At no point in the 12-day trial did they hear Noye apologise or show remorse. Nor had he expressed any sympathy for Cameron's fiance, Danielle Cable.

Noye was acquitted of another murder 15 years ago claiming self defence, just as he had in this trial. Detective Constable John Fordham was stabbed 10 times when Noye found him hiding in his garden, attempting undercover surveillance.

The officer's former partner, Neil Murphy, said yesterday: "Justice has been done. Noye is a dangerous and evil man."

One phrase cropped up in both murder trials. Noye, the pathologists said, had thrust the knife into his victims "up to the hilt".

Yesterday the jury returned an 11-to-one majority decision after eight hours and 21 minutes of deliberations.

They concluded Noye had lied about what happened when he got out of his Land Rover Discovery to confront Cameron, the passenger in a red Rascal van driven by Ms Cable.

He claimed Cameron had attacked him in a "wild rage", adding that he only carried a four-inch knife because he was in fear of his life.

The police "detested" him because of what had happened to DC Fordham. His conviction in 1986 for dishonestly handling gold from the Brink's-Mat bullion robbery - which led to his outburst at the jury - had made him a target for other gangsters who thought he knew where the gold was hoarded.

The jurors believed the evidence of witnesses who saw Noye throw the first punch, and then get more than he bargained for from the younger, fitter man.

Alan Decabral remembered seeing Noye take a step backwards and reach into his pocket. "Then I saw a flash. I could see the sun glinting on the blade. He then made a run at the younger man.

"The older man stabbed him in the chest. I saw him stab him."

Cameron's last words to Ms Cable as she cradled him in her arms were: "He stabbed me, Dan. Take his number plate."

During the extradition hearings Noye denied even being at the scene.

After the verdict, the Camerons said they were "overjoyed and relieved". Shortly before they addressed a press conference, the sirens of a police convoy wailed out side. It was Noye being taken to Belmarsh prison.

"The day that Stephen died, we felt we died," said Mr Cameron, 53. "It's only our family and friends that have kept us going." Mrs Cameron, 54, added: "Our lovely son is dead and our lives will never be the same again."

The couple's thoughts were with their son's fiance, whose courage in flying to Spain in August 1998 to identify Noye as the killer was praised repeatedly.

Ms Cable was not at the Old Bailey yesterday; she is living in a safe house under 24-hour protection. But she was told the verdict by phone.

Mrs Cameron said: "She's trying to get on with her life but until today she hasn't been able to. She has been an inspiration to us."

The search

 4,936 calls made to police incident room at Dartford

 5,477 inquiries completed

 1,314 statements taken

 854 Land Rover Discoveries traced and eliminated

 70 police officers worked on inquiry at its height

 69 men named Anthony Francis - in whose name the Land Rover Noye was driving was registered -traced and eliminated

 Police visited Cyprus, Canary Islands, Spain, Gibraltar, West Indies, Puerto Rico, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, Ireland, Scotland, Wales and the US

fields.headline: Detective was first stabbing victim
fields.standfirst: Partner recalls the night Noye killed his colleague Main story
fields.trailText: Neil Murphy bought a bottle of champagne a couple of weeks ago and put it in the fridge at his house in Herefordshire. Yesterday, he poured himself a glass, and with his wife, they toasted an old friend and the conviction of the man who stabbed him to death, Kenneth Noye.
fields.body:
Neil Murphy bought a bottle of champagne a couple of weeks ago and put it in the fridge at his house in Herefordshire. Yesterday, he poured himself a glass, and with his wife, they toasted an old friend and the conviction of the man who stabbed him to death, Kenneth Noye.

The friend was not Stephen Cameron. But John Fordham, the detective Noye found hiding in the grounds of his house fifteen years ago. Murphy, 47, was Fordham's partner at Scotland Yard's special operations and was with him the night that Fordham was killed.

Noye was acquitted of murder, claiming he slashed out in self-defence when the officer attacked him.

Though Murphy, a father of two, is cautious about saying justice has finally been done he has no doubt that Noye is a highly dangerous man, and that he might have killed again if he was freed.

"He obviously likes knives. If he'd got out this time, I wonder who victim number three would have been."

Murphy is not vindictive or vengeful for the loss of his close friend, and, having churned over the events "thousands of times", he does not believe he could have done anything to save him.

Murphy remembers the night very well. He and Fordham had been assigned to spy on Noye, who was suspected of melting down and recycling the gold stolen in the Brinks Mat bullion robbery in 1983.

Scotland Yard suspected gold was being taken to Noye's estate in West Kingsdown, but was unsure how it was being transported to and from the house. The suspicion was that an associate of Noye's, Brian Reader, was involved.

"Noye was a total unknown to me then," said Murphy. "John and I turned up to do the night shift, 6pm to 6am. We were based in a hide-out which was opposite the main gates. Almost immediately, a car turned up and we realised Reader was going in. So we had to follow.

"It was pitch black and frosty. We were wearing camouflage and gortex suits. We climbed over the fence and were hiding in the woodland up the drive with a good view of the house. Then the dogs surprised us.

"Noye had two rottweillers which were on the loose. They were jumping up at us, snapping at our arms and legs. We thought that they might get bored and leave us alone. But they kept barking and barking, and I was sure that Noye would come out of his house to see what the racket was.

"I gave John a nod to tell him I was pulling back. I thought he was coming too, but he must have decided to sit it out. As I approached the gate I heard voices. I was hoping that John was somewhere behind me.

"Then I heard someone say 'Show us your ID then ... I'll blow your head off.' I saw Reader step forward and kick John as he was lying on the ground. It all happened in a matter of seconds."

Murphy did not see Noye stab his colleague, but as soon as he realised he was in trouble, he radioed for help and squad cars arrived in minutes.

"I went back and found John lying on the grass. The ambulance had arrived and I went with him to hospital. They opened his shirt and found 10 stab wounds. I realised he was dead.

"I really don't think there was anything that I could have done to save him. It's something I'm quite strong about."

Noye claimed that Fordham attacked him, but Murphy finds this hard to believe.

"John had stab wounds in his back, which makes me think he was trying to get away. But I couldn't say that in court, because I didn't see it and I can't prove it.

"I'm not saying that John didn't attack him and I can understand that Noye was frightened to find him there. I would have been petrified to find a man in a balaclava in my garden. But striking out was the last thing John would have wanted to do.

"I just don't believe it. That wasn't him at all. As an officer, I had complete admiration for him. He was the top surveillance officer in the country, the ultimate professional."

Murphy has little contact with Fordham's widow, Annie, or his children, Lorraine and John.

"I don't think they blame me for what happened. I don't think they really understood what John's work was all about, because he preferred not to tell them. I know that John wanted to do that job. It was what he was best at."

Murphy left the force in 1992, while Noye was serving nine years of a 14-year term for dishonestly handling stolen Brinks Mat gold. Four years later, when Mr Cameron's death was frontpage news, Murphy did not consider that Noye might be involved.

"I was staggered when I heard. And if I'm being honest, I didn't think that the police would be able to bring him to court. But they did, and once Noye was forced to admit he was at the scene, he was running out of options.

"In John's case, the only eye witnesses were Noye, his wife and Reader. So, I wasn't surprised that he was acquitted. But this case has been different. There is a saying in the police. If someone is cleared of a crime, officers don't get too frustrated, they say 'don't worry, we'll get him again'.

"They did."

webTitle: Girlfriend praised for her courage giving evidence

fields.headline: Girlfriend praised for her courage giving evidence
fields.standfirst: Witness now living under 24-hour guardMain story
fields.trailText: Danielle Cable and Stephen Cameron had been engaged for four months when they met Kenneth Noye face to face for the first and only time. The encounter killed one of them and devastated the other.
fields.body:
Danielle Cable and Stephen Cameron had been engaged for four months when they met Kenneth Noye face to face for the first and only time. The encounter killed one of them and devastated the other.

Four years on, Ms Cable, 21, is still suffering from the trauma and the loss, and she will live the rest of her life knowing she is a target for Noye's gangster friends.

Ms Cable was not in court yesterday to hear the verdict, but she was referred to constantly by Stephen's parents, Ken and Toni, and the officer in charge of the case, Detective Superintendent Dennis McGookin, when they spoke afterwards. "We love her like a daughter and always will," Mrs Cameron said.

"Her courage was outstanding," said Mr McGookin.

Ms Cable, who is blond, gave evidence wearing a long auburn wig and spectacles.

She is now living in a safe house under 24-hour protection. Kent police do not know where she is staying. Nor do Mr and Mrs Cameron, who have to wait for her calls. Their letters to her, which have to be vetted, take six weeks to get through.

"She has a new name, a new life and is living in another part of the country," said Mr Cameron. "She has made new friends who only know her as she is now."

Before the murder, the couple had been living with Stephen's parents at their home in Beechen Lea Lane, Swanley, Kent. Friends of Danielle, who was a waitress, and Stephen, an electrician, said they had a tempestuous relationship, which began when she was 15. Living under the same roof and preparing for the wedding seemed to settle them down.

At Stephen's funeral, Ms Cable said: "When I met Stephen I thought it was forever. He was the love of my life, my everything." She continued to live with Stephen's parents afterwards, but was, according to Mr Cameron, "terribly lonely."

She rarely spoke of what happened on May 19 1996, and was withdrawn.

Part of the defence strategy was to paint Stephen as an aggressive man. Although he did not have any previous convictions, he could be fiery.

Mr and Mrs Cameron said yesterday they were not hurt by the allegations made in court, that their son had been involved in other road rage incidents.

"People can say what they like," said Mr Cameron. "We loved our son and we knew him. That's all we care about."
